We can also generate testable implications regarding prices and volume based on comparative statics analysis, which can provide reference for future empirical work. The results also have policy implications regarding regulations and market design.

按原申请摘要： 场外交易市场（OTC）与中央交易不同，是许多资产（包括政府和公司债券、资产支持证券和衍生品）的交易场所。在场外交易市场中，几乎所有的交易都是通过交易商进行的，实证结果表明，交易商之间的交易占整个交易的很大比例。 最近的论文记录了一些关于交易商间交易的实证结果。（一）交易商间交易方向持续。（2）交易关系具有核心-外围结构。中央经销商之间的联系更加紧密，外围经销商主要与中央经销商联系在一起。（3）中央经销商库存较多，持续时间较长。现有的研究已经为这些发现中的一个或多个提供了理论解释，但不能同时解决所有这些问题。 我们提出了一个可追踪的投资者-交易商动态随机搜索模型。这种细微差别是对异质库存容量的假设：经销商要么拥有大量库存容量，要么拥有少量库存容量。这可能是由于不同的财务成本或风险管理考虑。在每一个时期，交易商首先随机遇到投资者，这是由一定的匹配技术支配的。在会上，经销商只有在有存储空间的情况下才能向低价值资产所有者购买，只有在有库存的情况下才能向高价值非所有者出售。然后，经销商在竞争激烈的经销商间市场进行交易，以重新平衡库存。 我们期望均衡结果与上述程式化事实相符。每种类型的经销商都有他/她的最佳库存水平。由于搜索摩擦，与投资者交易后的库存可能高于或低于最优水平。然后，交易商之间的交易出现了重新平衡的需要。这种需要以及因此交易商间交易的方向一直处于稳定状态。此外，交易关系的结构应以大交易商为中心，以小交易商为外围，因为小交易商和大交易商之间以及大交易商之间的贸易有收益，但小交易商之间的贸易没有收益。最后，对于一个小经销商来说，持有存货的成本更高，因为这意味着失去更多潜在的购买机会。因此，中央交易商持有更多库存。 此外，我们还可以描述大、小交易商之间的交易方向如何取决于基础环境。基于比较静力学分析，我们还可以对价格和成交量产生可检验的影响，为以后的实证工作提供参考。研究结果对监管和市场设计也有政策影响。

Project.Title: How Child Welfare Workers in Norway, England and the United States Perceive Their Work With Ethnic Minority Children

Title_Other.Title: How Child Welfare Workers in Norway, England and the United States Perceive Their Work With Ethnic Minority Children
挪威、英国和美国的儿童福利工作者如何看待他们与少数民族儿童的工作

Project.Abstract:
I am applying to spend a total of six months at the University of Bergen to conduct research in collaboration with Senior Researcher Marit Skivenes on how child welfare workers in Norway, England and the United States understand their work with ethnic min ority children, especially children whose parents are first-generation immigrants. This project builds on several data sources gathered for CHILDPRO, a research project funded by the Norwegian Research Council that draws on case vignettes as well as qual itative interviews to compare how child welfare workers in countries with different child welfare systems take decisions about child welfare cases. The data material collected for CHILDPRO is a unique and rich comparative material that has not yet been f ully analyzed. I am applying for the Leiv Eiriksson mobility fellowship to have the opportunity to do so.
This project builds on in-depth qualitative interviews to explore how child welfare workers perceive the needs of minority children in Norway, Eng land and the United States, and how they make decisions about foster placements. The proposed projects are relevant in light of increasing immigration in Norway and because they address a fundamental dilemma faced by multicultural democratic societies to day: how to handle multiculturalism within a liberal democratic framework, which is based on unified standards expressed in laws that equally apply to all citizens (Archard, 2004). In addition, the proposed project responds to a scarcity of literature on child welfare practice with first-generation immigrant children in Norway, and the lack of comparative scholarship in general, and on Norway and England in particular. They will shed light on child welfare workers' decision-making processes and on the t ypes of knowledge that child welfare workers use in their encounters with ethnic minority children and their families.
Reference Archard, David. 2004. Children: Rights and Childhood. London: Routledge.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 我申请在卑尔根大学呆上六个月，与资深研究员玛丽特·斯基维内斯合作，研究挪威、英国和美国的儿童福利工作者如何理解他们与少数民族儿童，特别是父母是第一代移民的儿童的工作。该项目建立在为CHILDPRO收集的若干数据源的基础上，CHILDPRO是一个由挪威研究理事会资助的研究项目，该项目利用案例小插曲和平等访谈来比较不同儿童福利制度国家的儿童福利工作者如何就儿童福利案件作出决定。为CHILDPRO收集的数据资料是一种独特而丰富的比较资料，尚未得到充分的分析。我正在申请Leiv Eiriksson流动奖学金，以便有机会申请。 该项目以深入的定性访谈为基础，探讨儿童福利工作者如何看待挪威、英国和美国少数民族儿童的需求，以及他们如何决定寄养安置。鉴于挪威移民人数不断增加，而且由于这些项目解决了多文化民主社会目前面临的一个根本性难题：如何在自由民主框架内处理多文化主义，自由民主框架以平等适用于所有公民的法律所表达的统一标准为基础（Archard，2004年）。此外，拟议的项目还回应了挪威缺乏关于第一代移民儿童的儿童福利实践的文献，以及缺乏一般的比较奖学金，特别是关于挪威和英国的比较奖学金。他们将阐明儿童福利工作者的决策过程，以及儿童福利工作者在接触少数民族儿童及其家庭时使用的知识类型。 参考 阿尔查德，大卫。2004年。儿童：权利与童年。伦敦：劳特利奇。

I am applying for the Leiv Eiriksson mobility fellowship to have the opportunity to do so.

Project.Title: RR:(Instrumentation) Shooting in 3D with the Zmini Camera

Title_Other.Title: RR：（仪器）用Zmini相机进行3D拍摄
RR:(Instrumentation) Shooting in 3D with the Zmini Camera

Class.ClassName: 计算机在其他方面的应用

Project.Abstract: This project from an EPSCoR state, acquiring A Zmini camera that captures 3D information (real time color and depth) at video rates, aims to model and render 3D information. Activities include Acquiring a cloud of points using the Zmini camera from multiple viewpoints, Generating a surface using a modified marching cubes algorithm, and Automatically binding the model to a skeleton for character animation (called auto-rigging). Thus, point cloud modeling from the camera will be used to create surfaces, specifically humanoid, that can be auto-rigged and animated. Both Computer Science Graphics (CSG) and Digital Production Arts (DPA) programs will use the camera. The research involves the following projects: Surface Reconstruction from Point Cloud and Stream Line Digital Character Generation. Broader Impact: The use of the Zmini camera to capture and animate 3D images promises to have significant impact in teaching and learning, as well as advancing discovery and understanding of learners. The device will provide students and faculty with the opportunity to incorporate image-based modeling in their work at the DPA program. The camera will be used in classes with a high percentage of minority enrollment where students will gain research experience in the conference presentation interactive program.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: This project from an EPSCoR state, acquiring A Zmini camera that captures 3D information (real time color and depth) at video rates, aims to model and render 3D information. 这个项目从EPSCoR状态，获取一个Zmini相机捕捉三维信息（实时颜色和深度）的视频速率，旨在建模和渲染三维信息。活动包括使用Zmini相机从多个视点获取点云，使用改进的marching cubes算法生成曲面，以及自动将模型绑定到角色动画的骨架（称为自动装配）。因此，相机的点云建模将用于创建曲面，特别是人形曲面，这些曲面可以自动装配和设置动画。计算机科学图形（CSG）和数字制作艺术（DPA）程序都将使用相机。研究内容包括：点云曲面重建和流线数字字符生成。更广泛的影响：使用Zmini相机拍摄和制作三维图像的动画有望对教学和学习产生重大影响，并促进学习者的发现和理解。该设备将为学生和教师提供机会，将基于图像的建模纳入他们在DPA项目的工作中。该相机将用于少数民族入学率高的班级，学生将在会议演示互动项目中获得研究经验。

Source.Name: Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering

Graduate Research Fellowships Program

Project.Title: Discrete features and their applications in cryptography and mathematics

Title_Other.Title: 离散特征及其在密码学和数学中的应用
Diskrete funksjoner og deres applikasjoner i kryptografi og matematikk

Project.Abstract:
The aim of this project is to address essential problems related to discrete functions. Solutions of these problems may improve the reliability and security of modern communication systems and could make a big impact to many branches of mathematics. That is, the research involved in this project would have both theoretical and practical significance.
Discrete functions are mappings from one finite set to another one and an important particular case of such functions is the case of Boolean functions, whic h are ubiquitous, occurring at the heart of virtually all known digital systems: computers, telecommunications and cryptographic primitives, for example, all depend on the theory of Boolean functions. Moreover, functions with optimal cryptographic propert ies define optimal in certain sense objects in coding theory, combinatorics, algebra, finite geometry, sequence design, quantum information theory et al. Hence, construction and analysis of optimal cryptographic functions is connected with important mathe matical problems and solution of these problems would make a valuable contribution to both mathematics and information theory. On the other hand, it's certain that the potential of the theory of discrete functions is not used to its full extent and we als o aim to discover its further applications.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 这个项目的目的是解决与离散函数相关的基本问题。这些问题的解决可以提高现代通信系统的可靠性和安全性，并对数学的许多分支产生重大影响。也就是说，本课题的研究具有一定的理论和现实意义。 离散函数是从一个有限集到另一个有限集的映射，这种函数的一个重要的特殊情况是布尔函数的情况，布尔函数是普遍存在的，发生在几乎所有已知数字系统的核心：例如计算机、电信和密码原语，都依赖于布尔函数理论。此外，在编码理论、组合学、代数、有限几何、序列设计、量子信息理论等领域，具有最优密码特性的函数在一定意义上定义了最优对象。因此，最优密码函数的构造和分析与重要的数学问题密切相关，这些问题的求解对数学和信息论都有重要的贡献。另一方面，可以肯定的是，离散函数理论的潜力并没有得到充分的发挥，我们希望能进一步发现它的应用。

The aim of this project is to address essential problems related to discrete functions. Solutions of these problems may improve the reliability and security of modern communication systems and could make a big impact to many branches of mathematics. That is, the research involved in this project would have both theoretical and practical significance.
Discrete functions are mappings from one finite set to another one and an important particular case of such functions is the case of Boolean functions, whic h are ubiquitous, occurring at the heart of virtually all known digital systems: computers, telecommunications and cryptographic primitives, for example, all depend on the theory of Boolean functions. Moreover, functions with optimal cryptographic propert ies define optimal in certain sense objects in coding theory, combinatorics, algebra, finite geometry, sequence design, quantum information theory et al. Hence, construction and analysis of optimal cryptographic functions is connected with important mathe matical problems and solution of these problems would make a valuable contribution to both mathematics and information theory. On the other hand, it's certain that the potential of the theory of discrete functions is not used to its full extent and we als o aim to discover its further applications.

Project.Title: Structure and Assembly of the Budding Yeast Centromeric Nucleosome

Title_Other.Title: 芽接酵母着丝粒核小体的结构与组装
Structure and Assembly of the Budding Yeast Centromeric Nucleosome

Project.Abstract: The CenH3 histone variant (Cse4 in Saccharomyces cerevisiae) replaces the major H3 histone in centromeric nucleosomes. The composition, structure and the assembly mechanisms of CenH3-containing nucleosomes are not clearly defined. The study proposed here is intended to provide the structural information on centromeric nucleosomes and addresses the impact of non-histone protein Scm3 on the assembly and structure of budding yeast S. cerevisiae centromeric nucleosomes. We hypothesize that nucleosomes containing Cse4 are thermodynamically and structurally altered compared to canonical nucleosomes, and that the non-histone centromeric protein Scm3 significantly contributes to the assembly and properties of Cse4-containing nucleosomes. The specific aims are: 1. Solve the structure of the centromeric nucleosome from budding yeast, and 2. Establish the role of the non-histone centromeric protein Scm3 in the assembly of centromeric nucleosomes. A series of different biochemical, biophysical and structural techniques will be used to characterize the budding yeast centromeric nucleosomes and associated protein Scm3. Small-angle X-ray/neutron scattering and crystallography will be employed to solve the in solution and high-resolution crystal structure of budding yeast centromeric nucleosomes. Moreover, we will determine the structure of Scm3 in complex with Cse4 and H4 histones. The proposed experiments will provide valuable information on composition and structure of centromeric nucleosomes, and may give insight into the role of non-histone centromeric proteins on assembly of nucleosomes on centromeric DNA. These studies in budding yeast are applicable to our understanding of centromeric structure and function in higher organisms.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: The CenH3 histone variant (Cse4 in Saccharomyces cerevisiae) replaces the major H3 histone in centromeric nucleosomes. The composition, structure and the assembly mechanisms of CenH3-containing nucleosomes are not clearly defined. The specific aims are: 1. Solve the structure of the centromeric nucleosome from budding yeast, and 2. Establish the role of the non-histone centromeric protein Scm3 in the assembly of centromeric nucleosomes. These studies in budding yeast are applicable to our understanding of centromeric structure and function in higher organisms.

CenH3组蛋白变体（酿酒酵母中的Cse4）取代着丝粒核小体中的主要H3组蛋白。含CenH3核小体的组成、结构和组装机制尚不清楚。本研究旨在提供着丝粒核小体的结构信息，并探讨非组蛋白Scm3对芽接酵母S.cerevisiae着丝粒核小体组装和结构的影响。我们假设与典型核小体相比，含Cse4的核小体具有热力学和结构上的改变，并且非组蛋白着丝粒蛋白Scm3对含Cse4的核小体的组装和性质有显著的贡献。具体目标是：1。解决了芽接酵母着丝粒核小体的结构问题。建立非组蛋白着丝粒蛋白Scm3在着丝粒核小体组装中的作用。将采用一系列不同的生化、生物物理学和结构技术来表征芽接酵母着丝粒核小体和相关蛋白Scm3。用小角X射线/中子散射和晶体学方法研究芽接酵母着丝粒核小体的溶液内和高分辨率晶体结构。此外，我们将确定与Cse4和H4组蛋白复合物中Scm3的结构。这些实验将为着丝粒核小体的组成和结构提供有价值的信息，并有助于深入了解非组蛋白着丝粒蛋白在着丝粒DNA核小体组装中的作用。这些对芽接酵母的研究有助于我们了解高等生物着丝粒的结构和功能。

Project.Title: The effect of food availability on the reproductive success of birds in the urbanization gradient

Title_Other.Title: Wpływ dostępności pokarmu na sukces reprodukcyjny ptaków w gradiencie urbanizacji
城市化梯度下食物供应对鸟类繁殖成功的影响

Project.Title: Uncertainty-Analysis-Driven Reduced-Order Kinetic Models Targeting Combustion Dynamics

Title_Other.Title: Uncertainty-Analysis-Driven Reduced-Order Kinetic Models Targeting Combustion Dynamics
基于不确定性分析的燃烧动力学降阶模型

Project.Abstract: The design and development of a number of advanced Air Force propulsion systems is substantially limited by the current inability of computational design support tools to adequately and cost-effectively predict the complex flow physics and combustion dynamics that governs system performance and stability. The innovation proposed consists of a comprehensive experimental-modeling framework to (i) systematically evaluate chemical kinetic models, (ii) validate their predictions against experimental data and (iii) guide their enhancement in terms of both prediction accuracy and computational efficiency. Specifically, the joint team consisting of Combustion Research and Flow Technology, Inc., the University of Virginia and Georgia Tech will further mature and converge under a common framework a number of capabilities pertaining to the development of reduced-order kinetic models, inclusion of combustion dynamics characteristics, extension to extreme pressures and quantification of uncertainty bounds. Computationally-tractable kinetic models for RP-1/RP-2 fuels applicable for highly turbulent and unsteady liquid rocket engine simulations at the high pressure operating conditions of interest are addressed in this STTR program.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: The design and development of a number of advanced Air Force propulsion systems is substantially limited by the current inability of computational design support tools to adequately and cost-effectively predict the complex flow physics and combustion dynamics that governs system performance and stability. The innovation proposed consists of a comprehensive experimental-modeling framework to (i) systematically evaluate chemical kinetic models, (ii) validate their predictions against experimental data and (iii) guide their enhancement in terms of both prediction accuracy and computational efficiency. Specifically, the joint team consisting of Combustion Research and Flow Technology, Inc., the University of Virginia and Georgia Tech will further mature and converge under a common framework a number of capabilities pertaining to the development of reduced-order kinetic models, inclusion of combustion dynamics characteristics, extension to extreme pressures and quantification of uncertainty bounds. Computationally-tractable kinetic models for RP-1/RP-2 fuels applicable for highly turbulent and unsteady liquid rocket engine simulations at the high pressure operating conditions of interest are addressed in this STTR program.

许多先进的空军推进系统的设计和开发受到当前计算设计支持工具无法充分和经济有效地预测控制系统性能和稳定性的复杂流动物理和燃烧动力学的限制。该创新包括一个全面的实验建模框架，用于（i）系统地评估化学动力学模型，（ii）根据实验数据验证其预测，（iii）指导其在预测精度和计算效率方面的提高。具体而言，由燃烧研究和流动技术公司、弗吉尼亚大学和乔治亚理工大学组成的联合小组将在一个共同框架下进一步成熟和融合一些与发展降阶动力学模型、包括燃烧动力学特性有关的能力，极限压力的扩展和不确定性界限的量化。本文提出了适用于高紊流和非定常液体火箭发动机模拟的RP-1/RP-2燃料的可计算动力学模型。

Title_Other.Title: Medical Research Council of Canada - Eleven (11) Burroughs Wellcome Fund Student Research Awards.
加拿大医学研究委员会-十一（11）个巴勒斯威康基金学生研究奖。

Project.Title: Collaborative Research: Ecological and Evolutionary Forces Reshaping Mutualism During Species Introductions

Title_Other.Title: Collaborative Research: Ecological and Evolutionary Forces Reshaping Mutualism During Species Introductions
合作研究：在物种引进过程中重塑互惠关系的生态和进化力量

Class.ClassName: 环境生态系统、生态环境

Project.Abstract: Introduced species can wreak havoc on ecosystems by displacing natives and by altering environmental conditions. While much is known about the properties of invasive plants and animals, much less is known about the beneficial microbes (microscopic organisms) that accompany introduced species. Rhizobia are beneficial bacteria that inhabit leguminous plant root tissue where they convert nitrogen from the atmosphere to a plant-available form. Leguminous plants provide these microbes with sugars from photosynthesis. Legumes that disperse to habitats that lack these bacteria are typically unable to persist, however the bacteria can also spread through the soil or air. The aim of this research is to examine whether invasions change the nature of a mutualistic interaction. The investigators will study specialization and the evolution of cooperation in both natural and experimentally staged invasions for two plant species and their beneficial microbes. While this question has been addressed in aboveground systems, this is one of the first to utilize a belowground plant mutualism. This project will promote diversity in the sciences, provide research training and education in the biology of plant-microbe interactions, and inform efforts to control invasive plants. Diverse undergraduate students from Florida International University will participate in summer research at University of California at Riverside and Michigan State University. An educational module will also be developed on rhizobium-legume interactions in neighborhood soils, to be distributed to school children via MSU's Kellogg Biological Station Bioenergy Sustainability Program and the Fairchild Challenge, an environmental education program that reaches over 100,000 children a year in Miami. To understand whether mutualisms become less beneficial in the process of species invasions, this project will test the hypothesized trade-off between partner breadth and mutualism benefit across legume and rhizobium genotypes from the native and invasive range for two Medicago species. Medicago is the genus that includes alfalfa. Both species are native to Europe and invasive in the US. The researchers will 1) compare genetic diversity in native vs. invaded host range mutualists, using high marker density genotyping for hosts and whole-genome sequencing for symbionts, 2) assess divergence in mutualism properties between the native and invaded range to test hypotheses of reduced specialization, partner choice and mutualism dependence in invaded range mutualists using cross-inoculation trials, 3) test the impact of invasion on symbiont genome dynamics and mutualisms by simulated symbiont invasions in soil mesocosms under contrasting host density and diversity, and 4) identify the molecular underpinnings of mutualism specialization using a transcriptomic approach to nominate host-symbiont pathways. This research will shed light on the long-standing question of whether beneficial microbes face a trade-off between having a broad partner range and providing a high degree of benefit to a partner.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 引进的物种会通过转移当地人和改变环境条件而对生态系统造成严重破坏。虽然人们对入侵动植物的特性知之甚少，但对伴随引进物种的有益微生物（微生物）知之甚少。根瘤菌是一种有益的细菌，它们栖息在豆科植物的根组织中，将大气中的氮转化为植物可利用的形式。豆科植物通过光合作用为这些微生物提供糖。向缺乏这些细菌的栖息地扩散的豆科植物通常无法存活，然而这些细菌也可以通过土壤或空气传播。本研究的目的是探讨入侵是否会改变互惠互动的本质。研究人员将研究两种植物及其有益微生物在自然和实验阶段入侵中的专业化和合作进化。虽然这个问题已经在地上系统中得到了解决，但这是第一个利用地下植物互惠论的系统。该项目将促进科学的多样性，提供植物-微生物相互作用生物学方面的研究培训和教育，并为控制入侵植物的努力提供信息。来自佛罗里达国际大学的本科生将参加加州大学河滨分校和密歇根州立大学的暑期研究。此外，还将开发一个有关邻里土壤中豆科根瘤菌相互作用的教育单元，通过MSU的Kellogg生物站生物能源可持续性计划和Fairchild Challenge（迈阿密每年有超过10万名儿童参加的环境教育计划）分发给学龄儿童。为了了解互惠互利在物种入侵过程中是否变得不那么有利，本项目将对两种药用植物的本地和入侵范围内的豆科和根瘤菌基因型的伙伴广度和互惠互利之间的假设权衡进行测试。苜蓿属包括苜蓿。这两个物种都原产于欧洲，在美国都有入侵性。研究人员将1）比较本地和入侵宿主范围内互惠共生者的遗传多样性，使用宿主的高标记密度基因分型和共生体的全基因组测序，2）评估本地和入侵范围内互惠特性的差异，以测试专业化程度降低的假设，利用交叉接种试验，研究了侵染范围内互惠共生者的伙伴选择和互惠依赖性；3）在对比宿主密度和多样性的情况下，通过模拟土壤介观中的共生侵染，检验侵染对共生体基因组动力学和互惠性的影响；4）利用转录组学方法来指定宿主-共生体途径。这项研究将揭示有益微生物是否在拥有广泛的合作伙伴范围和为合作伙伴提供高度利益之间面临权衡的长期问题。

Introduced species can wreak havoc on ecosystems by displacing natives and by altering environmental conditions. While much is known about the properties of invasive plants and animals, much less is known about the beneficial microbes (microscopic organisms) that accompany introduced species. Rhizobia are beneficial bacteria that inhabit leguminous plant root tissue where they convert nitrogen from the atmosphere to a plant-available form. Leguminous plants provide these microbes with sugars from photosynthesis. Legumes that disperse to habitats that lack these bacteria are typically unable to persist, however the bacteria can also spread through the soil or air. The aim of this research is to examine whether invasions change the nature of a mutualistic interaction. The investigators will study specialization and the evolution of cooperation in both natural and experimentally staged invasions for two plant species and their beneficial microbes. While this question has been addressed in aboveground systems, this is one of the first to utilize a belowground plant mutualism. This project will promote diversity in the sciences, provide research training and education in the biology of plant-microbe interactions, and inform efforts to control invasive plants. Diverse undergraduate students from Florida International University will participate in summer research at University of California at Riverside and Michigan State University. An educational module will also be developed on rhizobium-legume interactions in neighborhood soils, to be distributed to school children via MSU's Kellogg Biological Station Bioenergy Sustainability Program and the Fairchild Challenge, an environmental education program that reaches over 100,000 children a year in Miami. To understand whether mutualisms become less beneficial in the process of species invasions, this project will test the hypothesized trade-off between partner breadth and mutualism benefit across legume and rhizobium genotypes from the native and invasive range for two Medicago species. Medicago is the genus that includes alfalfa. Both species are native to Europe and invasive in the US. The researchers will 1) compare genetic diversity in native vs. invaded host range mutualists, using high marker density genotyping for hosts and whole-genome sequencing for symbionts, 2) assess divergence in mutualism properties between the native and invaded range to test hypotheses of reduced specialization, partner choice and mutualism dependence in invaded range mutualists using cross-inoculation trials, 3) test the impact of invasion on symbiont genome dynamics and mutualisms by simulated symbiont invasions in soil mesocosms under contrasting host density and diversity, and 4) identify the molecular underpinnings of mutualism specialization using a transcriptomic approach to nominate host-symbiont pathways. This research will shed light on the long-standing question of whether beneficial microbes face a trade-off between having a broad partner range and providing a high degree of benefit to a partner.

Project.Title: CEDAR: Conjugate Studies of Low and Midlatitude Ionospheric Processes

Title_Other.Title: 电离层中低纬过程的共轭研究
CEDAR: Conjugate Studies of Low and Midlatitude Ionospheric Processes

Project.Abstract: This project addresses electrodynamic processes in the Earth's ionosphere at low and mid-latitudes. These processes will be studied simultaneously in both hemispheres in the American sector from locations along the same geomagnetic field lines. Data from ground-based all-sky imagers and in-situ satellite measurements will be analyzed. The results of this study will be made broadly available, will help to understand how inter-hemispheric coupling occurs, and can be incorporated in global scale models of ionospheric electrodynamics, which are relevant to understanding Space Weather. This research will involve graduate and undergraduate students. Specifically, this project will investigate the behavior of ionospheric perturbations related to equatorial Spread-F (ESF) and medium-scale traveling ionospheric disturbances (MSTIDs). Observations include all-sky imagers and Fabry-Perot interferometers at magnetically conjugate locations in the American Sector. The generation mechanism of MSTIDs will be investigated using the conjugate measurements as well as data from the C/NOFS satellite.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: This project addresses electrodynamic processes in the Earth's ionosphere at low and mid-latitudes. 这个项目研究中低纬度地区地球电离层的电动力学过程。这些过程将在美国板块的两个半球从同一地磁线的位置同时进行研究。将分析来自地面全天空成像仪和原位卫星测量的数据。这项研究的结果将广泛提供，将有助于了解半球间耦合是如何发生的，并可纳入与了解空间天气有关的电离层电动力学全球尺度模型。这项研究将涉及研究生和本科生。具体而言，本计画将探讨电离层扰动与赤道扩展F（ESF）及中尺度行波电离层扰动（MSTIDs）相关之行为。观测包括全天空成像仪和法布里-珀罗干涉仪在美国扇区的磁共轭位置。利用共轭测量和C/NOFS卫星的数据研究MSTIDs的产生机制。

Project.Title: Real Time Computer Simulation of Human Soft Organ Deformation for Computer Assisted Surgery

Title_Other.Title: Real Time Computer Simulation of Human Soft Organ Deformation for Computer Assisted Surgery
计算机辅助手术中人体软器官变形的实时计算机模拟

Project.Abstract: The proposed research will develop computational framework, which will allow calculation of soft organ (brain, liver, kidney, prostate, etc.) deformation during surgical operations in real time. Fully non-linear material models and geometrically non-linear finite element formulation will be used. The fundamental technology developed within this project: physically (or mechanically) realistic modelling and real time computer simulation of soft organ deformation, will have applications in many areas of computer assisted surgery, such as intra-operative, real time non-rigid registration and virtual reality surgeon training and operation planning systems with force and tactile feedback.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 该研究将开发一个计算框架，允许在外科手术中实时计算软器官（脑、肝、肾、前列腺等）的变形。将使用完全非线性材料模型和几何非线性有限元公式。本项目开发的基本技术：软器官变形的物理（或机械）真实建模和实时计算机模拟，将在计算机辅助手术的许多领域，如术中，具有力和触觉反馈的实时非刚性注册和虚拟现实外科医生培训及手术计划系统。

The proposed research will develop computational framework, which will allow calculation of soft organ (brain, liver, kidney, prostate, etc.) deformation during surgical operations in real time. Fully non-linear material models and geometrically non-linear finite element formulation will be used. The fundamental technology developed within this project: physically (or mechanically) realistic modelling and real time computer simulation of soft organ deformation, will have applications in many areas of computer assisted surgery, such as intra-operative, real time non-rigid registration and virtual reality surgeon training and operation planning systems with force and tactile feedback.

Project.Title: Role of transcription factors in intestinal development

Title_Other.Title: 转录因子在肠道发育中的作用
Role of transcription factors in intestinal development

Project.Abstract: The final formation of adult and functional intestinal epithelium is the result of several steps which begins with the coarse morphogenesis of the intestine, followed by the differentiation of epithelium and linduction intestine-specific genes such as the Sucrase- isomaltase (SI). SI gene represents a useful model for IceWatch molecular mechanisms that define the morphological and genetic differences between the gut epithelium of the colon versus hail. SI gene transcription is limited to gut enterocytes differentiated mature hail then what is repressed actively in colonic epithelium. IF becomes re-expressed in the majority of adenocarcinomas and human colonic polyps. GATA-4 and CDP are transcription factors that control the expression of the SI gene during development. The hypothesis of the proposed research plan is quune genetic alteration of GATA-4 or Cux / CDP in intestinal epithelial cells or cancerous colon result in specific alterations in the proliferative and differential potential of these cells. The proposed research program aims to gain a better understanding of the specific molecular mechanisms specialization of intestinal epithelial cells and have potential implications for understanding the molecular events involved in intestinal pathologies, specifically colorectal cancer.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 成人和功能性肠上皮的最终形成是由肠的粗形态发生、上皮分化和肠内特异性基因如蔗糖酶-异麦芽糖酶（SI）诱导的结果。SI基因代表了冰雹分子机制的一个有用模型，它定义了结肠肠上皮与冰雹之间的形态和遗传差异。SI基因的转录仅限于肠肠上皮细胞分化成熟的冰雹，然后在结肠上皮细胞中被抑制。IF在大多数腺癌和人类结肠息肉中重新表达。GATA-4和CDP是在发育过程中控制SI基因表达的转录因子。该研究计划的假设是，GATA-4或Cux/CDP在肠上皮细胞或癌性结肠中的遗传改变会导致这些细胞的增殖和分化潜能发生特异性改变。拟议的研究计划旨在更好地了解肠上皮细胞的特殊分子机制，并对了解与肠道病理学，特别是结直肠癌有关的分子事件具有潜在的意义。

La formation définitive de l�épithélium intestinal adulte et fonctionnel est le résultat de plusieurs étapes qui débute avec la morphogénèse grossière de l�intestin, suivie par la différenciation de l�épithélium et l�induction de gènes intestin-spécifiques tel que la Sucrase-Isomaltase (SI). Le gène SI représente un modèle utile pour l`étude des mécanismes moléculaires qui définissent les différences morphologiques et génétiques entre l�épithélium de l�intestin grèle versus celui du côlon. La transcription du gène SI est limitée aux entérocytes différenciés de l�intestin grèle mature alors qu�elle est réprimée de façon active dans l�épithélium colonique. SI devient réexprimée dans la majorité des adénocarcinomes et polypes coloniques humains. GATA-4 et CDP sont des facteurs de transcription qui contrôlent l�expression du gène SI au cours du développement. L�hypothèse du plan de recherche proposé est qu�une altération génétique de GATA-4 ou Cux/CDP dans les cellules épithéliales intestinales ou cancéreuses de côlon résultera en des altérations spécifiques au niveau du potentiel prolifératif et différencié de ces cellules. Le programme de recherche proposé vise donc à acquérir une meilleure compréhension des mécanismes moléculaires spécifiques à la spécialisation des cellules épithéliales intestinales et aura des retombées éventuelles sur la compréhension des événements moléculaires impliqués dans les pathologies intestinales, plus précisément, le cancer colorectal.

Project.Title: Hypothermic Storage and Cryopreservation of Corneas

Title_Other.Title: Hypothermic Storage and Cryopreservation of Corneas
角膜低温保存

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): Cell Preservation Services, Inc. (CPSI) is a biotechnology company dedicated to the development of novel technologies in the area of low temperature biology and medicine. CPSI's core molecular strategy is focused on understanding and manipulating the cell survival and cell death pathways that appear to be cell-specific and are activated as a consequence of low temperature exposure. This paradigm shift has led to improved processes for the hypothermic storage and cryopreservation of a variety of human cells and tissues. Recently, through preliminary studies, we have determined that it is not adequate to merely address stress response issues during preservation through solution design, as has been the focus in the past, but in fact a more comprehensive and integrated strategy involving pre- and post-preservation cell conditioning strategies is necessary. CPSI applied this novel strategic approach and has identified promising new methodologies that appear to improve corneal cell and tissue quality beyond that of typical protocols which rely only on the use of preservation media, such as Optisol-GS, to maintain tissue integrity and function. Feasibility data gathered on human corneal endothelial cells (HCEC), bovine corneal endothelial cells (BCEC) and other relevant human cell strains suggest that the development of improved cornea processing and preservation protocols is highly feasible and successful development of an integrated process should not only increase the quality and utility of corneal tissue, but increase the donor pool as well. Investigations conducted under this research project will utilize cDNA microarrays, proteomic profiling, and viability and functional analysis to define the stress response pathways activated in HCEC following low temperature exposure common to pre-transplant processing. It is the intent of these studies to provide a better understanding of the unique responses of HCEC and whole cornea to low temperature exposure and utilize these data to develop new procedures for corneal tissue processing. We have established collaborations and subcontracts with researchers from several organizations including Harvard Medical School, the Schepens Eye Research Institute, the Moran Eye Center and NDRI to facilitate access to various outside resources (including expertise, cell culture systems, IP, etc.) to evaluate new processes/protocols that are developed under this research project as well as to help ensure the success of this research program. It is our belief that the proposed investigations will lead to new methodologies for the processing of corneal tissue. These developments should have an impact not only on the quality and availability of harvested corneas, but also enable expanded utilization of corneal-derived cells in areas such as in vitro toxicological testing and HCEC transplant. Corneal opacities are leading causes of blindness. One method to resolve this impediment to clear vision is to transplant donor corneas to the patient. To do so typically means that donor corneas must be preserved in a state of suspended animation in the cold prior to transplant. The methodologies developed in the past using Optisol- GS are dated and not based on modern, molecular medicine. CPSI proposes to use a molecular strategy to develop improved protocols for the long term storage of human corneas - a set of integrated processes that will both increase the available cornea donor pool as well as the quality of the tissue for the cornea transplant market.

说明（申请人提供）：细胞保存服务公司（CPSI）是一家致力于低温生物学和医学领域新技术开发的生物技术公司。CPSI的核心分子策略集中于理解和操纵细胞存活和细胞死亡的途径，这些途径似乎是细胞特异性的，并且由于低温暴露而被激活。这种范式的转变导致了各种人类细胞和组织的低温储存和低温保存过程的改进。最近，通过初步研究，我们确定，仅仅通过溶液设计来解决保存过程中的应激反应问题是不够的，这在过去一直是关注的焦点，但事实上，需要一个更全面和综合的策略，包括保存前和保存后的细胞调节策略。CPSI应用了这一新的战略方法，并确定了一些有前途的新方法，这些方法似乎可以改善角膜细胞和组织质量，而不是仅仅依靠保存介质（如Optisol-GS）来维持组织完整性和功能的典型方案。收集人类角膜内皮细胞（HCEC）的可行性数据，牛角膜内皮细胞（BCEC）和其他相关的人细胞株表明，开发改良的角膜加工和保存方案是非常可行的，成功开发一种综合工艺不仅可以提高角膜组织的质量和利用率，还可以增加供体池。在本研究项目下进行的研究将利用cDNA微阵列、蛋白质组分析、生存能力和功能分析来确定在移植前处理中常见的低温暴露后HCEC中激活的应激反应途径。这些研究的目的是为了更好地了解HCEC和整个角膜对低温暴露的独特反应，并利用这些数据开发角膜组织处理的新程序。我们已与哈佛医学院、舍本斯眼科研究所、莫兰眼科中心和NDRI等多家机构的研究人员建立了合作关系和分包合同，以方便他们获得各种外部资源（包括专业知识、细胞培养系统、知识产权，评估在本研究项目下开发的新流程/协议，并帮助确保本研究项目的成功。我们相信这些研究将为角膜组织的加工带来新的方法。这些发展不仅对收获的角膜的质量和可用性有影响，而且还能够在体外毒理学试验和HEC移植等领域扩大角膜衍生细胞的利用。角膜混浊是导致失明的主要原因。解决视力障碍的一种方法是将供体角膜移植到病人身上。要做到这一点，通常意味着在移植前，供体角膜必须在寒冷的环境中保持悬浮状态。过去使用光学溶胶-凝胶的方法是过时的，不是基于现代分子医学。CPSI建议使用分子策略来开发改进的人类角膜长期保存方案，这是一套集成的过程，既可以增加可用的角膜供体池，也可以提高角膜移植市场的组织质量。

Project.Title: Cross-Site: Spatio-temporal Dynamics of Canopy and Soil Moisture: Linking Synthetic Aperture Radar Image Phenomenology with Ecosystem Processes

Title_Other.Title: Cross-Site: Spatio-temporal Dynamics of Canopy and Soil Moisture: Linking Synthetic Aperture Radar Image Phenomenology with Ecosystem Processes
跨站点：冠层和土壤水分的时空动态：将合成孔径雷达图像现象学与生态系统过程联系起来

Project.Title: Molecular genetic studies of familial multiple sclerosis in the Australian population

Title_Other.Title: 澳大利亚人群家族性多发性硬化的分子遗传学研究
Molecular genetic studies of familial multiple sclerosis in the Australian population

Project.Title: T Cell Maturation and the Nexus of Viral- and Allo-Immunity

Title_Other.Title: T Cell Maturation and the Nexus of Viral- and Allo-Immunity
T细胞成熟与病毒及同种免疫的关系

Class.ClassName: 碱土金属、碱土金属合金

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): Organ transplantation's considerable benefit is significantly offset by the complications associated with its required chronic immunosuppressive therapy. Patients are usually on several medications, but calcineurin inhibitors (CNIs) have long formed the centerpiece of most regimens. CNIs effectively prevent rejection, but their use is associated with non-antigen-specific T cell suppression, consequent impaired protective immunity, and numerous non-immune side effects. This year, a CNI alternative has been approved: belatacept, a fusion protein that mediates CD28-B7 costimulation blockade (CoB). Substantial clinical evidence suggests that belatacept can serve as a CNI replacement, avoiding CNI-specific off-target side effects. However, belatacept appears less able to prevent rejection in certain scenarios, and to inhomogenously impair viral immunity, particularly towards the common Epstein - Barr virus. Thus, clinicians now have two distinct approaches to prevent transplant rejection, CNI- and CoB-based immunosuppression, but little data guiding a rational choice between them. This application approaches this highly contemporary dilemma in transplantation, the CNI/belatacept choice and its relationship to the reciprocal complications of rejection and viral infection. We hypothesize that rejection and viral infection are mechanisticall related through a process known as heterologous alloimmunity-alloimmunity matured by prior viral infection-and that the changes in T cell phenotype known to emerge throughout life and influence allo- and viral-immunity can be used to anticipate one's response to CNIs and CoB. We believe these phenotypic changes can be used to develop a biologically plausible, therapeutically relevant, and diagnostically definable means of segregating those patients who will benefit from a belatacept-based regimen from those better served by a CNI-based approach. We explore this hypothesis in three Specific Aims, one observational study in humans to define the extent to which viral infection and rejection relate to kidney transplant recipients' T cell differentiation and exhaustion in the context of CNI- or belatacept-based therapy, and two experimental projects performed using well-defined, clinically relevant, mouse models of transplantation and viral infection to establish the mechanisms determining CNI- and CoB-specific effects on allo- and viral-specific-immunity. The investigative team formed for this study is facile in using observations in transplant patients to inform the conduct of rigorously controlled animal studies, and in the use of novel animal experiments to modify human studies. It is centered in a high volume transplant center that has developed an outstanding infrastructure for the acquisition of well-characterized human samples, and exceptional exposure to patients undergoing CNI- and belatacept-based regimens. Thus, each aim will be conducted cognizant of both the relevant clinical circumstances and mechanistic principles. This study will facilitate development of a unifying paradigm to guide the rational selection of immunosuppressive agents, and facilitate individualized, data-driven, immunological management for transplant patients.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 说明（由申请人提供）：器官移植的巨大效益被其所需的慢性免疫抑制治疗相关的并发症大大抵消。患者通常服用多种药物，但钙调神经磷酸酶抑制剂（CNIs）长期以来一直是大多数治疗方案的核心。CNIs能有效地防止排斥反应，但其使用与非抗原特异性T细胞抑制、保护性免疫受损以及许多非免疫副作用有关。今年，CNI的一个替代品被批准：belatacept，一种介导CD28-B7共刺激阻断（CoB）的融合蛋白。大量临床证据表明，belatacept可作为CNI替代物，避免CNI特异性的靶外副作用。然而，belatacept在某些情况下似乎不太能够防止排斥反应，并且不均匀地损害病毒免疫，特别是对常见的Epstein-Barr病毒。因此，临床医生现在有两种不同的方法来预防移植排斥反应，基于CNI和CoB的免疫抑制，但很少有数据指导他们之间的合理选择。这一应用在移植、CNI/belatacept选择及其与排斥反应和病毒感染的相互并发症之间的关系方面接近了这一高度当代的困境。我们假设，排斥反应和病毒感染是通过一个被称为异源异基因免疫的过程机械性地相关的，该过程是由先前的病毒感染成熟的，并且已知的T细胞表型的变化在整个生命中出现并影响了异基因和病毒免疫，可以用来预测一个人对CNIs和CoB的反应。我们相信，这些表型变化可以用于开发一种生物学上合理的、治疗上相关的、诊断上可定义的方法，将那些将从基于belatacept的治疗方案中获益的患者与那些通过基于CNI的方法更好地服务的患者分离开来。我们从三个具体的目的来探讨这个假设，一个是在CNI或belatacept为基础的治疗背景下对人类进行的观察研究，以确定病毒感染和排斥反应与肾移植受者T细胞分化和衰竭的关系，以及两个使用明确定义的实验项目，临床相关，建立小鼠移植和病毒感染模型，以确定CNI和CoB对同种和病毒特异性免疫的作用机制。为这项研究组建的研究小组可以方便地利用移植病人的观察结果来指导严格控制的动物研究，并利用新的动物实验来修改人类研究。该中心位于一个大容量移植中心，该中心开发了一个卓越的基础设施，用于采集特征良好的人体样本，以及与接受基于CNI和belatacept治疗的患者进行特殊接触。因此，每一个目标的实施都将认识到相关的临床情况和机械原理。这项研究将有助于发展一个统一的范式，以指导免疫抑制剂的合理选择，并有助于移植患者的个体化、数据驱动的免疫管理。

DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): Organ transplantation's considerable benefit is significantly offset by the complications associated with its required chronic immunosuppressive therapy. Patients are usually on several medications, but calcineurin inhibitors (CNIs) have long formed the centerpiece of most regimens. CNIs effectively prevent rejection, but their use is associated with non-antigen-specific T cell suppression, consequent impaired protective immunity, and numerous non-immune side effects. This year, a CNI alternative has been approved: belatacept, a fusion protein that mediates CD28-B7 costimulation blockade (CoB). Substantial clinical evidence suggests that belatacept can serve as a CNI replacement, avoiding CNI-specific off-target side effects. However, belatacept appears less able to prevent rejection in certain scenarios, and to inhomogenously impair viral immunity, particularly towards the common Epstein - Barr virus. Thus, clinicians now have two distinct approaches to prevent transplant rejection, CNI- and CoB-based immunosuppression, but little data guiding a rational choice between them. This application approaches this highly contemporary dilemma in transplantation, the CNI/belatacept choice and its relationship to the reciprocal complications of rejection and viral infection. We hypothesize that rejection and viral infection are mechanisticall related through a process known as heterologous alloimmunity-alloimmunity matured by prior viral infection-and that the changes in T cell phenotype known to emerge throughout life and influence allo- and viral-immunity can be used to anticipate one's response to CNIs and CoB. We believe these phenotypic changes can be used to develop a biologically plausible, therapeutically relevant, and diagnostically definable means of segregating those patients who will benefit from a belatacept-based regimen from those better served by a CNI-based approach. We explore this hypothesis in three Specific Aims, one observational study in humans to define the extent to which viral infection and rejection relate to kidney transplant recipients' T cell differentiation and exhaustion in the context of CNI- or belatacept-based therapy, and two experimental projects performed using well-defined, clinically relevant, mouse models of transplantation and viral infection to establish the mechanisms determining CNI- and CoB-specific effects on allo- and viral-specific-immunity. The investigative team formed for this study is facile in using observations in transplant patients to inform the conduct of rigorously controlled animal studies, and in the use of novel animal experiments to modify human studies. It is centered in a high volume transplant center that has developed an outstanding infrastructure for the acquisition of well-characterized human samples, and exceptional exposure to patients undergoing CNI- and belatacept-based regimens. Thus, each aim will be conducted cognizant of both the relevant clinical circumstances and mechanistic principles. This study will facilitate development of a unifying paradigm to guide the rational selection of immunosuppressive agents, and facilitate individualized, data-driven, immunological management for transplant patients.

Project.Title: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Chemistry at the University of Cincinnati

Title_Other.Title: 路透社网站：辛辛那提大学化学系本科生的研究经历
REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Chemistry at the University of Cincinnati

Project.Abstract: This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE), supports the renewal of a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Cincinnati (UC) for the summers of 2008-2010. This REU site will be managed by Bruce Ault with assistance from Anna Gudmundsdottir from the Department of Chemistry at the University of Cincinnati. This REU site will bring nine students to campus for a ten-week period each summer to conduct cutting edge research in chemistry. Eight of the nine students will be funded through NSF and one student each summer will be funded by the John J. Alexander Fellowship endowment in the Department of Chemistry. Recruitment plans are expected to identify these nine REU students, all from outside the University of Cincinnati. Though applications will be accepted from across the U.S., recruitment will target pre-senior chemistry and biochemistry students at predominantly undergraduate institutions (PUI's) within 300 miles of Cincinnati, with a special focus on minority students at regional historically black colleges and universities (HBCU's). Student projects available encompass a broad spectrum of research in chemistry including the core areas of organic, biochemistry, analytical, and computational. The students will work closely with one of twelve UC faculty members participating in the participating who all have extensive experience in working with undergraduate students. In addition, a faculty member from an HBCU will be brought to UC each summer to collaborate on research and serve as an informal mentor to the REU students. An active educational program will develop research and professional skills in the REU students and prepare them for their future careers. Educational activities will include hands-on enhancement of research skills, resume writing and interviewing, workshops on career options and planning, and discussions of issues of overarching importance in science. With institutional support from the University of Cincinnati, all participants will be given the opportunity to attend and present their research results at the ACS national meeting in the spring following their REU summer experience.

这项来自化学系（CHE）的奖项支持辛辛那提大学（UC）2008-2010年夏季本科生研究经历的更新。这个REU网站将由Bruce Ault在辛辛那提大学化学系的Anna Gudmundsdottir的帮助下管理。这个REU网站每年夏天将带9名学生到校园进行为期10周的化学前沿研究。九名学生中的八名将由国家科学基金会资助，一名学生每年夏天将由化学系约翰·J·亚历山大奖学金基金会资助。招聘计划预计将确定这9名REU学生，均来自辛辛那提大学以外。尽管申请将在全美范围内接受，但招聘对象将是辛辛那提300英里范围内以本科为主的大学（PUI）的高中前化学和生物化学学生，特别是地区历史黑人学院和大学（HBCU）的少数民族学生。学生项目包括广泛的化学研究，包括有机，生物化学，分析和计算的核心领域。学生们将与12位参与此次活动的加州大学教师中的一位紧密合作，他们都具有丰富的本科生工作经验。此外，哈佛商学院的一名教员将于每年夏天被带到坎特伯雷大学进行研究合作，并担任REU学生的非正式导师。一个积极的教育计划将发展研究和专业技能的学生，为他们的未来职业生涯做好准备。教育活动将包括亲自动手提高研究技能、撰写简历和面试、职业选择和规划讲习班，以及讨论在科学领域具有重大意义的问题。在辛辛那提大学（University of cincincinnati）的机构支持下，所有参与者都将有机会在他们的REU-summer体验之后的春季ACS全国会议上出席并展示他们的研究成果。

Project.Title: The connective tissue molecule hyaluronan and its cell surface receptor CD44 stimulate breast cancer development

Title_Other.Title: 结缔组织分子透明质酸及其细胞表面受体cd44刺激乳腺癌的发生
Bindvävsmolekylen hyaluronan och dess cellytereceptor CD44 stimulerar utveckling av bröstcancer

Project.Abstract: Hyaluronan is a major component of the extracellular matrix which has important functions during embryogenesis, but also promotes tumor progression. The synthesis of hyaluronan is increased in many tumors due to up-regulation of hyaluronan synthase 2 (HAS2) which is a risk factor for cancer progression. The hyaluronan receptor CD44, a marker for breast cancer stem cells, mediates signals promoting cell growth and migration. Our aim is to elucidate the mechanisms that control the synthesis of hyaluronan and how hyaluronan-CD44 interactions promote breast cancer progression. In particular, we will investigate how the hyaluronan synthase HAS2 is regulated by ubiquitinylation and how it promotes breast cancer aggressiveness. The signaling mechanisms hyaluronan induces by binding to its cell surface receptor CD44 to promote cell migration and growth will be investigated. In addition, we will develop inhibitors of the enzymatic activity of HAS2 and of CD44, and explore their usefulness for tumor treatment. We expect that our findings will further our understanding of the molecular mechanisms whereby hyaluronan-CD44 interaction facilitates the development of an invasive breast cancer phenotype. Such information will make possible the development of improved procedures for diagnosis, prognosis and treatment of patients with breast cancer.

透明质酸是细胞外基质的重要组成部分，在胚胎发育过程中发挥重要作用，同时也促进肿瘤的进展。由于透明质酸合成酶2（has2）的上调，透明质酸在许多肿瘤中的合成增加，has2是肿瘤进展的危险因素。乳腺癌干细胞标志物透明质酸受体cd44介导促进细胞生长和迁移的信号。 我们的目的是阐明控制透明质酸合成的机制以及透明质酸-CD44相互作用如何促进乳腺癌的进展。特别是，我们将研究透明质酸合成酶has2是如何被泛素化调节的，以及它如何促进乳腺癌的侵袭性。透明质酸通过与细胞表面受体cd44结合诱导细胞迁移和生长的信号机制将被研究。此外，我们将开发has2和cd44酶活性抑制剂，并探讨它们在肿瘤治疗中的作用。 我们期望我们的发现将进一步了解透明质酸-CD44相互作用促进浸润性乳腺癌表型发展的分子机制。这些信息将有可能改进乳腺癌患者的诊断、预后和治疗程序。

Project.Title: Collaborative Research: Deciphering the Genetic Diversity of Viruses through Gene Networks

Title_Other.Title: 协同研究：通过基因网络破译病毒的遗传多样性
Collaborative Research: Deciphering the Genetic Diversity of Viruses through Gene Networks

Class.ClassName: 环境生态系统、生态环境

Project.Abstract: Bacteriophages are viruses that infect bacteria and can have a profound impact on bacterial populations. These viruses are the most abundant and diverse members of most ecosystems on Earth, having been found in every environment that supports life. The majority of the DNA sequences of newly isolated bacteriophage samples bears little or no resemblance to any sequences contained within current databases. This means that identifying new samples by looking for similar sequences is not an effective strategy. It is therefore crucial to find different approaches to characterize these viruses, which will then help is understand the critical roles that they have as members of microbial communities. This research will develop a new network-based approach for classifying viruses, thereby opening new avenues for exploring virus ecology as well as providing genomic data for evolutionary studies. This new approach will redefine how the genetic diversity of viruses is represented, making possible direct analyses of complex viral communities at higher resolution than is currently possible. Furthermore, the project will unite students from the computational and biological sciences, creating interdisciplinary teams able to carry out this research, with this training taking both in the classroom and laboratory. The project will develop a new graphical framework for the investigation of viral metagenomes, specifically aimed at putting novel viral sequences into a global context of viral genetic diversity. Because virus genomes are mosaics of genes acquired over time from multiple sources, a 'gene-centric' rather than a 'genome-centric' approach to classify the sequences in viromes is taken. In addition to capturing the combinatorial structure of virus genomes, this approach is robust to variation in genome and contig size that can arise from diverse datasets. Through the development of novel algorithms and metrics, evolutionary and ecological signals in the data will be integrated to inform the network's structure. The network will also be used to test hypotheses driven from the data, in particular the signals of viral host-range. For more information about the project visit the PI's lab website at http://www.putonti-lab.com.

噬菌体是感染细菌的病毒，对细菌种群有着深远的影响。这些病毒是地球上大多数生态系统中最丰富和多样的成员，在支持生命的每一个环境中都有发现。新分离的噬菌体样品的大部分DNA序列与现有数据库中的任何序列几乎没有或根本没有相似之处。这意味着通过寻找相似序列来识别新样本不是一种有效的策略。因此，找到不同的方法来描述这些病毒是至关重要的，这将有助于理解它们作为微生物群落成员所起的关键作用。这项研究将开发一种新的基于网络的病毒分类方法，从而为探索病毒生态学以及为进化研究提供基因组数据开辟新的途径。这一新方法将重新定义病毒遗传多样性的表现方式，使得以比目前更高的分辨率对复杂病毒群落进行直接分析成为可能。此外，该项目将联合来自计算和生物科学的学生，建立跨学科团队，能够开展这项研究，这项培训将在课堂和实验室进行。该项目将为病毒基因组的研究开发一个新的图形框架，特别是旨在将新的病毒序列放入病毒遗传多样性的全球背景中。由于病毒基因组是从多个来源获得的基因的马赛克，因此采用“以基因为中心”而不是“以基因组为中心”的方法对病毒基因组中的序列进行分类。除了捕获病毒基因组的组合结构外，这种方法对来自不同数据集的基因组和控制大小的变化具有鲁棒性。通过开发新的算法和度量，数据中的进化和生态信号将被集成，以告知网络的结构。该网络还将用于测试由数据驱动的假设，特别是病毒宿主范围的信号。有关该项目的更多信息，请访问PI的实验室网站：http://www.putonti-lab.com。

Organization.Name: New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology
New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology

Project.Title: Nonrechargeable Battery Manufacturing Improvements

Title_Other.Title: 不充电电池制造改进
Nonrechargeable Battery Manufacturing Improvements

Project.Abstract: The U.S. military is seeking improved methods of battery manufacturing which will enhance the ability of DoD-interest in battery manufacturers to produce nonrechargeable (primary) batteries. The current dough-batch teflonated process for making MnO2 cathodes is quite labor intensive and time consuming. Twin screw extrusion technology is an alternative method of manufacture which offers faster production times, reliability, reduced labor, and higher efficiency. Twin screw extrusion technology is inherently scalable for "right-sizing" production capacity leading to lower production costs and labor time. Building upon previous success in the extrusion of rechargeable Li-Ion (LiCoO2 and LiNi0.8Co0.2O2) PVdF cathodes, MaxPower proposes to adapt the twin screw extrusion process to Li/MnO2 primary cell technology. The main objective of Phase I is to demonstrate that the twin screw extrusion process is compatible with these primary battery systems. Phase II will incur further optimization of the cathode compositions and the introduction of CFx as an alternative candidate system to be selected for the production of BA-5390 batteries for the U.S military. With successful implementation of Phase I and Phase II, the twin screw extrusion processing method should readily transfer to the market scale for both military and commercial applications of primary Li/MnO2 battery systems.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 美国军方正在寻求改进电池制造方法，以增强国防部对电池制造商生产不可充电（主）电池的兴趣。目前用于制造二氧化锰阴极的面团分批聚四氟乙烯工艺，劳动强度大，耗时长。双螺杆挤出技术是一种替代性的制造方法，具有生产速度快、可靠性高、劳动强度低、生产效率高等优点。双螺杆挤出技术本质上是可扩展的，以实现“正确的尺寸”生产能力，从而降低生产成本和劳动时间。MaxPower在先前锂离子（LiCoO2和LiNi0.8Co0.2O2）PVdF阴极挤出成功的基础上，提出将双螺杆挤出工艺应用于Li/MnO2原电池技术。第一阶段的主要目标是证明双螺杆挤出工艺与这些原电池系统兼容。第二阶段将进一步优化阴极成分，并引入CFx作为备选系统，供美军生产BA-5390电池使用。随着第一阶段和第二阶段的成功实施，双螺杆挤压加工方法应该很容易转移到军用和商用锂/二氧化锰电池系统的市场规模。

The U.S. military is seeking improved methods of battery manufacturing which will enhance the ability of DoD-interest in battery manufacturers to produce nonrechargeable (primary) batteries. The current dough-batch teflonated process for making MnO2 cathodes is quite labor intensive and time consuming. Twin screw extrusion technology is an alternative method of manufacture which offers faster production times, reliability, reduced labor, and higher efficiency. Twin screw extrusion technology is inherently scalable for "right-sizing" production capacity leading to lower production costs and labor time. Building upon previous success in the extrusion of rechargeable Li-Ion (LiCoO2 and LiNi0.8Co0.2O2) PVdF cathodes, MaxPower proposes to adapt the twin screw extrusion process to Li/MnO2 primary cell technology. The main objective of Phase I is to demonstrate that the twin screw extrusion process is compatible with these primary battery systems. Phase II will incur further optimization of the cathode compositions and the introduction of CFx as an alternative candidate system to be selected for the production of BA-5390 batteries for the U.S military. With successful implementation of Phase I and Phase II, the twin screw extrusion processing method should readily transfer to the market scale for both military and commercial applications of primary Li/MnO2 battery systems.

Project.Title: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Multi-party Collaborative Data Access

Title_Other.Title: CSR:Small:协作研究：多方协作数据访问
CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Multi-party Collaborative Data Access

Project.Abstract: As the richness and volume of data maintained by a wide variety of businesses and organizations increases, there is a growing need to derive useful information, not only from data owned by individual parties, but also across parties. The current data sharing practice is dominated by carefully negotiated, mostly secret, one-on-one agreements between organizations, and is seriously limited. It does not scale as the number of databases and organizations increase, cannot be formally analyzed for unintended information leaks or other violations, and may require unnecessary data exposure. This project explores a collaborative multi-party data sharing mechanism that allows safe and convenient sharing of databases in order to enable large-scale collaborative data analytics and knowledge extraction applications. Multi-party data sharing involves many challenges that the project attempts to address. First, it is necessary to have an intuitive specification of access control policies for data access across parties and an automated mechanism to translate those into a concise set of access rules while resolving conflicts, specification inadequacies, and other problems. Second, we need efficient and scalable implementation of allowed queries in spite of complex access restrictions. Third, it is necessary to handle both the traditional relational databases, its variants, and the emerging graph databases. Finally, we need mechanisms to efficiently check the integrity and completeness of the data supplied as answers. By addressing these challenges, the research hopes to establish the foundations of multiparty data sharing. Many of the formalizations in this research will exploit Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) based methods for testing assertions and for resolving conflicts. With tremendous amount of data being generated by both cyber and cyberphysical systems, this project will help devise practical mechanisms to share data in a wide variety of scenarios and thereby accelerate the pace of data driven innovation applied to information systems serving the society.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 随着各种各样的企业和组织维护的数据的丰富性和数量的增加，越来越需要获得有用的信息，不仅是从各方拥有的数据中，而且是从各方之间。目前的数据共享实践主要是由组织之间经过仔细协商、大多是秘密的一对一协议主导的，而且受到严重限制。它不会随着数据库和组织数量的增加而扩展，无法对意外的信息泄漏或其他违规行为进行正式分析，并且可能需要不必要的数据公开。该项目探索了一种协作多方数据共享机制，该机制允许安全和方便地共享数据库，以便实现大规模协作数据分析和知识提取应用程序。多方数据共享涉及项目试图解决的许多挑战。首先，有必要对跨参与方的数据访问的访问控制策略有一个直观的规范，并有一个自动化的机制将这些规范转换为一组简洁的访问规则，同时解决冲突、规范不足和其他问题。第二，尽管存在复杂的访问限制，我们仍需要高效且可伸缩的允许查询实现。第三，必须同时处理传统关系数据库及其变体和新兴的图形数据库。最后，我们需要机制来有效地检查作为答案提供的数据的完整性和完整性。通过解决这些挑战，研究希望建立多方数据共享的基础。本研究中的许多形式化将利用基于可满足性模理论（SMT）的方法来测试断言和解决冲突。随着网络和网络物理系统产生的大量数据，该项目将有助于设计在各种场景中共享数据的实用机制，从而加快数据驱动的创新应用于为社会服务的信息系统的步伐。

Second, we need efficient and scalable implementation of allowed queries in spite of complex access restrictions. Third, it is necessary to handle both the traditional relational databases, its variants, and the emerging graph databases. Finally, we need mechanisms to efficiently check the integrity and completeness of the data supplied as answers. By addressing these challenges, the research hopes to establish the foundations of multiparty data sharing. Many of the formalizations in this research will exploit Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT) based methods for testing assertions and for resolving conflicts. With tremendous amount of data being generated by both cyber and cyberphysical systems, this project will help devise practical mechanisms to share data in a wide variety of scenarios and thereby accelerate the pace of data driven innovation applied to information systems serving the society.

Project.Title: Whole heart suspended animation: leveraging the zebrafish to solve the organ shortage

Title_Other.Title: Whole heart suspended animation: leveraging the zebrafish to solve the organ shortage
全心悬浮动画：利用斑马鱼解决器官短缺

Project.Abstract: There are currently over 123,000 patients on the organ transplant waiting list in the US, a number that far exceeds the supply of available organs, and that continues to grow ~5% each year. In Canada, every ten minutes someone is added to the waitlist and ~22 people die each day while waiting for a transplant. A major reason is the limitations of our current organ preservation and handling practices, which severely restricts preservation duration and disallows the transplantation of marginally injured organs. This project aims to develop a protocol to bank hearts for several weeks to enable global organ matching and overcome limitations of ischemia tolerance to increase the donor pool of hearts. I propose that strategies to solve current barriers in heart transplantation, including ex vivo preservation and recovery of marginal organs, should look to nature for inspiration. More specifically, the ability to descend into a state of ?suspended animation?, characterized by the slowing of life processes and improved stress tolerance, holds promise. I will systematically leverage two methods of suspended animation; 1) freeze-tolerance, and 2) high-temperature hibernation. Using inspiration from freeze-tolerant wood frogs in nature, I seek to develop a protocol for whole heart preservation which will achieve high subzero storage temperatures in the presence of extracellular ice, and storage durations of weeks to months. Further, I will identify pharmacological agents which will strategically lower metabolic demands to match oxygen/nutrient availability, and increase warm ischemia tolerance from minutes to hours, using inspiration from hibernating primates in nature. To accomplish this goal, I propose to introduce the zebrafish as a novel model system for cryobiology and organ transplantation. While zebrafish has become a favored research animal for studying human disease, it has never been used as a tool to develop innovative approaches for organ handling and preservation or to understand the underlying biology of organ transplantation. Classical model organisms such as the zebrafish offer many advantages including robust genetic/biochemical tools, ease of real-time imaging, compatibility with high-throughput studies, and are cheap and easy to maintain. Complimented by scale-up experiments and validation in mammalian model systems, including rats, the present proposal will mend a critical gap in the research field.

目前，美国有超过12.3万名患者在器官移植等待名单上，这个数字远远超过可用器官的供应量，并且每年继续增长约5%。在加拿大，每十分钟就有人被列入等待名单，每天约有22人在等待移植时死亡。一个主要的原因是我们目前的器官保存和处理实践的局限性，这严重限制了保存时间，不允许移植边缘受伤的器官。这个项目的目的是制定一个方案，以银行心脏数周，使全球器官匹配，克服缺血耐受的限制，以增加供心池。我建议解决目前心脏移植障碍的策略，包括体外保存和边缘器官的恢复，应该向大自然寻求启示。更具体地说，能够下降到？暂停动画？它的特点是生活进程的减缓和压力承受能力的提高。我将系统地利用两种暂停动画的方法：1）冷冻耐受和2）高温冬眠。我从自然界中的耐寒林蛙身上获得灵感，试图开发出一种全心脏保存方案，在细胞外结冰的情况下，可以达到零度以下的高保存温度，保存时间为数周到数月。此外，我将利用自然界冬眠灵长类动物的灵感，确定一些药理学药物，这些药物将战略性地降低代谢需求，以匹配氧气/营养的可用性，并将热缺血耐受性从几分钟提高到几小时。为了实现这一目标，我建议引进斑马鱼作为一种新的冷冻生物学和器官移植模型系统。虽然斑马鱼已成为研究人类疾病的受欢迎的研究动物，但它从未被用作开发器官处理和保存的创新方法或了解器官移植的潜在生物学的工具。斑马鱼等经典模式生物具有许多优点，包括强大的遗传/生物化学工具、易于实时成像、与高通量研究兼容，并且价格低廉且易于维护。通过在包括大鼠在内的哺乳动物模型系统中的放大实验和验证，本提案将弥补研究领域中的一个关键空白。

Source.Name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

Project.Title: Ultrasound Imaging System for Prostate Cancer

Title_Other.Title: Ultrasound Imaging System for Prostate Cancer
前列腺癌超声成像系统

Project.Abstract:
PUBLIC ABSTRACT
Prostate cancer is the most common non-skin cancer found in men in the United States and is the second leading cause of cancer death in men, slightly behind lung cancer. Each year ~180,000 men are diagnosed with prostate cancer and ~31,000 succumb to the disease. However, there has been a 4%-per-year decrease in deaths caused by prostate cancer in the U.S. from 1994-2004 due to early detection and advancements in treatment. Improved imaging techniques may further reduce deaths through early detection, which improves surgical outcomes and the response to non-operative therapies.
Various imaging techniques have been applied to the early detection of prostate cancer, to pre-operative treatment planning, intra-operative image guidance, and post-operative assessment. However, the majority of these techniques have limited resolution and are only practical as pre- or post-operative imaging tools. These techniques do not provide sufficient resolution or tissue differentiation to diagnose diseases such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), or prostate enlargement, and typically cannot be used for guidance of prostate procedures during surgery. Ultrasound has the advantage that it is high resolution, low cost, non-ionizing, and has the ability to provide real-time imagery, and thus can be used for pre-, intra-, and post-operative imaging.
Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) is used for intra-operative needle guidance during radiation therapy and determination of overall prostate size. However, TRUS is limited in that the transducer is positioned in the rectum external to the prostate, therefore resulting in lower resolution imagery and shadowing, and difficulty in imaging the transition zone of the prostate.
This proposal develops transurethral ultrasound (TUUS) as an alternative to TRUS. In TUUS, imaging of the prostate is achieved through the penis rather than the rectum. Similar transurethral procedures are commonly performed today, such as insertion of Foley catheters, or thin sterile tubes used to drain urine from the bladder, and cystoscopy, in which an optical instrument is inserted through the urethral to image the bladder. The risks involved with the proposed TUUS procedure are expected to be similar to other such transurethral procedures, which are small.
By imaging the prostate from within, this approach will enable higher resolution imaging due to shorter required penetration depth, and at the same time eliminate shadowing effects that are prevalent in TRUS. TUUS therefore has the potential to provide considerable improvement to prostate imaging, image guidance, and monitoring as a new high resolution, real-time imaging tool. Specifically, TUUS is expected to provide improved imagery of the transition zone and anterior prostate, allow for volumetric assessment of the prostate, and provide more accurate therapeutic interventions, including radioactive seed placement and prostate biopsies.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 公共摘要 前列腺癌是美国男性最常见的非皮肤癌，是男性癌症死亡的第二大原因，略低于肺癌。每年约有18万男性被诊断患有前列腺癌，约3.1万男性死于该病。然而，由于早期发现和治疗的进步，从1994年到2004年，美国前列腺癌导致的死亡率每年下降4%。改进的成像技术可以通过早期发现进一步减少死亡，从而改善手术结果和对非手术治疗的反应。 各种影像学技术已被应用于前列腺癌的早期诊断、术前治疗计划、术中图像引导和术后评估。然而，这些技术大多分辨率有限，只能作为术前或术后成像工具使用。这些技术不能提供足够的分辨率或组织分化来诊断良性前列腺增生（BPH）或前列腺增大等疾病，并且通常不能在手术期间用于指导前列腺手术。超声具有分辨率高、成本低、无电离、能提供实时图像等优点，可用于术前、术中、术后成像。 经直肠超声（TRUS）用于放射治疗期间的术中穿刺引导和前列腺总大小的测定。然而，TRUS的局限性在于换能器位于前列腺外的直肠，因此导致低分辨率成像和阴影，并且难以成像前列腺的过渡区。 这项建议发展了经尿道超声（TUUS）作为TRUS的替代方法。在TUUS中，前列腺的成像是通过阴茎而不是直肠实现的。类似的经尿道手术在今天也很常见，比如插入Foley导尿管，或者用来从膀胱排出尿液的无菌细管，以及膀胱镜检查，在膀胱镜检查中，通过尿道插入一个光学仪器来成像膀胱。所建议的TUUS手术的风险预计与其他此类经尿道手术相似，后者较小。 通过从内部对前列腺进行成像，由于所需穿透深度较短，这种方法将实现更高分辨率成像，同时消除TRUS中普遍存在的阴影效应。因此，TUUS作为一种新的高分辨率、实时成像工具，有可能为前列腺成像、图像引导和监测提供相当大的改进。具体来说，TUUS有望改善过渡区和前前列腺的图像，允许前列腺的体积评估，并提供更精确的治疗干预，包括放射性种子植入和前列腺活检。

PUBLIC ABSTRACT
Prostate cancer is the most common non-skin cancer found in men in the United States and is the second leading cause of cancer death in men, slightly behind lung cancer. Each year ~180,000 men are diagnosed with prostate cancer and ~31,000 succumb to the disease. Project.Title: Quantifying and reversing the effects of PVL on postnatal forebrain neurogenesis

Title_Other.Title: Quantifying and reversing the effects of PVL on postnatal forebrain neurogenesis
pvl对产后前脑神经发生影响的量化及逆转

Class.ClassName: 光致发射、光阴极、外光电效应

Project.Abstract: Preterm infants are vulnerable to forebrain hypoxia/ischemia, which puts them at high risk of developing periventricular leukomalacia (PVL). PVL is the most common known cause of cerebral palsy. There are currently no effective therapies to prevent PVL or to protect premature infants with PVL against lifelong neurological disability. A commonly used PVL model is elicited by permanent occlusion of a carotid artery in neonatal rats, followed by brief exposure to reduced oxygen. We adapted this hypoxic/ischemic (H/I)-PVL model to neonatal mice and, using genetically modified mouse strains, will characterize the consequences of H/I-PVL for postnatal forebrain neuronogenesis. In Specific Aim 1, we will employ nestin fate-mapping to visualize and quantify the deleterious effects of H/I-PVL on generation of neuroblasts by subventricular zone neural stem cells (NSCs), the migration of these neuroblasts via the rostral migratory stream to the olfactory bulb, and their neuronal maturation. In Specific Aim 2, we will use the same fate-mapping strategy to evaluate the ill effects of H/I-PVL on dentate neuronogenesis by subgranular zone (SGZ) NSCs. As an additional component of Specific Aim 2, we will correlate our fate-mapping data with an examination of H/I-PVL-elicited deficiencies in hippocampus-dependent cognitive function, and evaluate the efficacy of chronic administration of the antidepressant, fluoxetine, in restoring SGZ neuronogenesis and cognitive capability to these mice. Specific Aim 3 will employ fluorescence-activated cell sorting and cDNA arrays to examine the impact of H/I-PVL, again with or without subsequent fluoxetine therapy, on patterns of SGZ NSC gene expression. Results of these 3 aims will expand our understanding of the acute and long-term cellular and molecular consequences of neonatal H/I PVL for postnatal forebrain neuronogenesis, and will enable us to assess the efficacy of fluoxetine, a well tolerated, FDA-approved drug, in improving post-H/I-PVL SGZ neuronogenesis and hippocampus-dependent cognitive function.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 早产儿易受前脑缺氧/缺血的影响，这使他们极易患室周白质软化症（pvl）。pvl是脑瘫最常见的病因。目前还没有有效的治疗方法来预防pvl或保护pvl早产儿免受终身神经残疾的影响。一种常用的pvl模型是通过永久性阻塞新生大鼠的颈动脉，然后短暂暴露于缺氧环境中诱发的。我们将这种缺氧/缺血（h/i）-pvl模型应用于新生小鼠，并使用转基因小鼠株，来描述h/i-pvl对出生后前脑神经元生成的影响。在具体目标1中，我们将使用nestin命运图来可视化和量化h/i-pvl对心室下区神经干细胞（nscs）产生神经母细胞的有害影响，这些神经母细胞通过嘴侧迁移流迁移到嗅球，以及它们的神经元成熟。在具体目标2中，我们将使用相同的命运映射策略来评估h/i-pvl对亚颗粒区（sgz）nscs齿状神经发生的不良影响。作为特定目标2的另一个组成部分，我们将我们的命运定位数据与海马依赖性认知功能H/I-PVL诱发缺陷的检查相关联，并评估长期服用抗抑郁药氟西汀的疗效，恢复sgz神经元的生成和认知能力。特定目的3将使用荧光活化细胞分类和cdna阵列，再次检测h/i-pvl（无论是否进行氟西汀治疗）对sgz-nsc基因表达模式的影响。这三个目标的结果将扩大我们对新生儿h/i-pvl对出生后前脑神经元发生的急性和长期细胞和分子后果的理解，并使我们能够评估氟西汀的疗效，氟西汀是一种耐受性良好的fda批准的药物，改善h/i-pvl后sgz神经元生成和海马依赖性认知功能。

Preterm infants are vulnerable to forebrain hypoxia/ischemia, which puts them at high risk of developing periventricular leukomalacia (PVL). PVL is the most common known cause of cerebral palsy. There are currently no effective therapies to prevent PVL or to protect premature infants with PVL against lifelong neurological disability. A commonly used PVL model is elicited by permanent occlusion of a carotid artery in neonatal rats, followed by brief exposure to reduced oxygen. We adapted this hypoxic/ischemic (H/I)-PVL model to neonatal mice and, using genetically modified mouse strains, will characterize the consequences of H/I-PVL for postnatal forebrain neuronogenesis. In Specific Aim 1, we will employ nestin fate-mapping to visualize and quantify the deleterious effects of H/I-PVL on generation of neuroblasts by subventricular zone neural stem cells (NSCs), the migration of these neuroblasts via the rostral migratory stream to the olfactory bulb, and their neuronal maturation. In Specific Aim 2, we will use the same fate-mapping strategy to evaluate the ill effects of H/I-PVL on dentate neuronogenesis by subgranular zone (SGZ) NSCs. As an additional component of Specific Aim 2, we will correlate our fate-mapping data with an examination of H/I-PVL-elicited deficiencies in hippocampus-dependent cognitive function, and evaluate the efficacy of chronic administration of the antidepressant, fluoxetine, in restoring SGZ neuronogenesis and cognitive capability to these mice. Specific Aim 3 will employ fluorescence-activated cell sorting and cDNA arrays to examine the impact of H/I-PVL, again with or without subsequent fluoxetine therapy, on patterns of SGZ NSC gene expression. Results of these 3 aims will expand our understanding of the acute and long-term cellular and molecular consequences of neonatal H/I PVL for postnatal forebrain neuronogenesis, and will enable us to assess the efficacy of fluoxetine, a well tolerated, FDA-approved drug, in improving post-H/I-PVL SGZ neuronogenesis and hippocampus-dependent cognitive function.

Project.Title: Targeting Intestinal Stem Cells to Augment the Repair of Epithelial Barrier

Title_Other.Title: Targeting Intestinal Stem Cells to Augment the Repair of Epithelial Barrier
靶向肠干细胞增强上皮屏障修复

Class.ClassName: 化学反应机理、化学反应动力学

Project.Abstract: PROJECT SUMMARY: This study tests a novel hypothesis that 1,25(OH)2D, i.e. the active vitamin D metabolite, augments regenerative capacity of the Lgr5+ intestinal stem cells (ISCs). To test this hypothesis, we are proposing two specific aims. Specific Aim 1 will determine whether 1,25(OH)2D promotes regenerative capacity of the Lgr5+ ISCs by in vivo tracing of the Lgr5+ ISCs and their progenies in the entire process of intestinal epithelium regeneration. We will use our previously developed strategy to deliver a locally high 1,25(OH)2D concentration to the intestines. Regenerative capacity will be determined by abundance, migration, proliferation, survivability, and differentiation of the Lgr5+ ISCs. In this specific aim, one study will be performed in normal healthy animals (Objective 1A). To determine clinical significance, the other study will be performed in animals induced for experimental colitis (Objective 1B). In both objectives, we will use immunohistochemistry (IHC) to investigate the entire regenerative process of the Lgr5+ ISCs. To do this, we will trace the Lgr5+ ISCs using F1 offspring of the cre-inducible Lgr5-EGFP-IRES-creERT2 (Lgr5-GFP) and the cre-reporter B6.Cg-Gt(ROSA)26Sortm9(CAG-tdTomato)Hze/J (Ai9 or Ai) mice. In the Lgr5-GFP mice, GFP expression is under the control of Lgr5 promoter and enhancer and Cre can be induced by tamoxifen injection. Additionally, the Ai mice express tdTomato when Cre is present independent of Lgr5 expression. Consequently, the F1 offspring (Lgr5-GFP-Ai mice), upon tamoxifen administration to activate the Cre, will express both GFP and tdTomato in crypt Lgr5+ ISCs but will only express tdTomato in the progenies of Lgr5+ ISCs outside the crypts. Since normal intestinal epithelia are replaced every 4-5 days, at days 1, 3, and 5 immediately following the 1,25(OH)2D delivery, we will study abundance of the Lgr5+ ISCs by staining for GFP, migration for tdTomato, proliferation for Brdu, survivability for bcl-2 and caspase 3, and differentiation for markers specific for each type of epithelial cells. Specific Aim 2 will determine whether the effects of 1,25(OH)2D treatment on regenerative capacity of the Lgr5+ ISCs depend on vitamin D receptor (VDR) using in vitro cultured multipotent Lgr5+ ISC lines. Since 1,25(OH)2D can function through both VDR-dependent and independent mechanisms, this study will investigate whether 1,25(OH)2D acts on the Lgr5+ ISCs directly through VDR signaling or indirectly via a VDR-independent mechanism. We will purify the Lgr5+ ISCs from Lgr5-GFP mice and establish multipotent Lgr5+ ISC lines in a multipotent medium. Using the multipotent Lgr5+ ISC lines, we will reach two objectives. Objective 2A will investigate the effects of 1,25(OH)2D treatment on proliferation (Ki-67) and survivability (bcl-2 and caspase 3) of the multipotent Lgr5+ ISCs with or without VDR knockdown. Objective 2B will examine the effects of 1,25(OH)2D treatment on differentiation of the Lgr5+ ISCs in a differentiation medium with or without VDR knockdown. The ultimate goal is to develop a 1,25(OH)2D- based strategy to enhance epithelium repair for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: PROJECT SUMMARY: This study tests a novel hypothesis that 1,25(OH)2D, i.e. the active vitamin D metabolite, augments regenerative capacity of the Lgr5+ intestinal stem cells (ISCs). To test this hypothesis, we are proposing two specific aims. Specific Aim 1 will determine whether 1,25(OH)2D promotes regenerative capacity of the Lgr5+ ISCs by in vivo tracing of the Lgr5+ ISCs and their progenies in the entire process of intestinal epithelium regeneration. We will use our previously developed strategy to deliver a locally high 1,25(OH)2D concentration to the intestines. Regenerative capacity will be determined by abundance, migration, proliferation, survivability, and differentiation of the Lgr5+ ISCs. In this specific aim, one study will be performed in normal healthy animals (Objective 1A). To determine clinical significance, the other study will be performed in animals induced for experimental colitis (Objective 1B). In both objectives, we will use immunohistochemistry (IHC) to investigate the entire regenerative process of the Lgr5+ ISCs. To do this, we will trace the Lgr5+ ISCs using F1 offspring of the cre-inducible Lgr5-EGFP-IRES-creERT2 (Lgr5-GFP) and the cre-reporter B6.Cg-Gt(ROSA)26Sortm9(CAG-tdTomato)Hze/J (Ai9 or Ai) mice. In the Lgr5-GFP mice, GFP expression is under the control of Lgr5 promoter and enhancer and Cre can be induced by tamoxifen injection. Additionally, the Ai mice express tdTomato when Cre is present independent of Lgr5 expression. Consequently, the F1 offspring (Lgr5-GFP-Ai mice), upon tamoxifen administration to activate the Cre, will express both GFP and tdTomato in crypt Lgr5+ ISCs but will only express tdTomato in the progenies of Lgr5+ ISCs outside the crypts. Since normal intestinal epithelia are replaced every 4-5 days, at days 1, 3, and 5 immediately following the 1,25(OH)2D delivery, we will study abundance of the Lgr5+ ISCs by staining for GFP, migration for tdTomato, proliferation for Brdu, survivability for bcl-2 and caspase 3, and differentiation for markers specific for each type of epithelial cells. Specific Aim 2 will determine whether the effects of 1,25(OH)2D treatment on regenerative capacity of the Lgr5+ ISCs depend on vitamin D receptor (VDR) using in vitro cultured multipotent Lgr5+ ISC lines. Since 1,25(OH)2D can function through both VDR-dependent and independent mechanisms, this study will investigate whether 1,25(OH)2D acts on the Lgr5+ ISCs directly through VDR signaling or indirectly via a VDR-independent mechanism. We will purify the Lgr5+ ISCs from Lgr5-GFP mice and establish multipotent Lgr5+ ISC lines in a multipotent medium. Using the multipotent Lgr5+ ISC lines, we will reach two objectives. Objective 2A will investigate the effects of 1,25(OH)2D treatment on proliferation (Ki-67) and survivability (bcl-2 and caspase 3) of the multipotent Lgr5+ ISCs with or without VDR knockdown.
