项目概述：本研究验证了一个新的假设，即1,25（OH）2D，即活性维生素D代谢物，增强Lgr5+肠干细胞（ISCs）的再生能力。为了验证这一假设，我们提出了两个具体目标。具体目的1是通过对Lgr5+ISCs及其后代在肠上皮再生全过程的活体追踪，确定1,25（OH）2D是否促进Lgr5+ISCs的再生能力。我们将使用我们先前开发的策略，向肠道输送局部高浓度的1,25（OH）2D。再生能力将取决于Lgr5+ISCs的丰度、迁移、增殖、存活和分化。在这一具体目标中，将对正常健康动物进行一项研究（目标1A）。为了确定临床意义，另一项研究将在实验性结肠炎的动物身上进行（目的1B）。在这两个目标中，我们将使用免疫组织化学（IHC）来研究Lgr5+ISCs的整个再生过程。为此，我们将使用cre诱导的Lgr5-EGFP-IRES-creERT2（Lgr5-GFP）和cre报告者B6.Cg-Gt（ROSA）26Sortm9（CAG-td番茄）Hze/J（Ai9或Ai）小鼠的F1后代追踪Lgr5+ISCs。在LGR5 GFP小鼠中，GFP的表达受LGR5启动子的控制，而他莫昔芬可诱导增强子和CRE。此外，当Cre独立于Lgr5表达时，Ai小鼠表达td番茄。因此，F1代（LGR5 GFP AI小鼠），在他莫昔芬给药激活CRE后，将表达GFP和TD-番茄在隐窝LGR5+ISCS中，但只表达TDGISH在LGR5+ISCS子代外的隐窝。由于正常肠上皮每4-5天更换一次，在1,25（OH）2D分娩后的第1、3和5天，我们将通过GFP染色、tdTomato迁移、Brdu增殖、bcl-2和caspase 3存活以及每种上皮特异性标记的分化来研究Lgr5+ISCs的丰度细胞。特定目的2将确定1,25（OH）2D处理对Lgr5+ISCs再生能力的影响是否依赖于使用体外培养的多能Lgr5+ISC系的维生素D受体（VDR）。由于1,25（OH）2D可以通过VDR依赖和独立机制发挥作用，本研究将探讨1,25（OH）2D是通过VDR信号直接作用于Lgr5+ISCs还是通过VDR独立机制间接作用于Lgr5+ISCs。我们将从Lgr5-GFP小鼠中纯化Lgr5+ISCs，并在多能培养基中建立多能Lgr5+ISC系。使用多能Lgr5+ISC线路，我们将达到两个目标。目的探讨1,25（OH）2D治疗对VDR基因敲除与否的Lgr5+ISCs增殖（Ki-67）和存活（bcl-2和caspase-3）的影响。目的探讨1,25（OH）2D处理对VDR基因敲除或不敲除的分化培养基中Lgr5+ISCs分化的影响。最终的目标是开发一种基于1，25（OH）2D的策略，以加强炎症性肠病的上皮修复。

Source.Name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Project.Title: Bridging Arizona Native American Students to Bachelor's Degrees

Title_Other.Title: 连接亚利桑那州美洲原住民学生与学士学位
Bridging Arizona Native American Students to Bachelor's Degrees

Project.Abstract: Project Summary/Abstract The objective of the proposed project is to increase the transfer of Native American students from accredited 2-year degree-granting institutions with historically high Native American student enrollments to baccalaureate degree programs in biomedical and behavioral sciences with the ultimate goal to assist these students in attaining their baccalaureate degrees. The program resides at Northern Arizona University (NAU), located in Flagstaff, AZ and is centered on a summer research experience for Native American students from Diné College (DC, the first established and one of the largest tribal college in the United States) and Coconino Community College (CCC, a community college located in Flagstaff). During the past five years, the program has supported 42 Native American students; of these 15 students have transferred to NAU or other 4-year institutions with four students earning or 36% of the 42 Bridges students. Our goal in the next funding cycle is to improve this percentage to 75% transfer rates of the students participating in the program. Programmatic modifications are proposed for the next funding cycle guided by the evaluation from the previous cycle. The program combines a summer program for the students to participate in a faculty mentored research experience as well as enrolling in HS299, a three-credit course focused on science communication. Additionally, the program offers workshops throughout the summer on topics ranging from transferring to NAU to resume development to research training grants at NAU. During the academic year, research and professional development is provided to Bridges alumni at CCC and DC. In 2008, NAU and CCC began a transfer program called CCC2NAU which provides a seamless transition for students at CCC to NAU by matriculating in both institutions with shared resources for the students. In February 2016, a memorandum of understanding was signed between NAU and DC to establish the DC2NAU program; the NAU Bridges program played a significant role in the DC2NAU program. Part of NAU?s strategic plan, is to provide a university climate and culture that enhance the academic experiences of Native American students, staff, and faculty including improving the recruitment, retention, and progress of Native American students with the goal of graduating these students with baccalaureate and graduate degrees. An important part of the NAU strategic plan is to expand partnerships with tribal colleges to enhance opportunities for Native American students to continue their education. NAU?s geographic location is ideal for this mission since Flagstaff is considered a border town for the Navajo and Hopi Nations and near the White River Apache and Hualapai Nations. With such a strong commitment to Native American students and an excellent geographic location with respect to a number of tribal lands, the NAU Bridges to Baccalaureate program plays a key role in Arizona in partnering with 2-year institutions with large Native American enrollments.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 项目摘要/摘要拟议项目的目标是增加美国原住民学生从认可的两年制学位授予机构向生物医学和行为科学学士学位课程的转移，最终目的是帮助这些学生获得学士学位。该项目位于亚利桑那州弗拉格斯塔夫市的北亚利桑那大学（NAU），主要是为来自迪内学院（DC，美国第一所建立的也是最大的部落学院之一）和科科尼诺社区学院（CCC，位于弗拉格斯塔夫的社区学院）的美洲原住民学生提供暑期研究经验。在过去的五年中，该项目资助了42名美洲土著学生；其中15名学生已转到NAU或其他四年制学校，其中4名学生的收入占42名桥梁学生的36%。我们在下一个资助周期的目标是将参与该计划的学生的转移率提高到75%。建议在前一个周期的评价指导下，对下一个供资周期进行方案修改。这个项目结合了一个暑期项目，让学生们参加一个由教师指导的研究体验，并参加HS299，这是一个以科学传播为重点的三学分课程。此外，该计划在整个夏季提供研讨会，主题从转移到NAU恢复发展到NAU的研究培训赠款。在学年期间，研究和专业发展是提供给桥梁在CCC和DC校友。2008年，NAU和CCC开始了一个名为CCC2NAU的转移项目，通过在两所学校注册入学，为CCC的学生提供了一个无缝的转移到NAU的过程，为学生提供共享资源。2016年2月，NAU与DC签署了建立DC2NAU计划的谅解备忘录；NAU桥梁计划在DC2NAU计划中发挥了重要作用。是NAU的一部分？其战略计划是提供一个大学氛围和文化，以提高美国原住民学生、员工和教师的学术经验，包括提高美国原住民学生的招聘、留任和进步，目标是使这些学生获得学士学位和研究生学位。NAU战略计划的一个重要部分是扩大与部落学院的伙伴关系，以增加美国原住民学生继续接受教育的机会。恶心？由于弗拉格斯塔夫被认为是纳瓦霍民族和霍皮民族的边境城镇，靠近白河阿帕奇和华拉帕民族，因此其地理位置是此次任务的理想选择。NAU Bridges to Baccalaureate计划对美洲原住民学生有着如此坚定的承诺，并且在许多部落土地上拥有优越的地理位置，因此在亚利桑那州与拥有大量美洲原住民入学人数的两年制院校合作方面发挥着关键作用。

Source.Name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

Project.Title: Structure function models of language and its recovery.

Title_Other.Title: 语言的结构功能模型及其恢复。
Structure function models of language and its recovery.

Project.Abstract: My proposal is to establish a functional anatomical model of language that predicts how speech and reading are lost and recovered following neurological damage. The novel aspect of this model rests on my hypothesis that distinct language tasks can be sustained by several different neuronal systems. Crucially, this means that when one system dysfunctions, recovery can be meditated by a surviving system. The neuronal systems engaged by each task will be identified by combining data from neuropsych ological and functional imaging studies. Validating the model involves structural neuroimaging and behavioural assessments in patients with acquired brain damage in the regions identified. This will determine how the impact of damage in one system depends on the integrity of another. The model will then be used to formulate and test predictions for recovery using functional imaging studies of patients who recover their language skills despite damage to the areas engaged by normal subjects. The ability to anticipate which brain systems emerge, during rehabilitation, may be important for targeting various therapies or, at least, in helping the patient anticipate his or her course of recovery.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 我的建议是建立一个语言的功能解剖模型，预测在神经损伤后，语言和阅读是如何丢失和恢复的。这个模型的新颖之处在于我的假设，即不同的语言任务可以由几个不同的神经系统来维持。关键的是，这意味着当一个系统功能失调时，可以通过一个幸存的系统来冥想恢复。每项任务所涉及的神经系统将通过结合神经心理学和功能成像研究的数据来确定。验证该模型涉及结构神经成像和行为评估患者获得性脑损伤的区域确定。这将决定一个系统中损坏的影响如何取决于另一个系统的完整性。然后，该模型将被用于制定和测试康复预测，使用功能成像研究，对尽管正常受试者所涉及的区域受到损害但仍能恢复语言技能的患者进行研究。在康复过程中，预测哪些脑系统出现的能力，对于针对各种疗法或至少在帮助患者预测其康复过程中可能是重要的。

My proposal is to establish a functional anatomical model of language that predicts how speech and reading are lost and recovered following neurological damage. The novel aspect of this model rests on my hypothesis that distinct language tasks can be sustained by several different neuronal systems. Crucially, this means that when one system dysfunctions, recovery can be meditated by a surviving system. The neuronal systems engaged by each task will be identified by combining data from neuropsych ological and functional imaging studies. Validating the model involves structural neuroimaging and behavioural assessments in patients with acquired brain damage in the regions identified. This will determine how the impact of damage in one system depends on the integrity of another. The model will then be used to formulate and test predictions for recovery using functional imaging studies of patients who recover their language skills despite damage to the areas engaged by normal subjects. The ability to anticipate which brain systems emerge, during rehabilitation, may be important for targeting various therapies or, at least, in helping the patient anticipate his or her course of recovery.

Project.Title: Study of the influence of progressive neurodegeneration of the noradrenergic system on the functioning of the dopamine system in the context of the presymptomatic phase of Parkinson's disease.

Title_Other.Title: 帕金森病前症状期去甲肾上腺素能系统进行性神经变性对多巴胺系统功能影响的研究。
Badanie wpływu postępującej neurodegeneracji układu noradrenergicznego na funkcjonowanie układu dopaminowego w kontekście presymptomatycznej fazy choroby Parkinsona.

Class.ClassName: 蛋白质的变性、蛋白质的变构

Project.Abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD), the second occurrence of neurodegenerative disorders, is a slowly progressive degenerative disease of the central nervous system characterized by the disappearance of nerve cells of the dopamine system in the substantia nigra (SN) and the ventral abdominal region (VTA). However, PD is associated not only with neurodegeneration within the dopamine system, directly responsible for the formation of symptoms (bradykinesia, muscle stiffness, slowness of movement), but also with disorders in the functioning of other extrapyramidal systems, in particular the noradrenergic system. It has been observed that the degeneration of noradrenergic cells in the locus coeruleus (LC) may exceed or even precede the loss of dopamine cells. Experimental data also indicate a significant relationship between norepinephrine levels in the brain and susceptibility to parkinsonism-inducing neurotoxins in mice. Nevertheless, so far only very few experimental attempts have been made to study the long-term effect of noradrenergic degeneration on the functioning of the dopamine system, primarily due to the lack of appropriate animal models. The working hypothesis of the project assumes that the progressive neurodegeneration of the noradrenergic system in adult mice may eventually induce negative changes in the functioning of the dopamine system (which has already been demonstrated in pilot studies). The goal of the proposed project is therefore: a) creating a mouse model characterized by selective, cerebral-specific, progressive degeneration of the noradrenergic system, which in turn will lead to spontaneous changes in the dopamine system; b) using the model to study the interrelationship between the above-mentioned neurotransmission systems in the context of the early, preclinical PD phase and the search for possible markers and pharmacotherapy handle points. The first stage of the project will be the creation of a new model of transgenic mice by the fusion of two conditional recombination systems (Cre / loxP and Flp / FRT) characterized by selective progressive neurodegeneration of the central nervous system's noradrenergic cells. This effect will be achieved by ablation of the TIF-IA transcription factor, essential for ribosomal RNA synthesis using the Cre / loxP system by crossing transgenic mice containing Cre recombinase under the control of the dopamine beta-hydroxylase promoter with animals in which the TIF-IA coding gene has been flanked with loxP sequences, which will reduce mutations to noradrenergic cells. In order to further narrow the mutation to the central nervous system only, the Flp / FRT system will be used in which the beta-adduct is used as the promoter. The resulting model will then be thoroughly characterized in subsequent time points as neurodegenerative changes develop. The evaluation of the model will focus on the long-term effect of noradrenergic degeneration on the functioning of the dopamine system (not directly affected by the mutation) and will include behavioral tests (including spontaneous activity test, rotarod, CatWalk gait analysis), histological (IHC staining with different markers neurodegeneration, among others FluoroJade, NeuN, TH), biochemical (in vivo neurotransmitter markers - microdialysis), molecular (including identification of pathways leading to cell death by profiling gene expression, analysis of expression of proinflammatory cytokines by Western Blot). The obtained results will be used to further use the model in order to test selected pharmacotherapies based, among others, on for inhibiting inflammatory or apoptotic processes. Understanding the mutual interactions between noradrenergic and dopamine neurotransmission will allow to broaden the knowledge about PD pathophysiology. The identification of mechanisms preceding the degeneration of the dopamine system may lead to both the detection of preclinical PD markers as well as the points of the handle for pharmacotherapy introduced already in the initial stage of the disease before the loss of dopamine neurons. The created model, based on the induction of intrinsic changes in the dopamine system, has the potential to test not only pharmacotherapy based on symptomatic treatment, but above all neuroprotective substances, which may be important for designing more effective drugs and indirectly contribute to lowering care costs health, especially in highly developed societies where there is a significant increase in the incidence of neurodegenerative diseases associated with the general aging of the population.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: Choroba Parkinsona (PD), druga co do częstości występowania spośród schorzeń neurodegeneracyjnych, jest powoli postępującą, zwyrodnieniową chorobą ośrodkowego układu nerwowego charakteryzującą się zanikiem komórek nerwowych układu dopaminowego w istocie czarnej (SN) i polu brzusznym nakrywki (VTA). Jednakże, PD jest związana nie tylko z neurodegeneracją w obrębie układu dopaminowego, odpowiedzialnego bezpośrednio za powstawanie symptomów (bradykinezja, sztywność mięśniowa, spowolnienie ruchowe), ale także z zaburzeniami w funkcjonowaniu innych systemów pozapiramidowych, w szczególności układu noradrenergicznego. Zaobserwowano, iż degeneracja komórek układu noradrenergicznego w miejscu sinawym (LC) może przewyższać a nawet poprzedzać utratę komórek dopaminowych. Dane eksperymentalne wskazują również na istotną zależność pomiędzy poziomem noradrenaliny w mózgu, a podatnością na neurotoksyny indukujące parkinsonizm u myszy. Mimo to, jak dotychczas podjęto bardzo niewiele prób eksperymentalnych polegających na badaniu długotrwałego wpływu degeneracji noradrenergicznej na funkcjonowanie układu dopaminowego, przede wszystkim z braku odpowiednich modeli zwierzęcych. Robocza hipoteza projektu zakłada, iż postępująca neurodegeneracja układu noradrenergicznego u dorosłych myszy może docelowo wywołać negatywne zmiany w funkcjonowaniu układu dopaminowego (co zostało już wstępnie wykazane w badaniach pilotażowych). Celem proponowanego projektu jest zatem: a) stworzenie modelu myszy charakteryzującego się selektywną, mózgowo-specyficzną, progresywną degeneracją układu noradrenergicznego, co w konsekwencji będzie prowadzić do spontanicznych zmian w układzie dopaminowym; b) wykorzystanie modelu dla badania wzajemnych zależności pomiędzy w/w układami neuroprzekaźnictwa w kontekście wczesnej, przedklinicznej fazy PD i poszukiwania ew. markerów i punktów uchwytu farmakoterapii. Pierwszym etapem projektu będzie stworzenie nowego modelu myszy transgenicznych poprzez fuzję dwóch systemów warunkowej rekombinacji (Cre/loxP i Flp/FRT), charakteryzującego się selektywną, postępującą neurodegeneracją komórek noradrenergicznych ośrodkowego układu nerwowego, Efekt ten będzie osiągnięty w wyniku ablacji czynnika transkrypcyjnego TIF-IA, niezbędnego dla syntezy rybosomalnego RNA, za pomocą systemu Cre/loxP poprzez skrzyżowanie myszy transgenicznych zawierających rekombinazę Cre pod kontrolą promotora beta-hydroksylazy dopaminy ze zwierzętami w których gen kodujący TIF-IA został oflankowany sekwencjami loxP, co spowoduje ograniczenie mutacji do komórek noradrenergicznych. W celu dodatkowego zawężenia mutacji tylko do ośrodkowego układu nerwowego, zostanie wykorzystany dodatkowo system Flp/FRT w którym jako promotor zostanie użyta beta-adducyna. Powstały model będzie następnie dogłębnie scharakteryzowany w kolejnych punktach czasowych w miarę rozwoju zmian neurodegeneracyjnych. Ewaluacja modelu będzie koncentrować się na długotrwałym wpływie degeneracji noradrenergicznej na funkcjonowanie układu dopaminowego (nie dotkniętego bezpośrednio mutacją) i obejmie badania behawioralne (m.in. test spontanicznej aktywności, koordynacji ruchowej rotarod, analiza chodu CatWalk), histologiczne (barwienia IHC z udziałem różnych markerów neurodegeneracji m.in. FluoroJade, NeuN, TH), biochemiczne (oznaczenia poziomu neurotransmiterów in vivo – mikrodializa), molekularne (m.in. identyfikacja szlaków prowadzących do śmierci komórkowej poprzez profilowanie ekspresji genów, analiza ekspresji cytokin prozapalnych metodą Western Blot). Uzyskane wyniki posłużą do dalszego wykorzystania modelu w celu przetestowania wybranych farmakoterapii opartych m.in. o hamowanie procesów zapalnych czy apoptotycznych. Poznanie wzajemnych interakcji pomiędzy neuroprzekaźnictwem noradrenergicznym i dopaminowym umożliwi poszerzenie wiedzy o patofizjologii PD. Identyfikacja mechanizmów poprzedzających degenerację układu dopaminowego może doprowadzić zarówno do wykrycia markerów przedklinicznej fazy PD, jak i punktów uchwytu dla farmakoterapii wprowadzanej już w początkowym okresie choroby, zanim nastąpi utrata neuronów dopaminowych. Stworzony model, oparty na wywołaniu samoistnych zmian w układzie dopaminowym, ma szanse umożliwić testowanie nie tylko farmakoterapii opartej na leczeniu objawowym, ale przede wszystkim substancji o działaniu neuroprotekcyjnym, co może mieć istotne znaczenie dla projektowania bardziej skutecznych leków i pośrednio przyczynić się do obniżenia kosztów opieki zdrowotnej, szczególnie w społeczeństwach wysokorozwiniętych gdzie obserwuje się znaczący wzrost zachorowań na choroby neurodegeneracyjne, powiązane ze ogólnym starzeniem się populacji.

帕金森病（Parkinson's disease，PD）是第二种神经退行性疾病，是中枢神经系统缓慢进行性退行性疾病，其特征是黑质（SN）和腹腹部（VTA）多巴胺系统的神经细胞消失。然而，帕金森病不仅与多巴胺系统内的神经退行性变有关，直接导致症状的形成（运动迟缓、肌肉僵硬、运动迟缓），而且与其他锥体外系，特别是去甲肾上腺素能系统的功能紊乱有关。已经观察到蓝斑（LC）中去甲肾上腺素能细胞的变性可能超过甚至先于多巴胺细胞的丢失。实验数据还表明，大脑中去甲肾上腺素水平与帕金森病诱发小鼠神经毒素的易感性之间存在显著的关系。然而，到目前为止，研究去甲肾上腺素能退行性变对多巴胺系统功能的长期影响的实验尝试很少，这主要是由于缺乏合适的动物模型。该项目的工作假设假定成年小鼠去甲肾上腺素能系统的进行性神经退行性变可能最终导致多巴胺系统功能的负性变化（这已经在初步研究中得到证实）。因此，拟议项目的目标是： a）建立一种小鼠模型，其特征是去甲肾上腺素能系统的选择性、脑特异性、进行性退化，进而导致多巴胺系统的自发变化； b）利用该模型研究上述神经传递系统在帕金森病早期、临床前阶段的相互关系，寻找可能的标记物和药物治疗处理点。 该项目的第一阶段将是通过融合两个条件重组系统（Cre/loxP和Flp/FRT）建立一个新的转基因小鼠模型，其特征是中枢神经系统去甲肾上腺素能细胞的选择性进行性神经变性。通过将含有Cre重组酶的转基因小鼠（在多巴胺β羟化酶启动子的控制下）与TIF-IA编码基因带有loxP序列的动物杂交，消除TIF-IA转录因子（利用Cre/loxP系统合成核糖体RNA所必需的）来实现这一效果，从而减少去甲肾上腺素能细胞的突变。为了进一步将突变范围缩小到中枢神经系统，将使用Flp/FRT系统，其中β-加合物作为启动子。随后，随着神经退行性改变的发展，所得到的模型将在随后的时间点得到彻底的表征。该模型的评估将着眼于去甲肾上腺素能退行性变对多巴胺系统功能的长期影响（不受突变的直接影响），包括行为测试（包括自发活动测试、旋转木马、猫步步态分析）、组织学（不同神经退行性变标记的IHC染色，其中包括氟化物、NeuN、TH）、生化（体内神经递质标记物-微透析）、分子（包括通过基因表达谱确定导致细胞死亡的途径、通过Western Blot分析促炎细胞因子的表达）。所获得的结果将用于进一步使用该模型，以便测试基于抑制炎症或凋亡过程等的选定药物疗法。 了解去甲肾上腺素能和多巴胺神经传递之间的相互作用将有助于拓宽帕金森病病理生理学的知识。多巴胺系统退化前机制的识别可能导致临床前帕金森病标志物的检测以及药物治疗的处理要点在疾病的初期就已经引入多巴胺神经元的丧失。所建立的模型基于多巴胺系统内在变化的诱导，不仅有可能测试基于症状治疗的药物治疗，而且最重要的是测试神经保护物质，这些物质可能对设计更有效的药物和间接降低保健成本很重要，尤其是在高度发达的社会，随着人口的普遍老龄化，神经退行性疾病的发病率显著增加。

Organization.Name: Instytut Farmakologii im. Jerzego Maja Polskiej Akademii Nauk
Instytut Farmakologii im. Jerzego Maja Polskiej Akademii Nauk

Project.Title: Find patterns in new data flows

Title_Other.Title: Find patterns in new data flows
在新数据流中查找模式

Project.Abstract:
Purpose and goal: The huge amounts of data in the Swedish metal industry are not fully utilized but new methods of analysis makes it possible to extract new knowledge from them. However, there have been no or few examples of the benefits of the new uses of data. Costly data integration has been prioritized while the value has been unclear. This project breaks the circle by showing concrete values of investing in data integration and analysis. We show that machine learning can be used to identify reasons for quality deficiencies.
Expected results and effects: The total production data from hot-rolling rolling at Outokumpu has been shown to, with machine learning algorithms, be able to predict telescoping of hot-rolling rolls, and where in production the risks for this appear to occur. Together with production analysts, this knowledge has been translated into concrete proposals for actions. A demonstrator developed in the project shows how the new knowledge can be used by operators and analysts to better understand the manufacturing process.
Approach and implementation: Around 2600 production parameters from the entire production line, with all details from 3 months of production were used to train a dozen machine learning algorithms and evaluate them for their ability to predict telescoping. As there is a high level of prediction early in the line it is profitable to invest there to achieve a more controlled production. With Deep Learning, a computer model was trained to predict telescoping based solely on the band´s side deviation.

Together with production analysts, this knowledge has been translated into concrete proposals for actions. 目的和目标： 瑞典金属工业的大量数据没有得到充分利用，但新的分析方法使从中提取新知识成为可能。然而，没有或很少有新的数据使用的好处的例子。成本高昂的数据集成已被优先考虑，但其价值尚不清楚。这个项目打破了这个圈子，展示了在数据集成和分析方面投资的具体价值。我们证明机器学习可以用来识别质量缺陷的原因。 预期结果和效果： Outokumpu热轧的总生产数据表明，通过机器学习算法，能够预测热轧辊的伸缩，以及在生产中出现这种情况的风险。与生产分析员一道，这些知识已经转化为具体的行动建议。在这个项目中开发的一个演示程序展示了操作员和分析师如何使用新知识来更好地理解制造过程。 方法和实施： 整个生产线大约2600个生产参数，包括3个月生产的所有细节，被用来训练十几种机器学习算法，并评估它们预测望远镜的能力。由于早期预测水平很高，因此在那里投资以实现更可控的生产是有利可图的。通过深入学习，我们训练了一个计算机模型，仅根据波段的侧偏来预测望远镜的观测。

Project.Title: SGER: Development of the Plan for Long Term Impact Assessment of Recent War-Related Pollution Events in The Gulf: The Marine Chemistry Component

Title_Other.Title: SGER: Development of the Plan for Long Term Impact Assessment of Recent War-Related Pollution Events in The Gulf: The Marine Chemistry Component
SGER：制定海湾近期战争相关污染事件长期影响评估计划：海洋化学成分

Class.ClassName: 环境生态系统、生态环境

Project.Abstract: The Gulf has long been recognized as an important biologically productive ecosystem which supports a diversity of coastal and oceanic habitats. These include mangroves, seagrass beds, reef flats, reefs and well as pelagic and benthic oceanic habitats. Commercial fisheries and shellfish industries provide income to regional fisherman and The Gulf provides a critical habitat to some endangered species including dugongs and birds. The massive oil spills and the depositions of oil burn products resulting from the 1991 war activities have potential for long term impact on both the oceanic and coastal biology. These events are superimposed on coastal habitat destruction due to military activities such as mines, bombs, vehicular movement and related mechanical disturbances. All of this additional stress must be assessed in the framework of the recent history of oil exploration and production activities and past wars. Many national and international groups have undertaken preliminary impact assessment work in the Northern Gulf. These include the USCG, US EPA, NOAA consultants sent by several UN agencies and regional Gulf state authorities. These efforts have been directed at initial animal rescue activities, clean up and assessment in coastal habitats. The UN agencies, in collaboration with ROPME, have intentions of developing and implementing a plan for the long term impact assessment of recent war related pollution and habitat destruction events on the marine ecology or The Gulf. To do this the UN requires input by appropriate expert. This effort will be conducted under the SGER Program to undertake this long range Plan Development regarding the marine chemical component.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 长期以来，海湾一直被认为是一个重要的生物生产生态系统，支持沿海和海洋生境的多样性。其中包括红树林、海草床、礁滩、珊瑚礁以及远洋和底栖海洋生境。商业渔业和贝类产业为区域渔民提供收入，海湾为包括儒艮和鸟类在内的一些濒危物种提供了重要的栖息地。1991年战争造成的大规模石油泄漏和石油燃烧产物的沉积，对海洋和沿海生物都有潜在的长期影响。这些事件与由于地雷、炸弹、车辆移动和相关机械干扰等军事活动造成的沿海生境破坏叠加在一起。所有这些额外的压力都必须在石油勘探和生产活动的最近历史以及过去战争的框架内加以评估。许多国家和国际团体在北部湾开展了初步影响评估工作。其中包括美国公民及移民服务局、美国环保署、美国国家海洋和大气管理局（noaa）几个联合国机构和海湾地区国家当局派出的顾问。这些努力是针对最初的动物救援活动，清理和评估沿海生境。联合国各机构与海洋环境行动方案合作，打算制定和执行一项计划，对最近与战争有关的污染和生境破坏事件对海洋生态或海湾的长期影响进行评估。为此，联合国需要有关专家的意见。这项工作将在SGER计划下进行，以进行有关海洋化学成分的长期计划开发。

All of this additional stress must be assessed in the framework of the recent history of oil exploration and production activities and past wars. To do this the UN requires input by appropriate expert. This effort will be conducted under the SGER Program to undertake this long range Plan Development regarding the marine chemical component.

Project.Title: The role of Hemeoxygenase-1 and its products in the course and pathology of malaria infection.

Title_Other.Title: 血红素氧合酶-1及其产物在疟疾感染过程和病理中的作用。
The role of Hemeoxygenase-1 and its products in the course and pathology of malaria infection.

Project.Title: Studies of Localized Impurities in Quantum Dots using Synchrotron Radiation

Title_Other.Title: Studies of Localized Impurities in Quantum Dots using Synchrotron Radiation
量子点局域杂质的同步辐射研究

Project.Abstract: 9732660 Kao This University/Industry collaborative GOALI project focuses on preparation and characterization of doped quantum dots to identify and gain understanding of mechanisms responsible for their unusual properties. New types of doped quantum dots will be designed, prepared, and characterized using synchrotron radiation at the National Synchrotron Light Source at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Various doped quantum dots, especially rare-earth doped oxides, as well as thin films and nano-channel grids, will be prepared and studied. Synchrotron radiation experiments will include x-ray excited luminescence (XEL), extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), response time of doped quantum dots to x-ray pulses, geometrical resonance, and studies of coherent light emission in nanowires and nanodots. The XEL and EXAFS measurements are expected to be particularly useful for probing the local environment surrounding impurity atoms and for understanding impurity-host interactions. The project is co- supported by the DMR Electronic Materials Program and the MPS OMA(Office of Multidisciplinary Activities). %%% Basic research issues in a topical area of materials science having strong technological relevance are addressed by this project. The basic knowledge and understanding gained from the research is expected to contribute to improving the performance of advanced materials by providing a fundamental understanding and a basis for designing and producing improved nanostructures. An important feature of the program is the integration of research and education by providing an important educational opportunity through the GOALI aspect of the project for students to experience both academic and industrial research approaches and environments. ***

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 9732660 Kao这所大学/工业合作的GOALI项目专注于掺杂量子点的制备和表征，以识别和了解导致其异常性质的机制。布鲁克海文国家实验室的国家同步辐射光源将设计、制备和表征新型掺杂量子点。将制备和研究各种掺杂的量子点，特别是稀土掺杂的氧化物，以及薄膜和纳米沟道网格。同步辐射实验将包括x射线激发发光（XEL）、扩展x射线吸收精细结构（EXAFS）、掺杂量子点对x射线脉冲的响应时间、几何共振以及纳米线和纳米点中相干光发射的研究。预计XEL和EXAFS测量对于探测杂质原子周围的局部环境和理解杂质与宿主的相互作用特别有用。该项目由DMR电子材料项目和MPS OMA（多学科活动办公室）共同支持。%%%本项目涉及材料科学领域的基础研究问题，具有很强的技术相关性。从研究中获得的基本知识和理解有望为设计和生产改进的纳米结构提供基本的理解和基础，从而有助于提高先进材料的性能。该项目的一个重要特点是研究与教育的结合，通过项目的目标方面为学生提供了一个重要的教育机会，让他们体验学术和工业研究方法和环境。***

9732660 Kao This University/Industry collaborative GOALI project focuses on preparation and characterization of doped quantum dots to identify and gain understanding of mechanisms responsible for their unusual properties. New types of doped quantum dots will be designed, prepared, and characterized using synchrotron radiation at the National Synchrotron Light Source at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Various doped quantum dots, especially rare-earth doped oxides, as well as thin films and nano-channel grids, will be prepared and studied. Synchrotron radiation experiments will include x-ray excited luminescence (XEL), extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), response time of doped quantum dots to x-ray pulses, geometrical resonance, and studies of coherent light emission in nanowires and nanodots. The XEL and EXAFS measurements are expected to be particularly useful for probing the local environment surrounding impurity atoms and for understanding impurity-host interactions. The project is co- supported by the DMR Electronic Materials Program and the MPS OMA(Office of Multidisciplinary Activities). %%% Basic research issues in a topical area of materials science having strong technological relevance are addressed by this project. The basic knowledge and understanding gained from the research is expected to contribute to improving the performance of advanced materials by providing a fundamental understanding and a basis for designing and producing improved nanostructures. An important feature of the program is the integration of research and education by providing an important educational opportunity through the GOALI aspect of the project for students to experience both academic and industrial research approaches and environments. ***

Project.Title: International Conference on Dynamical Systems and Differential Equations, May 24 - 27, 2002, University of North Carolina at Wilmington

Title_Other.Title: International Conference on Dynamical Systems and Differential Equations, May 24 - 27, 2002, University of North Carolina at Wilmington
动力系统与微分方程国际会议，2002年5月24-27日，北卡罗来纳大学威尔明顿分校

Project.Abstract: ABSTRACT PI: Feng, Wei and Lu, Xin Proposal: DMS-0139710 Institution: University of North Carolina at Wilmington The Fourth International Conference on Dynamical Systems and Differential Equations will be held at the University of North Carolina at Wilmington on May 24-May 27, 2002. This is a continuation of the Conference Series on Dynamical Systems and Differential Equations, a biennial event with a new hosting university each time to benefit researchers in USA. Details, including history of past conference series, can be found at http://AIMsciences.org. The goal of this conference is to gather mathematicians and scientists, with different training backgrounds and research interests, to report on their recent achievements, exchange new ideas and look for future directions. A majority of the NSF funds will be used specifically for partial support of 35 graduate students and ten new Ph-D's in mathematics. Priority will be given for support of students from under-represented groups in mathematics.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 文摘PI:Feng，Wei and Lu，Xin提案：DMS-0139710机构：北卡罗来纳大学威尔明顿分校第四届动力系统与微分方程国际会议将于2002年5月24日-5月27日在北卡罗来纳大学威尔明顿分校举行。这是动力系统和微分方程系列会议的延续，这是一个两年一次的活动，每次都有一所新的主办大学为美国的研究人员提供帮助。详情，包括过去的系列会议的历史，可以在http://AIMsciences.org上找到。这次会议的目的是聚集具有不同培训背景和研究兴趣的数学家和科学家，报告他们最近的成就，交流新的想法，并寻找未来的方向。NSF的大部分资金将专门用于35名研究生和10名数学博士的部分资助。优先资助数学代表性不足的学生。

Project.Title: SIRT1 Overexpression in Cellular Mitochondrial Metabolism and Function

Title_Other.Title: SIRT1 Overexpression in Cellular Mitochondrial Metabolism and Function
SIRT1在细胞线粒体代谢和功能中的过度表达

Class.ClassName: 理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): Oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction have been associated with a wide range of neurodegenerative diseases and metabolic disorders such as diabetes. A major public health problem is the increase in the incidence of obesity-related diseases, such as diabetes and its complications and the increased incidence of neurodegenerative diseases, for example Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases in the aging population. Therapeutic and preventive strategies to reduce the complications of diabetes and to treat neurodegenerative diseases are urgently needed. Several lines of evidence indicate that a common link in these diseases is diminished mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and response to oxidative injury. Key regulators of mitochondrial function, the nuclear respiratory coactivators help to regulate mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and prevent cellular and neuronal injury. SIRT1 is a member of the sirtuin family of NAD+dependent deacetylases, which is proposed to be responsible for health benefits provided by caloric restriction. Furthermore, resveratrol found in the skin of red grapes increases the activity SIRT1, prolongs life-span in mice, and may prevent neurodegeneration. A key component of the protective response mediated by SIRT1 is deacetylation and activation of the transcription factor PGC-11 leading to increased mitochondrial regeneration and improved cellular oxidative energy metabolism. The role of SIRT1 and its mechanism/s of action at cellular level are uncertain;however investigators with a wide spectrum of research foci have an interest in understanding the biological actions of SIRT1 in different tissues. To study this, generation of transgenic mice that conditionally expresses SIRT1 is needed. In response to an PA from NCRR (PA-07-336) to develop animal models of human disease that are applicable to the research interests of two or more categorical NIH Institutes/Centers, we will develop a transgenic mouse that expresses mouse SIRT1 and mitochondrial targeted enhanced yellow fluorescent protein under the control of tetracycline responsive element (TRE-SIRT1/mito-eYFP). Co-expression of mito-eYFP with SIRT1 will be used to identify, isolate and study the influence of SIRT1 expression on mitochondrial function. Then, SIRT1 expression will be targeted to central and peripheral neurons by crossing it with CamKII-1 tTA mice. The transgenic mice developed in this study will aid investigators from NINDS, NIDDK, NIA and other institutes to test disease mechanisms and develop SIRT1 mediated therapies. Specifically in this proposal, we will investigate the mechanism by which SIRT1 protects central and peripheral neurons against diabetes-induced neuronal injury. The proposal also describes how the animal models produced can be developed by other investigators to study SIRT1 biology in non-neuronal cells. We have two aims: (1) To develop a transgenic mouse that expresses mouse SIRT1 under the control of tetracycline responsive element (TRE;TRE-SIRT1/mito-eYFP). (2) To phenotype the bigenic SIRT1 neuron specific mouse model. Lay description: Obesity, diabetes, and neurodegenerative diseases affect large numbers of people. The SIRT1 protein is considered to be a master regulator of the body's defense against disease and is activated by resveratrol found in red grapes. We aim to uncover the mechanism by which S1RT1 protects neurons from diabetes induced neurological complications. PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: This proposal is submitted in response to a PA from NCRR PA-07-336 "Development of Animal models and Related Biological Materials for Research". The research objective of this PA is to "develop, characterize or improve animal models for human disease and that models to be considered must be applicable to the research interests of two or more categorical NIH Institutes/Centers". A major public health problem is the increase in the incidence of obesity-related diseases, such as diabetes and its complications and the increased incidence of neurodegenerative diseases, for example Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases in the aging population. We will develop a transgenic mouse that expresses mouse SIRT1 and mitochondrial targeted enhanced yellow fluorescent protein under the control of tetracycline responsive element (TRE-SIRT1/mito-eYFP). Co-expression of mito-eYFP with SIRT1 will be used to identify, isolate and study the influence of SIRT1 expression on mitochondrial function. Then, SIRT1 expression will be targeted to central and peripheral neurons by crossing it with CamKII-1 tTA mice. The transgenic mice developed in this study will aid investigators from NINDS, NIDDK, NIA and other institutes to test disease mechanisms and develop SIRT1 mediated therapies. Our overall hypothesis is that activation of SIRT1 in the central (CNS) and peripheral nervous system (PNS) would reduce oxidative stress and improve regulation of Mt function in neurons and other tissues that may be important in neurodegenerative diseases, diabetes and its complications, and in delaying or reducing the effect of aging in the nervous system. Activation of the sirtuins offers the potential for a novel treatment of several human diseases that are related to oxidative injury and defects of mitochondrial function.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 描述（由申请人提供）：氧化应激和线粒体功能障碍与广泛的神经退行性疾病和代谢紊乱如糖尿病有关。一个主要的公共卫生问题是肥胖相关疾病的发病率增加，如糖尿病及其并发症，以及神经退行性疾病的发病率增加，如老年人口中的帕金森氏症和阿尔茨海默氏症。减少糖尿病并发症和治疗神经退行性疾病的治疗和预防策略是迫切需要的。一些证据表明，这些疾病的共同联系是线粒体氧化磷酸化减少和对氧化损伤的反应。线粒体功能的关键调节因子，核呼吸辅活化因子有助于调节线粒体氧化磷酸化，防止细胞和神经元损伤。SIRT1是NAD+依赖性脱乙酰酶sirtuin家族的一员，被认为负责热量限制带来的健康益处。此外，在红葡萄皮中发现的白藜芦醇增加了SIRT1的活性，延长了小鼠的寿命，并可能预防神经变性。SIRT1介导的保护性反应的一个关键组成部分是转录因子PGC-11的去乙酰化和激活，导致线粒体再生增加和细胞氧化能量代谢改善。SIRT1的作用及其在细胞水平上的作用机制尚不清楚；然而，具有广泛研究热点的研究人员对了解SIRT1在不同组织中的生物作用感兴趣。为了研究这个问题，需要一代有条件表达SIRT1的转基因小鼠。为了响应NCRR（PA-07-336）的PA，开发适用于两个或多个分类NIH研究所/中心的研究兴趣的人类疾病动物模型，我们将开发一种在四环素反应元件（TRE-SIRT1/mito-eYFP）控制下表达小鼠SIRT1和线粒体靶向增强黄色荧光蛋白的转基因小鼠。利用mito-eYFP与SIRT1的共表达来鉴定、分离和研究SIRT1表达对线粒体功能的影响。然后，通过与CamKII-1tta小鼠杂交，SIRT1表达将靶向中枢和外周神经元。本研究开发的转基因小鼠将帮助NINDS、NIDDK、NIA和其他研究机构的研究人员测试疾病机制并开发SIRT1介导的疗法。特别是在这项提议中，我们将研究SIRT1保护中枢和外周神经元免受糖尿病诱导的神经元损伤的机制。该提案还描述了其他研究人员如何开发所产生的动物模型，以研究非神经元细胞中的SIRT1生物学。我们有两个目的：（1）在四环素反应元件（TRE；TRE-SIRT1/mito-eYFP）的调控下，建立表达小鼠SIRT1的转基因小鼠。（2） 建立大基因SIRT1神经元特异性小鼠模型。描述：肥胖、糖尿病和神经退行性疾病影响着大量的人。SIRT1蛋白被认为是人体抵御疾病的主要调节因子，并被红葡萄中的白藜芦醇激活。我们的目的是揭示S1RT1保护神经元免受糖尿病引起的神经并发症的机制。公共卫生相关性：本提案是根据NCRRPA-07-336“动物模型和相关研究生物材料的开发”中的PA提交的。本PA的研究目标是“开发、表征或改进人类疾病的动物模型，所考虑的模型必须适用于两个或多个分类NIH研究所/中心的研究兴趣”。一个主要的公共卫生问题是肥胖相关疾病的发病率增加，如糖尿病及其并发症，以及神经退行性疾病的发病率增加，如老年人口中的帕金森氏症和阿尔茨海默氏症。我们将开发一种在四环素反应元件（TRE-SIRT1/mito-eYFP）控制下表达小鼠SIRT1和线粒体靶向增强黄色荧光蛋白的转基因小鼠。将mito-eYFP与SIRT1共表达用于鉴定、分离和研究SIRT1表达对线粒体的影响

Source.Name: National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences

Project.Title: Phase shifting endocrine and sleep/activity rhythms with light and serotonergic drugs

Title_Other.Title: 光和5-羟色胺能药物的相移内分泌和睡眠/活动节律
Phase shifting endocrine and sleep/activity rhythms with light and serotonergic drugs

Project.Abstract: All biological systems, including those of humans, are influenced by changes in the environment, especially by variations in the amount of daylight. In animals the external rhythm of light and darkness interacts with a small part of the brain called the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN-often called the biological clock) which has its own self sustained rhythms. The SCN in turn orchestrates rhythms in the secretion of the hormone melatonin from the pineal gland, body temperature, the timing of sleep and the secretion of other hormones. The aim of this study is to extend our knowledge of the inter-relationships between light, the chemical messengers that nerves use to communicate with each other, the biological clock and rhythms in body functions. We will concentrate on one particular chemical messenger called serotonin which we believe plays an important role in keeping rhythms in synchrony with the natural day-night cycle. The results are expected to be of benefit in understanding how certain sleep timing disorders arise and provide some insight into how they might be treated.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 所有的生物系统，包括人类的生物系统，都受到环境变化的影响，特别是受到日光量变化的影响。在动物中，光和暗的外部节律与大脑中称为视交叉上核（SCN，通常称为生物钟）的一小部分相互作用，后者有自己的持续节律。SCN依次调节松果体褪黑激素的分泌、体温、睡眠时间和其他激素的分泌。这项研究的目的是扩展我们对光、神经用来相互交流的化学信使、生物钟和身体功能节律之间相互关系的知识。我们将专注于一种叫做血清素的特殊化学信使，我们相信它在保持节奏与自然昼夜周期同步方面起着重要作用。这一结果有望有助于理解某些睡眠时间紊乱是如何产生的，并为如何治疗这些紊乱提供一些见解。

All biological systems, including those of humans, are influenced by changes in the environment, especially by variations in the amount of daylight. In animals the external rhythm of light and darkness interacts with a small part of the brain called the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN-often called the biological clock) which has its own self sustained rhythms. The SCN in turn orchestrates rhythms in the secretion of the hormone melatonin from the pineal gland, body temperature, the timing of sleep and the secretion of other hormones. The aim of this study is to extend our knowledge of the inter-relationships between light, the chemical messengers that nerves use to communicate with each other, the biological clock and rhythms in body functions. We will concentrate on one particular chemical messenger called serotonin which we believe plays an important role in keeping rhythms in synchrony with the natural day-night cycle. The results are expected to be of benefit in understanding how certain sleep timing disorders arise and provide some insight into how they might be treated.

Source.Name: National Health and Medical Research Council

Project.Title: XPS: FULL: Collaborative Research: Maximizing the Performance Potential and Reliability of Flash-based Solid State Devices for Future Storage Systems

Title_Other.Title: XPS:FULL:Collaborative Research:最大限度地提高未来存储系统中基于Flash的固态设备的性能潜力和可靠性
XPS: FULL: Collaborative Research: Maximizing the Performance Potential and Reliability of Flash-based Solid State Devices for Future Storage Systems

Project.Abstract: Solid-state data storage built upon NAND flash memory is fundamentally changing the memory and storage hierarchy for virtually the entire information technology infrastructure. Nevertheless, there have been several fundamental and challenging issues to be addressed before the industry can explore the flash memory to its full potential. First, as flash memory technology scales down, its reliability degradation approaches to an alarming level, leading to serious concerns and skepticism of storage system architects and users in many applications. Second, system and application development of solid-state storage has been independently conducted, resulting in isolation, duplicated operations, and an inefficient management among these layers. Due to the technology scaling and information loss in existing simple interface with storage devices, flash memory has not been efficiently and reliably utilized in practice, and the situation will become worse with the technology scaling. The PIs of this project will apply a holistic system design methodology to cohesively address the challenges preventing wider adoption of flash memory. By innovating well-orchestrated cross-layer information sharing and utilization, this design methodology enables seamless utilization of system-level workload and physical-level device characteristics across the entire software/hardware stack without complicating overall system design. An integrated software and hardware prototyping infrastructure will be developed to demonstrate the potential using major and widely used software systems, such as Hadoop, virtual machines, and database. This project will achieve a high broader impact by transforming basic research results into storage systems, and by training both undergraduate and graduate students with research activities, and by timely integrating new research results to classrooms. Specifically, this project will carry out several closely related tasks: (1) It will develop techniques that can learn and predict the varying characteristics and their correlations of individual flash memory devices. This will provide run-time information that makes it possible to optimize the use of flash memory for alleviating the reliability crisis and adapting to varying system-level workload characteristics. (2) It will develop techniques that enable critical information exchange across the storage hierarchy in order to facilitate cross-layer information sharing. (3) It will further develop a set of techniques across the design hierarchy that can effectively utilize these runtime collections and predictions to improve the overall system reliability and performance.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 基于NAND闪存的固态数据存储从根本上改变了几乎整个信息技术基础架构的内存和存储层次结构。尽管如此，在业界能够充分挖掘闪存的潜力之前，仍有一些根本性和挑战性的问题需要解决。首先，随着闪存技术规模的缩小，它的可靠性降低到了一个令人担忧的程度，这导致了存储系统架构师和许多应用程序中的用户的严重担忧和怀疑。第二，固态存储器的系统和应用开发是独立进行的，导致这些层之间的隔离、重复操作和管理效率低下。由于现有简单的存储设备接口存在着技术扩展和信息丢失等问题，flash存储器在实际应用中没有得到有效可靠的利用，随着技术的扩展，这种情况将变得更加严重。该项目的PIs将应用一种整体系统设计方法，以一致地解决阻碍广泛采用闪存的挑战。该设计方法创新了精心编排的跨层信息共享和利用，使系统级工作负载和物理级设备特性在整个软硬件堆栈中得到无缝利用，而不会使整个系统设计复杂化。将开发一个集成的软件和硬件原型基础设施，以展示使用主要和广泛使用的软件系统（如Hadoop、虚拟机和数据库）的潜力。该项目将通过将基础研究成果转化为存储系统，通过研究活动对本科生和研究生进行培训，并及时将新的研究成果整合到课堂上，从而产生更广泛的影响。具体来说，该项目将执行几个密切相关的任务：（1）开发能够学习和预测单个闪存设备的变化特性及其相关性的技术。这将提供运行时信息，使优化闪存的使用成为可能，以减轻可靠性危机并适应系统级工作负载的变化特征。（2） 它将开发能够跨存储层次结构交换关键信息的技术，以促进跨层信息共享。（3） 它将在整个设计层次结构中进一步开发一组技术，这些技术可以有效地利用这些运行时集合和预测来提高整个系统的可靠性和性能。

Solid-state data storage built upon NAND flash memory is fundamentally changing the memory and storage hierarchy for virtually the entire information technology infrastructure. Nevertheless, there have been several fundamental and challenging issues to be addressed before the industry can explore the flash memory to its full potential. First, as flash memory technology scales down, its reliability degradation approaches to an alarming level, leading to serious concerns and skepticism of storage system architects and users in many applications. Second, system and application development of solid-state storage has been independently conducted, resulting in isolation, duplicated operations, and an inefficient management among these layers. Due to the technology scaling and information loss in existing simple interface with storage devices, flash memory has not been efficiently and reliably utilized in practice, and the situation will become worse with the technology scaling. The PIs of this project will apply a holistic system design methodology to cohesively address the challenges preventing wider adoption of flash memory. By innovating well-orchestrated cross-layer information sharing and utilization, this design methodology enables seamless utilization of system-level workload and physical-level device characteristics across the entire software/hardware stack without complicating overall system design. An integrated software and hardware prototyping infrastructure will be developed to demonstrate the potential using major and widely used software systems, such as Hadoop, virtual machines, and database. This project will achieve a high broader impact by transforming basic research results into storage systems, and by training both undergraduate and graduate students with research activities, and by timely integrating new research results to classrooms. Specifically, this project will carry out several closely related tasks: (1) It will develop techniques that can learn and predict the varying characteristics and their correlations of individual flash memory devices. This will provide run-time information that makes it possible to optimize the use of flash memory for alleviating the reliability crisis and adapting to varying system-level workload characteristics. (2) It will develop techniques that enable critical information exchange across the storage hierarchy in order to facilitate cross-layer information sharing. (3) It will further develop a set of techniques across the design hierarchy that can effectively utilize these runtime collections and predictions to improve the overall system reliability and performance.

Project.Title: Party Leadership and the Development of the Modern Presidency

Title_Other.Title: Party Leadership and the Development of the Modern Presidency
党的领导与现代总统制的发展

Project.Title: Deformation Behavior of Sintered Carbides Under High Stress and Elevated Temperatures

Title_Other.Title: Deformation Behavior of Sintered Carbides Under High Stress and Elevated Temperatures
高温高应力烧结碳化物的变形行为

Project.Title: Prediction and Validation of Phospho-Regulatory Sites in Crop Plant Proteomes

Title_Other.Title: 作物蛋白质组磷酸调节位点的预测与验证
Prediction and Validation of Phospho-Regulatory Sites in Crop Plant Proteomes

Project.Abstract: The genomes of vascular plants encode more than 1000 protein kinases. The long-term goal is to define all the regulatory phosphorylation sites in crop plant proteomes. Such sites represent potential control points for all aspects of plant growth, including responses to biotic and abiotic stress. The focus is to use bioinformatics to predict a subset of potentially important sites of phospho-regulation in the rice proteome, and then use a peptide-based experimental strategy to start validating those predictions. The four Specific Aims are: 1. Improve bioinformatics tools to identify motifs involved in phospho-signaling in plants. 2. Conduct a clustering analysis of all Ser and Thr containing sub-sequences in plant proteomes. 3. Design peptide array platform to profile kinase activities in vitro. 4. Identify peptides that can disrupt in vivo signaling pathways (more than 50 will be tested). The uniqueness and strength of the proposed research rests upon the underlying rationale that a computational comparison of two plant proteomes can be used as a 'noise filter' to identify important sequence motifs that are fundamental to signaling pathways conserved between monocots and dicots. This filtering provides the critical foundation for implementing 'peptide-disruptors' as a powerful new approach to understanding and manipulating the dynamics of the plant cell phosphorylome. DNA constructs for all genes found to encode a 'peptide disruptor' or function as a reporter for a particular kinase activity will be deposited at the ABRC at Ohio State University, and will be freely available.

维管植物的基因组编码1000多种蛋白激酶。长期目标是确定作物蛋白质组中所有的调控磷酸化位点。这些位点代表了植物生长各个方面的潜在控制点，包括对生物和非生物胁迫的反应。重点是利用生物信息学来预测水稻蛋白质组中磷酸调节的潜在重要位点的子集，然后使用基于肽的实验策略来开始验证这些预测。四个具体目标是：1。改进生物信息学工具，以识别植物磷酸信号转导中涉及的基序。2。对植物蛋白质组中所有含有Ser和Thr的亚序列进行聚类分析。三。设计肽阵列平台，在体外检测激酶活性。四。识别能扰乱体内信号传导途径的肽（将测试50个以上）。所提出的研究的独特性和强度取决于以下基本原理：两种植物蛋白质组的计算比较可以用作“噪声滤波器”，以识别对单子叶植物和双子叶植物之间保守的信号传导途径至关重要的重要序列模体。这种过滤为实现“肽破坏子”作为理解和操纵植物细胞磷酸化子动力学的强有力的新方法提供了重要的基础。所有被发现编码“肽破坏者”或作为特定激酶活性报告者的基因的DNA结构将被存放在俄亥俄州立大学的ABRC，并将免费提供。

Project.Title: Interaction between Age and Chrna4 Genotype on Nicotine Sensitivity in Mice

Title_Other.Title: 年龄与chrna4基因型对小鼠尼古丁敏感性的交互作用
Interaction between Age and Chrna4 Genotype on Nicotine Sensitivity in Mice

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): The main focus of this research proposal is to further explore the effect of the Chrna4 A529T polymorphism on nAChR function and behavioral sensitivity to nicotine using a mouse model that has been engineered to differ at the Chma4 A529T polymorphism. These studies will increase our understanding of the effect of this single amino acid change on nAChR function. By understanding how this polymorphism affects individual differences in the reinforcing and aversive effects of nicotine between adolescent and adult animals, we might gain new information of how naturally occurring genetic variability influences innate nicotine sensitivity and whether genetic influence in adolescents is stronger or weaker compared to adult animals. The proposal will specific try to establish which nicotine addiction-related behaviors are influenced by the Chrna4 A529T polymorphism in both adolescents and adults. Chrna4 knocking mice will be used to examine the effect of the polymorphism on nicotine oral preference, conditioned place preference, tolerance development, and conditioned taste aversion. Behavioral measures will provide new information regarding the reinforcing properties of nicotine measured in preference, development of tolerance, and aversion, which are behaviors that influence nicotine addition. Additionally, including adolescent animals will provide information regarding how age might influence some of these behaviors. The proposal will also determine the influence of the Chrna4 A529T polymorphism on the function and expression of a4(32* nAChRs in both adolescents and adults. Specifically, Chrna4 T529A knockin mice will be used to evaluate the genetic effect of the polymorphism on Rb+ efflux, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) release, dopamine (DA) release, [3H] cytisine binding in specific brain regions. Gathering data on these measures on both adolescent and adult mice will allow for a comparison of the function and expression of a4(32* nAChRs in order to further evaluate how age might influence biochemical and functional measures. PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: More than 438,000 people die each year due to smoking, making smocking the most preventable cause of death in the United States, and more than 70% of smokers want to qui' smoking; however very few (2.5%) are successful each year. Research has provided substantial evidence that nicotine addiction has a genetic component and more recent evidence, due to the fact that 80% smokers initiate use before the age of 18, that there is also a large age related component. This proposal will use a genetic approach in order to determine the influence of age on behavior and biochemica measures related to nicotine addiction.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 描述（由申请人提供）：本研究建议的主要重点是进一步探讨chrna4 a529t多态性对nachr功能和尼古丁行为敏感性的影响，使用一个小鼠模型，该模型已被设计成在chma4 a529t多态性上有所不同。这些研究将加深我们对这种单一氨基酸变化对nachr功能影响的理解。通过了解这种多态性如何影响青少年和成年动物之间尼古丁增强和厌恶作用的个体差异，我们可能获得新的信息，了解自然发生的遗传变异是如何影响天然尼古丁敏感性的，以及青少年的遗传影响是否比成年动物更强或更弱。该建议将具体尝试确定青少年和成人中哪些尼古丁成瘾相关行为受到chrna4 a529t多态性的影响。chrna4敲除小鼠将被用于检测多态性对尼古丁口服偏好、条件位置偏好、耐受性发展和条件味觉厌恶的影响。行为测量将提供有关尼古丁强化特性的新信息，这些特性包括偏好、耐受性和厌恶性的发展，这些都是影响尼古丁添加量的行为。此外，包括青春期动物将提供有关年龄如何影响这些行为的信息。该研究还将确定chrna4 a529t多态性对青少年和成人a4（32*nachrs）功能和表达的影响。特别地，chrna4 t529a基因敲除小鼠将被用于评估rb+外排、γ-氨基丁酸（gaba）释放、多巴胺（da）释放、[3h]胞苷结合在特定脑区的遗传效应。收集青少年和成年小鼠的这些测量数据，可以比较a4（32*nachrs）的功能和表达，以便进一步评估年龄对生化和功能测量的影响。公共卫生相关性：每年有超过43.8万人死于吸烟，使吸烟成为美国最可预防的死亡原因，超过70%的吸烟者希望戒烟；然而，每年成功戒烟的人很少（2.5%）。研究已经提供了大量证据，证明尼古丁上瘾有遗传因素，而且最近的证据表明，由于80%的吸烟者在18岁之前就开始使用尼古丁，也有很大的年龄相关因素。这项提议将使用遗传方法来确定年龄对尼古丁成瘾行为和生化指标的影响。

Project.Title: Collaborative Research: Socially Assistive Robots

Title_Other.Title: Collaborative Research: Socially Assistive Robots
协作研究：社会辅助机器人

Project.Abstract: Socially Assistive Robots Lead PI/Institution: Brian Scassellati, Yale University This Expedition will develop the fundamental computational techniques that will enable the design, implementation, and evaluation of robots that encourage social, emotional, and cognitive growth in children, including those with social or cognitive deficits. The need for this technology is driven by critical societal problems that require sustained, personalized support that supplements the efforts of educators, parents, and clinicians. For example, clinicians and families struggle to provide individualized educational services to children with social and cognitive deficits, whose numbers have quadrupled in the US in the last decade alone. In many schools, educators struggle to provide language instruction for children raised in homes where a language other than English is spoken (over 20%), the fastest-growing segment of the school-age population. This Expedition aims to support the individual needs of these children with socially assistive robots that help to guide the children toward long-term behavioral goals, that are customized to the particular needs of each child, and that develop and change as the child does. To achieve this vision, this Expedition will advance the state-of-the-art in socially assistive human-robot interaction from short-term interactions in structured environments to long-term interactions that are adaptive, engaging, and effective. This progress will require transformative computing research in three broad and naturally interrelated research areas. First, the Expedition will develop computational models of the dynamics of social interaction, so that robots can automatically detect, analyze, and influence agency, intention, and other social interaction primitives in dynamic environments. Second, the Expedition will develop machine learning algorithms that adapt and personalize interactions to individual physical, social, and cognitive differences, enabling robots to teach and shape behavior in ways that are tailored to the needs, preferences, and capabilities of each individual. Third, the Expedition will develop systems that guide children toward specific learning goals over periods of weeks and months, allowing for truly long-term guidance and support. Research in these three areas will be integrated into socially assistive robots that are deployed in schools and homes for durations of up to one year. This Expedition has the potential to substantially impact the effectiveness of education and healthcare for children, and the technological tools developed will serve as the basis for enhancing the lives of children and other groups that require specialized support and intervention. The proposed computing research is tied to a comprehensive student training program, bringing a compelling, engaging, and grounded STEM experience to K-12 students through in-school and after-school activities. It also establishes an annual training summit to provide undergraduates with the multi-disciplinary background to engage in this promising research area in graduate school. Finally, by establishing a brand name for socially assistive robotics, this effort will create a central authority for the distribution of high-quality, peer-reviewed information, providing a coherent focal point for enhancing outreach and education. For more information visit www.yale.edu/SAR

社交辅助机器人领导PI/机构：耶鲁大学Brian Scassellati本次考察将开发基本的计算技术，使机器人的设计、实现和评估能够促进儿童的社交、情感和认知发展，包括那些有社交或认知缺陷的儿童。这种技术的需求是由关键的社会问题驱动的，这些问题需要持续的、个性化的支持，以补充教育者、家长和临床医生的努力。例如，临床医生和家庭很难为有社会和认知缺陷的儿童提供个性化的教育服务，仅在过去十年里，这些儿童的数量就翻了两番。在许多学校，教育工作者努力为在讲英语以外的语言（超过20%）的家庭中长大的儿童提供语言教学，这是学龄人口中增长最快的部分。这个探险队的目的是用社会辅助机器人来支持这些孩子的个人需求，这些机器人有助于引导孩子达到长期的行为目标，这些目标是根据每个孩子的特殊需求定制的，并且随着孩子的成长和变化而变化。为了实现这一愿景，本次考察将推动社会辅助型人-机器人交互的最新进展，从结构化环境中的短期交互到适应性、参与性和有效的长期交互。这一进展将需要在三个广泛和自然相关的研究领域进行变革性的计算研究。首先，探险队将开发社会互动动力学的计算模型，使机器人能够在动态环境中自动检测、分析和影响代理、意图和其他社会互动原语。第二，探险队将开发机器学习算法，根据个体的生理、社会和认知差异调整和个性化交互，使机器人能够根据每个个体的需求、偏好和能力来教授和塑造行为。第三，探险队将开发系统，引导孩子们在数周和数月内实现特定的学习目标，从而提供真正长期的指导和支持。这三个领域的研究将被整合到社会辅助机器人中，这些机器人将被部署在学校和家庭中长达一年。这次考察有可能对儿童教育和保健的有效性产生重大影响，所开发的技术工具将作为提高儿童和其他需要专门支持和干预的群体生活的基础。拟议的计算研究与一个全面的学生培训计划相结合，通过校内和校外活动，为K-12学生带来引人注目的、引人入胜的、扎根的STEM体验。它还设立了一个年度培训峰会，为研究生院的本科生提供从事这一有前途的研究领域的多学科背景。最后，通过建立一个社会辅助机器人的品牌，这项努力将为分发高质量的同行评审信息建立一个中心机构，为加强外联和教育提供一个连贯的协调中心。更多信息请访问www.yale.edu/SAR

Source.Name: Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering

Project.Title: Targeted Development of Platinum Drugs

Title_Other.Title: Targeted Development of Platinum Drugs
铂类药物的靶向开发

Class.ClassName: 理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): A major treatment modality in the advanced disease setting is chemotherapy, with cisplatin-based regimens playing significant roles in the cancer management strategy of a number of cancers, including ovarian cancer, mesothelioma and non-small cell lung cancer. However, the majority of advanced cancer cases relapse and fail therapy due to the onset of cisplatin resistance, and patients eventually succumb to their disease. The most recent advance about two decades ago was the inclusion of taxol to the platinum regimen, but this has only provided short-term incremental benefit without impacting the 5-year survival rate. Thus, cisplatin resistance is a significant drawback, and there is a desperate need to understand the causes of resistance, so new agents can be developed. A major understanding emerging from our work is that wild-type p53 features prominently in the resistance phenotype and this represents a major puzzle why the apoptotic function of p53 is being inhibited. Since many advanced and refractory cancer disease types include substantial numbers of tumors that harbor wild-type p53, there is reason to believe that a common defect in a key gene or pathway may be the cause of p53 failing to become functionally activated. Based on the strong relationship of mutual exclusivity, tumors with wild-type p53 are likely to have defective Chk2 expression, and this defect will impact post-translational modification of p53 that is essential for stabilization and stimulation of its function. Indeed, wild-type p53 in cisplatin-resistant tumor cells often demonstrates defective function. Since specific cancers have intrinsic affinity for platinum drugs, we hypothesize that defective Chk2 expression prevents stabilization and/or stimulation of wild-type p53 in cisplatin-resistant cancers, and that platinum analogs can be designed to activate an alternative kinase to maximally restore p53 inducibility and cytotoxic activity. We will address this hypothesis through three specific aims: 1) Characterize cisplatin resistance as related to defective Chk2 in tumor panels harboring wild-type p53; 2) Identify the kinase activated by platinum analogs that restores p53 function in cisplatin-resistant cells; and 3) Establish structure-activity relationships for lead optimization and identify an analog that maximally stabilizes and stimulates wild-type p53 in resistant Chk2-defective tumor cells. Based on mouse models, activation of wild-type p53 is sufficient to kill tumor cells, and this raises the potential that targeting cisplatin resistance through a mechanism-directed drug development approach will restore wild-type p53 function and significantly increase response and 5-yr survival rates.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 说明（由申请人提供）：晚期疾病的主要治疗方式是化疗，以顺铂为基础的方案在许多癌症的癌症管理策略中发挥着重要作用，包括卵巢癌、间皮瘤和非小细胞肺癌。然而，大多数晚期癌症患者由于对顺铂产生耐药性而复发和治疗失败，患者最终死于疾病。大约20年前的最新进展是将紫杉醇纳入铂方案，但这只提供了短期的增量效益，而不影响5年生存率。因此，顺铂耐药是一个重大的缺点，迫切需要了解耐药的原因，以便开发新的药物。我们的研究发现野生型p53在耐药表型中具有显著的特征，这是p53凋亡功能被抑制的主要原因。由于许多晚期和难治性癌症疾病类型包括大量携带野生型p53的肿瘤，有理由相信关键基因或途径中的共同缺陷可能是p53未能发挥功能的原因。基于相互排斥的强相关性，野生型p53肿瘤可能存在chk2表达缺陷，这种缺陷将影响p53的翻译后修饰，而这对于稳定和刺激其功能至关重要。事实上，顺铂耐药肿瘤细胞中的野生型p53常常表现出功能缺陷。由于特定癌症对铂类药物具有内在的亲和力，我们假设缺陷的CHK2表达阻止了顺铂耐药癌症中野生型p53的稳定和/或刺激，并且铂类似物可以被设计来激活一种替代激酶，以最大限度地恢复p53的诱导性和细胞毒性活性。我们将通过三个特定的目的来解决这一假设：1）在含有野生型p53的肿瘤细胞中，将顺铂耐药性描述为与缺陷的chk2相关；2）识别由铂类似物激活的激酶，该激酶在顺铂耐药细胞中恢复p53功能；3）为铅的优化建立结构-活性关系。并鉴定一种类似物，它能最大限度地稳定和刺激耐药CHK2缺陷肿瘤细胞中的野生型p53。基于小鼠模型，野生型p53的激活足以杀死肿瘤细胞，这增加了通过机制导向的药物开发途径靶向顺铂耐药将恢复野生型p53功能并显著提高应答率和5年生存率的潜力。

DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): A major treatment modality in the advanced disease setting is chemotherapy, with cisplatin-based regimens playing significant roles in the cancer management strategy of a number of cancers, including ovarian cancer, mesothelioma and non-small cell lung cancer. However, the majority of advanced cancer cases relapse and fail therapy due to the onset of cisplatin resistance, and patients eventually succumb to their disease. The most recent advance about two decades ago was the inclusion of taxol to the platinum regimen, but this has only provided short-term incremental benefit without impacting the 5-year survival rate. Thus, cisplatin resistance is a significant drawback, and there is a desperate need to understand the causes of resistance, so new agents can be developed. A major understanding emerging from our work is that wild-type p53 features prominently in the resistance phenotype and this represents a major puzzle why the apoptotic function of p53 is being inhibited. Since many advanced and refractory cancer disease types include substantial numbers of tumors that harbor wild-type p53, there is reason to believe that a common defect in a key gene or pathway may be the cause of p53 failing to become functionally activated. Based on the strong relationship of mutual exclusivity, tumors with wild-type p53 are likely to have defective Chk2 expression, and this defect will impact post-translational modification of p53 that is essential for stabilization and stimulation of its function. Indeed, wild-type p53 in cisplatin-resistant tumor cells often demonstrates defective function. Since specific cancers have intrinsic affinity for platinum drugs, we hypothesize that defective Chk2 expression prevents stabilization and/or stimulation of wild-type p53 in cisplatin-resistant cancers, and that platinum analogs can be designed to activate an alternative kinase to maximally restore p53 inducibility and cytotoxic activity. We will address this hypothesis through three specific aims: 1) Characterize cisplatin resistance as related to defective Chk2 in tumor panels harboring wild-type p53; 2) Identify the kinase activated by platinum analogs that restores p53 function in cisplatin-resistant cells; and 3) Establish structure-activity relationships for lead optimization and identify an analog that maximally stabilizes and stimulates wild-type p53 in resistant Chk2-defective tumor cells. Based on mouse models, activation of wild-type p53 is sufficient to kill tumor cells, and this raises the potential that targeting cisplatin resistance through a mechanism-directed drug development approach will restore wild-type p53 function and significantly increase response and 5-yr survival rates.

Organization.Name: The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center
The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center

Project.Title: Role of Gap Junctions in the Regulation of Cell Migration

Title_Other.Title: 缝隙连接在细胞迁移调控中的作用
Role of Gap Junctions in the Regulation of Cell Migration

Project.Abstract: This project incorporates cutting-edge techniques for the identification of gap junctions and measurements of cell migration. Several types of adrenal cells will be studied that exhibit a wide variation in gap junction expression, either because of the initial phenotype of the cell or through experimental stimulation/inhibition of second messengers within the cell. In these studies, the influence of altered surface gap junctions on the regulation of cell migration will be explored in depth. The hypothesis that gap junctions play a pivotal role in cell migration will be addressed. Migration will be studied in cultures of adrenal cells that either have or do not have gap junctions (Specific Aim I). Cells will be treated with specific cAMP antagonists, agonist or diluent, and their migration characteristics will be assessed. Migration will be assayed using the following techniques: (1) time lapse imaging of the nuclear displacement or cell leading edge displacement of cells prelabeled with membrane permeable dyes; (2) counting the number of cells moving from a wound edge into a denuded area; and (3) counting the number of cells migrating in a silicon template compartmentalization chamber, in a microfluidic chamber, or through a Boyden chamber filter. A combination of time-lapse video microscopic and immunocytochemical techniques will be used to identify and elucidate the role of gap junction dynamics in cell migration. Infrastructural Contributions/Broader Impact The laboratory will continue to serve as a resource for the training of undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, visiting professors from minority institutions, and for mentoring high school students and (shadow program) teachers. Past NSF research funding has provided for the exposure and training of students, postdoctoral fellows, and faculty in areas of cell biology, endocrinology and signal transduction. Through seminars and workshops presented both nationally and internationally, information has been, and will continue to be, provided to members of the scientific community from a number of disciplines. High school students will continue to develop research projects and present at city and state science fairs. Recently, two undergraduate students won first place awards at national meetings, and others will be encouraged to follow in their path.

该项目结合了用于识别缝隙连接和测量细胞迁移的尖端技术。我们将研究几种类型的肾上腺细胞，它们在缝隙连接表达上表现出广泛的差异，这可能是由于细胞的初始表型，或者是通过实验刺激/抑制细胞内的第二信使。在这些研究中，我们将深入探讨表面缝隙连接的改变对细胞迁移调控的影响。缝隙连接在细胞迁移中起关键作用的假设将得到解决。将在有或没有间隙连接的肾上腺细胞培养物中研究迁移（特定目的I）。用特定的cAMP拮抗剂、激动剂或稀释剂处理细胞，并评估其迁移特性。将使用以下技术分析迁移：（1）用膜渗透染料预先标记的细胞的核位移或细胞前缘位移的延时成像；（2）计算从伤口边缘移动到裸露区域的细胞数量；以及（3）计算在硅模板分隔室、微流控室或通过Boyden室过滤器中迁移的细胞数。将采用延时视频显微镜和免疫细胞化学技术相结合的方法来鉴定和阐明间隙连接动力学在细胞迁移中的作用。基础设施贡献/更广泛的影响实验室将继续作为培养本科生和研究生、博士后研究员、少数民族院校客座教授以及指导高中生和（影子计划）教师的资源。过去国家科学基金会的研究基金为学生、博士后和细胞生物学、内分泌学和信号转导领域的教员提供了接触和培训。通过在国家和国际上举办的研讨会和讲习班，已经并将继续向来自若干学科的科学界成员提供信息。高中生将继续开展研究项目，并出席城市和国家科学博览会。近日，两名本科生在全国两会上获得一等奖，其他人将被鼓励走自己的路。

Project.Title: A New Tool for Directed Mouse ES Cell Differentiation and Germline Transmission

Title_Other.Title: 小鼠胚胎干细胞定向分化和生殖系传递的新工具
A New Tool for Directed Mouse ES Cell Differentiation and Germline Transmission

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): The use of embryonic stem (ES) cells, with their capacity to differentiate to almost any cell type, holds great promise for advancing research on human diseases, regenerative biology, and the development of more effective treatments. However, currently available methods for directing the differentiation of ES cells to specific cell types and producing sufficient numbers of the desired cells are inefficient, costly, and complex. In addition, the generation of genetically modified animals using ES cells is inefficient, primarily because of the unpredictability of germline transmission, and, where transmission is achieved, the resulting chimeric animals give rise to a mixture of offspring derived paternally from both the host and the introduced ES cells. At the same time, however, it is well established that when mouse embryonic stem (mES) cells are introduced into a mouse morula or blastocyst stage embryo, and then implanted into a pseudopregnant mouse, the introduced ES cells can contribute significantly to all tissues of the embryo proper, including the germline. Additionally, in mice it has been shown that embryos can often developmentally compensate during embryogenesis and survive when populations of cells nonessential to life are blocked or ablated by genetic manipulation. Of relevance here, it has also been shown that the resulting open developmental 'niche'can often be populated by ES cells introduced into the very early mouse embryo, with these cells differentiating to compensate and fill in for the ablated host populations. Hence, the capability to create embryonic niches and to cause their preferential ES-cell colonization represents a unique opportunity to develop tools enabling the efficient development of specific cell types within chimeras, including the germline, from ES cells. We propose to develop and implement a novel approach that will facilitate the directed differentiation of stem cells to specific cell types, and as a demonstration of the approach's utility, significantly improve germline transmission efficiency and the numbers of animals produced. To establish this tool, we will: 1) Develop and implement the efficient colonization of the mouse germline in chimeric animals through the introduction of mES or induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells into host embryos in which a niche will be opened by selectively ablating host embryo germ cells early in development;2) Apply this preferential chimerism approach to test the germline capability of a genetically diverse, novel set of fifteen mES and iPS cell lines;and 3) Use in vitro fertilization (IVF) to rapidly, specifically, and synchronously expand mES cell-derived germline offspring from the resulting chimeras. Establishment of this method will facilitate the selective colonization of specific tissues within chimeras. This will have far-reaching consequences for the examination of specific gene function within developing cells and tissues and for human regenerative biology. PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Stem cells, with their capacity to give rise to almost any cell type, have the potential to significantly advance biomedical research and the development of improved disease treatments including regenerative biology. Mouse models are critically important tools for the study of stem cells, control of their differentiation, and understanding gene function - research that is necessary prior to use of stem cell-based treatments in humans. We propose to develop a novel approach that will enable investigators to 'drive'stem cells to given desired cell types, which will also significantly facilitate the generation of mice for studying specific human diseases.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 描述（由申请人提供）：胚胎干细胞具有向几乎任何细胞类型分化的能力，它的应用为推进人类疾病、再生生物学的研究和开发更有效的治疗方法带来了巨大的希望。然而，目前用于指导ES细胞向特定细胞类型分化并产生足够数量的所需细胞的方法是低效的、昂贵的和复杂的。此外，利用胚胎干细胞产生转基因动物是低效的，主要是由于生殖系传播的不可预测性，并且，在实现传播的情况下，由此产生的嵌合体动物会产生父系来源于宿主和导入胚胎干细胞的后代的混合物。然而，同时，当小鼠胚胎干细胞（mES）被导入小鼠桑椹胚或囊胚期胚胎，然后被植入假孕鼠体内时，被导入的ES细胞可以显著地促进胚胎本身的所有组织，包括生殖系。此外，在老鼠身上，已经证明胚胎在胚胎发生过程中通常可以发育补偿，并且当非生命必需的细胞群被基因操作阻断或切除时可以存活。与此相关的是，研究还表明，由此产生的开放性发育“生态位”通常可以由引入小鼠胚胎的胚胎干细胞填充，这些细胞分化以补偿和填充被切除的宿主种群。因此，创造胚胎龛位并使胚胎胚胎干细胞优先定植的能力是一个独特的机会，可以开发工具，使胚胎干细胞在嵌合体内高效地发育特定的细胞类型，包括生殖系。我们建议开发并实施一种新的方法，以促进干细胞定向分化为特定细胞类型，并作为该方法实用性的证明，显著提高生殖系传播效率和动物数量。为了建立这一工具，我们将：1）通过将mES或诱导多能干（iPS）细胞导入宿主胚胎，开发并实现小鼠生殖系在嵌合体动物中的高效定殖，在宿主胚胎发育早期选择性地切除宿主胚胎生殖细胞，打开生态位；2） 应用这种优先的嵌合方法来测试一组遗传多样的、新的15个mES和iPS细胞系的生殖系能力；以及3）使用体外受精（IVF）快速、特异、同步地从产生的嵌合中扩增mES细胞衍生的生殖系后代。该方法的建立将有助于嵌合体内特定组织的选择性定殖。这将对检测发育中细胞和组织内的特定基因功能以及人类再生生物学产生深远的影响。公共卫生相关性：干细胞具有产生几乎任何细胞类型的能力，有潜力显著推进生物医学研究和改进疾病治疗的发展，包括再生生物学。小鼠模型是研究干细胞、控制其分化和了解基因功能的重要工具——在人类使用干细胞治疗之前，这是必要的。我们建议开发一种新的方法，使研究人员能够“驱动”干细胞到特定的细胞类型，这也将大大促进小鼠的产生，以研究特定的人类疾病。

Title_Other.Title: 在美洲建立一个控制和预防媒介传播疾病和其他传染病的有效方法的生态系统健康研究计划

Class.ClassName: 自然科学调查、自然科学考察

Project.Title: Stakeholder Survey

Title_Other.Title: Stakeholder survey
利益相关者调查

Project.Abstract:
Purpose and goal: The purpose of the survey was to determine whether respondents are in need of an Arena, which aims to speed up the development of ideas to commercial products/services. The survey was also designed to collect input on format and content of the Arena. Since the project confirmed stakeholder needs for the Arena and resulted in a number of concrete suggestions concerning content and format, the goals of the project were successfully reached. The project has given SWElife improved preconditions for developing an Arena that can speed up development of research ideas to practical applications
Expected results and effects: The stakeholder survey confirmed the need for a venue like the arena, with a focus on ´unmeet needs´ within a specific indication area. Several new ideas concerning content, focus and format for the Arena meetings were proposed. The project included a survey of issues that have made it more difficult or hindered the development of ideas into commercial product. These challenges are well suited to be addressed in the context of the Arena. A secondary effect of the stakeholder survey was to raise the profiles of the Arena and SWElife among key stakeholders within life science in Sweden.
Approach and implementation: The project was carried out by a strong team consisting of academics and industry representatives, and external organizational consultants. Key individuals who had worked, or are working, with diabetes from academia, industry and health care, as well as investors and groups of patient organizations were interviewed. The survey was conducted via telephone in a quantitative approach with qualitative elements, which means that respondents had the opportunity to comment on their answers and answer open questions.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 目的和目标： 调查的目的是确定受访者是否需要一个竞技场，该竞技场旨在加快商业产品/服务创意的发展。这项调查还旨在收集对竞技场的形式和内容的意见。由于该项目确认了利益相关者对竞技场的需求，并就内容和形式提出了一些具体建议，成功地实现了项目的目标。该项目为sulife提供了改进的先决条件，以便开发一个能够加快研究思路向实际应用发展的舞台 预期结果和效果： 利益相关者的调查确认了竞技场等场地的需求，重点是特定指示区域内的“未满足需求”。 就竞技场会议的内容、重点和形式提出了一些新的想法。 该项目包括一项调查，调查那些使创意更难或阻碍创意转化为商业产品的问题。这些挑战非常适合在竞技场范围内解决。 利益相关者调查的第二个影响是提高了瑞典生命科学领域主要利益相关者对竞技场和膨胀的认识。 方法和实施： 该项目由一个由学者和行业代表以及外部组织顾问组成的强大团队执行。采访了来自学术界、工业界和医疗保健界，以及投资者和患者组织团体的曾患有或正在患有糖尿病的关键人士。 这项调查是通过电话进行的，采用的是带有定性因素的定量方法，这意味着受访者有机会对自己的答案发表评论，回答公开问题。

Project.Title: Study of human globin gene regulation and hemoglobinopathies in transgenic mice

Title_Other.Title: Study of human globin gene regulation and hemoglobinopathies in transgenic mice
人珠蛋白基因调控与转基因小鼠血红蛋白病的研究

Class.ClassName: 氨基酸制剂生产、肽制剂生产、蛋白质制剂生产

Project.Abstract: Hemoglobin which binds oxygen is the major protein of the red blood cell. It is constituted of four subunits, two identical gamma-globin chains and two identical beta-globin chains. The alpha and beta units are produced from a group of different genes. At different stages of life, (i.e. embryo to fetus to adult) blood cells are produced in different tissues of the organism and in each tissue, a different globin gene is expressed. The shift from the use of fetal adult globin chains is called hemoglobin switch. The mechanism controlling this switch is still unknown. Thus, the molecular interactions responsible for the fetal to adult developmental control of the switch will be analyzed. Understanding the molecular aspects of this process may have important implications for patients suffering from diseases in which hemoglobin is not produced or is abnormal such as thalassemia and sickle cell disease. In order to better understand sickle cell disease and to develop a therapeutic strategy, we have produced a mouse model of this disease. We will therefore investigate the cellular pathophysiology of our murine model of sickle cell disease in the perspective of developing long term therapeutic strategies. Concurrently, we will attempt to cure our mouse model of sickle cell disease by using gene therapy approaches that are both safe and effective and eventually amenable to human use. This study will hopefully provide a comprehension of the hemoglobin switch phenomena and the development of novel approaches to the treatment of sickle cell disease.
