结合氧的血红蛋白是红细胞的主要蛋白质。它由四个亚单位，两条相同的γ珠蛋白链和两条相同的β珠蛋白链组成。α和β单位是由一组不同的基因产生的。在生命的不同阶段（从胚胎到胎儿再到成人），血液细胞在生物体的不同组织中产生，在每个组织中，表达不同的珠蛋白基因。使用胎儿-成人珠蛋白链的转变称为血红蛋白开关。控制此开关的机制仍然未知。因此，将分析负责胎儿到成人发育控制开关的分子相互作用。了解这一过程的分子方面可能对患有血红蛋白不产生或异常的疾病（如地中海贫血和镰状细胞病）的患者具有重要意义。为了更好地了解镰状细胞病并制定治疗策略，我们制作了镰状细胞病小鼠模型。因此，我们将从制定长期治疗策略的角度研究镰状细胞病小鼠模型的细胞病理生理学。同时，我们将尝试通过基因治疗方法治愈镰状细胞病小鼠模型，这种方法既安全又有效，最终可供人类使用。这项研究将有助于理解血红蛋白开关现象，并开发治疗镰状细胞病的新方法。

Project.Title: Mining real-time social media big data to monitor HIV: Development and Ethical Issues

Title_Other.Title: Mining real-time social media big data to monitor HIV: Development and Ethical Issues
挖掘实时社交媒体大数据监测艾滋病：发展与伦理问题

Project.Abstract: Social ?big data? holds information with wide-ranging implications for addressing issues along the HIV care continuum. Social big data refers to information from social media and online platforms on which individuals and communities create, share, and discuss content. One in four people worldwide, or over a billion people, are publically documenting their activities, intentions, moods, opinions, and social interactions on these sites. They are doing so with increasing volume and velocity, including 400 million ?tweets? per day on Twitter and 4.75 billion content items shared per day on Facebook. With an increasing number of these platforms supporting access to publicly-available user data, social big data analysis is a promising new approach for attaining organic observations of behavior that can be used to monitor and predict real-world public health problems, such as HIV incidence. New tools such as social data are therefore needed to supplement existing HIV data collection methods. In preliminary research, our team developed the first approach that identifies psychological and behavioral characteristics from social big data (>550 million tweets) found to be associated with HIV diagnoses. Since groups at the highest risk for HIV (e.g., minority populations) are the fastest growing Twitter users, and because social media users have been found to publicly share personal information, we identified and collected tweets suggesting HIV risk behaviors (e.g., drug use, high-risk sexual behaviors, etc.) and modeled them alongside CDC statistics on HIV diagnoses. We found a significant positive relationship between HIV- related tweets and county-level HIV cases, controlling for socioeconomic status measures and other variables. The problem is that this approach is not currently scalable for use by HIV researchers and public health organizations. Although public health agencies are interested in mining social data to address HIV, current tools are not accessible to most health scientists, as the tools require advanced computer science expertise. For example, analyzing 500 million tweets a day requires expertise in big data engineering, advanced machine learning, natural language processing, and artificial intelligence. Developing a single platform for mining social data that has been designed and tested by and for HIV researchers could provide a significant impact on HIV prevention, testing, and treatment. We seek to create a single automated platform that collects social media data; identifies, codes, and labels tweets that suggest HIV-related behaviors; and ultimately predicts regional HIV incidence. Because of the potential ethical issues associated with mining people's data, we also seek to interview staff at local and regional HIV organization and participants affected by HIV to gain their perspectives on the ethical issues associated with this approach. The software developed from this application will be shared with HIV researchers and health care workers to provide additional tools that can be used to combat the spread of HIV.

社交？大数据？持有对解决艾滋病毒护理连续性问题具有广泛影响的信息。社交大数据是指个人和社区在社交媒体和在线平台上创建、共享和讨论内容的信息。全世界每四个人中就有一个人，或超过十亿人，在这些网站上公开记录他们的活动、意图、情绪、意见和社交互动。他们这样做是随着体积和速度的增加，包括4亿？推特？每天在Twitter和Facebook上分享47.5亿条内容。随着越来越多的这些平台支持访问公共可用的用户数据，社会大数据分析是一种有希望的新方法，可以获得对行为的有机观察，这些观察可用于监测和预测真实世界的公共卫生问题，如艾滋病毒发病率。因此，需要新的工具，如社会数据来补充现有的HIV数据收集方法。在初步研究中，我们的团队开发了第一种方法，从发现与艾滋病诊断相关的社会大数据（超过5.5亿条推文）中识别心理和行为特征。由于感染艾滋病毒风险最高的群体（如少数群体）是增长最快的推特用户，而且由于发现社交媒体用户公开分享个人信息，我们确定并收集了暗示艾滋病毒风险行为（如吸毒、高危性行为、性行为、性行为、性行为、性行为、性行为、性行为和性行为）的推文，并将其与疾病预防控制中心关于艾滋病诊断的统计数据一起建模。我们发现与HIV相关的推特与县级HIV病例、社会经济地位控制措施等变量之间存在显著的正相关关系。问题是，这种方法目前不适合艾滋病毒研究人员和公共卫生组织使用。尽管公共卫生机构有兴趣挖掘社会数据来解决艾滋病毒问题，但大多数卫生科学家无法使用现有的工具，因为这些工具需要先进的计算机科学专门知识。例如，每天分析5亿条推文需要大数据工程、高级机器学习、自然语言处理和人工智能方面的专业知识。开发一个单一的平台来挖掘由HIV研究人员设计和测试的社会数据，可以对HIV的预防、检测和治疗产生重大影响。我们试图创建一个单一的自动化平台，收集社会媒体数据；识别、编码和标记提示艾滋病毒相关行为的推文；并最终预测区域艾滋病毒发病率。由于与挖掘人们的数据相关的潜在道德问题，我们还试图采访当地和区域艾滋病毒组织的工作人员以及受艾滋病毒影响的参与者，以获得他们对与这种方法相关的道德问题的看法。从这个应用程序开发的软件将与艾滋病毒研究人员和卫生保健工作者共享，以提供额外的工具，可以用来打击艾滋病毒的传播。

Source.Name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Project.Title: CIF: Medium Projects: Event-Triggered Sampling: Application to Decentralized Detection and Estimation

Title_Other.Title: CIF: Medium Projects: Event-Triggered Sampling: Application to Decentralized Detection and Estimation
CIF：中型项目：事件触发采样：在分散检测和估计中的应用

Class.ClassName: 理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract: Sampling continuous-time signals constitutes a fundamental process in the modern digital technology era. This research investigates a novel class of event-triggered samplers, in which the sampling times are dictated in a dynamic way by the actual signals to be sampled. The richness of the event-triggered sampling schemes allows for the mathematical formulation of meaningful optimization problems that can lead to sampling strategies with optimal characteristics and resulting in potentially significant performance gains. The theories and techniques to be developed in this project can potentially make significant contributions to important application areas such as sensor network systems for event surveillance and monitoring, and networked control systems for smart-grid-based power generation and distribution. This research focuses on three major problems in the general areas of decentralized statistical signal processing, namely, sequential detection (hypothesis testing and changepoint detection), parameter estimation, and signal estimation and control. In all three problems, optimal event-triggered mechanisms will be investigated that can optimize the corresponding detection or estimation performance. In addition, a special class of event-triggered samplers will be analyzed and the corresponding design methods for digital signal processing (DSP) will be developed .This research will have transformative impacts on the fields of statistical signal processing and digital signal processing. In particular, the use of event-triggered sampling in detection, estimation and control can significantly improve the performance in a decentralized setup and simplify considerably the communication requirements in terms of power and bandwidth.

采样连续时间信号是现代数字技术时代的一个基本过程。研究了一类新型事件触发采样器，其采样时间由实际采样信号动态决定。事件触发采样方案的丰富性允许数学公式化有意义的优化问题，这些问题可以导致具有最佳特性的采样策略，并导致潜在的显著性能提高。本项目将要开发的理论和技术可能对重要应用领域做出重大贡献，如用于事件监视和监测的传感器网络系统，以及基于智能电网的发电和配电网络控制系统。本文主要研究分散统计信号处理中的三个主要问题，即序列检测（假设检验和变点检测）、参数估计和信号估计与控制。在这三个问题中，将研究能够优化相应检测或估计性能的最优事件触发机制。此外，本文还分析了一类特殊的事件触发采样器，并提出了相应的数字信号处理（DSP）设计方法，将对统计信号处理和数字信号处理领域产生革命性的影响。特别是，在检测、估计和控制中使用事件触发采样可以显著提高分散设置中的性能，并大大简化功率和带宽方面的通信要求。

Source.Name: Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering

Project.Title: Investigation of EGFR Inter-domain Relations and Their Roles in Lung Cancer Drug Resistance

Title_Other.Title: EGFR跨域关系及其在肺癌耐药中的作用
Investigation of EGFR Inter-domain Relations and Their Roles in Lung Cancer Drug Resistance

Project.Abstract: Abstract as per original application: Lung cancer has the highest mortality rate among all cancer types and results in over a million deaths in the world yearly. Around 85% of lung cancer patients have non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). A major cause of NSCLC is the mutation of a protein called the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) in the tyrosine kinase (TK) domain. The first generation drugs, reversible EGFR TK inhibitors (TKIs), are effective initially for treating NSCLC, but almost all patients develop drug resistance after a period of time due to another EGFR mutation. Although recent second and third generation drugs are more effective, drug resistance can still occur, for example, through the activation of a downstream signaling pathway. We have made significant contributions to the analysis of NSCLC drug resistance. We have close collaborations with a genomics technology company and medical doctors at HKU and Queen Mary Hospital. Our research results have already been used by industry and in clinical work. However, our past work focused on EGFR mutants and the TK domain only. This project will address a much more challenging problem, how EGFR related proteins form homodimers and heterodimers and interact with each other, causing resistance even to new generations of drugs through downstream pathways. EGFR is a multi-domain protein and performs its biological functions through various dimerizations. The dimers can be formed due to interactions in different domains. Thus, it is important to investigate how mutations in the TK domain affect functions in other domains. We will develop advanced parametric spectral analysis, projection onto convex sets and probabilistic relaxation labeling based algorithms to identify interactions between EGFR and other proteins. The molecular dynamics data will be treated as non-stationary signals and tensor models will be employed to find the inter-domain relations. We will investigate the structural changes in different domains of EGFR for all known mutations that cause lung cancer and drug resistance. How these changes affect the dimer formation and influence the activities in related signaling pathways will be elucidated. We will study the possibility of targeting one or more proteins in the affected pathways to tackle the drug resistance problem. Through our research work, we can achieve a deep understanding of the drug resistance problem in NSCLC treatment. In addition to scientific contributions to a cutting-edge research area, this project will deliver powerful tools to medical doctors for personalized treatment of lung cancer patients and bring significant benefits to the society.

按原申请摘要： 肺癌是所有癌症类型中死亡率最高的一种，每年导致全球100多万人死亡。大约85%的肺癌患者患有非小细胞肺癌（NSCLC）。非小细胞肺癌的一个主要原因是酪氨酸激酶（TK）结构域中一种叫做表皮生长因子受体（EGFR）的蛋白质突变。第一代药物可逆性EGFR-TK抑制剂（TKIs）最初对NSCLC有效，但由于另一种EGFR突变，几乎所有患者在一段时间后都产生了耐药性。尽管最近的第二代和第三代药物更有效，但仍可能发生耐药性，例如通过激活下游信号通路。 我们对NSCLC的耐药性分析做出了重要贡献。我们与一家基因科技公司及港大及玛丽皇后医院的医生紧密合作。我们的研究成果已经被工业界和临床工作所采用。然而，我们过去的工作只关注EGFR突变体和TK结构域。这个项目将解决一个更具挑战性的问题，即EGFR相关蛋白如何形成同二聚体和异二聚体并相互作用，通过下游途径对新一代药物产生耐药性。 表皮生长因子受体（EGFR）是一种多结构域蛋白质，通过不同的二聚体作用发挥其生物学功能。二聚体的形成是由于不同区域的相互作用。因此，研究TK域的突变如何影响其它域的功能是很重要的。我们将开发先进的参数谱分析、凸集投影和基于概率松弛标记的算法来识别EGFR与其他蛋白质之间的相互作用。将分子动力学数据作为非平稳信号处理，利用张量模型求取域间关系。我们将研究所有已知的导致肺癌和耐药性突变的EGFR不同结构域的结构变化。这些变化如何影响二聚体的形成和相关信号通路的活性将被阐明。我们将研究在受影响的途径中靶向一个或多个蛋白质以解决耐药性问题的可能性。 通过我们的研究工作，我们可以对NSCLC治疗中的耐药问题有一个深入的了解。除了对前沿研究领域做出科学贡献外，该项目还将为医生提供强有力的工具，为肺癌患者的个性化治疗提供有力的工具，并为社会带来显著的效益。

Project.Title: BIOGENESIS OF THE GOLGI APPARATUS

Title_Other.Title: BIOGENESIS OF THE GOLGI APPARATUS
高尔基体的生物发生

Class.ClassName: 理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): Understanding the molecular mechanisms that establish and maintain the Golgi during development, cell division, and cellular stress are significant ongoing goals in biomedical research. Our long-term goal is to identify proteins required for Golgi structure and elucidate their mechanism. This work was initiated using an siRNA-based screen targeting candidates, especially golgins, and cell-based Golgi assembly assays followed by rescue after knockdown in conjunction with biochemical, permeabilized-cell, structural, and computational assays. Our screen identified golgin-160 (G160) as a critical requirement for inward motility of Golgi membranes and showed that its absence arrests Golgi assembly at the dispersed ministack stage impairing directed secretion and cell migration during wound healing. This observation raised the possibility that we could answer fundamental questions concerning the unknown identity and regulation of the motor receptor complex that moves secretory cargo and Golgi membranes inward along microtubules. To test the hypothesis that G160 recruits or activates the dynein motor complex we will 1) identify and functionally characterize its interaction with the motor cytoplasmic dynein, 2) identify and functionally characterize its Arf1-dependent interaction with the Golgi membrane, 3) test the acute dependence of the Golgi on G160-based motility by developing a technique to inactivate G160 using light in a time scale of seconds, and 4) elucidate the control mechanism that allows Golgi dispersal and inheritance during cell division. These aims are supported by key preliminary findings. G160 was required for microtubule +tip capture of Golgi membranes. The G160 C-term bound directly to the intermediate chain of the dynein complex. G160 was required for dynein Golgi association and it was also sufficient for functional motor recruitment as G160 targeted to mitochondria recruited dynein and induced mitochondrial inward motility. The G160 N-term mediated its Arf1-dependent membrane association and its binding was regulated such that G160 cycled to the cell periphery and returned inward on microtubules. Photo-inactivation of G160 showed that the Golgi acutely depends on G160-based inward motility because early Golgi enzymes constantly cycle to the cell periphery. Finally, G160 dissociated from the Golgi at mitosis but remained bound to dynein and collected at spindle poles. Thus, our experiments are poised to uncover components in the long-sought Golgi receptor for the dynein motor and elucidate the regulation that uncouples Golgi membranes from microtubule-based motility to allow Golgi partitioning into daughter cells.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): Understanding the molecular mechanisms that establish and maintain the Golgi during development, cell division, and cellular stress are significant ongoing goals in biomedical research. Our long-term goal is to identify proteins required for Golgi structure and elucidate their mechanism. This work was initiated using an siRNA-based screen targeting candidates, especially golgins, and cell-based Golgi assembly assays followed by rescue after knockdown in conjunction with biochemical, permeabilized-cell, structural, and computational assays. Our screen identified golgin-160 (G160) as a critical requirement for inward motility of Golgi membranes and showed that its absence arrests Golgi assembly at the dispersed ministack stage impairing directed secretion and cell migration during wound healing. This observation raised the possibility that we could answer fundamental questions concerning the unknown identity and regulation of the motor receptor complex that moves secretory cargo and Golgi membranes inward along microtubules. To test the hypothesis that G160 recruits or activates the dynein motor complex we will 1) identify and functionally characterize its interaction with the motor cytoplasmic dynein, 2) identify and functionally characterize its Arf1-dependent interaction with the Golgi membrane, 3) test the acute dependence of the Golgi on G160-based motility by developing a technique to inactivate G160 using light in a time scale of seconds, and 4) elucidate the control mechanism that allows Golgi dispersal and inheritance during cell division. These aims are supported by key preliminary findings. G160 was required for microtubule +tip capture of Golgi membranes. The G160 C-term bound directly to the intermediate chain of the dynein complex. G160 was required for dynein Golgi association and it was also sufficient for functional motor recruitment as G160 targeted to mitochondria recruited dynein and induced mitochondrial inward motility. The G160 N-term mediated its Arf1-dependent membrane association and its binding was regulated such that G160 cycled to the cell periphery and returned inward on microtubules. Photo-inactivation of G160 showed that the Golgi acutely depends on G160-based inward motility because early Golgi enzymes constantly cycle to the cell periphery. Finally, G160 dissociated from the Golgi at mitosis but remained bound to dynein and collected at spindle poles. Thus, our experiments are poised to uncover components in the long-sought Golgi receptor for the dynein motor and elucidate the regulation that uncouples Golgi membranes from microtubule-based motility to allow Golgi partitioning into daughter cells.

描述（由申请人提供）：理解在发育、细胞分裂和细胞应激过程中建立和维持高尔基体的分子机制是生物医学研究的重要目标。我们的长期目标是鉴定高尔基结构所需的蛋白质并阐明其机制。这项工作是通过基于siRNA的筛选靶向候选基因（尤其是高尔金）和基于细胞的高尔基体组装分析以及生物化学、渗透性细胞、结构和计算分析启动的。我们的筛选结果表明，高尔基-160（G160）是高尔基膜向内运动的一个关键要求，并且表明它的缺失阻止了高尔基在分散的微钉阶段的组装，损害了伤口愈合过程中的定向分泌和细胞迁移。这一观察结果提出了一种可能性，即我们可以回答有关运动受体复合体的未知特性和调节的基本问题，这种运动受体复合体沿着微管向内移动分泌物质和高尔基膜。为了验证G160招募或激活动力蛋白运动复合物的假设，我们将1）识别和功能表征其与运动细胞质动力蛋白的相互作用，2）识别和功能表征其与高尔基膜的Arf1依赖性相互作用，3） 测试高尔基对基于G160的运动的急性依赖性，方法是开发一种在数秒的时间范围内使用光灭活G160的技术；4）阐明在细胞分裂过程中允许高尔基扩散和遗传的控制机制。这些目标得到了主要初步调查结果的支持。高尔基膜微管+顶端捕获需要G160。G160C项直接与动力蛋白复合物的中间链结合。G160是强力蛋白高尔基结合所必需的，而且它也足够用于功能性运动募集，因为G160靶向线粒体募集强力蛋白并诱导线粒体内向运动。G160 N-term介导其Arf1依赖的膜结合，其结合被调控，使G160循环到细胞周围并在微管上向内返回。G160的光失活显示高尔基体严重依赖于G160的内向运动，因为早期高尔基体酶不断循环到细胞周围。最后，G160在有丝分裂时与高尔基体分离，但仍与动力蛋白结合并在纺锤体极处聚集。因此，我们的实验准备揭示长期以来寻找的强力蛋白运动高尔基受体的组成成分，并阐明将高尔基膜与微管基运动分离的调节，以允许高尔基细胞分裂为子细胞。

Project.Abstract: Research geared towards the development of new therapies for numerous diseases including cancer, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. Study of angiogenic and lymphangiogenic signaling includes distinct approaches to study, including gene expression profiling, proteomics, transgenic and gene targeting in mice, and signal transduction. Project.Title: CONTROLLING MECHANISMS FROM THE MITOSIS AND THE CITOCINESIS

Title_Other.Title: MECCANISMI DI CONTROLLO DELL'USCITA DALLA MITOSI E DELLA CITOCHINESI
有丝分裂与citocines的调控机制

Class.ClassName: 自动化技术、自动化技术设备
理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract: During myositis, chromosomal segregation, inactivation of mitotic cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) at mitosis and formation of two daughter cells for cytokines are fundamental processes that need to be strictly regulated and coordinated in all eukaryotic cells to ensure genetic stability Of a cellular line. Their timing adjustment is via activation / inactivation of mitotic CDKs and proteolytic events mediated by the Anaphase Promoting Complex (APC) ubiquitin ligase. In addition, specific checkpoint mechanisms respond to alterations in the assembly / orientation of the mitotic fuselage (checkpoint of the melt) or the actin cytoskeleton (checkpoint morphogenetic), delaying the cell cycle transitions until errors have been corrected. The ultimate goal of this research is to get information on two largely unknown fundamental aspects of these controls: i) how events caused by checkpoints are integrated with other cycle controls; Ii) what are the connections between the release of the mitosis and the beginning of the cytokines. Classical genetic approaches will be combined with sophisticated biochemical techniques and cellular and molecular biology using three different organisms, S. cerevisiae yeast, Drosophila melanogaster mice and mouse. The three units will be continuously involved in the exchange of reagents and information with the following specific objectives: A) Understanding the role of PAK kinases in regulating the release of mitosis and cytokines; B) Study of the function and regulation of Citron kinase in the control of the cytokines. A) The role in controlling the release of the yeast Cla4 and Ste20 yeast kinase mitosis, which share an essential function in the cytokines, will be thoroughly studied by the Lucchini Unit, which has recently discovered it. This analysis will be conducted by constructing and analyzing appropriate strains to identify possible actors and interactions in this control, by studying the connections between the mud checkpoints and the morphogenetic checkpoints. The latter is in fact triggered by inactivation of PAK kinases, which in turn suppresses defects in the meltdown checkpoint. PAK kinases will also be studied by the Gatti and Cunto Units, which will evaluate the possible involvement in the cytokines and checkpoints of the Drosofila spell and in the regulation of Citron kinase kin. B) Citin kinase kinase (CIT-K), expressed by most proliferating mouse cells, is required for the cytokinesis of specific cell types, such as neuronal precursors and germinal testicular cells, and this also seems to be true For his homologue in Drosofila (DCIT-K). CIT-K knockout balls show brain malformations, very similar to those of human microlissencephals, and the in-depth characterization of CIT-K could also help clarify the molecular basis of these pathologies. The Cunto and Catti Units will study with several complementary approaches function and regulation of this kinase. Cunto's Unit seeks molecular partners, both using standard biochemical approaches, using the results obtained for CIT-K homologues in Drophophil and Yeast. After functional validation in cell culture lines, the functions of the identified genes can be tested in modified mice by gene targeting. The Cats Unit contributes to defining the function of DCIT-K and its dependence on other cytokine factors by immunolocalization studies in wild and mutant Drosophila strains. In addition, I undertake in close collaboration with the Unit of Cunto the search for factors that interact with DCIT-K.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: Durante la mitosi, segregazione cromosomica, inattivazione delle chinasi mitotiche ciclina-dipendenti (CDKs) allâ uscita dalla mitosi e formazione di due cellule figlie per citochinesi sono processi fondamentali, che devono essere strettamente regolati e coordinati in tutte le cellule eucariotiche per garantire la stabilit genetica di una linea cellulare. La loro regolazione temporale avviene tramite attivazione/inattivazione delle CDKs mitotiche ed eventi proteolitici mediati dallâ ubiquitina ligasi Anaphase Promoting Complex (APC). Inoltre, specifici meccanismi di checkpoint rispondono ad alterazioni nellâ assemblaggio/orientazione del fuso mitotico (checkpoint del fuso) o nel citoscheletro di actina (checkpoint morfogenetico), ritardando le transizioni del ciclo cellulare finchÃ© gli errori sono stati corretti. Lâ obiettivo finale di questa ricerca Ã¨ di ottenere informazioni su due aspetti fondamentali ancora largamente sconosciuti di questi controlli: i) come gli eventi causati dai checkpoints siano integrati con altri controlli del ciclo; ii) quali siano le connessioni fra lâ uscita dalla mitosi e lâ inizio della citochinesi. Classici approcci genetici verranno combinati con sofisticate tecniche biochimiche e di biologia cellulare e molecolare usando tre diversi organismi, il lievito S. cerevisiae, il moscerino Drosophila melanogaster e il topo. Le tre Unit saranno continuamente coinvolte in scambi di reagenti ed informazioni, con i seguenti obiettivi specifici: A) Comprensione del ruolo delle PAK chinasi nella regolazione dellâ uscita dalla mitosi e della citochinesi; B) Studio della funzione e regolazione della Citron chinasi nel controllo della citochinesi. A) Il ruolo nel controllo dellâ uscita dalla mitosi delle chinasi di lievito Cla4 e Ste20, che condividono una funzione essenziale nella citochinesi, verr studiato a fondo dallâ Unit Lucchini, che lo ha recentemente scoperto. Qestâ analisi verr condotta sia costruendo ed analizzando ceppi appropriati per definire possibili attori ed interazioni in questo controllo, che studiando le connessioni fra checkpoint del fuso e checkpoint morphogenetico. Questâ ultimo viene infatti attivato dallâ inattivazione delle PAK kinasi, che a sua volta sopprime difetti nel checkpoint del fuso. Le PAK chinasi verranno anche studiate dalle Unit Gatti e Di Cunto, che ne valuteranno rispettivamente il possibile coinvolgimento nella citochinesi e nel checkpoint del fuso di Drosofila e nella regolazione della Citron chinasi di topo. B) La serina/treonina chinasi CIT-K (Citron chinasi), espressa dalla maggior parte delle cellule proliferanti di topo, Ã¨ richiesta per la citochinesi di specifici tipi cellulari, come precursori neuronali e cellule germinali dei testicoli, e questo sembra vero anche per il suo omologo in Drosofila (DCIT-K). Topi CIT-K knockout mostrano malformazioni del cervello, molto simili a quelle delle microlissencefalie umane, e la caratterizzazione approfondita di CIT-K potrebbe contribuire anche a chiarire le basi molecolari di queste patologie. Le Unit Di Cunto e Gatti studieranno con diversi approcci complementari funzione e regolazione di questa chinasi. Lâ Unit Di Cunto ne cercher i partners molecolari, sia utilizzando approcci biochimici standard che sfruttando in topo i risultati ottenuti per gli omologhi di CIT-K in Drosofila e lievito. Dopo la validazione funzionale in linee cellulari in coltura, le funzioni dei geni identificati potranno essere saggiate in topi modificati mediante gene targeting. Lâ Unit Gatti contribuir a definire la funzione di DCIT-K e la sua dipendenza da altri fattori di citochinesi mediante studi di immunolocalizzazione in ceppi di Drosofila selvatici e mutanti. Inoltre, intraprender in stretta collaborazione con lâ Unit Di Cunto la ricerca di fattori che interagiscono con DCIT-K.

在肌炎过程中，染色体分离、有丝分裂时有丝分裂周期蛋白依赖性激酶（CDKs）失活和细胞因子两个子细胞的形成是所有真核细胞需要严格调控和协调的基本过程，以确保细胞系的遗传稳定性。它们的时间调节是通过有丝分裂cdk的激活/失活和后期促进复合物（APC）泛素连接酶介导的蛋白水解酶事件。此外，特定的检查点机制对有丝分裂体（熔体的检查点）或肌动蛋白细胞骨架（检查点形态发生）的装配/方向的改变作出反应，延迟细胞周期的转变，直到错误被纠正。 本研究的最终目的是获得关于这些控制的两个基本未知方面的信息：i）由检查点引起的事件如何与其他周期控制相结合；Ii）有丝分裂的释放和细胞因子的开始之间有什么联系。经典的遗传方法将结合复杂的生化技术和细胞和分子生物学，使用三种不同的生物，酿酒酵母，果蝇黑腹鼠和小鼠。这三个单位将继续参与试剂和信息的交流，具体目标如下：A）了解PAK激酶在调节有丝分裂和细胞因子释放中的作用；B）研究柠檬酸激酶在细胞因子控制中的功能和调节。 A）Lucchini单位将对控制酵母Cla4和Ste20有丝分裂的作用进行深入研究，后者在细胞因子中具有重要功能。该分析将通过构建和分析适当的菌株来进行，以确定该控制中可能的因素和相互作用，通过研究泥浆检查站和形态发生检查站之间的联系来进行。后者实际上是由PAK激酶失活触发的，而PAK激酶又抑制了熔毁检查点的缺陷。PAK激酶也将由Gatti和Cunto单位进行研究，该单位将评估Drosofila咒语的细胞因子和检查点以及Citron激酶kin的调节是否可能参与其中。 B）CIT in激酶（CIT-K）由大多数增殖的小鼠细胞表达，是特定细胞类型的胞质分裂所必需的，如神经元前体和生精睾丸细胞，这似乎也适用于Drosofila（DCIT-K）中的同系物。CIT-K基因敲除球显示脑畸形，与人类微裂头畸形非常相似，对CIT-K基因的深入研究也有助于阐明这些病理学的分子基础。Cunto和Catti单位将用几种互补的方法研究这种激酶的功能和调节。Cunto的研究小组使用标准的生化方法寻找分子伴侣，同时使用在滴虫和酵母中获得的CIT-K同系物结果。在细胞培养基中进行功能验证后，可以通过基因打靶的方法在转基因小鼠中检测所鉴定基因的功能。猫单位有助于确定DCIT-K的功能和依赖于其他细胞因子的野生和突变果蝇株的免疫定位研究。此外，我还与库托大学的单位密切合作，寻找与DCIT-K相互作用的因素。

Project.Title: Exploration of Transition Metal Carbenes for Catalytic Cross Coupling Reactions. Catalyst Design for Stereoselective and Asymmetric Carbon-Carbon Bond Formation

Title_Other.Title: 过渡金属卡宾催化交叉偶联反应的研究。立体选择性和不对称碳-碳键形成催化剂设计
Exploration of Transition Metal Carbenes for Catalytic Cross Coupling Reactions. Catalyst Design for Stereoselective and Asymmetric Carbon-Carbon Bond Formation

Class.ClassName: 金属元素、金属元素化合物
非金属元素、非金属元素化合物

Project.Abstract: (This application form GRF1 is for reference ONLY. All applications MUST be submitted to the RGC via the GRF EIS at: http://cerg1.ugc.edu.hk/.) GRF1 RGC Ref No. (c) Abstract of Research comprehensible to a non-specialist (a maximum of one A-4 page in standard RGC Format for attaching PDF documents or a maximum of 400 words for direct input in the text box): through modulating the outer-sphere reactivity of Transition metal-catalyzed diazo transformations via reactive metal-carbene complexes are powerful strategies for stereoselective and enantioselective carbon-carbon bond formation. Over the last decades, highly enantioselective catalytic alkene cyclopropanations and C-H bond insertions have been developed the metal-carbene complexes. Our development of catalytic carbenoid cross coupling reactions is based on two premises: (1) diazo compounds (carbene precursors) are effective nucleophiles for coordinatively unsaturated organometallic complexes, and (2) the carbene ligand would undergo migratory insertion resulting in carbon-carbon bond formation. Indeed, the migratory carbene insertion pathway (inner-sphere reactivity) for catalytic cross coupling reactions remains relatively unexplored. Previously, we developed a highly stereoselective synthesis of (E)-1,2-diarylacrylates by Pd-catalyzed coupling of arylboronic acids with diazoesters [Organic Letters, 2010, 12, 4506] at mild conditions (50 oC) with dioxygen as the sole oxidant. This reaction involves coupling of arylpalladium complexes with diazoesters as the principal step, followed by stereoselective -hydrogen elimination to afford the (E)-alkene product. By employing the migratory carbene insertion strategy, our first challenge is to develop a chiral synthesis of -aryl substituted carbonyl functionalities (e.g. ketones, acids, esters, amides) by catalytic coupling of organoboron / silicon with -diazocarbonyl compounds. Initially, our study is to establish a model catalytic system using chiral rhodium catalysts; enantioselective migratory carbene insertion of the organorhodium(I) would generate chiral oxa- -allylrhodium complexes bearing a stereogenic center at the carbenic carbon. Protonolysis of the latter would furnish enantioenriched -aryl carbonyl compounds, which are valuable scaffolds of pharmaceutical products. Experimental and computational studies will be undertaken to discern the mechanistic details and to establish the optimal ligand structures for attaining excellent enantioselectivtiy. The reactivity of the oxa- -allylrhodium complexes will be exploited to bring about tandem stereoselective carbon-carbon bond formation. In particular, catalytic reactions for constructing quaternary stereocenters will be explored. Development of catalytic direct functionalization of arenes / aliphatic alkanes constitutes another challenging area. Direct regioselective carbene C-H insertions to arenes and alkanes are less established. Based on the miagratory carbene insertion strategy, we would examine the formation of coordinatively unsaturated organotransition metal complexes by C-H bond activation with electron rich metal centers. With chiral chelating ligands, we hypothesize that enantioselective migratory carbene insertion would lead to formal asymmetric arene /alkane functionalization. It is hoped that our investigation would advance our knowledge of metal-carbene reactivitiy and offer new catalytic pathways for stereoselective carbon-carbon bond formations. The successful exploration of the migratory carbene insertion would expand the reaction manifolds and the substrate pools that complement the conventional carbenoid reactions. Our research in transition metal carbenoid cross coupling reactions should augment the current art of asymmetric synthesis. GRF1 (Aug 10) Page 2

Our research in transition metal carbenoid cross coupling reactions should augment the current art of asymmetric synthesis. GRF1 (Aug 10) Page 2

（本申请表格GRF1仅供参考。所有申请必须通过GRF EIS提交给RGC，地址：http://cerg1.ugc.edu.hk/） GRF1 RGC参考号。 （c）非专业人员可理解的研究摘要（在标准的RGC格式中最多有一个A4页，用于附加PDF文档或最多400个字，用于在文本框中直接输入）： 通过活性金属卡宾配合物调节过渡金属催化重氮转化的外层反应性，是形成立体选择性和对映选择性碳碳键的有力策略。近几十年来，金属卡宾配合物在催化烯烃环丙烷化反应和C-H键插入反应中得到了广泛的应用。我们发展催化碳-碳交叉偶联反应的前提是：（1）重氮化合物（卡宾前体）是配位不饱和金属有机配合物的有效亲核剂；（2）卡宾配体发生迁移插入，形成碳-碳键。事实上，用于催化交叉偶联反应的迁移卡宾插入途径（内球反应）仍相对未被探索。以前，我们开发了一个高度立体选择性合成（E）-1,2-二芳基丙烯酸酯通过钯催化偶联芳基硼酸与重氮酯[有机字母，2010, 12, 4506 ]在温和条件下（50 OC）与氧气作为唯一的氧化剂。该反应以芳基二钠配合物与重氮酯的偶联为主要步骤，然后进行立体选择性氢消除，得到（E）-烯烃产物。 采用迁移卡宾插入策略，我们的第一个挑战是通过有机硼/硅与-重氮羰基化合物的催化偶联来开发-芳基取代羰基功能物（如酮、酸、酯、酰胺）的手性合成。首先，我们的研究是建立一个使用手性铑催化剂的模型催化体系；有机铑（I）的对映选择性迁移卡宾插入将产生手性氧烯铑配合物，该配合物在卡宾碳上具有立体生成中心。后者的质子解反应将提供对映体富集的芳基羰基化合物，它们是有价值的医药产品支架。将进行实验和计算研究，以辨别机理细节，并建立最佳配体结构，以获得优良的对映体选择性。烯丙基铑配合物的反应性将被开发用来形成串联的立体选择性碳碳键。特别是，将探索用于构建四元立体中心的催化反应。芳烃/脂肪族烷烃催化直接功能化的发展是另一个具有挑战性的领域。直接区域选择性卡宾C-H插入芳烃和烷烃的研究较少。基于米格雷卡宾插入策略，我们研究了富电子金属中心C-H键活化形成配位不饱和有机过渡金属配合物。在手性螯合配体的作用下，我们假设对映选择性迁移卡宾的插入将导致形式的不对称芳烃/烷烃功能化。 希望我们的研究能提高我们对金属卡宾反应性的认识，为立体选择性碳碳键的形成提供新的催化途径。迁移卡宾插入的成功探索将扩大反应流形和底物池，以补充传统的卡宾反应。我们对过渡金属-碳烯酸交叉偶联反应的研究，应该扩大目前不对称合成的研究。 GRF1（8月10日）第2页

Project.Title: Dissertation Research: Effects of a Recent Population Size Bottleneck on Genetic Variation in Whooping Cranes

Title_Other.Title: Dissertation Research: Effects of a Recent Population Size Bottleneck on Genetic Variation in Whooping Cranes
论文研究：最近种群规模瓶颈对百日鹤遗传变异的影响

Class.ClassName: 公差测量、技术测量、机械量仪

Project.Abstract: 9321604 Stephan/Glenn The whooping crane is a well known endangered species that is successfully recovering from a severe reduction in population size (a population size bottleneck). Whooping cranes were reduced to one wild population with 14 adults in 1941, but now number more than 300 individuals. Additionally there are large numbers of whooping cranes in museum collections from previous historical populations. Because it is now possible to obtain genetic information from museum specimens, whooping cranes represent an opportunity to measure directly the loss of genetic variation in an uniquely well studied species that has experienced a population bottleneck. Stephan and Glenn propose to sequence and analyze mitochondrial and nuclear DNA loci of the whooping cranes. By obtaining genetic information from individuals that lived prior to, during, and following the most severe portion of the bottleneck, they will be able to compare the level of the genetic variation in whooping cranes with that predicted by population genetic models. Based on these comparisons, they will have the opportunity to assess the accuracy of theoretical models and to suggest the reintroduction strategy that most closely mimics the historical pattern of genetic variation among the populations of whooping cranes.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 9321604斯蒂芬/格伦百鸣鹤是一种著名的濒危物种，它正在从种群数量严重减少（种群数量瓶颈）中成功恢复。1941年，百鸣鹤减为一个野生种群，有14只成年鹤，但现在数量超过300只。此外，博物馆还收藏了大量历史人物的鸣鹤。因为现在有可能从博物馆标本中获得遗传信息，百鸣鹤代表了一个机会，可以直接测量一个独特的研究良好的物种的遗传变异损失，该物种已经经历了种群瓶颈。斯蒂芬和格伦建议对百日鹤的线粒体和细胞核DNA位点进行测序和分析。通过从生活在瓶颈最严重部分之前、期间和之后的个体获得遗传信息，他们将能够比较百日鸟的遗传变异水平和种群遗传模型预测的水平。在这些比较的基础上，他们将有机会评估理论模型的准确性，并提出最接近于百鸣鹤种群遗传变异历史模式的重新引入策略。

9321604 Stephan/Glenn The whooping crane is a well known endangered species that is successfully recovering from a severe reduction in population size (a population size bottleneck). Whooping cranes were reduced to one wild population with 14 adults in 1941, but now number more than 300 individuals. Additionally there are large numbers of whooping cranes in museum collections from previous historical populations. Because it is now possible to obtain genetic information from museum specimens, whooping cranes represent an opportunity to measure directly the loss of genetic variation in an uniquely well studied species that has experienced a population bottleneck. Stephan and Glenn propose to sequence and analyze mitochondrial and nuclear DNA loci of the whooping cranes. By obtaining genetic information from individuals that lived prior to, during, and following the most severe portion of the bottleneck, they will be able to compare the level of the genetic variation in whooping cranes with that predicted by population genetic models. Based on these comparisons, they will have the opportunity to assess the accuracy of theoretical models and to suggest the reintroduction strategy that most closely mimics the historical pattern of genetic variation among the populations of whooping cranes.

Project.Title: Closed-Shell Ion Pair Structure and Dynamics

Title_Other.Title: 闭壳离子对结构与动力学
Closed-Shell Ion Pair Structure and Dynamics

Project.Abstract: This grant from the Organic Dynamics Program supports the NMR spectroscopic studies of Professor Pochapsky at Brandeis University. The studies focus on the characterization of closed-shell ion pairs and ionic aggregates. The research on chiral and achiral ammonium cations with borohydride and chloride anions concentrates on the structures of ion-pairs, the effect of ion pairing on chemical reactivity, and dynamic self-assembling systems. The design of improved stereo-selectivity in phase-transfer catalysis is targeted. A broad spectrum of advanced NMR techniques will be used in conjunction with molecular modeling techniques and vibrational spectroscopy to illucidate the structural and dynamic properties of ion-pairs. In this spectroscopic project Dr. Pochapsky uses nuclear magnetic resonance techniques for the characterization of the structures, reactivities, and dynamic behavior of ion-pairs and ionic aggregates. These studies use chiral ammonium cations and are valuable for the design of improved chiral recognition in the important area of phase transfer catalysis. The combined use of advanced spectroscopic techniques and molecular modeling is of further interest to the chemical community.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 这项来自有机动力学计划的拨款支持布兰代斯大学波查普斯基教授的核磁共振波谱学研究。本文主要研究了封闭壳离子对和离子聚集体的性质。硼氢化和氯离子对手性和非手性铵离子的研究主要集中在离子对的结构、离子对化学反应性的影响以及动态自组装体系等方面。针对相转移催化中提高立体选择性的设计进行了研究。一系列先进的核磁共振技术将与分子模拟技术和振动光谱技术结合使用，以了解离子对的结构和动力学性质。在这个光谱项目中，波查普斯基博士使用核磁共振技术来表征离子对和离子聚集体的结构、反应性和动力学行为。这些研究利用了手性铵离子，对相转移催化这一重要领域中改进手性识别的设计具有一定的参考价值。将先进的光谱技术与分子模拟相结合是化学界进一步关注的问题。

The design of improved stereo-selectivity in phase-transfer catalysis is targeted. A broad spectrum of advanced NMR techniques will be used in conjunction with molecular modeling techniques and vibrational spectroscopy to illucidate the structural and dynamic properties of ion-pairs. In this spectroscopic project Dr. Pochapsky uses nuclear magnetic resonance techniques for the characterization of the structures, reactivities, and dynamic behavior of ion-pairs and ionic aggregates. These studies use chiral ammonium cations and are valuable for the design of improved chiral recognition in the important area of phase transfer catalysis. The combined use of advanced spectroscopic techniques and molecular modeling is of further interest to the chemical community.

Project.Title: Role of cell cycle signals in neuronal death

Title_Other.Title: 细胞周期信号在神经元死亡中的作用
Role of cell cycle signals in neuronal death

Project.Abstract: Neuronal cell death is an important event during brain development and in diseases related to the brain such as stroke. Recent efforts in this field have focused on understanding the regulatory processes which control one type of death known as apoptosis. Previous evidence indicated that certain signalling elements play a key role in controlling the apoptotic death of neurons and that these events are uniquely arranged depending upon cell type and the initiator of death. We have recently made the exciting observation that dying neurons utilize cell cycle components to signal for death. The present research is designed to uncover how these abnormal cell division signals actually cause death following ischemia and stroke. In understanding these pathways, we hope to, not only gain an appreciation for an important basic biological process, but also devise therapeutic strategies to treat brain injury conditions such as stroke.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: Neuronal cell death is an important event during brain development and in diseases related to the brain such as stroke. Recent efforts in this field have focused on understanding the regulatory processes which control one type of death known as apoptosis. Previous evidence indicated that certain signalling elements play a key role in controlling the apoptotic death of neurons and that these events are uniquely arranged depending upon cell type and the initiator of death. We have recently made the exciting observation that dying neurons utilize cell cycle components to signal for death. The present research is designed to uncover how these abnormal cell division signals actually cause death following ischemia and stroke. In understanding these pathways, we hope to, not only gain an appreciation for an important basic biological process, but also devise therapeutic strategies to treat brain injury conditions such as stroke.

神经元细胞死亡是脑发育过程中的一个重要事件，在脑卒中等与脑有关的疾病中也是如此。最近在这个领域的研究集中在了解控制一种叫做凋亡的死亡的调控过程。先前的证据表明，某些信号分子在控制神经元凋亡性死亡中起着关键作用，并且这些事件是根据细胞类型和死亡的始作俑者而独特安排的。我们最近做了一个令人兴奋的观察，即死亡的神经元利用细胞周期成分发出死亡信号。本研究旨在揭示这些异常的细胞分裂信号是如何导致缺血和中风后死亡的。在理解这些途径的过程中，我们不仅希望获得对一个重要的基本生物学过程的认识，而且还希望设计出治疗脑损伤的策略，例如中风。

Project.Title: Scholarship

Title_Other.Title: 奖学金
Stypendium naukowe

Source.Name: Ministry of Science and Higher Education

Project.Title: Genes, reproduction and inheritance in a microbe

Title_Other.Title: 微生物的基因、繁殖和遗传
Genes, reproduction and inheritance in a microbe

Project.Abstract: The project aims to particularly explore sexual gene inheritance in Plasmodium, a representative of a large group of human and animal parasites. Plasmodium must have a sexual exchange of genes in the mosquito for the transfer of disease to a new host. This project will investigate the fate and behaviour of Plasmodium genes during reproduction; the differing chromosome states resulting from sexual genetic processes and the asymmetrical inheritance of some Plasmodium genes. The project is expected to advance Australia’s ability to understand the reproduction and survival of these parasites in their mosquito vector and develop cutting-edge genetic tools that will advance the microbial genetics discipline globally. This may ultimately lead to biotechnology and biomedical outcomes.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 该项目旨在特别探索疟原虫的性基因遗传，疟原虫是一大类人和动物寄生虫的代表。疟原虫必须在蚊子体内进行基因的性交换，才能将疾病转移到新的宿主身上。该项目将研究疟原虫基因在生殖过程中的命运和行为；由于性遗传过程和一些疟原虫基因的不对称遗传而导致的染色体状态的不同。该项目预计将提高澳大利亚了解这些寄生虫在蚊子载体中的繁殖和存活情况的能力，并开发尖端的遗传工具，推动全球微生物遗传学学科的发展。这可能最终导致生物技术和生物医学成果。

The project aims to particularly explore sexual gene inheritance in Plasmodium, a representative of a large group of human and animal parasites. Plasmodium must have a sexual exchange of genes in the mosquito for the transfer of disease to a new host. This project will investigate the fate and behaviour of Plasmodium genes during reproduction; the differing chromosome states resulting from sexual genetic processes and the asymmetrical inheritance of some Plasmodium genes. The project is expected to advance Australia’s ability to understand the reproduction and survival of these parasites in their mosquito vector and develop cutting-edge genetic tools that will advance the microbial genetics discipline globally. This may ultimately lead to biotechnology and biomedical outcomes.

Project.Title: Symmetry Map and Symmetry Transforms for Shape Recovery and Object Recognition

Title_Other.Title: Symmetry Map and Symmetry Transforms for Shape Recovery and Object Recognition
用于形状恢复和目标识别的对称映射和对称变换

Project.Abstract: This project is concerned with the problem of recovery, representation, and recognition of shapes in images. The PI proposes to use the symmetry map, the shock graph of an edge map, as an intermediate-level representation for 2D shape. Deformations of shape are then expressed as a sequence of symmetry transforms which correspond to the inherent instabilities of skeletons (shock transitions). The optimal deformation path between two shapes is found using an edit distance approach to finding the least action sequence of transforms, or edits, on the shock graph. The cost of this path is used as a dissimilarity measure for indexing into image databases. This approach also allows for shape modeling and design, the construction of morphing sequences, and deformable templates. In 3D, The PI proposes to reduce the three-dimensional skeleton to a shock scaffold consisting of 1D space curves on which the 3D skeleton can be analytically constructed, leading to significant savings in recovery and storage of complex shapes, e.g., Michelangelo's Pieta, human lungs, etc. The research is generic and can potentially significantly impact a number of industrial and medical applications, including shape-based retrieval and construction of computational atlases.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 该项目涉及图像中形状的恢复、表示和识别问题。PI建议使用对称映射（边缘映射的冲击图）作为2D形状的中间层表示。然后，形状变形被表示为一系列对称变换，这些变换对应于骨骼的固有不稳定性（冲击跃迁）。两个形状之间的最佳变形路径是使用编辑距离方法在冲击图上找到变换或编辑的最小动作序列。此路径的成本用作索引到图像数据库的不同度量。这种方法还允许形状建模和设计、变形序列的构造和可变形模板。在3D中，PI建议将三维骨骼简化为一个由一维空间曲线组成的冲击支架，在该支架上可以解析地构建三维骨骼，从而大大节省复杂形状的恢复和存储，例如米开朗基罗的Pieta、人的肺等。这项研究是一般性的，并且可能具有重大意义影响许多工业和医学应用，包括基于形状的检索和计算地图集的构建。

This project is concerned with the problem of recovery, representation, and recognition of shapes in images. The PI proposes to use the symmetry map, the shock graph of an edge map, as an intermediate-level representation for 2D shape. Deformations of shape are then expressed as a sequence of symmetry transforms which correspond to the inherent instabilities of skeletons (shock transitions). The optimal deformation path between two shapes is found using an edit distance approach to finding the least action sequence of transforms, or edits, on the shock graph. The cost of this path is used as a dissimilarity measure for indexing into image databases. This approach also allows for shape modeling and design, the construction of morphing sequences, and deformable templates. In 3D, The PI proposes to reduce the three-dimensional skeleton to a shock scaffold consisting of 1D space curves on which the 3D skeleton can be analytically constructed, leading to significant savings in recovery and storage of complex shapes, e.g., Michelangelo's Pieta, human lungs, etc. The research is generic and can potentially significantly impact a number of industrial and medical applications, including shape-based retrieval and construction of computational atlases.

Source.Name: Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering

Project.Title: Synthesis, study and functionalization of redox-active molecular nanomagnets

Title_Other.Title: 氧化还原活性分子纳米磁体的合成、研究及功能化
Synthesis, study and functionalization of redox-active molecular nanomagnets

Class.ClassName: 自动化技术、自动化技术设备

Project.Abstract: The miniaturization of electronic components is a major challenge. In computer sciences, it is expected by 2019 that Moore’s law will not be able to be respected with classical “top-down” strategies for miniaturization (photolithography…). New approaches and new techniques need to be developed. For data storage and information processing, a potential solution to this large problem can come in the form of single-molecule magnets (SMMs) or single chain magnets (SCMs) as these materials show appealing and potentially useful properties at the molecular scale. Their ability to store information at a nanometric scale makes them ideal candidates for future information storage devices as they offer a potentially much higher information storage density. In addition, their quantum properties can also be used as “qubit” for future quantum computers. This research project aims at the synthesis, the study and the functionalization of new redox-active SMMs or SCMs with enhanced properties, through a rational design of the molecular components. The redox activity will be provided either by the metal centre or the bridging ligand, or both. This will allow us to tune and sometimes to enhance significantly the magnetic properties of the resulting molecular architectures, with the goal of making molecular magnets with higher operating temperatures, which is a long standing challenge in this research area and a requirement for industrial applications. The first step for this project will be to make a new class of ligand specially designed i) to act as a redox-active bridge between the metallic spin carriers with the possibility of being stabilized in a radical form, ii) to promote the formation of metal carbon bonds, iii) to stabilize delocalized mixed valence states to promote interesting electronic, optical and improved magnetic properties. For the metallic spin carrier, the primary focus will be on using 4d/5d metal for several reasons, explained in this proposal, which make them ideal candidates to promote higher operating temperature for the SMMs and SCMs they will be part of. Initially bimetallic “prototype” systems will be synthesised by reaction of the bridging ligand with “capped” metal centres. This will allow us to undertake complete magnetic and electronic studies of both the metal centres and ligand within the complex. The isolation of these prototype systems will allow the selection of the most interesting building blocks for the synthesis of polynuclear complexes as potential SMMs as well as one dimensional coordination networks with potential SCM properties, with a better understanding of their behaviour. All these new potential enhanced SMMs/SCMs will be fully characterized and investigated. As well as creating a number of new potential SMMs/SCMs, the bridging ligand will be functionalized by different suitable groups in order to i) “tune” its redox/electronic properties, ii) to increase the solubility, iii) isolate magnetically the complexes or chains, iv) add liquid crystalline properties to the molecular assemblies toward organized magnetically active films. All the new isolated complexes or chains will be fully characterized by a large number of techniques including X-ray diffraction, cyclic voltammetry, UV/Vis/NIR and IR spectrometry, NMR, calorimetry, SQUID magnetometry and EPR. This will give us a comprehensive understanding of all the properties of the new complexes. The achievement of this innovative and ambitious research proposal should have a strong impact in the molecular magnetism community, and could contribute to the next generation of some basic components of computers.

This will give us a comprehensive understanding of all the properties of the new complexes. The achievement of this innovative and ambitious research proposal should have a strong impact in the molecular magnetism community, and could contribute to the next generation of some basic components of computers.

电子元件的小型化是一大挑战。在计算机科学领域，预计到2019年，摩尔定律将无法得到经典的“自上而下”小型化（光刻）策略的尊重。需要开发新的方法和新技术。对于数据存储和信息处理来说，解决这一大问题的一个潜在办法是采用单分子磁体（smms）或单链磁体（scms），因为这些材料在分子尺度上显示出吸引人的潜在有用特性。它们以纳米尺度存储信息的能力使它们成为未来信息存储设备的理想候选，因为它们提供了潜在的更高的信息存储密度。此外，它们的量子特性也可以作为未来量子计算机的“量子位”。本课题旨在通过合理的分子组分设计，合成、研究和功能化具有增强性能的新型氧化还原活性表面活性剂或表面活性剂。氧化还原活性将由金属中心或桥配体提供，或两者都提供。这将使我们能够调整并有时显著增强所得到的分子结构的磁性，以期制备具有更高工作温度的分子磁体，这是这一研究领域的长期挑战，也是工业应用的要求。该项目的第一步将是制造一种特别设计的新配体，i）作为金属自旋载体之间的氧化还原活性桥，有可能以自由基形式稳定下来，ii）促进金属碳键的形成，iii）稳定非定域混合价态，以促进有趣的电子、光学和改进的磁性。对于金属自旋载体，主要关注的是使用4d/5d金属的几个原因，在本提案中解释了这些原因，使它们成为促进其所属的smms和scms的更高工作温度的理想候选者。最初，双金属“原型”系统将通过桥联配体与“带帽”金属中心的反应合成。这将使我们能够对配合物中的金属中心和配体进行完整的磁学和电学研究。这些原型系统的分离将允许选择合成多核配合物的最有趣的构建块作为潜在的smms以及具有潜在scm特性的一维配位网络，从而更好地理解它们的行为。所有这些新的潜在增强型表面贴装/表面贴装质谱将得到充分的表征和研究。除了创造许多新的潜在的SMMS/SCMS外，桥联配体还将由不同的合适基团进行功能化，以i）“调节”其氧化还原/电子性质，ii）增加溶解度，iii）磁分离配合物或链，iv）将液晶特性添加到分子组装中，以形成有组织的磁活性薄膜。所有新分离的配合物或链都将通过x射线衍射、循环伏安法、uv/vis/nir和ir光谱、nmr、量热法、squid磁强计和epr等技术进行全面表征。这将使我们对新配合物的所有性质有一个全面的了解。这项具有创新性和雄心勃勃的研究计划的完成，将对分子磁学界产生重大影响，并有助于下一代计算机的一些基本组件。

Project.Title: CompBio: A New Paradigm of Protein Threading: simultaneous backbone threading and side-chain packing prediction.

Title_Other.Title: CompBio：一种新的蛋白质穿线模式：同时进行主链穿线和侧链包装预测。
CompBio: A New Paradigm of Protein Threading: simultaneous backbone threading and side-chain packing prediction.

Project.Abstract: The knowledge of the tertiary structure is essential to understanding of the biological function and functional mechanism of a protein. The importance of computational solution to protein structures is increasing owing to the rapid growth in the number of sequenced genomes, and the relatively slow growth rate in the number of experimentally determined protein structures. Here we propose to develop a new paradigm for threading-based protein structure prediction using side-chain information. While residue-based approaches have made threading computationally feasible to predict protein structures in the past decade, we clearly see an urgent need now for more accurate prediction techniques that can provide structural data at higher resolution, to meet the rapidly growing need of structural and functional genomics studies. To address this challenging issue, we will develop a novel computational framework for solving a generalized threading problem, in which backbone threading and side-chain packing are predicted simultaneously. Specifically, we will (a) develop a new energy function that combines residue-level information for backbone threading and atom-level information for side-chain packing; (b) develop a novel algorithmic framework for solving the generalized threading problem; (c) extend this algorithmic framework to deal with more general threading problems such as constrained threading problems; (d) test and evaluate the new threading energy functions and algorithms to demonstrate the feasibility and the power of using side-chain information in protein structure prediction, and (e) develop a freely accessible web-based prediction server to benefit the entire research community. To the best of our knowledge, this project probably represents the first systematic effort in generalizing the current threading paradigm to include the detailed side-chain information during the threading process. While the side-chain information should help to significantly improve the prediction accuracy and resolution of protein structures, the generalized threading problem raises some very challenging computational problems. We expect that this new threading capability, when fully developed and implemented, will significantly improve the state of the art of protein structure prediction. In addition, the new threading energy functions and the algorithmic techniques developed in this project will prove to be useful to other researchers in their own development of protein structure prediction capabilities. We believe that our new threading framework will lead the way in developing a new generation of prediction techniques for protein structures, which will not only provide much more accurate backbone structures compared to the existing threading methods but also provide a big portion of the missing structural information by the current threading techniques, i.e., the side-chains. This project provides an ideal training ground for both undergraduate and graduate students to learn bioinformatics tool development for solving complex biological problems. A new course on "Algorithms for Protein Structure Prediction and Modeling" will be developed based on the research results of this project, which will be offered to both undergraduate and graduate students.

了解蛋白质的三级结构对理解蛋白质的生物学功能和功能机制至关重要。由于测序基因组数量的快速增长和实验确定的蛋白质结构数量的相对缓慢增长，计算解对蛋白质结构的重要性日益增加。本文提出了一种利用侧链信息进行基于线程的蛋白质结构预测的新方法。在过去的十年中，基于残基的方法已经使线程计算在预测蛋白质结构上变得可行，但我们清楚地看到，现在迫切需要更精确的预测技术，能够以更高的分辨率提供结构数据，以满足结构和功能基因组学研究迅速增长的需要。为了解决这个具有挑战性的问题，我们将开发一个新的计算框架来解决一个广义线程问题，在这个框架中，主干线程和边链包装同时被预测。具体来说，我们将（a）开发一个新的能量函数，将主干线程的剩余级信息和侧链打包的原子级信息结合起来；（b）开发一个新的算法框架来解决广义线程问题；（c）扩展此算法框架来处理更一般的线程问题，例如约束线程问题；（d）测试和评估新的线程能量函数和算法，以证明在蛋白质结构预测中使用侧链信息的可行性和能力；（e）开发一个可自由访问的基于web的预测服务器，以造福整个研究界。据我们所知，这个项目可能代表了对当前线程范例进行概括的第一个系统工作，以便在线程过程中包含详细的侧链信息。虽然侧链信息有助于显著提高蛋白质结构的预测精度和分辨率，但广义线程问题提出了一些非常具有挑战性的计算问题。我们期望这种新的线程能力，在充分开发和实现后，将大大提高蛋白质结构预测的技术水平。此外，本课题所开发的新的线程能量函数和算法技术，将对其他研究人员在自身蛋白质结构预测能力的开发方面具有一定的参考价值。我们相信新的线程框架将引领新一代蛋白质结构预测技术的发展，与现有的线程方法相比，它不仅能提供更精确的主干结构，而且能提供当前线程技术（即侧链）丢失的大部分结构信息。该项目为本科生和研究生提供了一个学习生物信息学工具开发以解决复杂生物问题的理想培训基地。在本课题研究成果的基础上，将开设“蛋白质结构预测与建模算法”新课程，面向本科生和研究生。

Source.Name: Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering

Project.Title: AgreenSkills+

Title_Other.Title: 同意杀人+
AgreenSkills+

Class.ClassName: 西洋器乐理论、西洋器乐演奏法

Project.Abstract: Further to the high interest and response to the AgreenSkills programme launched in 2012, INRA and Agreenium have decided to set up a ‘phased-in’ 5 years follow-up programme ‘AgreenSkills+’. The overall goal of the AgreenSkills international mobility programme is to increase the research potential (and thus career prospective) of researchers in the field of Agriculture, Environment and Nutrition so as to better respond to the challenges of food security and global change. AgreenSkills+ offers a wider scope of eligibility and a greater number of fellowships for basic and applied research projects as a means of both responding to the demand and to fulfilling the long-term ambitions of the partner organisations: - 200 fellow years of which 28% outgoing and 72% incoming over the 5 years. The capacity of outgoing mobility will be significantly increased from 14 to 28 fellows. -Fellowships for more experienced researchers (up to 10 years post PhD) than the current programme. -Extending fellowships to up to 3 years for incoming fellows. -Wider opportunities thanks to the larger number of Agreenium partners acting as hosting institutions (9 as oppose to 6 currently) -Partnerships with non-national institutions to stimulate mobility and set-up long-term twinning/exchange programmes with these institutions. -Individualised career development support and training (via the AgreenSkills Pass). The AgreenSkills+ programme will be ‘phased in’ for the 1st year so that there is no eligibility or funding overlap with the current programme. The further calls of the AgreenSkills+ programme will cover the full range of eligibility criteria. There will be a seamless continuity to the AgreenSkills+ programme from an evaluation, management and hosting capacity perspective. AgreenSkills+ as its predecessor is based on flexibility and openness with a broad range of topics, open calls and individual support in finding the most appropriate receiving lab so as to attract the best candidates.

由于对2012年启动的Agreenskills计划的高度关注和响应，印度研究所和Agreenium决定设立一个“分阶段”的5年后续计划“Agreenskills+”。Agreenskills国际流动方案的总体目标是增加农业、环境和营养领域研究人员的研究潜力（从而提高其职业前景），以便更好地应对粮食安全和全球变化的挑战。 Agreenskills+为基础和应用研究项目提供了更广泛的资格范围和更多的研究金，作为满足需求和实现合作组织长期抱负的一种手段： -200人，其中28%在5年内离职，72%在5年内入职。从14名研究员到28名研究员的离职流动能力将大大提高。 -为更有经验的研究人员提供的研究金（博士后最多10年）比目前的方案要多。 -将新入职研究员的奖学金延长至3年。 -由于有更多的Agreenium合作伙伴作为托管机构（目前有9个，而不是6个），所以机会更大。 -与非国家机构建立伙伴关系，促进流动，并与这些机构建立长期的结对/交流方案。 -个性化的职业发展支持和培训（通过Agreenskills通行证）。 Agreenskills+计划将在第一年“分阶段实施”，因此没有资格或资金与当前计划重叠。Agreenskills+计划的进一步呼吁将涵盖所有资格标准。从评估、管理和托管能力的角度来看，Agreenskills+计划将保持无缝的连续性。GraseSks+ +的前身是基于灵活性和开放性，具有广泛的主题、公开电话和个人支持，以找到最合适的接收实验室，以吸引最佳候选人。

Project.Title: Women Workers in the Southern Piedmont, 1870-1940

Title_Other.Title: 1870-1940年南皮德蒙特的女工
Women Workers in the Southern Piedmont, 1870-1940

Project.Title: Determining feedback mechanisms between cell cycle and cell fate in pluripotent cells

Title_Other.Title: 多能干细胞周期与细胞命运反馈机制的研究
Determining feedback mechanisms between cell cycle and cell fate in pluripotent cells

Project.Abstract: Project Summary/Abstract Embryonic stem cells (ESCs) hold great promise for medicine because they can be propagated to virtually unlimited numbers and can generate any disease relevant cell type. ESCs have three unique cell biological features that make them distinct from somatic cell lineages: (i) A pluripotency transcriptional network that promotes its own activity; (ii) An atypically rapid cell cycle with short G1 phase that lacks a typical restriction point; (iii) An atypical response to Mitogen Activated Protein Kinase (MAPK) activity1?3. While a lot of attention has focused on the maintenance of ESC pluripotency by a transcriptional network, research on the ESC cell cycle network has been largely descriptive, and the mechanistic links between the two networks have yet to be explored. In addition, a critical but poorly understood process is how ESCs use MAPK pathway to control the exit from pluripotency. My long-term career goal is to discover the molecular mechanisms that allows ESCs to choose between two conflicting fates, i.e, self-renewal vs. fate commitment. The driving hypothesis of this proposal is that the ESC-specific cell cycle is functionally linked with the transcriptional pluripotency network by mutual, positive feedback that is regulated by upstream activity of MAPK signaling. To test this hypothesis, we propose to investigate the function of phosphorylation sites on the pluripotency factors using both genetic and biochemical methods (Aim1). We will employ single cell quantitative imaging to measure dynamics of cell cycle in ESCs expressing reporters of pluripotency and cell cycle. To test if pluripotency factors directly promote cell cycle progression, we are proposing to develop a novel method by repurposing the CRISPR/Cas9 technology to examine the function of specific transcription factor binding sites in vivo (Aim2). To determine how MAPK signaling regulates exit from pluripotency, we will combine protein engineering and quantitative phosphoproteomics to uncover novel targets of this pathway (Aim3). Completion of these aims will reveal the mechanisms by which ESCs choose between opposing fates, i.e. self-renewal vs. fate commitment. During the training phase of this award (K99), I plan to leverage quantitative insight of Skotheim?s lab to advance an interdisciplinary research plan to study cell fate in pluripotent cells in my lab. To this end, I have established collaboration with Wernig?s lab (Stanford), Qi?s lab(Stanford) and Macek?s lab(Tubingen University, Germany) that will greatly facilitate the progress of my research project. To prepare for transition to an independent investigator, I will take part in career training courses such as The Future Faculty Series that are offered by Stanford University. In addition to representing an important advance in basic biological sciences, our mechanistic insight may facilitate propagation and lineage differentiation of ESCs for regenerative medicine.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 项目摘要/摘要胚胎干细胞（ESCs）具有巨大的医学前景，因为它们可以繁殖到几乎无限的数量，可以产生任何与疾病相关的细胞类型。ESCs具有三个独特的细胞生物学特性，使其不同于体细胞系：（i）一个促进自身活性的多能转录网络；（ii）一个具有短G1期的非典型快速细胞周期，缺乏典型的限制点；（iii）对丝裂原活化蛋白激酶（MAPK）活性的非典型反应1？三。虽然许多研究集中在通过转录网络维持ESC多能性上，但对ESC细胞周期网络的研究在很大程度上是描述性的，这两个网络之间的机制联系尚待探索。此外，一个关键但不清楚的过程是ESCs如何利用MAPK途径来控制多能性的退出。我的长期职业目标是发现让esc在两个相互冲突的命运中做出选择的分子机制，即自我更新与命运承诺。这一提议的驱动性假设是，ESC特异性细胞周期通过相互的、正反馈与转录多能性网络在功能上相连，而正反馈是由MAPK信号的上游活性调节的。为了验证这一假设，我们提出用遗传和生化方法研究磷酸化位点对多能性因子的作用（Aim1）。我们将使用单细胞定量成像技术来测量表达多能性和细胞周期的ESCs中细胞周期的动态。为了验证多能性因子是否直接促进细胞周期的进展，我们提出利用CRISPR/Cas9技术来检测体内特定转录因子结合位点（Aim2）的功能，从而开发一种新的方法。为了确定MAPK信号如何调节多能性的退出，我们将结合蛋白质工程和定量磷酸蛋白质组学来揭示该途径的新靶点（Aim3）。这些目标的完成将揭示esc在对立命运之间选择的机制，即自我更新与命运承诺。在这个奖项（K99）的培训阶段，我计划利用斯科瑟姆的定量洞察力？为了推进一个跨学科的研究计划，在我的实验室里研究多能干细胞的命运。为此，我与Wernig建立了合作关系？s实验室（斯坦福），齐？s实验室（斯坦福）和梅斯克？s实验室（德国图宾根大学），这将大大促进我的研究项目的进展。为了准备成为一名独立调查员，我将参加职业培训课程，如斯坦福大学提供的未来教师系列课程。除了代表基础生物学的一个重要进展，我们的机械洞察力可能有助于再生医学的胚胎干细胞的繁殖和谱系分化。

Source.Name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

Project.Title: High-Beam-Quality, High-Average-Power Yb:YAG Lasers

Title_Other.Title: High-Beam-Quality, High-Average-Power Yb:YAG Lasers
高光束质量、高平均功率Yb:YAG激光器

Class.ClassName: 激光技术、微波激射技术

Project.Abstract: Precision tracking of airborne targets, atmospheric sensing, and active imaging require high-average-power, high-beam-quality laser sources. We propose to address these requirements through the use of a side-pumped Yb:YAG laser where high beam quality isachieved by multi-passing the fundamental mode of the laser resonator several times through the gain region to effi-ciently extract the stored energy. The pump sources will be coupled to the Yb:YAG crystal using multimode fibers. This allows forflexibility in design and for the laser output power to be scaled to hundreds of watts by increasing the number of fibers pumping the crystal or the pump power in each fiber. In our proposed design, heat is removed from the laser crystal by direct contactto heat sinks; flowing liquid contacting the crystal is not required as it is in many high-average-power laser schemes, allowing the use of a variety of cooling schemes. Thermal lensing, which can cause aberration of the output beam, is kept low byspreading the heat load over a large area and minimizing the distance between the heat load and heat sinks. The use of Yb:YAG will also contribute to reduced thermal lensing due to its low quantum defect and high thermal conductivity. We anticipate thatthe lasers to be developed under this program would have wide applicability in laser machining and material processing. Specifically marking, drilling, cutting, welding, scribing, and ablation applications would benefit. Also, because of the high beamquality, harmonic conversion to other wavelengths for tailored laser machining applications would be very efficient. Military applications, where high beam quality illuminators are needed, would also be pursued.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: Precision tracking of airborne targets, atmospheric sensing, and active imaging require high-average-power, high-beam-quality laser sources. We propose to address these requirements through the use of a side-pumped Yb:YAG laser where high beam quality isachieved by multi-passing the fundamental mode of the laser resonator several times through the gain region to effi-ciently extract the stored energy. The pump sources will be coupled to the Yb:YAG crystal using multimode fibers. This allows forflexibility in design and for the laser output power to be scaled to hundreds of watts by increasing the number of fibers pumping the crystal or the pump power in each fiber. In our proposed design, heat is removed from the laser crystal by direct contactto heat sinks; flowing liquid contacting the crystal is not required as it is in many high-average-power laser schemes, allowing the use of a variety of cooling schemes. Thermal lensing, which can cause aberration of the output beam, is kept low byspreading the heat load over a large area and minimizing the distance between the heat load and heat sinks. The use of Yb:YAG will also contribute to reduced thermal lensing due to its low quantum defect and high thermal conductivity. We anticipate thatthe lasers to be developed under this program would have wide applicability in laser machining and material processing. Specifically marking, drilling, cutting, welding, scribing, and ablation applications would benefit. Also, because of the high beamquality, harmonic conversion to other wavelengths for tailored laser machining applications would be very efficient. Military applications, where high beam quality illuminators are needed, would also be pursued.

精确跟踪空中目标、大气传感和主动成像需要高平均功率、高光束质量的激光源。我们建议使用侧面泵浦的Yb:YAG激光器来满足这些要求，在这种激光器中，通过多次将激光谐振器的基本模穿过增益区域来获得高光束质量，从而有效地提取存储的能量。泵浦源将使用多模光纤耦合到Yb:YAG晶体上。这使得设计的灵活性和激光输出功率可以通过增加抽运晶体的光纤数量或每根光纤中的抽运功率扩展到数百瓦。在我们提出的设计中，通过直接接触散热片来去除激光晶体中的热量；在许多高平均功率激光方案中，不需要流动的液体接触晶体，允许使用多种冷却方案。热透镜通过将热负荷分散在大面积上并使热负荷与散热片之间的距离最小化，使输出光束的像差保持在较低的水平。由于Yb:YAG具有低的量子缺陷和高的热导率，它的使用也将有助于降低热透镜效应。我们预计，在本计划下开发的激光器将在激光加工和材料加工中具有广泛的适用性。特别是标记、钻孔、切割、焊接、划线和烧蚀应用将受益。此外，由于高光束质量，为定制的激光加工应用，谐波转换到其他波长将是非常有效的。在需要高光束质量照明器的军事应用方面，也将继续努力。

Project.Title: The Higher Classification of the Ephemeroptera

Title_Other.Title: The Higher Classification of the Ephemeroptera
短翅目的高等分类

Class.ClassName: 基本建设组织、基本建设管理

Project.Title: REU Site: Ifugao Archaeological Project

Title_Other.Title: REU遗址：Ifugao考古项目
REU Site: Ifugao Archaeological Project

Project.Abstract: This project is supported under the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program, which is an NSF-wide program although each Directorate administers its own REU Site competition. This program supports active research participation by undergraduate students in an effort to introduce them to scientific research so as to encourage their continued engagement in the nation's scientific research and development enterprise. REU projects involve students in meaningful ways in ongoing research programs or in research projects designed especially for the purpose. The REU program is a major contributor to the NSF's goal of developing a diverse, internationally competitive, and globally-engaged science and engineering workforce. The Social, Behavioral and Economic (SBE) sciences Directorate awarded this REU Site grant to the University of California-Los Angeles in order to enhance undergraduate experience in scientific methods and analyses in a long-term research project at the UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Ifugao, Philippines. Students in this REU program are actively involved in investigating highland economic and political responses to the arrival of the Spanish in the northern Philippines. As an REU Site, the project recruits junior- and senior-level undergraduates from a wide-range of backgrounds, home institutions, ages, gender, and ethnicity, with emphasis on under-represented and female students. The PI-team strives to focus the recruitment on minority-serving institutions, including community colleges, by utilizing the institutional connections of the UCLA Academic Advancement Program-Center for Community College Partnerships. Students participating in the project are actively involved in the research design, data collection, and laboratory analysis of archaeologically retrieved materials. Students receive intensive training in archaeological field methods, faunal and botanical analyses, human osteology, and, artifact identification and cataloguing. Through the collaboration between UCLA (lead institution), University of Washington, University of Wisconsin-Madison, University of Philippines, the National Museum of the Philippines, and the Save the Ifugao Terraces Movement, Inc., students in this REU Site program receive intensive mentorship during and after the program. Although the Spanish failed to colonize the northern Philippine highlands, preliminary analysis of the archaeological record from Ifugao suggests drastic landscape and social transformations ensued after c. AD 1600. To determine the impacts of Spanish colonialism in highland Philippines, this research program conducts subsurface excavations, spatial modeling, and analyses of faunal and paleobotanical samples, artifacts, and human osteolical remains. The research program investigates the political and economic impacts of Spanish colonialism in highland Philippines, particularly, in the UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Ifugao, Philippines, where the most extensive rice terraces in the world are located. Previous models suggest that the rice terraces are at least 2,000 years old. Recent archaeological information, however, indicates that the agricultural marvels were constructed after the arrival of the Spanish in the northern Philippines at c. AD 1600. In addition, rapid social and environmental change occurred in the region shortly after AD 1600. This research provides another perspective to our understanding of Spanish colonialism, which has largely focused on the Americas. The Ifugao rice terraces are rapidly deteriorating and the Ifugao people are losing both their tangible and intangible heritage to changes brought about by economic and political transformations. The rice terraces are examples of landesque and the assimilation of Ifugao social organization to that of the state together with the low status given to farmers and the rapid disappearance of traditional knowledge could further spell degradation of the terraces. One of the overarching goals of this study is to contribute to heritage conservation programs in Ifugao, in both tangible and intangible heritage. As such, this REU Site engages the community by promoting direct and active participation of descendant communities. The project also helps with the establishment of a community museum and on-site museum to complement the development of indigenous culture and history curriculum. In addition, this program aims to encourage undergraduate students to pursue STEM-related and anthropology graduate studies. The NSF International Science and Engineering (ISE) program co-funds this REU Site project.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 这个项目是在大学生研究经验（REU）网站计划下支持的，这是一个全国性的计划，虽然每个董事会管理自己的REU网站竞争。该计划支持本科生积极参与研究，努力向他们介绍科学研究，以鼓励他们继续参与国家的科学研究和发展事业。REU项目以有意义的方式让学生参与正在进行的研究项目或专门为此目的设计的研究项目。REU计划是国家科学基金会发展多样化、具有国际竞争力和全球参与的科学和工程劳动力目标的主要贡献者。社会、行为和经济（SBE）科学理事会授予加州大学洛杉矶分校这一REU场地拨款，以加强在菲律宾伊夫高教科文组织世界遗产地长期研究项目中的科学方法和分析方面的本科生经验。参加这项REU计划的学生积极参与调查高地对西班牙人抵达菲律宾北部的经济和政治反应。作为一个REU网站，该项目招募来自不同背景、家庭机构、年龄、性别和种族的初级和高级本科生，重点是代表性不足和女性学生。PI团队通过利用加州大学洛杉矶分校学术进步计划中心的机构关系，努力将招聘重点放在少数族裔服务机构，包括社区学院。参与该项目的学生积极参与考古检索材料的研究设计、数据收集和实验室分析。学生接受考古领域方法、动植物分析、人体骨科学和人工制品鉴定和编目方面的强化培训。通过加州大学洛杉矶分校（牵头机构）、华盛顿大学、威斯康星大学麦迪逊分校、菲律宾大学、菲律宾国家博物馆和拯救伊夫高梯田运动公司之间的合作，参加这一REU现场项目的学生在项目期间和之后接受了密集的指导。尽管西班牙人未能殖民菲律宾北部高地，但对伊富高考古记录的初步分析表明，公元1600年后，景观和社会发生了剧烈的变化。为了确定西班牙殖民主义对菲律宾高地的影响，这项研究计划进行了地下挖掘、空间建模以及对动物区系和古植物标本、文物和人类骨化石的分析。这项研究计划调查西班牙殖民主义对菲律宾高地的政治和经济影响，特别是对联合国教科文组织（UNESCO）位于菲律宾伊夫高（Ifugao）的世界遗产地的影响，那里有世界上最广泛的水稻梯田。以前的模型表明，梯田至少有2000年的历史。然而，最近的考古资料表明，这些农业奇迹是公元1600年西班牙人到达菲律宾北部后建造的。此外，公元1600年后不久，该地区社会和环境发生了迅速变化。这项研究为我们理解西班牙殖民主义提供了另一个视角，西班牙殖民主义主要集中在美洲。伊富高梯田正在迅速恶化，伊富高人民正因经济和政治变革带来的变化而失去有形和无形遗产。水稻梯田是土地类型的例子，伊富高社会组织与国家社会组织的同化，加上农民地位低下，传统知识迅速消失，可能进一步导致梯田退化。这项研究的首要目标之一是为伊富高的有形和无形遗产保护项目做出贡献。因此，这个REU网站通过促进后代社区的直接和积极参与来吸引社区。该项目还帮助建立社区博物馆和现场博物馆，以补充土著文化和历史课程的发展。此外，该计划旨在鼓励大学生追求STEM相关和anth
