Source.Name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral & Economic Sciences

Project.Title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Testing Biodiversity-Ecosystem Functioning Relationships in an Ecological Stoichiometry Framework in the World's Largest Natural Grassland

Title_Other.Title: 合作研究：在全球最大天然草地的生态化学计量框架中测试生物多样性生态系统功能关系
COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Testing Biodiversity-Ecosystem Functioning Relationships in an Ecological Stoichiometry Framework in the World's Largest Natural Grassland

Class.ClassName: 环境生态系统、生态环境

Project.Abstract: Global sustainability and human prosperity ultimately depend on biodiversity and ecosystem services that result from ecological functions such as primary productivity and nutrient cycling. With accelerating biodiversity loss worldwide, it is critically important to understand how biodiversity and ecosystem functioning (BEF) are related. However, current knowledge is incomplete because almost all BEF studies so far have been conducted in artificial grasslands, focusing solely on plants. This project will directly manipulate plant diversity in large-scale experimental plots and measure a number of ecosystem function variables to test existing BEF and evaluate new hypotheses regarding ecosystem function for multiple trophic levels (plants, herbivores, and soil microbes) in the Inner Mongolian Grassland, part of the largest natural grassland in the world. This study will permit a better assessment of potential impacts of future global and local biodiversity loss. It will also improve management practices for arid and semi-arid ecosystems. The project will provide exceptional educational, cultural, and research experiences for US and Chinese scientists and students, and contribute to the development of a globally engaged workforce. Finally, it will help establish a long-term scientific platform in the Inner Mongolia Grassland for US-China collaborations on ecological research and sustainability science.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 全球的可持续性和人类的繁荣最终取决于生物多样性和生态系统服务，这些服务源于初级生产力和营养循环等生态功能。随着世界范围内生物多样性损失的加剧，了解生物多样性与生态系统功能之间的关系至关重要。然而，目前的知识是不完整的，因为几乎所有的BEF研究都是在人工草地上进行的，只关注植物。该项目将直接操纵大型试验区的植物多样性，并测量一些生态系统功能变量，以测试现有的BEF，并评估内蒙古草原（内蒙古最大的天然草地的一部分）多种营养水平（植物、食草动物和土壤微生物）的生态系统功能的新假设世界上的草原。这项研究将有助于更好地评估未来全球和地方生物多样性丧失的潜在影响。它还将改进干旱和半干旱生态系统的管理做法。该项目将为我们和中国的科学家和学生提供特殊的教育、文化和研究经验，并有助于发展一支全球参与的劳动力队伍。最后，将有助于在内蒙古草原建立中美生态研究和可持续发展科学合作的长期科学平台。

Global sustainability and human prosperity ultimately depend on biodiversity and ecosystem services that result from ecological functions such as primary productivity and nutrient cycling. With accelerating biodiversity loss worldwide, it is critically important to understand how biodiversity and ecosystem functioning (BEF) are related. However, current knowledge is incomplete because almost all BEF studies so far have been conducted in artificial grasslands, focusing solely on plants. This project will directly manipulate plant diversity in large-scale experimental plots and measure a number of ecosystem function variables to test existing BEF and evaluate new hypotheses regarding ecosystem function for multiple trophic levels (plants, herbivores, and soil microbes) in the Inner Mongolian Grassland, part of the largest natural grassland in the world. This study will permit a better assessment of potential impacts of future global and local biodiversity loss. It will also improve management practices for arid and semi-arid ecosystems. The project will provide exceptional educational, cultural, and research experiences for US and Chinese scientists and students, and contribute to the development of a globally engaged workforce. Finally, it will help establish a long-term scientific platform in the Inner Mongolia Grassland for US-China collaborations on ecological research and sustainability science.

Project.Title: Mathematical Sciences: Linear Operators and Complex Variables

Title_Other.Title: Mathematical Sciences: Linear Operators and Complex Variables
数学科学：线性算子与复变量

Project.Abstract: 9500954 Putinar This project involves continued research in multivariable spectral theory and in the theory of hyponormal operators. In the first area, standard cohomological methods will be combined with hard analysis techniques of several complex variables in the study of a class of Hilbert modules over function algebras. In the second area, a novel correspondence between quadrature domains and hyponormal operators will be exploited and expanded in both directions. The research will focus on several new and not yet fully investigated relations between two areas of mathematical analysis: function theory and operator theory. The benefits are expected to be on both sides, with a great potential of further research and with applications to computational mathematics and quantum physics. ***

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 9500954 Putinar This project involves continued research in multivariable spectral theory and in the theory of hyponormal operators. In the first area, standard cohomological methods will be combined with hard analysis techniques of several complex variables in the study of a class of Hilbert modules over function algebras. In the second area, a novel correspondence between quadrature domains and hyponormal operators will be exploited and expanded in both directions. The research will focus on several new and not yet fully investigated relations between two areas of mathematical analysis: function theory and operator theory. The benefits are expected to be on both sides, with a great potential of further research and with applications to computational mathematics and quantum physics. ***

9500954 Putinar本项目涉及多变量谱理论和次正态算子理论的持续研究。在第一个领域中，标准上同调方法将与几个复变量的硬分析技术相结合，用于研究函数代数上的一类Hilbert模。在第二个领域中，我们将在两个方向上开发和扩展求积域和次正规算子之间的新对应关系。这项研究将集中在两个数学分析领域：函数理论和算子理论之间的一些新的和尚未完全研究的关系上。这两方面都有好处，具有进一步研究的巨大潜力，并在计算数学和量子物理中得到应用。***

Project.Title: Control of sex in Atlantic halibut: Towards production of monosex all-female stocks

Title_Other.Title: 大西洋大比目鱼的性别控制：单性繁殖
Control of sex in Atlantic halibut: Towards production of monosex all-female stocks

Project.Abstract: Producing all-female market-sized Atlantic halibut shows high potential to the industry because of sexual growth dimorphism in this species. It is proposed to undertake multidisciplinary research on mechanisms and control of sex determination and differen tiation in halibut in order to develop the strategy to produce monosex all-female stocks. The project involves several research groups with relevant expertise in the different research areas. We will search for sex-specific DNA sequences and conduct thoro ugh cytogenetics research to better understand sex determination.. We will induce gynogenetic development to verify female homogamety and to obtain genetically all-female progeny. We will undertake extensive research on altering phenotypic sex (sex revers al) in order to produce masculinized females (neo-males). The cell- and molecular-level effects of various agents on endocrine sex control will be investigated. Different strategies to produce all-female stocks will be examined. It is anticipated that the project will result in (i) substantial knowledge of genetic and endocrine sex control mechanisms in Atlantic halibut, (ii) development of efficient protocols to produce all-female halibut, and (iii) establishing neo-male broodstocks.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 由于大西洋大比目鱼有性生长的二型性，生产市场上所有雌性大比目鱼显示出很高的潜力。建议对大比目鱼性别决定和性别分化的机制和控制进行多学科研究，以制定生产单性别全雌性种群的战略。该项目涉及几个在不同研究领域具有相关专业知识的研究小组。我们将寻找性别特异的DNA序列，并进行细胞遗传学研究，以更好地了解性别决定。。我们将诱导雌核发育，以验证雌配子性，并获得遗传上所有的雌性后代。我们将对改变表型性别（性别逆转）进行广泛的研究，以产生男性化的女性（新男性）。我们将研究不同药物在细胞和分子水平上对内分泌性别控制的影响。将审查生产所有雌性种群的不同战略。预计该项目将导致（i）对大西洋比目鱼的遗传和内分泌性别控制机制有充分的了解，（ii）制定有效的方案以生产所有雌性比目鱼，以及（iii）建立新的雄性亲鱼种群。

Producing all-female market-sized Atlantic halibut shows high potential to the industry because of sexual growth dimorphism in this species. It is proposed to undertake multidisciplinary research on mechanisms and control of sex determination and differen tiation in halibut in order to develop the strategy to produce monosex all-female stocks. The project involves several research groups with relevant expertise in the different research areas. We will search for sex-specific DNA sequences and conduct thoro ugh cytogenetics research to better understand sex determination.. We will induce gynogenetic development to verify female homogamety and to obtain genetically all-female progeny. We will undertake extensive research on altering phenotypic sex (sex revers al) in order to produce masculinized females (neo-males). The cell- and molecular-level effects of various agents on endocrine sex control will be investigated. Different strategies to produce all-female stocks will be examined. It is anticipated that the project will result in (i) substantial knowledge of genetic and endocrine sex control mechanisms in Atlantic halibut, (ii) development of efficient protocols to produce all-female halibut, and (iii) establishing neo-male broodstocks.

Project.Title: Wellcome Trust PhD Programme for Clinicians at the University of Cambridge: Generation of patient specific stem cells towards cell based therapy of inherited metabolic diseases of the liver.

Title_Other.Title: 剑桥大学惠康信托基金临床医生博士项目：产生患者特异性干细胞，以细胞为基础治疗遗传性肝脏代谢疾病。
Wellcome Trust PhD Programme for Clinicians at the University of Cambridge: Generation of patient specific stem cells towards cell based therapy of inherited metabolic diseases of the liver.

Class.ClassName: 链上含两个异原子的聚合物、链上含多异原子的聚合物

Project.Abstract: To evaluate the potential of patient specific induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) derived hepatocytes to generate cells for cell transplant therapy in treating inherited metabolic diseases of the liver, a new chimeric mouse - human diseased liver model will be created. The first step will involve taking hepatocyte / skin fibroblast cells from Alpha 1 Antitrypsin deficient patients and reprogramming them in vitro to iPSCs. These cells will then be differentiated to hepatic progenitors and used to repopulate the liver of the FAH-/- mouse to produce a novel chimeric mouse - human liver model. The same patient specific iPSC derived hepatocytes will be genetically corrected and engrafted into the mouse model to try and achieve functional correction of the disease phenotype. By this we aim to 1) produce a new human hepatocyte cell line for Alpha 1 Antitrypsin deficiency 2) produce a new chimeric mouse - human liver 3) produce a new patient specific corrected human hepatocyte cell line from (1) 4) show proof of principle that engrafting the corrected cell line could be a therapeutic strategy towards treatment of A1ATD and other inherited metabolic disorders of the liver.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 为了评价患者特异性诱导多能干细胞（iPSC）来源的肝细胞在细胞移植治疗遗传性肝脏代谢性疾病中产生细胞的潜力，我们将建立一种新的嵌合小鼠-人疾病肝模型。 第一步是从α1抗胰蛋白酶缺乏患者中提取肝细胞/皮肤成纤维细胞，并在体外将其重新编程为iPSCs。然后，这些细胞将分化为肝祖细胞，并用于重新填充FAH-/-小鼠的肝脏，以产生一种新的嵌合小鼠-人类肝脏模型。 将同一患者特异性iPSC来源的肝细胞进行基因纠正并植入小鼠模型中，尝试实现疾病表型的功能纠正。 我们的目标是 1） α1抗胰蛋白酶缺乏症人肝细胞系的建立 2） 一种新的嵌合小鼠-人肝 3） 从（1）中产生新的病人特异性校正人肝细胞系 4） 证明移植正确的细胞系是治疗A1ATD和其他遗传性肝脏代谢紊乱的一种治疗策略。

To evaluate the potential of patient specific induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) derived hepatocytes to generate cells for cell transplant therapy in treating inherited metabolic diseases of the liver, a new chimeric mouse - human diseased liver model will be created. The first step will involve taking hepatocyte / skin fibroblast cells from Alpha 1 Antitrypsin deficient patients and reprogramming them in vitro to iPSCs. These cells will then be differentiated to hepatic progenitors and used to repopulate the liver of the FAH-/- mouse to produce a novel chimeric mouse - human liver model. The same patient specific iPSC derived hepatocytes will be genetically corrected and engrafted into the mouse model to try and achieve functional correction of the disease phenotype. By this we aim to 1) produce a new human hepatocyte cell line for Alpha 1 Antitrypsin deficiency 2) produce a new chimeric mouse - human liver 3) produce a new patient specific corrected human hepatocyte cell line from (1) 4) show proof of principle that engrafting the corrected cell line could be a therapeutic strategy towards treatment of A1ATD and other inherited metabolic disorders of the liver.

Project.Title: Hyperaciature of matter to a black hole

Title_Other.Title: 物质向黑洞过度分解
Hiperakrecja materii na czarną dziurę

Project.Title: Seabed ploughing: modelling for infrastructure installation

Title_Other.Title: Seabed ploughing: modelling for infrastructure installation
海底犁耕：基础设施安装模型

Project.Abstract: Soil ploughing, an activity carried out by man for thousands of years for agriculture, is now used at a much larger scale on the seabed to connect offshore energy production and generation devices to the supply network. In the next 50 years many more of these offshore devices (wind, wave, current and oil & gas) will be installed, meaning that considerably more seabed ploughing will be undertaken. However, we do not possess the same level of understanding of the mechanical and hydraulic processes associated with soil ploughing as we have developed for other soil-structure interaction problems. This means that ploughing schemes and equipment have to be designed on the basis of semi-empirical and conservative approaches, leading to financial uncertainty. In this project, new computational methods will be applied to the simulation of seabed ploughing to provide better estimates of key parameters such as the towing force and speed of ploughing in a given seabed deposit along with insights into plough stability. Given the likely ploughing activity in the next 20-50 years in UK waters and elsewhere, we expect that this new predictive approach will result in major savings for industry.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 土壤耕作是人类几千年来为农业而进行的一项活动，现在在海床上被更大规模地用于连接近海能源生产和发电设备与供应网络。在未来的50年里，将安装更多的这些海上设备（风、浪、流和油气），这意味着将进行更多的海底耕作。然而，我们对与土壤耕作相关的机械和水力过程的理解程度与我们对其他土壤-结构相互作用问题的理解程度不同。这意味着耕作方案和设备必须基于半经验和保守方法设计，从而导致财务不确定性。在这个项目中，新的计算方法将被应用到海床犁削的模拟中，以便更好地估计关键参数，如给定海床沉积物中的牵引力和犁削速度，以及犁削稳定性。考虑到未来20-50年英国水域和其他地方可能的耕作活动，我们预计这种新的预测方法将为工业带来重大节约。

Soil ploughing, an activity carried out by man for thousands of years for agriculture, is now used at a much larger scale on the seabed to connect offshore energy production and generation devices to the supply network. In the next 50 years many more of these offshore devices (wind, wave, current and oil & gas) will be installed, meaning that considerably more seabed ploughing will be undertaken. However, we do not possess the same level of understanding of the mechanical and hydraulic processes associated with soil ploughing as we have developed for other soil-structure interaction problems. This means that ploughing schemes and equipment have to be designed on the basis of semi-empirical and conservative approaches, leading to financial uncertainty. In this project, new computational methods will be applied to the simulation of seabed ploughing to provide better estimates of key parameters such as the towing force and speed of ploughing in a given seabed deposit along with insights into plough stability. Given the likely ploughing activity in the next 20-50 years in UK waters and elsewhere, we expect that this new predictive approach will result in major savings for industry.

Source.Name: Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council

Project.Title: Establishing the Efficacy, Safety and Persistence of biopesticides based on naturally occurring beneficial bacteria

Title_Other.Title: Establishing the Efficacy, Safety and Persistence of biopesticides based on naturally occurring beneficial bacteria
以天然有益细菌为基础建立生物农药的有效性、安全性和持久性

Project.Abstract:
HARNESSING NATURAL BACTERIA TO PROTECT CROPS AND SUSTAIN AGRICULTURE The aim of our research is to establish the fundamental scientific knowledge required to use naturally occuring plant protective bacteria in an effective, safe and environmentally non-persistent manner. Current agriculture is reliant on the use of chemical pesticides to protect crops from attack by disease-causing microorganisms. One such disease, known as damping off, is a major problem killing crop plants as they germinate. To feed the growing world population we will need to intensify agriculture and adding more chemical pesticides to protect crops. We cannot sustain high usage of pesticides, especially when they damage the environment and human health. Alternative approaches which are sustainable must be developed and natural bacterial biopesticides offer an attractive solution to enhance future agriculture and protect crops from disease.
BURKHOLDERIA AMBIFARIA - A NATURALLY PLANT PROTECTIVE BACTERIA Several natural bacteria live very closely with plants and provide protection against disease causing microbes. One group of bacteria, Burkholderia ambifaria (B. ambifaria), when applied as a seed coat are very good at protecting germinating crops from lethal attack by damping off fungi. This led to their safe use as biopesticides up to 1999 in the US, but during the 1990s, a related group of Burkholderia bacteria were found to cause lung infections in people with cystic fibrosis. At the time, the safety of B. ambifaria could not be fully defined, it was decided that registration of new biopesticides would not be permitted until they were demonstrated to have no health risks. Although the registered Burkholderia biopesticide products could still be used, the agricultural industry moved away from using them and expanded their use of chemical pesticides to sustain agriculture.
UNDERSTANDING HOW BURKHOLDERIA AMBIFARIA PROTECTS PLANTS AND ENSURING IT IS SAFE AND ENVIRONMENTALLY NON-PERSISTENT Using modern research techniques, we found B. ambifaria's plant protective ability was due to a set of genes that the bacterium uses to make an antifungal molecule called cepacin. When the cepacin-making genes were removed, plant protection was lost from the bacterial seed coat. By sequencing all the genes in B. ambifaria bacteria we also identified multiple new genes that make natural products potentially exploitable as biopesticide molecules, antibiotics or fine chemicals. These new findings have allowed us to map out a research program to re-purpose B. ambifaria as a biopesticide which will be carried out as the following four research objectives:
1. We will map all the molecules and pathways B. ambifaria uses to protect plants from attack by pathogens, specifically identifying those which are switched on when the bacteria grow on the exudates released by germinating crop seeds.
2. We will engineer the cepacin pathway allowing it to be moved into other biotechnological bacteria and also exploring how it is able to make the unusual chemical structure of this biopesticidal molecule.
3. We will improve the safety of B. ambifaria by identifying the genes it uses to cause disease and exploring different strategies to remove these genes. Infectious live bacteria can be used as vaccines when specific genes are removed, and the same approach will be exploited to make a safe biopesticide.
4. We will explore what happens to B. ambifaria when it is placed in the soil as a seed coat and how it affects other soil microorganisms, so that we understand it's environmental persistence.
Overall this integrated research programme will seek to deliver an effective, safe and environmentally non-persistent B. ambifaria biopesticide, which can significantly enhance and sustain agricultural production without the need to use chemical pesticides.
Technical Summary OVERALL AIM
There is an urgent unmet need to reduce chemical pesticides use and develop alternative approaches to sustain agricultural production. We will obtain the fundamental biological data to enable effective, safe and environmentally non-persistent exploitation of natural bacterial biopesticides, specifically repurposing Burkholderia ambifaria as a historically effective agent.
UNDERPINNING DATA AND APPROACHES
Genome mining of a unique collection of 64 B. ambifaria defined 7 known antimicrobial metabolites and >30 interesting secondary metabolite pathways. A novel pathway encoding biosynthesis of the polyyne antifungal, cepacin, was identified and shown to mediate protection of peas against damping off by the plant pathogen Pythium, when B. ambifaria was applied as a seed coat. Deletion of the B. ambifaria third genomic replicon, which results in reduced virulence, left the damping off control phenotype intact. From this knowledge base, we will apply an interdisciplinary genomics, chemical biology, crop-interaction assays and soil microbiome analyses to repurpose B. ambifaria as a biopesticide.
OUR HYPOTHESIS is "Pathogen targeted, virulence-attenuated Burkholderia biopesticides are effective, safe and environmentally non-persistent,"
TECHNICAL OBJECTIVES
1 - EFFICACY MAPPING: To define the biosynthetic pathways, activation signals and metabolites that underpin B. ambifaria biopesticidal activity of against multiple crop pathogens.
2 - EFFICACY ENGINEERING: To harness Burkholderia polyynes as potent, environmentally non-persistent biological control molecules.
3 - SAFETY: Using transposon-sequencing and third replicon deletion as next generation tools to map beneficial biopesticidal genes and in parallel identify pathogenic pathways.
4 - PERSISTENCE: To apply culture and culture-independent analysis to understand the persistence of B. ambifaria biopesticides with the soil microbiome.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 利用自然细菌保护农作物维持农业 我们的研究目的是建立必要的基本科学知识，以有效、安全和环保的非持久性方式使用天然植物保护细菌。目前的农业依靠使用化学杀虫剂来保护作物免受致病微生物的攻击。其中一种被称为“受潮”的疾病，是作物在发芽时死亡的主要问题。为了养活日益增长的世界人口，我们将需要加强农业，增加更多的化学农药来保护农作物。我们无法维持农药的大量使用，特别是当它们破坏环境和人类健康时。必须开发可持续的替代方法，而天然细菌生物杀虫剂提供了一个有吸引力的解决方案，以加强未来的农业和保护作物免受疾病。 一种天然植物保护菌 一些自然细菌与植物生活得非常紧密，并能防止致病微生物。其中一组细菌，Burkholderia ambifaria（B.ambifaria）作为种皮使用时，能够很好地保护正在发芽的作物免受真菌的致命攻击。这导致了他们在1999年以前在美国作为生物杀虫剂的安全使用，但是在1990年代，一组相关的伯克霍尔德菌被发现导致囊性纤维化患者的肺部感染。当时，尚不能完全确定安非他明杆菌的安全性，决定在证明新的生物农药不存在健康风险之前，不允许进行登记。虽然已登记的伯克霍尔德菌生物农药产品仍然可以使用，但农业工业已不再使用这些产品，而是扩大使用化学农药来维持农业。 了解AMBIFARIA伯克霍尔德菌如何保护植物，并确保其安全性和环境非持久性 利用现代研究技术，我们发现ambifaria的植物保护能力是由于细菌利用一组基因来制造一种名为cepacin的抗真菌分子。当cepacin制造基因被移除时，细菌种皮失去了植物保护。通过对ambifaria细菌的所有基因进行测序，我们还发现了多个新基因，这些新基因使天然产物有可能被用作生物农药分子、抗生素或精细化学品。这些新发现使我们能够制定一个研究计划，将B.ambifaria重新用作生物农药，该计划将按照以下四个研究目标进行： 一。我们将绘制ambifaria用来保护植物免受病原体攻击的所有分子和路径图，特别是识别细菌在发芽作物种子释放的分泌物上生长时打开的那些分子和路径。 2。我们将设计使其进入其他生物技术细菌的头孢沙星途径，并探索它如何能够制造这种生物杀灭分子的不寻常的化学结构。 三。我们将通过鉴定ambifaria引起疾病的基因，并探索不同的策略来移除这些基因，从而提高ambifaria的安全性。当特定基因被移除时，感染性活菌可以用作疫苗，同样的方法也将被用来制造安全的生物杀虫剂。 四。我们将探讨安氏毕赤酵母作为种衣剂被置于土壤中时会发生什么，以及它如何影响其他土壤微生物，以便我们了解它的环境持久性。 总的来说，这一综合研究方案将力求提供一种有效、安全和环境上非持久性的ambifaria B.生物杀虫剂，它可以大大提高和维持农业生产，而无需使用化学杀虫剂。 技术总结 总体目标 目前迫切需要减少化学农药的使用，并制定其他办法来维持农业生产。我们将获得基本的生物数据，以便能够有效、安全和环保地非持续开发天然细菌生物农药，特别是将ambifaria伯克霍尔德菌重新用作一种历史上有效的药剂。 支持数据和方法 对64株ambifaria菌株的基因组挖掘定义了7种已知的抗菌代谢物和30多种有趣的次级代谢物途径。一种新的多炔生物合成途径

Project.Title: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Methods for Fractional Partial Differential Equations

Title_Other.Title: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Methods for Fractional Partial Differential Equations
协同研究：分数阶偏微分方程的随机方法

Project.Abstract: Brownian motion, the scaling limit of a simple random walk, is a stochastic model for diffusion. Probability densities for this stochastic process solve the classical diffusion equation. A continuous time random walk is a simple random walk subordinated to a renewal process, used in physics to model anomalous diffusion. Increments of the simple random walk represents particle jumps, and the renewal epochs represent the particle jump times. Infinite variance particle jumps cause superdiffusion, in which a cloud of particles spreads faster than the classical model predicts. Infinite mean waiting times lead to subdiffusion. Scaling limits of continuous time random walks are stochastic processes whose densities solve fractional partial differential equations. Infinite variance particle jumps lead to operator stable Levy motions, while infinite mean waiting times induce subordination to an inverse stable subordinator. Fractional derivatives are generators of stable continuous convolution semigroups. The research funded by this grant is developing a sound mathematical basis for this physical theory, and pursuing practical applications to problems in contaminant transport. The goals of this research include limit theory for continuous time random walks with possible dependence between the jump sizes and the waiting times, extension to more realistic multidimensional jump vectors with matrix scaling to allow different rates of particle spreading in each coordinate, parallel development of multiscaling fractional derivative operators in space, analysis of the fundamental physical basis of fractional diffusion to elucidate the physical meaning of the model parameters, development of useful statistical methods for parameter estimation, numerical methods for fractional partial differential equations, and application of these methods to real data from laboratory and field experiments and remediation efforts involving porous media and fracture flow. Movement of contaminants in a mountain stream takes place over a vast range of time scales. A majority will move away quickly, but a small amount can be caught in eddies for minutes or days. Another fraction may move into the relatively motionless water beneath the streambed, and it may take months or years for the last molecules to disappear completely. The movement of contaminants in underground water spreads over a similar range of time scales. Our team of mathematicians and hydrogeologists uses modern interdisciplinary research methods to develop accurate models for the movement and spread of these contaminants. Much more than an academic exercise, this work is needed for realistic models of contaminant and nutrient movement in drinking water supplies. The research is necessary because existing diffusion models greatly underestimate the time and concentration at which contaminants arrive downstream, when compared to actual data.

Much more than an academic exercise, this work is needed for realistic models of contaminant and nutrient movement in drinking water supplies. The research is necessary because existing diffusion models greatly underestimate the time and concentration at which contaminants arrive downstream, when compared to actual data.

布朗运动是一个简单随机游动的尺度极限，是一个随机扩散模型。这个随机过程的概率密度求解了经典的扩散方程。连续时间随机游动是一种简单的随机游动，隶属于一个更新过程，在物理学中用于模拟反常扩散。简单随机游动的增量表示粒子跳跃，更新周期表示粒子跳跃时间。无限方差粒子跳跃导致超扩散，其中粒子云的扩散速度比经典模型预测的要快。无限的平均等待时间会导致子扩散。连续时间随机游动的标度极限是密度解分数阶偏微分方程的随机过程。无限方差粒子跳跃导致算子稳定的Levy运动，而无限平均等待时间则导致从属于逆稳定的从属于。分数阶导数是稳定连续卷积半群的生成元。这项由该基金资助的研究正在为这一物理理论发展一个健全的数学基础，并寻求在污染物运输问题上的实际应用。本研究的目标包括连续时间随机游动的极限理论，跳跃大小和等待时间之间可能存在依赖关系，扩展到更真实的多维跳跃向量，矩阵缩放以允许不同的粒子在每个坐标系中的扩散速率，空间多尺度分数阶导数算子的并行发展，分析分数阶扩散的基本物理基础以阐明模型参数的物理意义，发展有用的参数估计统计方法，分数阶偏微分方程的数值方法，并将这些方法应用于实验室和现场实验的真实数据，以及多孔介质和裂缝流的修复工作。污染物在山间溪流中的运动在很大的时间尺度上发生。大多数人会很快离开，但也有一小部分人会在几分钟或几天内陷入漩涡。另一部分可能进入河床下相对静止的水中，最后的分子可能需要数月或数年才能完全消失。污染物在地下水中的运动在相似的时间尺度范围内扩散。我们的数学家和水文地质学家团队利用现代跨学科的研究方法，为这些污染物的运动和扩散建立精确的模型。这项工作不仅仅是一项学术工作，还需要建立饮用水供应中污染物和营养物运动的现实模型。这项研究是必要的，因为现有的扩散模型大大低估了污染物到达下游的时间和浓度，与实际数据相比。

Project.Title: Metalloproteinases and Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Transactivation by the Bradykinin B2 Receptor in Kidney Cells

Title_Other.Title: Metalloproteinases and Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor Transactivation by the Bradykinin B2 Receptor in Kidney Cells
缓激肽B2受体激活肾细胞金属蛋白酶和表皮生长因子受体

Project.Abstract: The vasoactive peptide bradykinin (BK) not only regulates electrolyte and water excretion in kidney, but acts as a potent growth factor for multiple cell types. We have previously established a mitogenic role for BK in a cultured murine cell model of the inner medullary collecting duct (mIMCD-3 cells), and described the involvement of B2 receptor-induced epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) transactivation in the stimulation of mIMCD-3 cell proliferation. The mechanism of B2 receptor-induced transactivation of EGFR in mIMCD-3 cells appears to be novel, for it does not involve complex formation between the B2 receptor and EGFR, and does not require pertussis toxin-sensitive Gi/o proteins, Ca2+, Calmodulin, Phospholipase C, or Protein kinase C activation. Our preliminary studies suggest that matrix metalloproteinases (MMP), specifically collagenases 2 and 3, are involved in Gq- coupled B2 receptor signaling in mIMCD-3 cells. The purpose of this application is to delineate a novel mechanism of BK-induced MMP-dependent transactivation of EGFR in kidney cells. The Specific Aims of this project are as follows: 1. To identify the mechanism by which MMPs induce transactivation of EGFR a) Is there BK-induced MMP-dependent release of an EGF- like ligand? b) Is there a direct effect of MMPs on EGFR molecule? 2. To study the mechanism of BK-induced activation of MMPs in mIMCD-3 cells. To accomplish these Aims, we will use a combination of biochemical and molecular biological techniques, immunoprecipitation, Western blotting, and RNA methods,selective MMPs activity assays, and fluorescence microscopy. We will employ chemical inhibitors, neutralizing antibodies against the candidate proteins, and small interfering RNAs to support the involvement of specific proteins in BK-induced signaling in mIMCD-3 cells. These studies will contribute to better understanding of the molecular mechanisms by which BK affects proliferation of kidney cells, and will ultimately provide new strategies for treatment of renal tubulointerstitial fibrosis.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 血管活性肽缓激肽（BK）不仅调节肾脏电解质和水的排泄，而且对多种细胞类型起到有效的生长因子的作用。我们已经在培养的小鼠髓内集合管（mIMCD-3）细胞模型中建立了BK的有丝分裂作用，并描述了B2受体诱导的表皮生长因子受体（EGFR）反式激活在刺激mIMCD-3细胞增殖中的作用。B2受体诱导的IGFR在MIMCD-3细胞中的反式激活机制似乎是新颖的，因为它不涉及B2受体和EGFR之间的复杂形成，并且不需要百日咳毒素敏感的GI/O蛋白、Ca2+、钙调蛋白、磷脂酶C或蛋白激酶C激活。我们的初步研究表明，基质金属蛋白酶（MMP），特别是胶原酶2和3，参与了mIMCD-3细胞的Gq偶联B2受体信号传导。本研究旨在揭示BK诱导肾细胞MMP依赖性EGFR反式激活的新机制。本项目的具体目标如下：1。为了确定MMPs诱导EGFR a反式激活的机制，BK是否诱导了EGF样配体的MMP依赖性释放？b） MMPs对EGFR分子有直接作用吗？2。探讨BK诱导mIMCD-3细胞MMPs活化的机制。为了实现这些目标，我们将使用生物化学和分子生物学技术、免疫沉淀、Western blotting和RNA方法、选择性MMPs活性测定和荧光显微镜。我们将使用化学抑制剂、中和候选蛋白的抗体和小干扰rna来支持特定蛋白参与BK诱导的mIMCD-3细胞信号传导。这些研究将有助于更好地理解BK影响肾细胞增殖的分子机制，并最终为肾小管间质纤维化的治疗提供新的策略。

The mechanism of B2 receptor-induced transactivation of EGFR in mIMCD-3 cells appears to be novel, for it does not involve complex formation between the B2 receptor and EGFR, and does not require pertussis toxin-sensitive Gi/o proteins, Ca2+, Calmodulin, Phospholipase C, or Protein kinase C activation. Project.Title: Atmospheric Environmental Metrology for Electro-Optical/Infra-Red (EO/IR) Sensor Flight Test

Title_Other.Title: 光电/红外（EO/IR）传感器飞行试验大气环境计量
Atmospheric Environmental Metrology for Electro-Optical/Infra-Red (EO/IR) Sensor Flight Test

Project.Abstract: The Naval Air Warfare Center (NAWC) needs accurate, autonomous techniques for atmospheric correction of airborne imaging sensors to support flight testing, specifically validation of Noise-Equivalent Differential Temperature (NEDT) capabilities of Electro-Optical/Infrared (EO/IR) sensors used for Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) applications. Outside of a controlled laboratory environment, temperature retrieval and measurement of NEDT are subject to the uncertainties that enter in through a number of variable terms, most of which are due to the earth"s atmosphere. The lack of timely atmospheric measurements with regard to any given test location and duration makes it a challenge to accurately characterize the composition of absorbing species along a sensor"s line of sight to a target under real-world conditions. SciTec proposes to develop and deliver a capability to perform autonomous ingest and fusion of available atmospheric profile data with that collected by a ground-based meteorological station. This capability will contain a direct implementation of MODTRAN for performing the radiative transport calculations, thus providing representations of the atmosphere that will dramatically enhance EO/IR temperature retrieval and NEDT characterization. SciTec will bring its decades of experience in ISR sensor testing and performance evaluation to deliver a precision automated process for sensor calibration and testing to the NAVAIR T & E team.

Outside of a controlled laboratory environment, temperature retrieval and measurement of NEDT are subject to the uncertainties that enter in through a number of variable terms, most of which are due to the earth"s atmosphere. The lack of timely atmospheric measurements with regard to any given test location and duration makes it a challenge to accurately characterize the composition of absorbing species along a sensor"s line of sight to a target under real-world conditions. SciTec proposes to develop and deliver a capability to perform autonomous ingest and fusion of available atmospheric profile data with that collected by a ground-based meteorological station. 海军空战中心（NAWC）需要精确、自主的机载成像传感器大气校正技术，以支持飞行测试，特别是验证用于情报、监视和侦察（ISR）的光电/红外（EO/IR）传感器的噪声等效温差（NEDT）能力应用。在受控的实验室环境之外，NEDT的温度恢复和测量受到许多变量项的不确定性影响，其中大部分是由于地球的大气层。对于任何给定的测试位置和持续时间，缺乏及时的大气测量，使得在现实条件下，沿着传感器对目标的视线准确描述吸收物种的组成成为一个挑战。SciTec建议开发和交付一种能力，能够自动接收和融合可用的大气剖面数据和地面气象站收集的数据。这种能力将包含MODTRAN的直接实现，用于执行辐射传输计算，从而提供大气的表示，这将显著提高EO/IR温度恢复和NEDT特性。SciTec将利用其在ISR传感器测试和性能评估方面数十年的经验，为NAVAIR T&E团队提供传感器校准和测试的精确自动化过程。

Source.Name: United States Department of the Navy

Project.Title: CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Smart Buttons: Bio-Enabled Wearable Devices

Title_Other.Title: CSR:Small:协作研究：智能按钮：支持生物的可穿戴设备
CSR: Small: Collaborative Research: Smart Buttons: Bio-Enabled Wearable Devices

Project.Abstract: This project aims to build Smart Buttons, a bio-enabled wearable device weighing less than 2 grams. A network of smart buttons will be built that scales from a few buttons for each person individually to over a hundred of buttons for a crowd. This network simultaneously records, generates, compiles posture and interaction data spanning various scenarios, time scales and physical settings. The smart button platform will be able to assist domain scientists in understanding human posture and behavior as well as social interaction in a crowd. The intellectual contributions include a novel bio-enable design philosophy and a set of concrete approaches to seamlessly integrate computation with bio-enabled functions. Subjects (e.g., humans) are treated not only as the source of information, but also as the source of functionality. Unlike electronic computation functions, bio-enabled functions are highly unpredictable and have inherent uncertainty in both measurement and control. The research explores (i) how computation from electronic systems interact with physical bio-enabled functions from living subjects, and (ii) how to integrate these functions. The proposal work first demonstrates a few cases of bio-enabled functions and their effectiveness, including bio-enabled proximity detection, ranging, bio-enabled on-demand sensing, bio-enabled networking and energy management. After these case studies, reusable patterns are extracted, and principles and methodologies to design bio-enabled wearable devices are derived. The results of this research can be used in the future by domain scientists to support (i) individual's behavior predictions and generalizations, and (ii) crowd social interaction modeling and control. The broader impact of this work includes (i) utilizing the smart button technology to analyze teaching effectiveness and reveal the issues and desired features in a teaching environment; (ii) improving curriculum development with hand-on smart button projects; (iii) raising interest in technology among K-12 students and under-represented minority groups through smart button demos in open houses; and (iv) supporting talented female and minority PhD students to successfully accomplish their doctoral studies. The ultimate impact of the smart button technology is to provide a low-cost open experimental platform for behavior/social scientists, leading to a solid foundation for a new science of social interaction. The principles based on bio-feedback can give rise to new paradigms, principles, theory and methods in computer system control with bio-in-the-loop.

这个项目的目标是制造智能按钮，一种生物功能的可穿戴设备，重量小于2克。一个由智能按钮组成的网络将被建立起来，从个人的几个按钮扩展到人群的一百多个按钮。该网络同时记录、生成、编译跨越各种场景、时间尺度和物理设置的姿态和交互数据。智能按钮平台将能够帮助领域科学家了解人群中的人类姿势和行为以及社交互动。其智力贡献包括一种新颖的生物使能设计理念和一套将计算与生物使能功能无缝集成的具体方法。受试者（如人类）不仅被视为信息的来源，而且被视为功能的来源。与电子计算功能不同，生物功能具有高度的不可预测性，在测量和控制方面都具有固有的不确定性。这项研究探索了（i）电子系统的计算如何与活体的物理生物功能相互作用，以及（ii）如何整合这些功能。提案工作首先展示了一些生物功能及其有效性的案例，包括生物功能近程探测、测距、生物功能按需传感、生物功能联网和能源管理。在这些案例研究之后，我们提取出可重复使用的模式，并推导出设计生物可穿戴设备的原则和方法。这项研究的结果可以在未来被领域科学家用来支持（i）个人的行为预测和概括，以及（ii）人群社会互动的建模和控制。这项工作的广泛影响包括：（i）利用智能按钮技术分析教学效果，揭示教学环境中的问题和期望的特点；（ii）利用智能按钮项目改进课程开发；（iii）提高K-12学生和代表性不足的少数民族对技术的兴趣通过开放式的智能按钮演示进行分组；以及（iv）支持有才华的女性和少数民族博士生成功完成博士研究。智能按钮技术的最终影响是为行为/社会科学家提供一个低成本开放的实验平台，从而为一个新的社会互动科学奠定坚实的基础。基于生物反馈的控制原理，可以为生物在环的计算机系统控制提供新的范式、原理、理论和方法。

Source.Name: Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering

Project.Title: Biochemical signalling for costimulation through I CAM-1

Title_Other.Title: I-CAM-1协同刺激的生化信号
Biochemical signalling for costimulation through I CAM-1

Project.Title: Learning Reading Strategies for Science Texts in a Gaming Environment: iSTART vs iTG

Title_Other.Title: 游戏环境下科技文本的学习阅读策略：iSTART与iTG
Learning Reading Strategies for Science Texts in a Gaming Environment: iSTART vs iTG

Class.ClassName: 理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract: It is well known that many students find science text challenging to comprehend. Students' reading ability is partly to blame. Reading problems become most apparent when the student is faced with a challenging text for which they have knowledge deficits. Science text, in particular, has many technical terms that are difficult to ground in everyday experience. Thus, there is a need for reading comprehension interventions to improve science comprehension. This project compares the effectiveness of two types of tutoring environments in improving high-school students' ability to understand challenging science text. Both environments contain the same pedagogical content, but present it differently: as a lesson or as a game. The first environment, developed and tested over the past 5 years, is an automated reading strategies tutor called iSTART (Interactive Strategy Training for Active Reading and Thinking) that uses animated pedagogical agents to deliver interactive instruction on self-explanation and reading strategies (comprehension monitoring, paraphrasing, generating inferences). Instruction occurs in three stages with each stage requiring increased interaction on the part of the learner. Results across a wide range of studies indicate that iSTART is highly effective in improving students' ability to understand challenging science text. While effective, iSTART can be somewhat unappealing to an average high-school student in extended practice situations. While students need extended practice to master the strategies, iSTART becomes monotonous over time. To increase students' engagement, an alternative version of iSTART practice will be developed that allows students to practice iSTART strategies in a game environment. iSTART-The Game (iTG) will present the same reading strategy practice to students, but will incorporate game-based principles to enhance engagement. This project examines whether a gaming environment for learning strategies for science text comprehension more effectively sustains students' attention and engagement during training, and thereby results in improved acquisition and mastery of these strategies. In the first year of funding, an automated reading strategy tutoring system that is framed in a gaming environment will be developed. In Year 2, pilot studies will be conducted to refine the system. In Year 3, practice using the strategies will be compared in three conditions: iTG, iSTART, and a control condition. Students will practice the strategies over a period of five additional sessions after the initial training. This experiment will provide information on the potential value of iTG over time and specifically, whether iTG engages students over repeated practice sessions. The potential interactive effects of individual differences such as prior science knowledge, reading skill, and motivational levels will also be examined. This research will contribute to better understanding of engagement as a factor in learning gains. It is predicted by the investigators that many students who do not find the standard tutoring environment sufficiently engaging will significantly benefit from the alternative approach. Most importantly, this instructional intervention should be especially valuable for those students most at risk due to having lower ability and interest in science. This research will accomplish the goal of creating a test-bed learning environment intended to improve reader engagement and advance our understanding of the potential instructional gains from such environments. The project will contribute to our understanding of the relationship between game features and engagement. It will provide students with tools that help them more effectively meet the challenges of learning from difficult science texts. In addition, this research will contribute to our understanding of the roles that cognition and emotion play in fostering learning, the specific processes involved with learning from science texts, and the complex interplay of factors such as reading strategies, knowledge, reading skill, interest, and motivation.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 众所周知，许多学生发现科学文本难以理解。学生的阅读能力是部分原因。当学生面对具有知识缺陷的挑战性文本时，阅读问题变得最为明显。尤其是科学文本，有许多在日常经验中难以理解的技术术语。因此，有必要对阅读理解进行干预，以提高科学理解能力。本研究比较了两种辅导环境对提高高中生理解挑战性科学课文能力的效果。这两个环境包含相同的教学内容，但呈现方式不同：作为课程或作为游戏。第一个环境，在过去的5年中开发和测试，是一个名为iSTART（主动阅读和思考的互动策略培训）的自动阅读策略导师，使用动画教学代理提供关于自我解释和阅读策略（理解监控，释义，产生推论）。教学分三个阶段进行，每个阶段都需要学习者加强互动。广泛的研究结果表明，iSTART在提高学生理解具有挑战性的科学文本的能力方面是非常有效的。虽然iSTART是有效的，但对于一个普通的高中生来说，在长期的实践中，它可能有点不吸引人。虽然学生需要更多的练习来掌握这些策略，但随着时间的推移，iSTART变得单调乏味。为了增加学生的参与度，将开发一个iSTART实践的替代版本，允许学生在游戏环境中实践iSTART策略。iSTART The Game（iTG）将向学生展示相同的阅读策略实践，但将纳入基于游戏的原则，以增强参与度。本项目旨在探讨一个科学文本理解策略的游戏环境是否能更有效地维持学生在训练过程中的注意力和参与度，从而提高对这些策略的习得和掌握。在资助的第一年，将开发一个在游戏环境中构建的自动阅读策略辅导系统。在第二年，将进行试点研究，以完善这一制度。在第三年，将在三个条件下比较策略的使用：iTG、iSTART和对照条件。学生将在初始培训后的五个额外课程中练习这些策略。这项实验将提供信息，说明随着时间的推移，iTG的潜在价值，特别是iTG是否吸引学生在重复的实践环节。还将研究个体差异的潜在交互作用，如先前的科学知识、阅读技能和动机水平。这项研究将有助于更好地理解参与是学习收益的一个因素。研究人员预测，许多学生如果觉得标准的辅导环境不够吸引人，他们将从另一种方法中受益匪浅。最重要的是，这种教学干预对于那些由于对科学的能力和兴趣较低而处于危险中的学生来说应该特别有价值。本研究的目的是建立一个实验性的学习环境，以提高读者的参与度，并增进我们对这种环境潜在教学效果的了解。该项目将有助于我们了解游戏功能和参与度之间的关系。它将为学生提供工具，帮助他们更有效地应对从困难的科学课文中学习的挑战。此外，这项研究将有助于我们理解认知和情感在促进学习中的作用，从科学文本中学习所涉及的具体过程，以及阅读策略、知识、阅读技能、兴趣和动机等因素的复杂相互作用。

It is well known that many students find science text challenging to comprehend. Students' reading ability is partly to blame. Reading problems become most apparent when the student is faced with a challenging text for which they have knowledge deficits. Science text, in particular, has many technical terms that are difficult to ground in everyday experience. Thus, there is a need for reading comprehension interventions to improve science comprehension. This project compares the effectiveness of two types of tutoring environments in improving high-school students' ability to understand challenging science text. Both environments contain the same pedagogical content, but present it differently: as a lesson or as a game. The first environment, developed and tested over the past 5 years, is an automated reading strategies tutor called iSTART (Interactive Strategy Training for Active Reading and Thinking) that uses animated pedagogical agents to deliver interactive instruction on self-explanation and reading strategies (comprehension monitoring, paraphrasing, generating inferences). Instruction occurs in three stages with each stage requiring increased interaction on the part of the learner. Results across a wide range of studies indicate that iSTART is highly effective in improving students' ability to understand challenging science text. While effective, iSTART can be somewhat unappealing to an average high-school student in extended practice situations. While students need extended practice to master the strategies, iSTART becomes monotonous over time. To increase students' engagement, an alternative version of iSTART practice will be developed that allows students to practice iSTART strategies in a game environment. iSTART-The Game (iTG) will present the same reading strategy practice to students, but will incorporate game-based principles to enhance engagement. This project examines whether a gaming environment for learning strategies for science text comprehension more effectively sustains students' attention and engagement during training, and thereby results in improved acquisition and mastery of these strategies. In the first year of funding, an automated reading strategy tutoring system that is framed in a gaming environment will be developed. In Year 2, pilot studies will be conducted to refine the system. In Year 3, practice using the strategies will be compared in three conditions: iTG, iSTART, and a control condition. Students will practice the strategies over a period of five additional sessions after the initial training. This experiment will provide information on the potential value of iTG over time and specifically, whether iTG engages students over repeated practice sessions. The potential interactive effects of individual differences such as prior science knowledge, reading skill, and motivational levels will also be examined. This research will contribute to better understanding of engagement as a factor in learning gains. It is predicted by the investigators that many students who do not find the standard tutoring environment sufficiently engaging will significantly benefit from the alternative approach. Most importantly, this instructional intervention should be especially valuable for those students most at risk due to having lower ability and interest in science. This research will accomplish the goal of creating a test-bed learning environment intended to improve reader engagement and advance our understanding of the potential instructional gains from such environments. The project will contribute to our understanding of the relationship between game features and engagement. It will provide students with tools that help them more effectively meet the challenges of learning from difficult science texts. In addition, this research will contribute to our understanding of the roles that cognition and emotion play in fostering learning, the specific processes involved with learning from science texts, and the complex interplay of factors such as reading strategies, knowledge, reading skill, interest, and motivation.

Source.Name: Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering

Project.Title: A new method of recycling PVC; bolstering the circular economy through producing both a purer REACH compliant R-PVC and other new high-value outputs

Title_Other.Title: 一种新的回收聚氯乙烯的方法；通过生产更纯的可达到的R-PVC和其他新的高价值产品来促进循环经济
A new method of recycling PVC; bolstering the circular economy through producing both a purer REACH compliant R-PVC and other new high-value outputs

Project.Abstract: PVC often contains additives, some of which are considered to be substances of very high concern and are undergoing REACH authorisation which bans their use in new PVC materials, including recycled PVCs (R-PVC).This is leading to limitations on the PVC recycling industry and has already caused the closure of one PVC recycling plant. Our innovation looks to respond to this market need and provide the first method to recycle PVC containing banned additives through removing and re-purposing into new, valuable polymers which can be used in a range of applications, including coatings and composite materials for construction - benefiting the environment and the UK economy through reduced imports of materials and exports of plastic waste and increased revenue.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: PVC often contains additives, some of which are considered to be substances of very high concern and are undergoing REACH authorisation which bans their use in new PVC materials, including recycled PVCs (R-PVC).This is leading to limitations on the PVC recycling industry and has already caused the closure of one PVC recycling plant. Our innovation looks to respond to this market need and provide the first method to recycle PVC containing banned additives through removing and re-purposing into new, valuable polymers which can be used in a range of applications, including coatings and composite materials for construction - benefiting the environment and the UK economy through reduced imports of materials and exports of plastic waste and increased revenue.

PVC通常含有添加剂，其中一些被认为是非常令人关注的物质，并且正在接受REACH授权，禁止其用于新的PVC材料，包括回收的PVC（R-PVC）。这导致了对PVC回收行业的限制，并且已经导致了一个PVC回收厂的关闭。 我们的创新旨在响应这一市场需求，并通过去除含有违禁添加剂的PVC并将其重新用于可用于多种应用的新的、有价值的聚合物，提供第一种回收含有违禁添加剂的PVC的方法，包括建筑用涂料和复合材料——通过减少材料进口、减少塑料废料出口和增加收入，有利于环境和英国经济。

Title_Other.Title: NachhMaMobilitaet - Nachhaltige Mitarbeitermobilität als Teil der nachhaltigen Unternehmensstrategie
NACHHMAMobility-可持续的员工流动是可持续企业战略的一部分

Project.Title: Mathematical Sciences: Mathematical Statistics

Title_Other.Title: Mathematical Sciences: Mathematical Statistics
数理科学：数理统计

Project.Abstract: This project involves basic research into the mathematical properties of statistical procedures. Of special interest are questions of admissibility of common parametric estimators. For example, the least squares estimator of a regression parameter or of such a parameter after selection based on the data will be studied. Also of interest are the conditional properties of such estimators and related confidence procedures, non-parametric estimates of density function, (nearly) distribution free confidence bands and tests for multivariate distribution functions. This research in statistics focuses on the mathematical properties of estimators. Insight derived from this research will assist the development of statistical methodologies and improve the application of statistics in many scientific fields.

Insight derived from this research will assist the development of statistical methodologies and improve the application of statistics in many scientific fields.
这个项目涉及统计过程的数学性质的基础研究。特别关注的是公共参数估计的可容许性问题。例如，将研究基于数据选择的回归参数或此类参数的最小二乘估计。此外，我们还感兴趣的是这些估计的条件性质和相关的置信过程，密度函数的非参数估计，（几乎）无分布置信带和多元分布函数的检验。统计学研究的重点是估计量的数学性质。从这项研究中获得的见解将有助于统计方法的发展，并改善统计在许多科学领域的应用。

Project.Title: A randomised controlled trial of the effectiveness of ‘Enable Me’: an e-health innovation for stroke survivors and support persons.

Title_Other.Title: 一项关于“使我成为现实”的有效性的随机对照试验：一项针对中风幸存者和支持人员的电子健康创新。
A randomised controlled trial of the effectiveness of ‘Enable Me’: an e-health innovation for stroke survivors and support persons.

Class.ClassName: 控制论（数学）、信息论（数学）

Project.Abstract: Stroke survivors experience significant burdens, including depression and reduced quality of life. The demands placed on support persons of stroke survivors also impact on the physical and mental health of these individuals. This study will examine the effectiveness of Enable Me, an online program developed to support stroke survivors and their support persons following discharge from hospital. We will also identify effective strategies which encourage uptake and continued use of the program.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 中风幸存者经历了巨大的负担，包括抑郁和生活质量下降。对中风幸存者的支持人员提出的要求也影响到这些人的身心健康。这项研究将检验一个在线项目Enable Me的有效性，该项目旨在支持中风幸存者及其出院后的支持人员。我们还将确定有效的战略，鼓励吸收和继续使用该方案。

Stroke survivors experience significant burdens, including depression and reduced quality of life. The demands placed on support persons of stroke survivors also impact on the physical and mental health of these individuals. This study will examine the effectiveness of Enable Me, an online program developed to support stroke survivors and their support persons following discharge from hospital. We will also identify effective strategies which encourage uptake and continued use of the program.

Project.Title: Virgin Islands Lionfish Response Project

Title_Other.Title: 维尔京群岛狮子鱼应对项目
Virgin Islands Lionfish Response Project

Class.ClassName: 陆地水文学、水文地理学（水象学）

Project.Abstract: The St. Croix Environmental Association (SEA) will fill a critical gap in Virgin Islands government resources by increasing targeted education and outreach on the invasive lionfish to all three islands of the USVI and sustain a targeted lionfish detection and removal program on these reefs. Outreach and education activities include: 1) Continued production of educational lionfish posters and brochures; 2) Development and airing of two 30-second lionfish videos for television; and 3) Airing of two 30 second lionfish radio PSAs.  SEA will assemble lionfish diver response kits that include spears, dry bags, puncture proof gloves, dive floats and flags, dive sausages and reels, whistles, and underwater flashlights. These kits will be used by volunteer divers one day per month to survey waters around St. Croix in a systematic pattern looking for lionfish and once located; the divers will capture and kill lionfish in St. Croix waters before they become established.

圣克罗伊岛环境协会（SEA）将通过增加有针对性的教育和扩大对USVI所有三个岛屿的入侵狮子鱼的宣传，填补维尔京群岛政府资源的一个重大缺口，并在这些珊瑚礁上维持一个有针对性的狮子鱼检测和清除方案。外联和教育活动包括：1）继续制作狮子鱼宣传画和小册子；2）制作和播放两个30秒的狮子鱼电视录像带；3）播放两个30秒的狮子鱼电台公益广告。SEA将组装狮子鱼潜水员响应套件，包括矛、干袋、防刺穿手套、潜水浮标和旗子、潜水香肠和卷轴、口哨和水下手电筒。志愿者潜水员每月一天将使用这些工具包，以系统的方式调查圣克罗伊附近的水域，寻找狮子鱼，一旦确定位置；潜水员将在圣克罗伊水域捕获并杀死狮子鱼，然后再确定位置。

Project.Title: Psychosocial determinants of health in a high-risk sample: A longitudinal study

Title_Other.Title: 高危人群健康的心理社会决定因素：一项纵向研究
Psychosocial determinants of health in a high-risk sample: A longitudinal study

Class.ClassName: 计算机安全、计算机保密

Project.Abstract: Children who are either aggressive or withdrawn are at risk for emotional, social and academic difficulties. Although we know that they are also vulnerable to health problems, the nature and prevalence of these problems as they move from childhood to maturity has not as yet been well delineated. It is important to do so to make the argument for adequately resourced preventive and remedial measures persuasive and compelling. The Concordia Longitudinal Project began in 1976 and has been following 1770 inner-city aggressive, withdrawn, and average children who are now in their 30s and have children of their own. The project has assembled a large amount of archival data that covers a 25-year period without identifying the children, their parents, and their offspring by name. The children are now adults in their mid- to- late thirties and have children of their own. These data will enable us to document the frequency and nature of the particular health problems of these children over the course of adolescence and adulthood, as well the health problems of their parents, and their offspring. We will also determine the impact of such factors as poverty, crime, education, and health undermining lifestyles on the links between childhood aggression and withdrawal and later health problems. The study has unusual features. It has followed aggressive and withdrawn girls as well as boys into adulthood, so it can document the health problems that are specific to each sex for each stage of development; its archival database provides details about a broad spectrum of health problems, both mental and physical; the follow-up period is unusually long � from childhood to mature adulthood; and perhaps, its most unusual and original feature � the study's three-generational databank provides a perspective on the health hazards of aggression and withdrawal that transfer from one generation to the next.

Although we know that they are also vulnerable to health problems, the nature and prevalence of these problems as they move from childhood to maturity has not as yet been well delineated. It is important to do so to make the argument for adequately resourced preventive and remedial measures persuasive and compelling. 有攻击性或孤僻的儿童有可能出现情绪、社交和学习上的困难。尽管我们知道他们也容易受到健康问题的影响，但这些问题从童年到成熟的性质和普遍性尚未得到很好的描述。重要的是，这样做是为了使资源充足的预防和补救措施的论点具有说服力和说服力。康科迪亚纵向项目始于1976年，一直在跟踪1770名市中心好斗、孤僻、普通的孩子，这些孩子现在30多岁，有自己的孩子。该项目收集了大量的档案数据，涵盖了25年的时间，没有指认孩子、父母和子女的名字。孩子们现在已经是三十多岁的成年人了，有了自己的孩子。这些数据将使我们能够记录这些儿童在青春期和成年期间的特殊健康问题的频率和性质，以及他们的父母和子女的健康问题。我们还将确定贫困、犯罪、教育和损害健康的生活方式等因素对儿童攻击和退缩以及后来的健康问题之间联系的影响。这项研究具有不同寻常的特点。它跟踪了好斗和孤僻的女孩和男孩到成年，因此它可以记录每一性别在每个发育阶段的具体健康问题；它的档案数据库提供了关于广泛的健康问题的详细信息，包括心理和身体问题；从童年到成熟的成年期；也许，它最不寻常和最原始的特征——研究的三代数据库提供了一个视角，可以看到攻击和退缩的健康危害从一代转移到下一代。

Project.Title: MOLECULAR GENETIC MARKERS FOR TICK VECTORS

Title_Other.Title: 蜱虫载体的分子遗传标记
MOLECULAR GENETIC MARKERS FOR TICK VECTORS

Class.ClassName: 计算机安全、计算机保密

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (adapted from applicant's abstract): The long term goal of the proposed research is to identify and develop molecular genetic markers for the identification and assessment of vector competence of Ixodes spp. ticks. Ticks in the genus Ixodes (~240 spp), and especially those in the largest subgenus Ixodes (~75 spp), are becoming increasingly familiar to the public health community because of their ability to transmit multiple diseases to humans and animals, such as protozoa (e.g., Babesia), viruses (e.g., tick-borne encephalitis), and bacteria (e.g., Erlichia and the Lyme disease agent, Borrelia burgdorferi). Although only about 10% of tick species are of public health importance, it is necessary to accurately identify all species because of their different abilities to transmit disease agents, as is the case with Ixodes spp. For example, it is difficult to distinguish members of this genus when individuals become damaged upon removal, which is too often true when ticks are submitted for identification. Therefore, the specific aims of this proposal are to (1) develop a pcr-based key to all 34 species of Ixodes found in the USA using the proven segment of nuclear ribosomal DNA, the second internal transcribed spacer (ITS-2), (2) develop new polymorphic molecular genetic markers from single copy nuclear genes and introns (e.g., beta tubulin and ef-1 alpha) and by using proven RAPD primers, single-strand polymorphisms, and other techniques for identifying multiple markers in the 300-500 bp range, optimal for SSCP. In this aim, tick cell cultures will be utilized as a source of consistent and high-quality DNA, and (3) compare the vector competence of the 18 mitochondrial haplotypes of Ixodes scapularis to I. (I.) pacificus and I. (Ixodiopsis) woodi using 3 B. burgdorferi strains from the northeastern, southeastern, and western regions of the USA.

In this aim, tick cell cultures will be utilized as a source of consistent and high-quality DNA, and (3) compare the vector competence of the 18 mitochondrial haplotypes of Ixodes scapularis to I. (I.) pacificus and I. (Ixodiopsis) woodi using 3 B. burgdorferi strains from the northeastern, southeastern, and western regions of the USA.

描述（改编自申请人的摘要）：本研究的长期目标是鉴定和开发用于鉴定和评估硬蜱病媒能力的分子遗传标记。硬蜱属（约240种）的蜱类，特别是硬蜱最大亚属（约75种）的蜱类，因其能将多种疾病传播给人和动物，如原生动物（如巴贝虫）、病毒（如蜱媒脑炎）和细菌（如二里峡）而越来越为公共卫生界所熟悉莱姆病的病原体，伯格多菲螺旋体。尽管只有大约10%的蜱类具有公共卫生重要性，但由于其传播疾病病原体的能力不同，必须准确识别所有物种，硬蜱属就是这样。例如，当个体在被移走时受到损害时，很难区分该属的成员，在提交勾号进行标识时，这种情况经常发生。因此，本提案的具体目的是：（1）利用已证实的核核糖体DNA片段，即第二个内部转录间隔区（ITS-2），为在美国发现的所有34种硬编码物种开发基于pcr的密钥；（2）从单拷贝核基因和内含子（例如。，β-微管蛋白和ef-1α）以及利用已证实的RAPD引物、单链多态性和其他技术识别300-500bp范围内的多个标记，是SSCP的最佳选择。在这个目标中，蜱细胞培养将被用作一致和高质量DNA的来源，并且（3）使用来自美国东北部、东南部和西部地区的3个burgdorferi菌株比较肩胛硬蜱18个线粒体单倍型与太平洋硬蜱和木硬蜱的载体能力。

Source.Name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Project.Title: Development of a prediction model for advanced age-related macular degeneration

Title_Other.Title: 老年性黄斑变性预测模型的建立
Development of a prediction model for advanced age-related macular degeneration

Project.Abstract: PROJECT ABSTRACT Background Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a progressive disease, the advanced forms of which account for over 50% of legal blindness in the US. Vision impairment due to advanced AMD also significantly reduces quality of life and consumes a large portion of Medicare budget. Diminishing the modifiable risk factors for the progression of AMD could lead to significant clinical benefit and save health care cost. However, early identification and close follow-up of patients at high risk of developing advanced AMD are essential to allow for implementing strategies to delay progression of the disease to stages when vision is compromised. Recently, using the Age-Related Eye Disease Study (AREDS) dataset PI (Chiu) developed a prediction model for advanced AMD (c-index=0.877). However, validation analysis of this AREDS model in the Blue Mountains Eye Study (BMES) cohort indicated that it is necessary to use data from multiple cohorts to develop a prediction model with maximal generalizability. Objective Our objective is to use risk factor information provided in the patient history and clinical eye examinations to develop a widely applicable tool for the early prediction of advanced AMD. Methods Using methods extended from PI's (Chiu's) previous publications and pooled data of over 15,000 persons from four major cohorts, including the AREDS cohort (n=4,757 at baseline; data followed for 8 y will be used), the Beaver Dam Eye Study (BDES) cohort (n= 4,926 at baseline; data followed for 15 y will be used), the BMES cohort (n= 3,654 at baseline; data followed for 10 y will be used), and the Melbourne Visual Impairment Project (VIP) cohort (n= 3,271 at baseline; data followed for 5 y will be used), we will use logistic regression to model result-specific likelihood ratios of developing advanced AMD by 8 baseline demographic (n=5) and ocular (n=3) predictors. The quasi-likelihood under the independence model criterion (QIC) statistic will be used to determine the best model. Next, a composite scoring system (C score) derived from this regression analysis will be applied in the four cohorts individually to evaluate the accuracy and to depict the relationship of C score-advanced AMD risk at various times during follow-up (up to 15 y) by Kaplan-Meier estimators and Cox proportional-hazards regression using the Andersen-Gill estimators. Potential implications Our C scoring system will enhance our ability to delay progress of AMD from early stages to clinically relevant diseases. It will be useful to clinicians for communicating with patients and guiding prevention and treatment plans at very early stages of disease well in advance of vision- compromising manifestations, to researchers for increasing study power while reducing cost, and to policymakers for allocating Medicare resources.

老年性黄斑变性（AMD）是一种进行性疾病，其晚期占美国法定盲的50%以上。晚期AMD导致的视力损害也显著降低了生活质量，并消耗了医疗保险预算的很大一部分。减少AMD进展的可改变的危险因素可以带来显著的临床效益和节省医疗费用。然而，早期发现和密切随访有发展为晚期AMD高风险的患者是必要的，以便实施策略，将疾病进展延迟到视力受损的阶段。最近，利用年龄相关性眼病研究（AREDS）数据集PI（Chiu）建立了一个预测晚期AMD（c指数=0.877）的模型。然而，在蓝山眼科研究（BMES）队列中，对AREDS模型的验证分析表明，有必要使用来自多个队列的数据来开发具有最大概化性的预测模型。目的利用患者病史和临床眼科检查中提供的危险因素信息，为早期预测晚期AMD提供一个广泛应用的工具。方法采用PI's（Chiu's）以前发表的方法和4个主要队列的15000多人的综合数据，包括AREDS队列（基线时n=4757；使用8年后的数据）、Beaver Dam Eye Study队列（基线时n=4926；使用15年后的数据）、BMES队列（n=3，基线时654例；使用10年随访的数据）和墨尔本视觉障碍项目（VIP）队列（基线时n=3271；使用5年随访的数据），我们将使用logistic回归，通过8个基线人口统计学（n=5）和眼科（n=3）预测因子，对进展性AMD的结果特异性似然比进行建模。在独立模型准则（QIC）统计量下的拟似然将被用来确定最佳模型。接下来，从回归分析中得到的综合评分系统（C评分）将分别应用于四个队列中，通过Kaplan-Meier估计器和使用Andersen Gill的Cox比例危险回归，评估其准确性，并描述随访期间（15年内）不同时间C评分与晚期AMD风险之间的关系估计员。我们的C评分系统将提高我们延缓AMD从早期进展到临床相关疾病的能力。这将有助于临床医生与患者沟通，在疾病的早期阶段指导预防和治疗计划，在视力受损的表现之前，有助于研究人员在降低成本的同时提高研究能力，也有助于决策者分配医疗保险资源。

Project.Title: Mechanisms of gene expression control during the cellular response to hypoxia

Title_Other.Title: Mechanisms of gene expression control during the cellular response to hypoxia
细胞缺氧反应中基因表达调控机制的研究

Class.ClassName: 理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract: PROJECT SUMMARY. Oxygen homeostasis is critical for cell survival, normal development, and tissue function. Low levels of oxygen (hypoxia) activate the transcription factors known as hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs). HIFs are the key regulators of the adaptive response to hypoxia, regulating genes involved in metabolic reprograming, angiogenesis, pluripotency and differentiation, epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT), and apoptosis. Accordingly, HIF activity is critical during many pathological processes, including cancer progression, obesity, heart disease, and stroke. The work proposed here focuses on HIF1A with the immediate goal of significantly advancing our mechanistic knowledge of the cellular response to hypoxia, and the ultimate goal of illuminating novel therapeutic strategies for human pathologies driven by HIF1A. A detailed dissection of the molecular mechanisms by which HIF1A and its cofactors regulate gene expression, both directly and indirectly, as well as the identification of the key genes required for the cellular adaptation to hypoxia will be critical to fully understand how different cell types and tissues react to this stress, and to envision how these responses can be manipulated during the course of disease. Using a combination of genomic, molecular biology, and functional approaches, this research proposal aims to: · Define mechanisms driving cell type-specific gene expression upon activation of HIF1A by hypoxia. · Elucidate the mechanisms of action of HIF1A transcriptional coactivators. · Identify and characterize genes required for cell survival in hypoxia.

Low levels of oxygen (hypoxia) activate the transcription factors known as hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs). HIFs are the key regulators of the adaptive response to hypoxia, regulating genes involved in metabolic reprograming, angiogenesis, pluripotency and differentiation, epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT), and apoptosis. Accordingly, HIF activity is critical during many pathological processes, including cancer progression, obesity, heart disease, and stroke. A detailed dissection of the molecular mechanisms by which HIF1A and its cofactors regulate gene expression, both directly and indirectly, as well as the identification of the key genes required for the cellular adaptation to hypoxia will be critical to fully understand how different cell types and tissues react to this stress, and to envision how these responses can be manipulated during the course of disease. 项目总结。氧稳态对细胞存活、正常发育和组织功能至关重要。低水平的氧气（缺氧）激活了被称为缺氧诱导因子（HIFs）的转录因子。HIFs是低氧适应性反应的关键调控因子，参与代谢重编程、血管生成、多能性和分化、上皮间质转化（EMT）和细胞凋亡等基因的调控。因此，HIF活性在许多病理过程中至关重要，包括癌症进展、肥胖、心脏病和中风。本文提出的工作重点是HIF1A，其直接目标是显著提高我们对细胞缺氧反应机制的认识，最终目的是阐明HIF1A驱动的人类病理治疗新策略。HIF1A及其辅因子直接或间接调控基因表达的分子机制的详细分析，确定细胞适应缺氧所需的关键基因，对于充分了解不同细胞类型和组织如何对这种压力作出反应，以及设想如何在疾病过程中操纵这些反应，都是至关重要的。结合基因组学、分子生物学和功能学的研究方法，本研究计划旨在：定义缺氧激活HIF1A时细胞类型特异性基因表达的机制。·阐明HIF1A转录辅活化子的作用机制。·识别和鉴定缺氧条件下细胞生存所需的基因。

Source.Name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

Project.Title: AF: Small: Distributed Optimization Beyond Worst Case Topologies

Title_Other.Title: AF:Small：超越最坏情况拓扑的分布式优化
AF: Small: Distributed Optimization Beyond Worst Case Topologies

Project.Abstract: The modern computation and information processing systems shaping our world are ever increasing in scale and have become massively distributed. A fundamental understanding of distributed algorithms and optimization problems has in the past and inevitably will in the future lead to more efficient, more scalable, and overall vastly more powerful systems and applications with broad impacts on society. With this goal in mind, this project is developing an algorithmic toolbox for designing distributed optimization algorithms which drastically outperform state-of-the-art algorithms on non-worst-case topologies, common in practice. The project will also contribute greatly to the education and professional training of students in this critical field. The project plans to integrate research and education through curriculum development activities spanning graduate and undergraduate courses and provides initiatives and concrete steps taken by the project team to attract, excite, mentor, and support students from underrepresented groups. The shift towards massively distributed systems in practice has led to an increased interest and fast acceleration in our theoretical understanding of distributed optimization problems. However much of this work focuses on the algorithmic performance in worst-case topologies. Real world networks, however, do not always exhibit worst-case behavior and most networks of interest do not share the limiting bottleneck characteristics which dominate the current analyses of worst-case algorithms and their provable performance guarantees. In particular, there is no known barrier for ultra-fast polylogarithmic round distributed algorithms on any network of interest, while most current algorithms require Theta(sqrt(n)) rounds on any (such) topology, mostly because such a running time can be shown to be necessary on some practically irrelevant pathologically bad topologies. This almost exponential gap between worst-case-optimal Theta(sqrt(n)) algorithms and the ultra-fast performance which is likely possible in many, if not all, real-world settings motivates this project. This project provides a detailed program for designing instance-optimal distributed algorithms. Instance-optimal algorithms are competitive with the best algorithm on any given topology and thereby constitute the strongest possible form of algorithmically adjusting to non-worst-case topologies. This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 塑造我们世界的现代计算和信息处理系统规模不断扩大，并已成为大规模分布。对分布式算法和优化问题的基本理解过去和将来都将不可避免地导致更高效、更可扩展和总体上更强大的系统和应用，并对社会产生广泛影响。考虑到这一目标，本项目正在开发一个用于设计分布式优化算法的算法工具箱，该工具箱在非最坏情况下的拓扑上大大优于目前最先进的算法，这在实践中是常见的。该项目还将大大有助于在这一关键领域对学生进行教育和专业培训。该项目计划通过跨研究生和本科课程的课程开发活动，整合研究和教育，并提供项目团队为吸引、激励、指导和支持来自代表性不足群体的学生而采取的举措和具体步骤。在实践中向大规模分布式系统的转变，使我们对分布式优化问题的理论理解越来越感兴趣，并加快了速度。然而，这些工作大多集中在最坏情况下拓扑的算法性能上。然而，现实世界中的网络并不总是表现出最坏情况下的行为，而且大多数感兴趣的网络并不具有限制性的瓶颈特征，这些特征支配了当前对最坏情况下算法及其可证明性能保证的分析。特别是，对于任何感兴趣的网络上的超快多段对数圆形分布算法，没有已知的障碍，而大多数当前算法要求在任何（这样的）拓扑上执行θ（sqrt（n））圆形，主要是因为这样的运行时间可以被证明在一些几乎不相关的病态不良拓扑上是必要的。最坏情况下的最优Theta（sqrt（n））算法和超高速性能之间的这种几乎指数级的差距，在许多（如果不是全部的话）现实世界中都可能实现，这一差距激励了这个项目。该项目为设计实例优化分布式算法提供了详细的程序。实例优化算法与任何给定拓扑上的最佳算法具有竞争性，因此构成对非最坏情况拓扑进行算法调整的最强可能形式。该奖项反映了NSF的法定使命，通过使用基金会的知识价值和更广泛的影响审查标准进行评估，被认为值得支持。

This almost exponential gap between worst-case-optimal Theta(sqrt(n)) algorithms and the ultra-fast performance which is likely possible in many, if not all, real-world settings motivates this project. Project.Title: Use of biotechnological methods, new starting materials and effective practices in winter rape breeding

Title_Other.Title: 生物技术方法、新原料和有效措施在冬油菜育种中的应用
Využití biotechnologických metod, nových výchozích materiálů a efektivních postupů ve šlechtění ozimé řepky

Project.Abstract: To use newly developed, optimized and proven biotechnology and analytical methods, new starting materials and effective breeding practices for winter rape, to create linear and hybrid varieties able to compete with foreign varieties

Abstract_Other.Abstract: Využít nově vyvinuté, optimalizované a ověřené biotechnologické a analytické metody, nové výchozí materiály a efektivní šlechtitelské postupy u ozimé řepky, vytvořit liniové a hybridní odrůdy, schopné konkurovat zahraničním odrůdám
利用新开发、优化和验证的生物技术和分析方法、新的起始材料和有效的冬油菜育种方法，创造出能与国外品种抗衡的线性和杂交品种

Project.Title: CCTN - CONTRACEPTIVE CLINICAL TRIALS NETWORK - CORE - FEMALE

Title_Other.Title: CCTN - CONTRACEPTIVE CLINICAL TRIALS NETWORK - CORE - FEMALE
CCTN-避孕临床试验网络-核心-女性

Project.Abstract: The National Institutes of Health (NIH), Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD), is the lead Federal agency for the conduct of basic, clinical research to develop new contraceptives and to evaluate existing methods of contraception and reproductive health. The Center for Population Research (CPR), within NICHD, was established in 1968 by the Secretary of Health Education and Welfare, with the important goal of developing new contraceptives through the use of contracts and grants. Within CPR, the Contraception and Reproductive Health Branch (CRHB) has long supported several preclinical contraceptive testing facilities as well as facilities for synthetic chemical and synthetic peptide formulation. To further expand their contraceptive development capabilities, in 1996 CRHB established the NICHD Contraceptive Clinical Trials Network (CCTN). The current CCTN has conducted Phase I, II, and III clinical trials of both female and male contraceptive methods. With the recompetition of the CCTN, clinical sites will perform Phase I, II, III, and Phase IV clinical trials of a wide variety of new or existing female contraceptive methods.

The Center for Population Research (CPR), within NICHD, was established in 1968 by the Secretary of Health Education and Welfare, with the important goal of developing new contraceptives through the use of contracts and grants. With the recompetition of the CCTN, clinical sites will perform Phase I, II, III, and Phase IV clinical trials of a wide variety of new or existing female contraceptive methods.

美国国立卫生研究院（NIH）、尤尼斯·肯尼迪·施赖弗国家儿童健康和人类发展研究院（NICHD）是进行基础和临床研究的主要联邦机构，旨在开发新的避孕药具，并评估现有的避孕方法和生殖健康。人口研究中心（CPR）由卫生教育及福利局局长于1968年成立，其重要目标是通过使用合同和补助金开发新的避孕药具。在CPR中，避孕和生殖健康处（CRHB）长期以来一直支持一些临床前避孕测试设施以及合成化学和合成肽制剂的设施。为了进一步扩大其避孕药具的开发能力，1996年CRHB建立了NICHD避孕药具临床试验网络（CCTN）。目前，CCTN已经对女性和男性避孕方法进行了一期、二期和三期临床试验。随着CCTN的重新申请，临床中心将对各种新的或现有的女性避孕方法进行一期、二期、三期和四期临床试验。

Project.Title: Collaborative: US-GLOBEC NEP Phase IIIa-CCS: Effects of Meso- and Basin-scale Variability on Zooplankton Populations in the CCS using Data-Assimilative, Physical/Ecosystem Models

Title_Other.Title: 协作：US-GLOBEC NEP II期IA CCS：利用数据同化、物理/生态系统模型研究中尺度和流域尺度变化对CCS中浮游动物种群的影响
Collaborative: US-GLOBEC NEP Phase IIIa-CCS: Effects of Meso- and Basin-scale Variability on Zooplankton Populations in the CCS using Data-Assimilative, Physical/Ecosystem Models

Project.Abstract: The studies are designed to elucidate mechanisms that determine how physical features influence ecosystem processes. The investigators will develop nested models that encompass phenomena across the entire North Pacific basin -- e.g., ENSO and regime shift/PDO-linked features -- and incorporate variability over interannual to decadal time scales. They will direct special attention to zooplankton, at both the individual population level (e.g., euphausiids), and at the aggregated community level and employ advanced data assimilation (e.g., of the mesoscale surveys) to produce optimal merged data/model products for use by the GLOBEC NEP synthesis effort. The coupled physical-ecosystem model products will include dynamically consistent, data-assimilative hindcasts for the region and time of the CCS field experiments and multi-decadal, basin-scale, nested calculations (1970-present). With this research, the investigators seek to (i) quantify how physical features in the California Current System and variability related to climate change impact zooplankton biomass, production, distribution, and the retention and loss of zooplankton from coastal regions and (ii) compare the impacts of climate variability and change (such as El Nino-La Nina cycles and regime shifts) on marine animal populations (euphausiids) in the CCS and CGOA. Both of these respond directly to stated goals of the GLOBEC NEP synthesis program. In addition, this project will afford the opportunity for multiple Ph.D. scientists and undergraduate students, working either directly with the PIs or by attendance at the proposed workshops, to participate in GLOBEC synthesis.
