Project.Title: Unentangled glassy polymer nanofilms and string-like hopping motions

Title_Other.Title: 无缠结的玻璃状聚合物纳米薄膜与弦状跳跃运动
Unentangled glassy polymer nanofilms and string-like hopping motions

Project.Abstract: Abstract as per original application: Structural glasses, such as common silicate glasses, glassy polymers, and amorphous metals, are supercooled liquids with atomic or molecular motions dramatically slowed down upon cooling towards the glass transition temperature. The fundamental mechanism responsible for the corresponding glass transition is one of the most fundamental and long-standing puzzles in condensed matter physics. Besides being studied in bulk form, glasses in confined geometries including glassy polymer films of thickness in the nanometer regime have provided much further information. Their studies are also important technologically as polymer nanostructures are widely used in advanced electronic packaging, photoresist structures, battery matrix, lubrication, and adhesive applications. Experiments on short-chain unentangled polystyrene nanofilms have shown that a highly mobile surface layer exists on the free film surface and this mobile layer is believed to be responsible for many confinement effects including enhanced flow mobility and reduced glass transition temperature commonly observed. Computer simulations also show that particles in glasses in general move via intermittent hopping motions each over a distance comparable to the particle diameter. Moreover, hopping events typically occur in small groups of particles in a correlated form called string-like motion in which neighboring particles arranged in a line displace one another from head to tail. Recently, we observe from molecular dynamics simulations of bulk polymers that string-like motions become highly reversible and repetitive close to the glass transition temperature and this can be the major cause of the slow down of the dynamics. Our simulations of polymer films also indicate that the mobile surface layer may be induced by the propagation of strings to and from the free surface throughout the layer. We propose to study glassy polymer films using large-scale molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and analytical calculations. We will quantitatively measure using MD simulations of short-chain polymer films various statistical properties of string-like motions in the surface mobile layer. A mathematical explanation of the mobile layer based on string propagation will be attempted. We will also refine the definition of strings to better describe the logical sequence of particle motions and to better generalize its application to film geometry. Moreover, starting from a unified set of measured or calculated particle hopping probabilities, we will derive and relate the diverse behaviors of confinement effects exhibited in viscous flow, thermal expansion, and other phenomena.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 按原申请摘要： 结构玻璃，如普通硅酸盐玻璃、玻璃状聚合物和非晶金属，是原子或分子运动在向玻璃转变温度冷却时显著减慢的过冷液体。玻璃化转变的基本机制是凝聚态物理中最基本、最长久的难题之一。除了以体积形式进行研究外，受限几何结构的玻璃（包括厚度为纳米的玻璃状聚合物膜）还提供了更多的信息。由于聚合物纳米结构广泛应用于先进的电子封装、光刻胶结构、电池基体、润滑和粘合剂等领域，因此它们的研究在技术上也很重要。 短链未缠结聚苯乙烯纳米薄膜的实验表明，在自由膜表面上存在高度移动的表面层，并且认为该移动层负责许多限制效应，包括增强的流动迁移率和通常观察到的降低的玻璃化转变温度。计算机模拟还表明，玻璃中的粒子通常通过间歇跳跃运动移动，每一个跳跃运动的距离与粒子直径相当。此外，跳跃事件通常以一种称为弦状运动的相关形式出现在一小群粒子中，其中排列成一条直线的相邻粒子从头部到尾部相互位移。近年来，我们从大体积聚合物的分子动力学模拟中观察到，在接近玻璃化转变温度的情况下，弦状运动具有高度的可逆性和重复性，这可能是导致动力学缓慢的主要原因。我们对聚合物薄膜的模拟也表明，流动表面层可能是由弦在整个层的自由表面上的传播引起的。 我们建议使用大规模分子动力学（MD）模拟和分析计算来研究玻璃状聚合物薄膜。我们将利用分子动力学模拟定量测量短链聚合物薄膜表面移动层中弦状运动的各种统计特性。将尝试基于字符串传播对移动层进行数学解释。我们还将改进字符串的定义，以更好地描述粒子运动的逻辑序列，并更好地将其应用于胶片几何。此外，我们将从一组统一的测量或计算的粒子跳跃概率出发，推导并关联在粘性流动、热膨胀和其他现象中所表现出的各种约束效应行为。

Abstract as per original application: Structural glasses, such as common silicate glasses, glassy polymers, and amorphous metals, are supercooled liquids with atomic or molecular motions dramatically slowed down upon cooling towards the glass transition temperature. The fundamental mechanism responsible for the corresponding glass transition is one of the most fundamental and long-standing puzzles in condensed matter physics. Besides being studied in bulk form, glasses in confined geometries including glassy polymer films of thickness in the nanometer regime have provided much further information. Their studies are also important technologically as polymer nanostructures are widely used in advanced electronic packaging, photoresist structures, battery matrix, lubrication, and adhesive applications. Experiments on short-chain unentangled polystyrene nanofilms have shown that a highly mobile surface layer exists on the free film surface and this mobile layer is believed to be responsible for many confinement effects including enhanced flow mobility and reduced glass transition temperature commonly observed. Computer simulations also show that particles in glasses in general move via intermittent hopping motions each over a distance comparable to the particle diameter. Moreover, hopping events typically occur in small groups of particles in a correlated form called string-like motion in which neighboring particles arranged in a line displace one another from head to tail. Recently, we observe from molecular dynamics simulations of bulk polymers that string-like motions become highly reversible and repetitive close to the glass transition temperature and this can be the major cause of the slow down of the dynamics. Our simulations of polymer films also indicate that the mobile surface layer may be induced by the propagation of strings to and from the free surface throughout the layer. We propose to study glassy polymer films using large-scale molecular dynamics (MD) simulations and analytical calculations. We will quantitatively measure using MD simulations of short-chain polymer films various statistical properties of string-like motions in the surface mobile layer. A mathematical explanation of the mobile layer based on string propagation will be attempted. We will also refine the definition of strings to better describe the logical sequence of particle motions and to better generalize its application to film geometry. Moreover, starting from a unified set of measured or calculated particle hopping probabilities, we will derive and relate the diverse behaviors of confinement effects exhibited in viscous flow, thermal expansion, and other phenomena.

Project.Title: IDENTIFICATION AND VALIDATION OF NEW MARKERS OF METASTATING PHENOTIP OF MAMMELLA CARCINOMA

Title_Other.Title: IDENTIFICAZIONE E VALIDAZIONE DI NUOVI MARCATORI DEL FENOTIPO METASTATIZZANTE DEL CARCINOMA DELLA MAMMELLA
乳腺癌二尖瓣新标记物的鉴定与验证

Class.ClassName: 理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract:
Recurrences and metastases continue to represent the most important challenges in treating patients with breast cancer. As the clinical history of the disease and its treatment depend on the stage, it is essential to have accurate staging procedures. The available prognostic parameters consist of the traditional pathological features that make up the TNM system, based only on anatomic extension elements of the disease. After loco-regional radical surgery, the presence of metastasis in axillary lymph nodes is used to identify patients at high risk for disease recovery; Multivariate statistical analyzes consistently indicate that the presence (N +) or absence (N) of metastasis in axillary lymph nodes is the most potent prognostic indicator of recurrence and death for neoplasia. However, one-third of N-patients are not cured by loco-regional treatment and one-quarter of N + patients are alive and ill-treated even after many years. This problem can be addressed by developing a set of factors that allow for a specific risk assessment for the individual patient, as an alternative to the current risk assessment for casualty population, following three integrated and converging paths: - evaluating the impact of new lymph node staging techniques - identifying the biological mechanisms that regulate the variability of the metastatic capacity of the different tumors - generating statistical models that produce numerical estimates of individual risk.
The study focuses on the identification and validation of old and new prognostic and predictive parameters, useful in defining diversified adjuvant strategies and proportional to the individual risk of each patient suffering from breast cancer. For this purpose, all Affiliated Research Units will use the same starting case, contributing their respective parameters to an integrated assessment. The baseline case consists of 1000 pTNM consecutive consecutive consecutive median follow-ups> 8 years, already characterized by immunohistochemistry and image analysis for: Estrogen Receptor, Progesterone Receptor, Proliferative Index with MIB-1, p53 overexpression, over-expression of c- ErbB-2 / Neu, ploidia. All cases include tumor and lymph node inclusions in paraffin. Cryopreserved tumor samples are available for 400 cases Proceed as follows: - Immunohistochemical lymph node restenosis with anti-cytotoxic monoclonal antibodies - Biomolecular lymph node restenosis with RT-PCR for CEA and Mammoglobin - Biological tumor staging by immunohistochemistry (E-caderine, nm23, galectine, 90K, neoangiogenesis, integrins, bone sialoprotein, p27Kip1, EGF-R) - Biomolecular tumor staging with PCR (BRCA1, BRCA2, 16q, TP53, NM23 / NDPK.H1 / .H2 The case will be analyzed step by step through innovative statistical models and artificial neural networks. The objectives of the study are as follows: - Assessment of sensitivity / specificity and cost / benefit of immunohistochemical techniques and molecular biology of lymph node staging - Evaluation of the contribution of the new lymph node staging so as to predict the course of the neoplastic disease - Evaluation of prognostic significance of lymph node micrometastases - Identification of tumor characteristics and their biological mechanisms associated with the acquisition of metastatic lymph node and systemic capacity - Evaluation of the prognostic contribution of new markers characterizing the metastatic tumor phenotype - Generation of integrated prognostic classification models optimized for the predictive capacity of the individual patient's course.

Abstract_Other.Abstract:
Recidive e metastasi continuano a rappresentare le sfide piÃ¹ importanti nel trattamento delle pazienti con carcinoma mammario. PoichÃ¨ la storia clinica della malattia ed il suo trattamento dipendono dallo stadio, Ã¨ essenziale disporre di procedure accurate di stadiazione. I parametri prognostici disponibili consistono nelle tradizionali caratteristiche patologiche che compongono il sistema TNM, basato soltanto su elementi di estensione anatomica della malattia. Dopo chirurgia radicale loco-regionale, la presenza di metastasi nei linfonodi ascellari Ã¨ utilizzata per identificare le pazienti ad alto rischio di ripresa di malattia; le analisi statistiche multivariate costantemente indicano che la presenza (N+) o l'assenza (N-) di metastasi nei linfonodi ascellari rappresenta il piÃ¹ potente indicatore prognostico di recidiva e morte per neoplasia. Tuttavia, un terzo delle pazienti N- non sono guarite dal trattamento loco-regionale ed un quarto delle pazienti N+ sono vive ed esenti da malattia anche dopo molti anni. Questo problema puÃ² essere affrontato sviluppando un insieme di fattori che consentano di ottenere una valutazione specifica del rischio per la singola paziente, in alternativa alla corrente valutazione del rischio per popolazione casistica, seguendo tre percorsi integrati e convergenti: - valutando l'impatto di nuove tecniche di stadiazione linfonodale - identificando i meccanismi biologici che regolano la variabilit della capacit metastatizzante dei diversi tumori - generando modelli statistici che producano stime numeriche del rischio individualizzato.
Lo studio Ã¨ incentrato sulla identificazione e validazione di vecchi e nuovi parametri prognostici e predittivi, utili a definire strategie di trattamento adiuvante diversificate e proporzionate al rischio individuale di ciascuna paziente affetta da carcinoma mammario. A tal fine tutte le Unit di ricerca consociate utilizzeranno la medesima casistica di partenza, contribuendo i rispettivi parametri ad una valutazione integrata. La casistica base consta di 1000 casi consecutivi stadiati pTNM con followup mediano >8 anni, gi caratterizzati mediante immunoistochimica e analisi di immagine per:Recettore degli estrogeni, Recettore del Progesterone, Indice Proliferativo con MIB-1, overespressione di p53, overespressione di c-erbB-2/Neu, ploidia. Per tutti i casi sono disponibili i campioni tumorali e linfonodali inclusi in paraffina. Per 400 casi sono disponibili i campioni tumorali criopreservati Si proceder come segue: - Ristadiazione linfonodale immunoistochimica con anticorpi monoclonali anticitocheratine - Ristadiazione linfonodale biomolecolare con RT-PCR per CEA e Mammoglobina - Stadiazione tumorale biologica mediante immunoistochimica (E-caderina, nm23, galectine, 90K, neoangiogenesi, integrine, sialoproteina ossea, p27Kip1, EGF-R) - Stadiazione tumorale biomolecolare con PCR (BRCA1, BRCA2, 16q, TP53, NM23/NDPK.H1/.H2 La casistica verr analizzata passo passo mediante modelli statistici innovativi e reti neurali artificiali. Gli obiettivi dello studio sono i seguenti: - Valutazione di sensibilit/specificit e di costo/beneficio delle tecniche immunoistochimiche e di biologia molecolare di stadiazione linfonodale - Valutazione del contributo della nuova stadiazione linfonodale cosÃ¬ conseguita alla previsione del decorso della malattia neoplastica - Valutazione del significato prognostico delle micrometastasi linfonodali - Identificazione delle caratteristiche tumorali, e dei rispettivi meccanismi biologici, che si associano all'acquisizione della capacit metastatizzante linfonodale e sistemica - Valutazione del contributo prognostico dei nuovi marcatori caratterizzanti il fenotipo tumorale metastatizzante - Generazione di modelli integrati di classificazione prognostica ottimizzati per capacit predittiva del decorso della singola paziente.

复发和转移仍然是治疗乳腺癌患者最重要的挑战。由于该病的临床病史和治疗取决于分期，因此有准确的分期程序是至关重要的。可用的预后参数包括构成TNM系统的传统病理特征，仅基于疾病的解剖扩展元素。局部区域根治术后，腋窝淋巴结转移的存在被用于识别高危患者的疾病恢复；多元统计分析一致地表明腋窝淋巴结转移的存在（n+）或缺失（n）是最有希望的复发和死亡的预后指标。对于肿瘤。然而，三分之一的N患者没有通过局部治疗治愈，四分之一的N+患者甚至在多年后仍然活着并受到虐待。 这个问题可以通过开发一组因素来解决，这些因素允许对单个患者进行特定的风险评估，作为对伤亡人口当前风险评估的替代，遵循以下三条综合和聚合路径： -新淋巴结分期技术的效果评价 -识别调节不同肿瘤转移能力变异的生物学机制 -产生统计模型，产生个人风险的数值估计。 这项研究的重点是确定和验证新旧的预后和预测参数，有助于确定各种辅助策略，并与每个乳腺癌患者的个体风险成比例。 为此，各所属研究单位将使用同一起始案例，为综合评估贡献各自的参数。 基线病例包括1000ptnm连续中位随访>8年，已经通过免疫组化和图像分析的特征：雌激素受体、孕激素受体、MIB-1增殖指数、p53过度表达、c-ErbB-2/Neu过度表达、ploidia。 所有病例均为石蜡包埋的肿瘤和淋巴结。 冷冻保存的肿瘤标本可用于400例 按以下步骤进行： 免疫组织化学单克隆抗体免疫组化淋巴结再狭窄 -应用RT-PCR检测癌胚抗原和乳腺球蛋白的生物分子淋巴结再狭窄 -免疫组化检测肿瘤分期（E-caderine，nm23，galectine，90K，新生血管生成，整合素，骨唾液蛋白，p27Kip1，EGF-R） -用PCR进行生物分子肿瘤分期（BRCA1、BRCA2、16q、TP53、NM23/NDPK.H1/.H2 该案例将通过创新的统计模型和人工神经网络逐步分析。 研究的目标如下： -免疫组化技术与淋巴结分期分子生物学的敏感性/特异性及成本/效益评价 -评估新淋巴结分期对预测肿瘤病程的作用 -淋巴结微转移的预后意义 -转移性淋巴结获得及系统功能相关肿瘤特征及其生物学机制的研究 -转移瘤表型新标志物对预后的影响 -生成综合预后分类模型，优化单个患者病程的预测能力。

Source.Name: Ministry of Education, Universities and Research

Project.Title: SHF: Small: Collaborative Research: Integrated Framework for System-Level Approximate Computing

Title_Other.Title: SHF: Small: Collaborative Research: Integrated Framework for System-Level Approximate Computing
小型：协作研究：系统级近似计算的集成框架

Project.Abstract: Nanocomputing is encountering fundamental challenges with respect to performance and power consumption; it requires different computational paradigms that exploit specific features in the targeted set of applications as well as an integrated framework for assessing the interactions between hardware and the processing algorithms (software). Approximate (inexact) computing has been advocated as a novel approach for nanocomputing design. Approximate computing generates results that are good enough rather than always fully accurate and correct outputs. Recent advances at circuit level have shown that there is an urgent need to investigate and enable at system-level the flexible utilization, improvement and close monitoring of approximate resources; this allows the efficient and integrated interaction of algorithms and hardware to meet the multiple and often conflicting figures of merit of high performance, lower power consumption and reduced inaccuracy. The goal of this project is to develop approximate computing systems that are capable of adjusting performance by exploiting relationships between hardware and software (referred to as intra-level) in different applications such as cognitive processing, DSP, big data and scientific processing for which data can be adaptively utilized and manipulated. This project is an organized effort that combines recent advances in technology with architectural enhancements into an integrated framework for approximate computing that will tackle the critical challenges of emerging computer designs in a comprehensive manner. This framework consists of new functional and computational primitives of hardware resources and related algorithms to allow an evaluation at system-level to meet the desired metrics for approximate computing. Intra-layer relationships such as number representation (such as floating point and logarithm) and accuracy by employing dynamic approximation schemes and data remediation for both communication and computing are also analyzed. This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 纳米计算在性能和功耗方面面临着根本性的挑战；它需要不同的计算范式，利用目标应用程序集中的特定功能，以及评估硬件和处理算法（软件）之间交互作用的集成框架。近似（不精确）计算被认为是纳米计算设计的一种新方法。近似计算产生足够好的结果，而不是总是完全准确和正确的输出。电路级的最新进展表明，迫切需要在系统级研究和实现对近似资源的灵活利用、改进和密切监控；这使得算法和硬件的高效集成交互能够满足高性能、低功耗和减少不精确性的多重且经常相互冲突的优点。本项目的目标是开发近似计算系统，该系统能够通过在不同的应用中利用硬件和软件（称为内部层）之间的关系来调整性能，例如认知处理、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字信号处理器、数字，大数据和科学处理，可对数据进行自适应利用和操作。该项目是一项有组织的工作，将技术的最新进展与架构的改进结合起来，形成一个综合的近似计算框架，全面应对新兴计算机设计的关键挑战。该框架由硬件资源的新功能和计算原语以及相关算法组成，允许在系统级进行评估，以满足近似计算所需的度量。文中还分析了数字表示（如浮点和对数）等层内关系，以及采用动态逼近方案和数据修正方法在通信和计算中的精度。该奖项反映了NSF的法定使命，通过使用基金会的知识价值和更广泛的影响审查标准进行评估，被认为值得支持。

Project.Title: Meal Ixil Tenam, Daughters of the People Ixil: Perception of gender in the processes of change in the modern religions of the Maya Ixil of Guatemala.

Title_Other.Title: Meal Ixil Tenam, Córki ludu Ixil: Perpektywa płci kulturowej w procesach zmian we współczesnej religijności Majów Ixil z Gwatemali.
Meal Ixil Tenam，IXIL人的女儿：瓜地马拉Maya Ixil现代宗教变迁过程中的性别意识。

Project.Title: Receiving Contexts of Return through Deportation

Title_Other.Title: 通过驱逐出境接收返回的情况
Receiving Contexts of Return through Deportation

Class.ClassName: 理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract: The research supported by this award addresses one facet of the global migration crisis: return migration through deportation. Deportation is a widely significant contemporary social, political, and intellectual problem. Existing social science scholarship has theorized deportation as a straightforward politics of exclusion that culminates in the removal of people from one national territory and their return to another. However, for most people, deportation is not only an endpoint; it also marks the beginning of long-term efforts to build viable post-deportation lives. Yet despite the key role that nation states play in shaping their citizens' decisions to migrate in the first place as well as their post-deportation experiences, contexts of return have received little sustained research attention. This project takes a broader perspective to provide the more complete picture that is needed by both theorists and policy makers. The research will be carried out by Loyola University of Chicago anthropologist, Dr. Ruth M. Gomberg-Munoz. Using a multi-year and multi-sited approach, this project involves the sustained ethnographic research necessary to better understand the sociopolitical afterlife of deportation and its effects in both Mexico and the United States. The research design comprises a three-year study of the contexts of deportees in Mexico City and Chicago. The researcher will use a mix of ethnographic research methods including participant observation, digital ethnography, in-depth and follow-up interviews, targeted semi-structured interviews, and research on state and municipal policies regarding migration and deportees. The study population will include Mexican government agents, a sample of deportees, and organizations that work with deportees. Findings from this research will advance a more robust and reliable theorization of life after deportation in three key ways. 1. The project's longitudinal design will provide the time depth needed to understand post-deportation life. 2. The analytical focus on deportees' interactions with Mexican state agencies will illuminate the role of emigrant states in shaping contexts of migrant return. 3. Attention to the quotidian activities of deportees will shed light on dynamic, cross-border cultural formations that arise in response to global securitization concerns. Using a collaborative approach to research design and dissemination, this project will make a timely and important intervention in social science scholarship on migration and removal, and it will contribute critical information for policy makers. This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

这一奖项支持的研究涉及全球移民危机的一个方面：通过驱逐出境的返回移民。驱逐出境是当代一个具有广泛意义的社会、政治和知识问题。现有的社会科学学术理论认为，驱逐出境是一种直截了当的排斥政治，最终导致人们离开一个国家领土，返回另一个国家领土。然而，对大多数人来说，驱逐出境不仅是一个终点；它还标志着建立可行的驱逐出境后生活的长期努力的开始。然而，尽管民族国家在一开始就决定其公民的移民以及他们被驱逐出境后的经历方面发挥着关键作用，但返回背景却很少得到持续的研究关注。这个项目采取了一个更广泛的视角，以提供理论界和政策制定者所需要的更完整的画面。这项研究将由芝加哥洛约拉大学人类学家露丝·M·戈姆伯格·穆诺兹博士进行。该项目采用多年和多地点的方法，进行必要的持续民族志研究，以便更好地了解驱逐出境的社会政治后果及其在墨西哥和美国的影响。研究设计包括对墨西哥城和芝加哥被驱逐者的背景进行为期三年的研究。研究人员将采用多种民族志研究方法，包括参与者观察、数字民族志、深入访谈和后续访谈、有针对性的半结构化访谈，以及有关移民和被驱逐者的国家和市政政策的研究。研究对象包括墨西哥政府官员、被驱逐者样本以及与被驱逐者合作的组织。这项研究的发现将从三个关键方面推进驱逐出境后生活更为稳健和可靠的理论化。一。该项目的纵向设计将提供了解驱逐出境后生活所需的时间深度。2。分析重点放在被驱逐者与墨西哥国家机构的互动上，将阐明移民国家在塑造移民返回环境方面的作用。三。关注被驱逐出境者的日常活动，将有助于了解为应对全球证券化问题而出现的动态、跨国界的文化形态。该项目采用合作的方式进行研究设计和传播，将对移民和迁移问题的社会科学研究进行及时和重要的干预，并将为决策者提供重要信息。该奖项反映了NSF的法定使命，通过使用基金会的知识价值和更广泛的影响审查标准进行评估，被认为值得支持。

Source.Name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral & Economic Sciences

Project.Title: Collaborative Research: Optimizing Multibeam Data Acquisition Operations and Quality for the U.S. Academic Research Fleet

Title_Other.Title: 协同研究：优化美国学术研究舰队的多波束数据采集操作和质量
Collaborative Research: Optimizing Multibeam Data Acquisition Operations and Quality for the U.S. Academic Research Fleet

Project.Abstract: This collaborative effort proposes to establish technical resources and new communication mechanisms to develop and share common information, tools, and expertise regarding the operation and monitoring of multibeam sonars across the U.S. Academic Fleet. The strategy is to create a community of stakeholders including representatives from each operating institution, complemented by key outside experts from the user and technical/engineering communities that can assist in providing guidance on a broad array of multibeam issues to improve how these data are collected and assessed. In addition, the effort proposes to establish a Multibeam Advisory Committee (MAC) that will act as an overall coordinating body with the primary goal of supporting mapping operations onboard vessels in the U.S. academic research fleet and ensuring that high quality data are consistently acquired. They will also assemble small groups of individuals from the MAC and community of stakeholders into technical teams, each of which is tasked with specific components of multibeam system performance evaluation. Broader Impacts The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The support of maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers. All users (or the appropriate funding agencies) share support for basic pooled services on the vessel equally, with NSF paying a share of the support costs based on fractional usage of the vessel during the year.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 这项合作计划旨在建立技术资源和新的通信机制，以开发和共享有关美国学术舰队多波束声纳操作和监测的共同信息、工具和专业知识。该战略是建立一个利益相关者社区，包括每个运营机构的代表，并辅之以用户和技术/工程社区的关键外部专家，这些专家可协助就广泛的多波束问题提供指导，以改进如何收集和评估这些数据。此外，该项工作还提议建立一个多波束咨询委员会（MAC），作为一个整体协调机构，其主要目标是支持美国学术研究舰队船只上的测绘作业，并确保一致获得高质量数据。他们还将把来自MAC和利益相关者社区的一小群人组织成技术团队，每个团队负责多波束系统性能评估的特定组成部分。更广泛的影响本提案的主要影响是根据标准2，为科学家使用船只及其共用仪器支持其国家科学基金资助的海洋学研究项目提供基础设施支持（这些项目单独接受国家科学基金相关研究计划的单独审查）。支持共享使用仪器的维护和操作，使NSF资助的任何美国大学或实验室的研究人员都可以使用工作的、经过校准的仪器进行研究，降低研究成本，并扩大潜在研究人员的基础。所有用户（或适当的供资机构）平等分享对船舶上基本集合服务的支持，NSF根据船舶在年内的部分使用情况支付一部分支持费用。

This collaborative effort proposes to establish technical resources and new communication mechanisms to develop and share common information, tools, and expertise regarding the operation and monitoring of multibeam sonars across the U.S. Academic Fleet. The strategy is to create a community of stakeholders including representatives from each operating institution, complemented by key outside experts from the user and technical/engineering communities that can assist in providing guidance on a broad array of multibeam issues to improve how these data are collected and assessed. In addition, the effort proposes to establish a Multibeam Advisory Committee (MAC) that will act as an overall coordinating body with the primary goal of supporting mapping operations onboard vessels in the U.S. academic research fleet and ensuring that high quality data are consistently acquired. They will also assemble small groups of individuals from the MAC and community of stakeholders into technical teams, each of which is tasked with specific components of multibeam system performance evaluation. Broader Impacts The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The support of maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers. All users (or the appropriate funding agencies) share support for basic pooled services on the vessel equally, with NSF paying a share of the support costs based on fractional usage of the vessel during the year.

Project.Title: Networked embedded control systems

Title_Other.Title: 网络化嵌入式控制系统
Networked embedded control systems

Class.ClassName: 自动控制、自动控制系统
自动化技术、自动化技术设备

Project.Abstract:
Purpose and goal: The revolutionary developments in microelectronics over the past decades have led to inexpensive yet powerful devices that can communicate with one another, sense and act on their environment. Such devices and the networks they form bring together communication, computation, sensing and control and enable monitoring and automation applications at an unprecedented scale. To take full advantage of this new technology in Swedish systems industry, novel design methods are necessary that transcend the traditional borders between disciplines. The objective of the NECS (Networked Embedded Control Systems) project is to generate precisely such a co-design framework, to integrate architectural constraints and performance tradeoffs from control and communication, while taking into account platform restrictions on complexity and energy management. This will allow the development of more efficient, robust and affordable networked control technologies that scale and adapt with changing application demands. To demonstrate and evaluate this framework, we will apply it on an experimental test-bed and in collaboration with industry on wireless automation test cases.
Expected results and effects: The NECS project focuses on embedded systems that are interconnected through wireless communication networks. The project will focus on developing rigorous methodologies for the design of networked embedded control systems and will thus result in fundamental principles and computational tools. The outcome of the project should contribute to new design paradigms that will help the application programmer and system developer to deal with the higher system complexity of wirelessly networked systems. Wireless technology has a great potential in many applications for embedded systems. Important domains for networked embedded control of particular relevance to Swedish industry are found in industrial automation, process control, automotive industry, security and telecommunication. The fundamental results of NECS will be applicable to all these areas. The experimental test-bed and target application of the project will be in wireless automation, i.e., the use of wireless technology in industrial automation and control; a major Swedish export industry.
Approach and implementation: The project is organized into the following work-packages: WP1 Scenarios and design assumptions WP2 Networked control WP3 Networking for control WP4 Transmission for control WP5 Co-design WP6 Exploitation and dissemination WP7 Test-bed

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 目的和目标： 微电子学在过去几十年里的革命性发展导致了廉价而强大的设备，它们可以相互通信、感知环境并对环境采取行动。这些设备和它们形成的网络将通信、计算、传感和控制结合在一起，使监控和自动化成为可能 空前规模的应用。为了在瑞典系统工业中充分利用这项新技术，必须采用超越学科间传统边界的新设计方法。 NECS（Networked Embedded Control Systems）项目的目标是精确地生成这样一个协同设计框架，以集成架构约束和性能权衡 从控制和通信的角度出发，同时考虑到平台复杂性和能量管理的限制。这将允许开发更高效、更健壮和更经济的网络控制技术，以适应不断变化的应用需求。为了演示和评估这个框架，我们将把它应用到一个实验测试平台上，并与业界合作进行无线自动化测试用例。 预期结果和效果： NECS项目的重点是通过无线通信网络互连的嵌入式系统。该项目将着重于开发网络化嵌入式控制系统设计的严格方法，从而产生基本原理和 计算工具。该项目的结果应该有助于新的设计模式，这将有助于应用程序程序员和系统开发人员处理无线网络系统更高的系统复杂性。无线技术在嵌入式系统中有着巨大的应用潜力。与瑞典工业特别相关的网络嵌入式控制的重要领域如下 工业自动化，过程控制，汽车工业，安全和电信。NECS的基本结果将适用于所有这些领域。该项目的实验测试台和目标应用将是在无线自动化领域，即无线技术的应用 工业自动化和控制；瑞典主要的出口工业。 方法和实施： 该项目分为以下工作包： WP1场景和设计假设 WP2网络控制 WP3控制网络 WP4控制传输 WP5共同设计 WP6开发和传播 WP7试验台

Project.Title: Extragalactic archaeology: our galaxy as a rosetta stone of galaxy evolution

Title_Other.Title: Extragalactic archaeology: our galaxy as a rosetta stone of galaxy evolution
银河系外考古学：我们的星系是星系演化的罗塞塔石

Class.ClassName: 恒星天文学、星系天文学、宇宙学

Project.Abstract: This project aims to measure the stellar populations of nearby galaxies that are apparently similar to the Milky Way. The stellar population of a galaxy provides a fossil record of its entire history and is a key window into galaxy evolution. The project will use the well-studied stellar population of our own galaxy as a galactic Rosetta Stone to interpret the light from nearby galaxies, revealing their chemical compositions and star formation histories. This project will advance understanding of galaxy evolution and reveal the evolutionary history of galaxies that are similar to our own Milky Way. The highly novel approach used will enable Australia to capitalise on its investment in optical astronomy, provide training and inspiration for the next generation of scientists, and maintain Australia’s international reputation for cutting-edge optical astronomy research.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 这个项目旨在测量与银河系相似的附近星系的恒星种群。星系的恒星群提供了整个星系历史的化石记录，是了解星系演化的关键窗口。该项目将利用我们银河系研究的恒星种群作为银河罗塞塔石来解释来自附近星系的光，揭示它们的化学成分和恒星形成历史。该项目将促进星系演化的理解，揭示银河系的演化历史，类似于我们自己的银河系。所采用的高度新颖的方法将使澳大利亚能够利用其在光学天文学方面的投资，为下一代科学家提供培训和灵感，并保持澳大利亚在光学天文学前沿研究方面的国际声誉。

This project aims to measure the stellar populations of nearby galaxies that are apparently similar to the Milky Way. The stellar population of a galaxy provides a fossil record of its entire history and is a key window into galaxy evolution. The project will use the well-studied stellar population of our own galaxy as a galactic Rosetta Stone to interpret the light from nearby galaxies, revealing their chemical compositions and star formation histories. This project will advance understanding of galaxy evolution and reveal the evolutionary history of galaxies that are similar to our own Milky Way. The highly novel approach used will enable Australia to capitalise on its investment in optical astronomy, provide training and inspiration for the next generation of scientists, and maintain Australia’s international reputation for cutting-edge optical astronomy research.

人口转型、经济增长与中国无子女家庭悖论

Project.Title: Adaptive Compliant Wing

Title_Other.Title: 自适应柔顺机翼
Adaptive Compliant Wing

Project.Abstract: Traditionally, engineered artifacts are designed to be strong and stiff. Designs in nature are strong but not stiff - they are compliant. Although nature thrives on use of compliance, the engineering world has traditionally limited itself to rigid structures and mechanisms. Practical solutions can be developed by exploiting preferred effects of compliance. Majority of current research in adaptive structures embraces the traditional notion of deploying a plethora of actuators (distributed actuation) within a stiff structure to simulate compliant behavior in an adaptive airfoil. Scalability and reliability of such distributed actuation methods is questionable. If the underlying structure is designed to be inherently compliant, then the resulting design will require fewer actuators and simpler controls.The proposed Adaptive Compliant Wind (ACW) concept relies on distributed compliance rather than distributed actuation. The ACW potentially offers significant advantages in terms of unitized light-weight construction actuated by a single conventional electric motor, high strain and force capabilities, low power requirements, excellent packaging efficiency, no heat generation, excellent dynamic response, low hysteresis and can be tailored for force or displacement amplification. The ACW concept is a new approach and a scaleable solution to the problem of achieving desired shape changes in airfoils. The ACW eliminates discrete control surfaces since the mechanism is contained within the airfoil.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 传统上，工程工件的设计是坚固的。设计在本质上是强大的，但不是僵硬的-他们是顺从的。尽管自然在顺应性的使用上蓬勃发展，但工程界传统上仅限于刚性结构和机制。可以通过利用遵从性的首选效果来开发实际的解决方案。目前对自适应结构的研究大多采用传统的概念，即在刚性结构中部署过多的执行器（分布式驱动）来模拟自适应翼型的柔顺行为。这种分布式驱动方法的可扩展性和可靠性值得怀疑。如果底层结构设计为固有柔顺，那么最终的设计将需要更少的执行器和更简单的控制，而提出的自适应柔顺风（ACW）概念依赖于分布式柔顺而不是分布式驱动。ACW在单台常规电动机驱动的组合式轻质结构、高应变和力能力、低功率要求、优异的封装效率、无发热、良好的动态响应等方面具有潜在的显著优势，低滞后，可为力或位移放大量身定制。ACW的概念是一种新的方法和可缩放的解决方案，以实现理想的形状变化的翼型。ACW消除了离散的控制面，因为该机制是包含在翼型。

Traditionally, engineered artifacts are designed to be strong and stiff. Designs in nature are strong but not stiff - they are compliant. Although nature thrives on use of compliance, the engineering world has traditionally limited itself to rigid structures and mechanisms. Practical solutions can be developed by exploiting preferred effects of compliance. Majority of current research in adaptive structures embraces the traditional notion of deploying a plethora of actuators (distributed actuation) within a stiff structure to simulate compliant behavior in an adaptive airfoil. Scalability and reliability of such distributed actuation methods is questionable. If the underlying structure is designed to be inherently compliant, then the resulting design will require fewer actuators and simpler controls.The proposed Adaptive Compliant Wind (ACW) concept relies on distributed compliance rather than distributed actuation. The ACW potentially offers significant advantages in terms of unitized light-weight construction actuated by a single conventional electric motor, high strain and force capabilities, low power requirements, excellent packaging efficiency, no heat generation, excellent dynamic response, low hysteresis and can be tailored for force or displacement amplification. The ACW concept is a new approach and a scaleable solution to the problem of achieving desired shape changes in airfoils. The ACW eliminates discrete control surfaces since the mechanism is contained within the airfoil.

Project.Title: Research Fellowship GW Lambert

Title_Other.Title: Research Fellowship GW Lambert
研究奖学金

Class.ClassName: 自然科学调查、自然科学考察

Project.Abstract: My projects are associated with three research themes: psychological stress, obesity and hypertension. While these projects may appear diverse they are linked, both in terms of the significant co morbidity that they share, and that the underlying pathologies are initiated and sustained, at least in part, by disturbances in sympathetic nervous regulation. My research program will focus on these conditions and, in their content, will aim to develop and implement improved treatment srategies in these areas of major clinical need.

While these projects may appear diverse they are linked, both in terms of the significant co morbidity that they share, and that the underlying pathologies are initiated and sustained, at least in part, by disturbances in sympathetic nervous regulation. My research program will focus on these conditions and, in their content, will aim to develop and implement improved treatment srategies in these areas of major clinical need.
我的项目涉及三个研究主题：心理压力、肥胖和高血压。虽然这些项目可能看起来多种多样，但它们是相互联系的，既有它们共同的严重并发症，也有潜在的病理学是由交感神经调节紊乱引起和维持的，至少在一定程度上是这样。我的研究计划将集中于这些情况，并在其内容中，旨在开发和实施这些主要临床需要领域的改进治疗策略。

Project.Title: CHEMOKINE RECEPTORS IN IMMUNITY TO C NEOFORMANS

Title_Other.Title: CHEMOKINE RECEPTORS IN IMMUNITY TO C NEOFORMANS
趋化因子受体在新生C细胞免疫中的作用

Project.Abstract: Cryptococcus neoformans is a common cause of fatal fungal infection in patients with AIDS. The respiratory tract is the portal of entry for this ubiquitous, encapsulated yeast and the development of protective Th1 cell-mediated immunity (CMI) is crucial to eradicate the organism and control cryptococcal dissemination from the lungs to the brain. Production of cytokines and other mediators by cells of the innate immune system direct the development of CMI, but the precise nature of these early cellular and molecular events remains to be determined. CCR2 and other chemokine receptors (CKRs) have recently been identified as important co-factors for HIV infections and therapies aimed at blocking CKR binding are being considered. It is of considerable importance to understand the role of CKRs in host defense against infection by AIDS-associated pathogens because CKR antagonists will likely be used in patients concurrently infected with one or more of these pathogens. We have identified in preliminary studies with CCR2 knockout mice that protective Th1 immunity against C. neoformans cannot develop in the absence of CCR2 even if CD4+ and CD8+ T cell numbers in the lungs, blood, and spleen are normal. Hypothesis: MCP-1 via CCR2 mediates mononuclear cell co-stimulation and recruitment which is required to develop protective Th1 immunity against C. neoformans; deficient CCR2 function results in Th2 immunity and an inability to clear C. neoformans. Specific Aims: (1) To identify the cells in the lungs that express CCR2 during C. neoformans infection; (2) to determine the role of the CCR2 ligand MCP-1 in the development of Th1 immunity to C. neoformans; (3) to determine the role of CCR2 in the activation and recruitment of macrophages during pulmonary C. neoformans infection; (4) to determine the role of CCR2 in the recruitment and activation of T cells during pulmonary C. neoformans infection; (5) To determine the role of MCP-1 and CCR2 in the development of a Th2 response to C. neoformans.

The respiratory tract is the portal of entry for this ubiquitous, encapsulated yeast and the development of protective Th1 cell-mediated immunity (CMI) is crucial to eradicate the organism and control cryptococcal dissemination from the lungs to the brain. 新生隐球菌是艾滋病患者致命真菌感染的常见原因。呼吸道是这种无处不在的包裹酵母的入口，而保护性Th1细胞介导免疫（CMI）的发展对于根除生物体和控制隐球菌从肺部向大脑的传播至关重要。先天免疫系统细胞产生的细胞因子和其他介质直接导致CMI的发生，但这些早期细胞和分子事件的确切性质尚待确定。CCR2和其他趋化因子受体（CKR）最近被认为是HIV感染的重要共因子，目前正在考虑采用阻断CKR结合的治疗方法。了解CKR在宿主防御艾滋病相关病原体感染中的作用是非常重要的，因为CKR拮抗剂可能用于同时感染其中一种或多种病原体的患者。我们在对CCR2基因敲除小鼠的初步研究中发现，即使在肺、血液和脾脏中CD4+和CD8+T细胞数量正常的情况下，没有CCR2基因敲除的小鼠也不能产生对新生C。假设：MCP-1通过CCR2介导单核细胞共刺激和募集，这是发展对新生隐球菌Th1保护性免疫所必需的；CCR2功能缺陷导致Th2免疫和不能清除新生隐球菌。具体目的：（1）鉴定新生C.neoformans感染时肺内表达CCR2的细胞；（2）确定CCR2配体MCP-1在新生C.neoformans感染时Th1免疫形成中的作用；（3）确定CCR2在新生C.neoformans感染时巨噬细胞活化和募集中的作用；（4）确定CCR2在新生C.neoformans肺部感染时T细胞募集和活化中的作用；（5）确定MCP-1和CCR2在新生C.neoformans Th2反应中的作用。

Source.Name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

Project.Title: Studies of Antimony Allyls and Oxo-Allyls

Title_Other.Title: Studies of Antimony Allyls and Oxo-Allyls
锑烯丙基和氧烯丙基的研究

Project.Title: RUI: Plant-Herbivore Dynamics in an Herbivore-Protection Mutualism

Title_Other.Title: RUI: Plant-Herbivore Dynamics in an Herbivore-Protection Mutualism
RUI：植食性动物保护互惠中的植食性动力学

Class.ClassName: 环境生态系统、生态环境

Project.Abstract: Many mutualisms involve the exchange of a resource reward by one partner for some service by the other. Such interactions can influence the structure of ecological communities as well as the functioning of ecosystems. For example, in ant-protection mutualisms, ants protect plants or herbivores in exchange for a nectar reward. Ant mutualisms are hypothesized to have large effects on plant and herbivore species diversity and abundance. This project combines modeling and field work to explore the long-term consequences of a mutualism involving ant-protected herbivores. Understanding the feedbacks among plants, mutualistic herbivores and ants across multiple growing seasons will advance ecology by highlighting the potentially destabilizing effects of mutualisms on terrestrial ecosystems. This project brings together two researchers at a primarily undergraduate institution with a strong record of undergraduate training and incorporation of underrepresented groups in science. The proposed work will employ honors undergraduate research as its primary vehicle for outreach and training, including integrative empirical and theoretical approaches. By definition, the short-term effect of mutualism is to increase population densities. In herbivore-protection mutualisms, this increase in population density may lead to over-exploitation of host plants in the long-term with corresponding negative consequences for protected herbivores. Preliminary results show that herbivory by the ant-protected herbivore, Publilia concava, reduces the attractiveness of its perennial host-plant, tall goldenrod, to subsequent generations. Using a two-way factorial design experiment (presence/absence of herbivores and presence/absence of ants) in two tall goldenrod field sites, this project will experimentally evaluate the consequences of the delayed herbivore effect on host-plants for host-plant selection and performance of Publilia concava. Repeated censuses of plants, herbivores, and ants over two years will document if herbivory mediates plant responses that influence herbivore performance and future host plant selection. These data will also be used to test a generalized spatial model of herbivore-protection mutualisms linking host choice behavior, induced plant resistance, and herbivore population dynamics. Results from the proposal will increase understanding of the potentially destabilizing effects of mutualism and the effect of host-choice behavior by herbivores on herbivore-plant dynamics following delayed effects of herbivory.

These data will also be used to test a generalized spatial model of herbivore-protection mutualisms linking host choice behavior, induced plant resistance, and herbivore population dynamics. Results from the proposal will increase understanding of the potentially destabilizing effects of mutualism and the effect of host-choice behavior by herbivores on herbivore-plant dynamics following delayed effects of herbivory.

许多互惠互利关系涉及到一个合作伙伴为另一个合作伙伴的某些服务交换资源报酬。这种相互作用可以影响生态群落的结构和生态系统的功能。例如，在蚂蚁保护互惠中，蚂蚁保护植物或草食动物以换取花蜜奖励。蚂蚁互利共生对植物和食草动物物种的多样性和丰富度有很大的影响。这个项目结合了建模和实地工作，以探索涉及蚂蚁保护草食动物的互惠互利的长期后果。了解植物、共生食草动物和蚂蚁在多个生长季节之间的反馈，将通过强调共生对陆地生态系统的潜在破坏性影响来促进生态。这个项目汇集了两位在一个主要本科院校的研究人员，他们在本科教育方面有着很好的记录，并在科学领域吸收了代表性不足的群体。拟议的工作将采用荣誉本科研究作为其外展和培训的主要工具，包括综合经验和理论方法。根据定义，互惠互利的短期效应是增加人口密度。在食草动物保护互惠关系中，种群密度的增加可能导致长期对寄主植物的过度开发，并对受保护的食草动物产生相应的负面影响。初步结果表明，蚂蚁保护下的草食动物海胆（Publilia concava）的草食行为降低了其多年生寄主植物高黄花对后代的吸引力。利用双向因子设计实验（存在/不存在草食动物和存在/不存在蚂蚁）在两个高黄花地进行，本项目将实验评估延迟草食动物对寄主植物的影响，以选择寄主植物，并研究其性能。两年来，对植物、食草动物和蚂蚁的反复调查将证明，食草动物是否介导了影响食草动物性能和未来寄主植物选择的植物反应。这些数据还将用于测试一个草食动物保护互惠的广义空间模型，该模型将宿主选择行为、诱导植物抗性和草食动物种群动态联系起来。该研究结果将有助于进一步了解互生作用的潜在失稳效应，以及草食动物的宿主选择行为对草食动物延迟效应后植物动力学的影响。

Project.Title: Cardiomics: Integration of -omics methods for identification of novel drug targets and clinical biomarkers for coronary heart disease

Title_Other.Title: 心脏组学：确定冠心病新药物靶点和临床生物标记物的组学方法的集成
Cardiomics: Integration of -omics methods for identification of novel drug targets and clinical biomarkers for coronary heart disease

Project.Abstract: There is a large need for revitalization of the cardiovascular field with: a) improved risk stratification on the individual level through personalized medicine for more adequate individually-tailored treatments; and b) new targets for drug development based on pathways previously unknown to be involved in coronary heart disease (CHD) pathophysiology.The specific aims of this proposal include: a) Identification of causal genes and functional variants through re-sequencing and other fine-mapping methods in known CHD regions, combined with expression profiling in subcutaneous fat and skeletal muscle; b) Functional characterization of genes and pathways implicated in CHD pathophysiology via global metabolomic profiling, targeted proteomic profiling, and human system biology; c) Clinical biomarker identification and validation in the primary prevention setting.I will integrate genomic, transcriptomic, metabolomic and proteomic data from six longitudinal, population-based cohort studies (STHLM2, Karma, TWINGENE, PIVUS, ULSAM and GOSH) including >200,000 individuals; there are 2,368 incident CHD cases at time of submission, and the estimated number of cases by 2015 is 9,086.My work is anticipated to lead to new important insights of the pathophysiology of coronary heart disease, opening up new avenues for drug development, and leading to new biomarkers that will improve risk prediction and prognostication.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: There is a large need for revitalization of the cardiovascular field with: a) improved risk stratification on the individual level through personalized medicine for more adequate individually-tailored treatments; and b) new targets for drug development based on pathways previously unknown to be involved in coronary heart disease (CHD) pathophysiology.The specific aims of this proposal include: a) Identification of causal genes and functional variants through re-sequencing and other fine-mapping methods in known CHD regions, combined with expression profiling in subcutaneous fat and skeletal muscle; b) Functional characterization of genes and pathways implicated in CHD pathophysiology via global metabolomic profiling, targeted proteomic profiling, and human system biology; c) Clinical biomarker identification and validation in the primary prevention setting.I will integrate genomic, transcriptomic, metabolomic and proteomic data from six longitudinal, population-based cohort studies (STHLM2, Karma, TWINGENE, PIVUS, ULSAM and GOSH) including >200,000 individuals; there are 2,368 incident CHD cases at time of submission, and the estimated number of cases by 2015 is 9,086.My work is anticipated to lead to new important insights of the pathophysiology of coronary heart disease, opening up new avenues for drug development, and leading to new biomarkers that will improve risk prediction and prognostication.

有一个很大的需要振兴心血管领域：a）改善个人层面上的风险分层，通过个性化的药物更充分的个人定制治疗；（b）基于先前未知的与冠心病（CHD）病理生理学相关的途径的药物开发的新靶点。本提案的具体目的包括：a）通过在已知的CHD区域中重新测序和其他精细定位方法来鉴定因果基因和功能变异，结合皮下脂肪和骨骼肌的表达谱；b）通过整体代谢谱、靶向蛋白质谱和人类系统生物学，对冠心病病理生理相关基因和途径的功能特征进行分析；c） 一级预防环境中的临床生物标记物识别和验证。我将整合来自6个纵向的、基于人群的队列研究（STHLM2、Karma、TWINGENE、PIVUS、ULSAM和GOSH）的基因组、转录组、代谢组和蛋白质组数据，其中有2个，在提交报告时，共有368例冠心病病例，到2015年估计病例数为9086例。我的工作预计将对冠心病的病理生理学产生新的重要见解，为药物开发开辟新的途径，并产生新的生物标记物，以改进风险预测和预测。

Project.Title: INSPIRE Track 1: Manufacture and Characterization of Nanocrystalline/Amorphous Silicon for Particle Detection

Title_Other.Title: INSPIRE Track 1:用于粒子检测的纳米晶/非晶硅的制备与表征
INSPIRE Track 1: Manufacture and Characterization of Nanocrystalline/Amorphous Silicon for Particle Detection

Project.Abstract: This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Elementary Particle Physics Program in the Division of Physics in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Accelerator Physics and Physics Instrumentation Program in the Division of Physics in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program in the Division of Materials Research in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, and the NanoManufacturing Program in the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation in the Directorate for Engineering. This is an INSPIRE Track 1 Award to the University of Minnesota for the manufacture and characterization of nanocrystalline/amorphous silicon for particle detection. In alignment with INSPIRE program objectives, this is a high risk, multidisciplinary effort including particle physics, R. Rusack, condensed matter physics, J. Kakalios and materials engineering, U. Kortshagen. The program objectives include: the identification, fabrication and testing of at least one suitable amorphous/nanocrystalline Si material with excellent performance characteristics for charge mobility, recombination rate and robustness to radiation damage; the development of processing conditions for these identified material(s) that allow production of a reasonable detector size and thickness on a practical timescale per device; and technology transfer to industry to produce the materials at scale suitable for detector applications. In the first phase of the program, the group will utilize an existing dual reactor co-deposition system to produce and study a number of amorphous/nanocrystal silicon films to determine the nanocrystal size and density that will optimize mobility and recombination lifetime. Irradiation studies will factor into this optimization. In parallel with these studies, a new, replacement reactor system with a translatable substrate stage will be designed and fabricated. In the final phase and with the new reactor system, the group's objective is to demonstrate a functioning new co-deposition system for mixed phase growth over a reasonable area, from which larger scale industrial processing could be based. Development of such scalable nano-manufacturing technologies could enable mixed-phase amorphous/nanocrystalline materials to find a broad range of applications. In addition to the development of innovative new particle detector materials and technologies, novel mixed-phase materials might lead to other important applications, for example potential advances in high efficiency photovoltaic devices, non-volatile memories, materials for medical x-ray imaging, thermo-electrics and electroluminescent devices.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 该激励奖部分由数学和物理科学理事会物理部的基本粒子物理计划、数学和物理科学理事会物理部的加速器物理和物理仪器计划资助，数学和物理科学理事会材料研究司的电子和光子材料方案、数学和物理科学理事会的多学科活动办公室和民用部门的纳米制造方案，工程局的机械和制造创新。这是明尼苏达大学因纳米晶/非晶硅粒子检测的制造和表征而获得的激励性轨道1奖。与INSPIRE计划目标一致，这是一项高风险、多学科的工作，包括粒子物理学、R.Rusack、凝聚态物理、J.Kakalios和材料工程、U.Kortshagen。项目目标包括：识别、制造和测试至少一种适合的非晶/纳米晶硅材料，该材料具有电荷迁移率、复合速率和抗辐射损伤的优异性能；为这些确定的材料开发加工条件，以便在每个设备的实际时间尺度上生产合理的探测器尺寸和厚度；向工业转移技术，以生产适合探测器应用的尺度的材料。在该方案的第一阶段，该组将利用现有的双反应器共沉积系统来生产和研究多个非晶/纳米晶硅膜，以确定纳米晶尺寸和密度，这将优化迁移率和重组寿命。辐射研究将成为这一优化的因素。在进行这些研究的同时，还将设计和制造一种带有可平移衬底级的新型替代反应器系统。在最后阶段和新的反应器系统中，该小组的目标是在合理的区域内展示一个有效的新共沉积系统，用于混合相生长，从中可以进行更大规模的工业加工。这种可扩展的纳米制造技术的发展可以使混合相非晶/纳米晶材料得到广泛的应用。除了开发新型粒子探测器材料和技术外，新型混合相材料还可能带来其他重要应用，例如在高效光伏器件、非易失性存储器、医用x射线成像材料、热电和电致发光器件方面的潜在进展。

This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Elementary Particle Physics Program in the Division of Physics in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Accelerator Physics and Physics Instrumentation Program in the Division of Physics in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program in the Division of Materials Research in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, and the NanoManufacturing Program in the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation in the Directorate for Engineering. Kortshagen. The program objectives include: the identification, fabrication and testing of at least one suitable amorphous/nanocrystalline Si material with excellent performance characteristics for charge mobility, recombination rate and robustness to radiation damage; the development of processing conditions for these identified material(s) that allow production of a reasonable detector size and thickness on a practical timescale per device; and technology transfer to industry to produce the materials at scale suitable for detector applications. In the first phase of the program, the group will utilize an existing dual reactor co-deposition system to produce and study a number of amorphous/nanocrystal silicon films to determine the nanocrystal size and density that will optimize mobility and recombination lifetime. Irradiation studies will factor into this optimization. In parallel with these studies, a new, replacement reactor system with a translatable substrate stage will be designed and fabricated. In the final phase and with the new reactor system, the group's objective is to demonstrate a functioning new co-deposition system for mixed phase growth over a reasonable area, from which larger scale industrial processing could be based. Development of such scalable nano-manufacturing technologies could enable mixed-phase amorphous/nanocrystalline materials to find a broad range of applications. Project.Title: Bcl11b transcription factor regulation by phosphorylation and sumoylation

Title_Other.Title: Bcl11b转录因子的磷酸化和酰化调控
Bcl11b transcription factor regulation by phosphorylation and sumoylation

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): Cellular growth, maturation and transformation, among other functions, require the translation of extracellular signals into altered programs of gene expression. The key translators for these signals are transcription factor proteins. Bcl11b is a transcription factor that is critical for the development and function of several organ systems, including the immune and central nervous systems, skin, and craniofacial structures. Importantly, dysregulation of Bcl11b is strongly associated with T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL), an aggressive childhood cancer, and acceleration to the lethal blast crisis stage in a mouse model of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). The mechanism whereby loss of Bcl11b leads to tumor progression is not understood. In addition, the means by which extracellular signals impinge on transcriptional factors to regulate the transcriptome, in development or neoplastic transformation, is also poorly understood. The long-term goal of this laboratory is to elucidate the mechanisms by which signal transduction pathways regulate transcription factor activities with the goal of altering this regulation for treatment of human diseases. Bcl11b is richly modified by activation of the MAP kinase pathway in thymocytes, and its activity varies from gene repressor to activator dependent upon stimulation. Thus, Bcl11b not only has relevance to human disease, but is an excellent model to study the relationship between sub-molecular structural changes and transcription factor function. The goal of this proposal is to identify the stimulated, post-translation modifications of Bcl11b, and to understand the relationship between varying modified states of Bcl11b and its varied activities. For these studies we will use advanced mass spectrometry techniques, site-directed mutants, over expression and knockdown. Upon successful completion of our specific aims, we will provide a methodological blueprint for others seeking to understand the importance of the temporal organization of amino acid-level modifications of richly decorated transcription factors. Our findings should also highlight potential molecular targets for development of novel therapies in leukemia and perhaps other T cell-associated disorders. We also expect to better understand the regulation of Bcl11b in thymocyte maturation and to apply our findings to other organ systems. Finally, we will train a next generation of students in 21st century biomedical research techniques. PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: We wish to ultimately understand how to manipulate the gene expression changes leading to T cell cancers and in T cell development. To this end we are studying Bcl11b, an important regulator of gene expression in the immune cells and neurons. Bcl11b is dysregulated in certain T cell leukemia, and mice that lack Bcl11b have an incomplete immune system that lacks mature T cells among other defects. We wish to understand how the activity of Bcl11b is controlled at a molecular level in T cells to begin to understand its control of gene expression.

The key translators for these signals are transcription factor proteins. 描述（由申请人提供）：细胞生长、成熟和转化等功能需要将细胞外信号转换成改变的基因表达程序。这些信号的关键翻译是转录因子蛋白。Bcl11b是一种转录因子，对多种器官系统的发育和功能至关重要，包括免疫和中枢神经系统、皮肤和颅面部结构。重要的是，在慢性粒细胞白血病（CML）小鼠模型中，Bcl11b的失调与T细胞急性淋巴细胞白血病（T-ALL）密切相关，T细胞急性淋巴细胞白血病（T-ALL）是一种侵袭性儿童癌症，并加速到致命的急变期。Bcl11b丢失导致肿瘤进展的机制尚不清楚。此外，细胞外信号冲击转录因子以调节转录组的方式，在发育或肿瘤转化中，也鲜为人知。本实验室的长期目标是阐明信号转导途径调节转录因子活性的机制，目的是改变这种调节，以治疗人类疾病。Bcl11b通过激活胸腺细胞中的MAP激酶途径进行了丰富的修饰，其活性从基因阻遏物到依赖于刺激的激活物不等。因此，Bcl11b不仅与人类疾病有关，而且是研究亚分子结构变化与转录因子功能关系的一个极好的模型。本提案的目的是确定Bcl11b的受激、翻译后修饰，并了解Bcl11b的不同修饰状态与其各种活动之间的关系。在这些研究中，我们将使用先进的质谱技术、定点突变、过度表达和敲除。在成功完成我们的具体目标后，我们将为其他人提供一个方法学蓝图，以期了解富含修饰转录因子的氨基酸水平修饰的时间组织的重要性。我们的发现也应该强调潜在的分子靶点，为白血病和其他T细胞相关疾病的新疗法的发展。我们也希望能更好地了解Bcl11b在胸腺细胞成熟中的调节作用，并将我们的发现应用于其他器官系统。最后，我们将培养21世纪生物医学研究技术的下一代学生。公共卫生相关性：我们希望最终了解如何操纵导致T细胞癌和T细胞发育的基因表达变化。为此，我们正在研究Bcl11b，它是免疫细胞和神经元基因表达的重要调节因子。Bcl11b在某些T细胞白血病中失调，缺乏Bcl11b的小鼠免疫系统不完整，缺乏成熟T细胞和其他缺陷。我们希望了解Bcl11b的活性是如何在分子水平上控制在T细胞中的，从而开始了解其对基因表达的控制。

Source.Name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

Project.Title: Influence of Long-range Ionospheric and Atmospheric Effects on Surveillance and Communication Systems

Title_Other.Title: Influence of Long-range Ionospheric and Atmospheric Effects on Surveillance and Communication Systems
远距离电离层和大气效应对监视和通信系统的影响

Project.Abstract: ABSTRACT:Abstract: Electromagnetic signals used in communications and sensor systems can be seriously impacted after propagation through a region of the atmosphere or ionosphere disturbed by turbulence. This work will develop new physics-based technology that calculates EM propagation from HF to laser frequencies, including the effects of turbulence with long correlation length in the direction of propagation. The work will combine the existing NWRA ray-trace code with a new 3D multiple phase screen calculation that will run on Air Force high power computers to achieve improvement by factors of 10 to 100 in spatial and temporal resolution. The end product will calculate realizations of the propagating EM field, including the effects of refraction, reflection, magneto-ionic coupling, and ionospheric and atmospheric turbulence.BENEFIT:Commercial benefits: This 3D EM propagation code will support sensor and communication systems including NGOTHR, MUOS, P-band space based radar, directed energy systems, high-energy laser, airborne laser weapon systems, tactical laser, cruise missile, ballistic missile, and drone defense and directed energy weapons. This support is valuable and will allow improved system development with comprehensive mitigation of propagation disturbances.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 摘要：摘要：电磁信号在大气或电离层受湍流干扰的区域传播后，会受到严重的影响。这项工作将发展新的基于物理学的技术，计算电磁波从高频到激光频率的传播，包括传播方向上长相关长度湍流的影响。这项工作将结合现有的NWRA射线追踪代码和一个新的3D多相屏幕计算，该计算将在空军高功率计算机上运行，以实现在空间和时间分辨率上提高10到100倍。最终产品将计算传播电磁场的实现，包括折射、反射、磁离子耦合、电离层和大气湍流的影响。好处：商业好处：此三维电磁传播代码将支持传感器和通信系统，包括NGOTHR、MUOS、P波段空基雷达，定向能系统，高能激光，机载激光武器系统，战术激光，巡航导弹，弹道导弹，无人机防御和定向能武器。这种支持是有价值的，将允许改进系统开发，全面缓解传播干扰。

ABSTRACT:Abstract: Electromagnetic signals used in communications and sensor systems can be seriously impacted after propagation through a region of the atmosphere or ionosphere disturbed by turbulence. This work will develop new physics-based technology that calculates EM propagation from HF to laser frequencies, including the effects of turbulence with long correlation length in the direction of propagation. The work will combine the existing NWRA ray-trace code with a new 3D multiple phase screen calculation that will run on Air Force high power computers to achieve improvement by factors of 10 to 100 in spatial and temporal resolution. The end product will calculate realizations of the propagating EM field, including the effects of refraction, reflection, magneto-ionic coupling, and ionospheric and atmospheric turbulence.BENEFIT:Commercial benefits: This 3D EM propagation code will support sensor and communication systems including NGOTHR, MUOS, P-band space based radar, directed energy systems, high-energy laser, airborne laser weapon systems, tactical laser, cruise missile, ballistic missile, and drone defense and directed energy weapons. This support is valuable and will allow improved system development with comprehensive mitigation of propagation disturbances.

Source.Name: United States Department of the Air Force

Project.Title: Identification and Characterization of MYC Regulatory Elements: Links to Prostate Cancer

Title_Other.Title: Identification and Characterization of MYC Regulatory Elements: Links to Prostate Cancer
MYC调节元件的鉴定与特性：与前列腺癌的关系

Project.Abstract:
PUBLIC ABSTRACT
My goal for the next two years (and beyond) is to develop the skills necessary to succeed as an independent investigator and to contribute to the current understanding of gene misregulation in prostate cancer. Understanding the genetics underlying prostate cancer initiation and progression is integral to the development of diagnostic tools and therapeutic targets; I want to further the field's ability to provide genetic explanations and treatments for prostate cancer patients and their families. My studies and laboratory experiences as a predoctoral student at the University of Chicago's Human Genetics training program have provided me with a strong knowledge base in the field of human disease genetics, as well as a thorough command of the scientific method. My rigorous coursework, teaching experiences, and skilled mentors have helped to shape my goals and define my focus. I now believe that much of the genetics behind cancer initiation and progression will eventually be explained by regulatory mutations controlling gene expression and that prostate cancer is an ideal place to begin testing such a hypothesis. I am deeply interested in gene regulation and am committed to pursuing a career in understanding how the tissue-specific misregulation of key tumorigenic genes could lead to malignancies. The proposed research will help me to expand my current analytical abilities and will aid me in sharpening the technical skills and knowledge needed to thrive in the world of prostate cancer research.
A gene is a segment of DNA that contains both "coding" sequences that encode for a functioning protein and "non-coding" sequences that regulate when and where that protein is expressed. These non-coding regulatory sequences can act to enhance or silence gene expression in a tissue-specific manner and can be located far away from the protein that they control. Due to their relatively recent discovery, much remains unknown about the prevalence and location of these non-coding regulatory elements across the genome.
In the traditional model of human disease genetics, mutations in protein-coding regions of the genome were assumed to underlie disease states. It is only recently that the functional non-coding regions -- such as enhancers and silencers -- have been implicated in disease. When and where a gene is expressed is essential to normal human growth and development; researchers have come to understand that aberrant gene expression can lead to the unrestrained growth that is cancer.
While prostate cancer is the most common cancer diagnosed in males in the developed world, the search for causal genes has yielded few results. Several recent studies in prostate cancer patients and healthy controls have conclusively shown that genetic variation contained within four distinct blocks of sequence can predict disease susceptibility. Strikingly, these variants all fall within the same DNA interval on chromosome 8q24. Although there are no well-characterized genes within this 430 kilobase region, the protein-coding region of the MYC gene -- known to be overexpressed in prostate cancer -- lies just downstream. A gene essential to the proper regulation of cell proliferation and growth, overexpression of MYC, is known to result in uncontrolled cancerous growth. Non-coding sequences regulating expression of MYC have yet to be mapped, but the association with the nearby region and prostate cancer suggests that the risk interval may contain functional sequences implicated in MYC regulation. I hypothesize that the underlying genetic basis for this increased risk of prostate cancer rests on mutations in distant regulatory elements controlling the tissue-specific expression of MYC. This hypothesis predicts that variants in these regulatory elements predispose to and/or cause the misregulation of MYC in the prostate, leading to the initiation and/or progression of prostate cancer. In this proposal, I put forward a system to identify regulatory sequences in the MYC locus and to functionally test sequence variations in these regulatory elements.
If successful, the proposed work will identify and localize prostate-specific enhancer elements contained within the prostate-cancer susceptibility regions on chromosome 8q24. By identifying these MYC enhancers and determining whether variation within each element can alter the expression of the MYC protein, specific DNA targets for increased risk or diagnosis of prostate cancer could be identified. Future characterization of the enhancers identified in this proposed study also has the possibility to impact prostate cancer treatment. By further investigating each enhancer, other proteins involved in controlling MYC expression in the normal and diseased prostate will be uncovered. This will serve not only as a window into prostate cancer initiation and progression, but these proteins can be evaluated as new potential therapeutic targets.
While clinical applications and direct patient-related outcomes are far away, this proposed research will work toward identifying a causal genetic explanation for the increased risk of prostate cancer associated with this region of chromosome 8q24. I believe that by working to understand the putative contribution of MYC misregulation in prostate cancer initiation and/or progression, this proposed study will provide the prostate cancer community with novel targets for both diagnosis and treatment of the disease.

Abstract_Other.Abstract:
PUBLIC ABSTRACT
My goal for the next two years (and beyond) is to develop the skills necessary to succeed as an independent investigator and to contribute to the current understanding of gene misregulation in prostate cancer. Understanding the genetics underlying prostate cancer initiation and progression is integral to the development of diagnostic tools and therapeutic targets; I want to further the field's ability to provide genetic explanations and treatments for prostate cancer patients and their families. My studies and laboratory experiences as a predoctoral student at the University of Chicago's Human Genetics training program have provided me with a strong knowledge base in the field of human disease genetics, as well as a thorough command of the scientific method. My rigorous coursework, teaching experiences, and skilled mentors have helped to shape my goals and define my focus. I now believe that much of the genetics behind cancer initiation and progression will eventually be explained by regulatory mutations controlling gene expression and that prostate cancer is an ideal place to begin testing such a hypothesis. I am deeply interested in gene regulation and am committed to pursuing a career in understanding how the tissue-specific misregulation of key tumorigenic genes could lead to malignancies. The proposed research will help me to expand my current analytical abilities and will aid me in sharpening the technical skills and knowledge needed to thrive in the world of prostate cancer research.

公共摘要 我未来两年（及以后）的目标是发展成为一名独立研究者所必需的技能，并为目前对前列腺癌基因失调的理解做出贡献。了解前列腺癌发生和发展的遗传学基础对于诊断工具和治疗目标的发展是不可或缺的；我想进一步提高该领域为前列腺癌患者及其家属提供遗传学解释和治疗的能力。作为芝加哥大学人类遗传学培训项目的一名十岁前学生，我的研究和实验室经验为我提供了人类疾病遗传学领域的强大知识基础，以及对科学方法的全面掌握。我严谨的课程、教学经验和熟练的导师帮助我制定了目标并确定了我的重点。我现在相信，癌症发生和发展背后的许多遗传因素最终将由控制基因表达的调节性突变来解释，前列腺癌是开始检验这种假设的理想场所。我对基因调控非常感兴趣，并致力于研究关键致瘤基因的组织特异性失调如何导致恶性肿瘤。拟议中的研究将帮助我扩展我目前的分析能力，并帮助我提高在前列腺癌研究领域蓬勃发展所需的技术技能和知识。 基因是DNA的一个片段，它既包含编码功能蛋白的“编码”序列，也包含调控该蛋白何时何地表达的“非编码”序列。这些非编码调控序列可以以组织特异性的方式增强或沉默基因表达，并且可以远离它们所控制的蛋白质。由于他们最近的发现，关于这些非编码调控元件在整个基因组中的普遍性和位置仍有很多未知之处。 在传统的人类疾病遗传学模型中，基因组蛋白质编码区的突变被认为是疾病状态的基础。直到最近，功能性非编码区，如增强子和消音器，才与疾病有关。基因在何时何地表达对人类的正常生长发育至关重要；研究人员已经认识到，基因的异常表达会导致癌症的无节制生长。 虽然前列腺癌是发达国家男性最常见的癌症，但对其致病基因的研究却收效甚微。最近在前列腺癌患者和健康对照组中的几项研究表明，包含在四个不同序列块内的遗传变异可以预测疾病易感性。值得注意的是，这些变异都属于8q24号染色体上相同的DNA间隔。尽管在这个430千碱基的区域内没有特征明确的基因，但MYC基因的蛋白质编码区（已知在前列腺癌中过度表达）就在下游。一种对细胞增殖和生长的适当调节至关重要的基因，MYC的过度表达，被认为会导致不受控制的癌细胞生长。调控MYC表达的非编码序列尚未被绘制出来，但与邻近区域和前列腺癌的关联表明，风险区间可能包含与MYC调控相关的功能序列。我假设前列腺癌风险增加的潜在遗传基础在于控制MYC组织特异性表达的远隔调控元件的突变。这一假说预测，这些调节因子的变异易导致和/或引起前列腺中MYC的失调，从而导致前列腺癌的发生和/或进展。在这项提议中，我提出了一个系统来识别MYC基因座中的调控序列，并在功能上测试这些调控元件中的序列变化。 如果成功的话，这项工作将确定并定位8q24号染色体上前列腺癌易感区内的前列腺特异性增强因子。通过鉴定这些MYC增强子并确定每个元素的变异是否能改变MYC蛋白的表达，增加风险的特异性DNA靶点或诊断

Project.Title: Identification of causal coronary heart disease variation in smooth muscle cells

Title_Other.Title: 导致冠心病的平滑肌细胞变异的鉴定
Identification of causal coronary heart disease variation in smooth muscle cells

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): Coronary heart disease (CHD) is a growing medical problem in minority groups in this country and is predicted to become epidemic in regions of Sub-Saharan Africa, countries of the Mideast and India. New treatment options are needed that will expand beyond known risk factors to target primary disease processes in the blood vessel wall. In this regard, recent large-scale genome wide association studies (GWAS) have identified 46 genome wide significant CHD loci and a further 104 independent variants strongly associated with a 5% false discovery rate. A majority of the causal genes in these loci function independently of risk factors. It is postulated that a number of the CHD associated genes regulate basic cellular processes in the vascular smooth muscle cell (SMC), a critical mediator of atherosclerosis, and that study of the signaling pathways that are modulated in this cell type by causal regulatory variation will provide critical new insights for targeting the initiation and progression of disease. The primary goals of work proposed here are to identify CHD associated genes that exhibit allele specific expression (ASE) in SMC, map the causal variation responsible for this ASE, and characterize the transcriptional signaling pathways that are modulated by these regulatory variants. The work proposed here will build on recent studies identifying causal variation at 6q23.2 and elucidating the growth factor and developmental signaling pathways that regulate the basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor TCF21, a known critical regulator of embryonic vascular SMC development. A newly developed microfluidics multiplex PCR sequencing approach will be employed for evaluating allele-specific expression in vascular SMC, and these ASE data used to map the causal regulatory variation in CHD associated loci. Transcription factor binding sites that colocalize with causal regulatory variatio, and allele-specific transcription factor binding and transactivation will be characterized. Correlation will be made to chromatin architecture in these regions of the genome, and association with epigenetic signaling investigated. In vivo significance of these data will be provided by mouse transgenic reporter gene studies that map temporal and cell-specific expression directed by the causal transcription factor binding sites in the context of vascular development, SMC response to injury and contribution to atherosclerotic disease. Taken together, these data will provide critical information regarding the upstream signaling pathways and specific mechanisms that mediate the CHD risk in GWAS loci for this phenotype.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 描述（由申请人提供）：冠心病（CHD）是我国少数民族日益严重的医学问题，预计在撒哈拉以南非洲地区、中东和印度等国将流行。需要新的治疗方案，这些方案将超越已知的危险因素，以血管壁的原发性疾病过程为目标。在这方面，最近的大规模全基因组关联研究（GWAS）已经鉴定出46个全基因组显著的CHD基因座和另外104个与5%的错误发现率密切相关的独立变异。这些基因座中的大多数致病基因的功能与危险因素无关。有人推测，许多与冠心病相关的基因调节动脉粥样硬化的关键介质血管平滑肌细胞（SMC）的基本细胞过程，对这种细胞类型中由因果调节变异调节的信号通路的研究将为靶向疾病的发生和发展提供重要的新见解。本文提出的主要工作目标是识别在平滑肌细胞中表现等位基因特异性表达（ASE）的CHD相关基因，绘制该酶的因果变异图，并描述这些调控变异所调控的转录信号通路。本文提出的工作将建立在最近的研究基础上，确定6q23.2的因果变异，并阐明调控基本螺旋环螺旋转录因子TCF21（已知的胚胎血管平滑肌细胞发育的关键调控因子）的生长因子和发育信号途径。新发展的微流控多重PCR测序方法将用于评价血管平滑肌细胞中等位基因的特异性表达，这些ASE数据将用于绘制冠心病相关基因座的因果调节变化。转录因子结合位点与因果调节变异、等位基因特异性转录因子结合和反式激活共同定域。将与基因组中这些区域的染色质结构相关，并与表观遗传信号相关。这些数据的体内意义将由小鼠转基因报告基因研究提供，该研究绘制了在血管发育、SMC对损伤的反应和对动脉粥样硬化疾病的贡献的背景下，由因果转录因子结合位点指导的时间和细胞特异性表达。综上所述，这些数据将提供有关上游信号通路和在GWAS基因座中介导该表型冠心病风险的特定机制的关键信息。

New treatment options are needed that will expand beyond known risk factors to target primary disease processes in the blood vessel wall. Source.Name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

Project.Title: Examining the Effects of Maternal-Infant and System-Level Factors on Rates of Exclusive Breastfeeding

Title_Other.Title: Examining the Effects of Maternal-Infant and System-Level Factors on Rates of Exclusive Breastfeeding
母婴及系统因素对纯母乳喂养率的影响

Project.Abstract: Health Canada recommends exclusive breastfeeding for the first six months of life because of the known health benefits to infant and mother (e.g., nutritional, immunological, and developmental). This has resulted in many hospitals adopting the evidence-based, internationally-endorsed Baby Friendly Initiative (BFI), which has been shown to increase rates of exclusive breastfeeding. However, the success of the BFI may be jeopardized during periods of high hospital bed occupancy. Due to the fluctuating census on maternity units, it is becoming more common for their beds to be occupied by non-maternity patients (off-service). Off-service patients on maternity units may divert nursing care away from new mothers during the first 24 hours following delivery when effective breastfeeding practices are being established. Research is needed to examine the impact of off-service patients on rates of exclusive breastfeeding at time of hospital discharge. Using information from the health records data from three maternity units in New Brunswick, I will examine the effect of system level factors (i.e., hospital occupancy rate and number of off-service patients during first 24 hrs) on the likelihood of exclusive breastfeeding at time of discharge after accounting for characteristics of the mother (e.g., previous breastfeeding, mode of delivery) and infant (e.g., weeks gestation, skin-to-skin contact with mother within first hour). I am proposing that the likelihood of exclusive breastfeeding will be lower during periods when more off-service patients are on the maternity unit. Findings will inform health policies targeting exclusive breastfeeding, which is important as less than 14% of Canadian mothers currently meet Health Canada's recommendation. Findings will contribute to an understanding of the impact of off-service patients on exclusive breastfeeding and provide a foundation for future research on the effect of changing healthcare delivery patterns on maternal-infant outcomes.
