Project.Title: Physiological Genomics of the Zebrafish Heart

Title_Other.Title: Physiological Genomics of the Zebrafish Heart
斑马鱼心脏生理基因组学

Class.ClassName: 理论、技术、方法、研究、评价、策略

Project.Abstract: The successful completion of the Human Genome Project has highlighted a major need for experimental approaches designed to relate genomic information to complex physiologic phenomena in the whole organism. The identification of those genes critical for the normal development of growth and function will be an important first step in the characterization of the underlying regulatory genomic networks. The zebrafish has proven an excellent model system for the study of the genetic basis of cardiovascular form. Phenotype based genetic screens have revealed a series of unitary components in cardiogenesis helping to dissect the logic of development. This proposal extends this approach to mutations that perturb early heart growth and/or function, in a broad way exploring the feasibility of a physiologic genomics effort. The project has two specific aims: 1) To clone positionally the mutated genes responsible for 40 physiologic phenotypes isolated from large genetic screens. These phenotypes are those in which the heart tube forms initially, generates chambers, but then fails to grow normally or to contract vigorously and with proper rhythmicity. 2) To systematically characterize the phenotypes and to begin to more precisely categorize the phenotypic effects in vivo and at the level of both organ and cell. All mutations will be made immediately available to the community, annotated by gene mutation and progressively refined phenotypic information. This unique resource will provide the entry points for subsequent investigation in zebrafish, other organisms and eventually humans, of those pathways central to the normal growth and function of the cardiovascular system.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 人类基因组计划的成功完成，突出了对实验方法的重大需求，这些方法旨在将基因组信息与整个生物体内复杂的生理现象联系起来。鉴定那些对生长和功能正常发育至关重要的基因，将是表征潜在调控基因组网络的重要第一步。斑马鱼已经证明是研究心血管形态遗传基础的一个极好的模型系统。基于表型的基因筛选揭示了心脏发生中的一系列单一成分，有助于剖析发育的逻辑。这项提议将这种方法扩展到干扰早期心脏生长和/或功能的突变，以广泛的方式探索生理基因组学努力的可行性。该项目有两个具体的目的：1）从大的基因筛选中克隆40个生理表型的突变基因。这些表现型是那些心脏管最初形成，产生心室，但随后无法正常生长或以适当的节律剧烈收缩的表现型。2） 系统地描述表型，并开始更精确地分类体内和器官和细胞水平上的表型效应。所有突变将立即提供给社区，由基因突变和逐步完善的表型信息注释。这一独特的资源将为以后在斑马鱼、其他有机体和最终人类中研究心血管系统正常生长和功能的核心途径提供切入点。

The successful completion of the Human Genome Project has highlighted a major need for experimental approaches designed to relate genomic information to complex physiologic phenomena in the whole organism. The identification of those genes critical for the normal development of growth and function will be an important first step in the characterization of the underlying regulatory genomic networks. The zebrafish has proven an excellent model system for the study of the genetic basis of cardiovascular form. Phenotype based genetic screens have revealed a series of unitary components in cardiogenesis helping to dissect the logic of development. This proposal extends this approach to mutations that perturb early heart growth and/or function, in a broad way exploring the feasibility of a physiologic genomics effort. The project has two specific aims: 1) To clone positionally the mutated genes responsible for 40 physiologic phenotypes isolated from large genetic screens. These phenotypes are those in which the heart tube forms initially, generates chambers, but then fails to grow normally or to contract vigorously and with proper rhythmicity. 2) To systematically characterize the phenotypes and to begin to more precisely categorize the phenotypic effects in vivo and at the level of both organ and cell. All mutations will be made immediately available to the community, annotated by gene mutation and progressively refined phenotypic information. This unique resource will provide the entry points for subsequent investigation in zebrafish, other organisms and eventually humans, of those pathways central to the normal growth and function of the cardiovascular system.

Source.Name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

Project.Title: Synkrotronrelatert research - grants to cover travel and subsistence expenses for researchers in the Stavanger region

Title_Other.Title: Synkrotronrelatert研究-资助斯塔万格地区研究人员的旅费和生活费
Synkrotronrelatert forskning - Tilskudd til dekning av reise- og oppholdsutgifter for forskere i Stavanger-regionen

Project.Abstract: Board for Science and Technology has appointed a smaller program group to manage funds allocated to ESRF-related tasks. These include follow-up research, travel agents etc. For Norwegian researchers' use of the facilities by ES RF and SNBL. The group has decided that the management of funds for the payment of such travel and subsistence expenses delegated to perform research communities in Oslo, Trondheim-, Tromsø and Stavanger region through the four groups assigned rundsumbevil renderings over a 3 year period. The funds are administered locally so it's most appropriate and use reported to the Research Council in retrospect by standard procedures. The contribution is intended to supplement, and the institutions themselves must also cover part of Ed iftene. The funding will primarily cover stays at the ESRF. If finances allow, you can also cover visits to other synkrotronstrålekilder.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: Områdestyret for naturvitenskap og teknologi har oppnevnt en mindre programgruppe til å forvalte midler avsatt til ESRF-relaterte oppgaver. Disse omfatter blant annet følgeforskning, reisemidler osv. for norske forskeres utnyttelse av fasilitetene ved ES RF og SNBL. Gruppen har besluttet at forvaltningen av midler til dekning av slike reise-og oppholdsutgifter delegeres til de forskningsutførende miljøene i Oslo-, Trondheim-, Tromsø- og Stavanger-regionen gjennom at de fire gruppene tildeles rundsumbevil gninger over en 3 års-periode. Midlene administreres lokalt slik det finnes mest hensiktsmessig og bruken rapporteres til Forskningsrådet i ettertid etter standard rutiner. Bidraget er ment som tilskudd,og institusjonene må også selv dekke en del av utg iftene. Bevilgningen skal primært dekke opphold ved ESRF. Dersom økonomien tillater kan man også dekke opphold ved andre synkrotronstrålekilder.

科学和技术委员会已经指定了一个较小的项目组来管理分配给ESRF相关任务的资金。其中包括后续研究、旅行社等，供挪威研究人员使用ES RF和SNBL的设施。专家组决定，通过分配给Rundsumbvil的四个小组，在3年期间管理用于支付这些旅费和生活费的资金，这些旅费和生活费被授权在奥斯陆、特隆赫姆、特罗姆瑟和斯塔万格地区进行研究。这些基金是在当地管理的，因此它是最合适的，并通过标准程序向研究委员会报告。捐款的目的是补充，各机构本身也必须包括部分教育基金。这笔资金将主要用于在ESRF的住宿。如果资金允许，你也可以去参观其他的synkrotronstrålekilder。

Project.Title: Magnetic Resonance of Cardiac C13 Flux & Metabolic Rate

Title_Other.Title: 心脏C13流量及代谢率的磁共振研究
Magnetic Resonance of Cardiac C13 Flux & Metabolic Rate

Project.Abstract: The long term objectives of this research are: 1) elucidate intracellular mechanisms linking cardiac dysfunction to protein-mediated, cellular uptake, accumulation and turnover of lipid, in the form of triacylglyceride (TAG), and the altered fatty acid oxidation in diabetic cardiomyopathy;2)advance nondestructive, metabolic profiling of the heart using novel applications of carbon-13 (13C) NMR, to monitor distinct contributions of lipid transport processesinto the cardiac muscle cell during the altered TAG turnover that occurs in diseased and stressed hearts. Based on data acquired during the currently funded period, new experiments will test a 3-fold hypothesis: 1)The balance between long chain fatty acid uptakeand oxidation that determines TAG turnover is heavily influenced by the activity of fatty acid transport proteins on the cell membrane and that disruption of this balance in the diabetic heart contributes to the development of cardiac dysfunction; 2) dynamic NMR of 13C enrichment rates of TAG in the intact, beating heart provide precise kinetic information on the activity of fatty acid transporters on the cell membrane that determine the extent of lipid deposition in both normal and diseased hearts; and 3) intramyocardial lipid content affects regional strain in the left venctricle (LV) wall by either intracellular mechanisms leading to contractile dysfunction and/or mechanical influences on LV wall dynamics. The hypotheses will betested on rats and mice using a unique multidisciplinary approach that combines 13C NMR of metabolic flux and lipid uptake dynamics in intact hearts with genetic manipulation of fatty acid uptake and oxidation for comparisonto diabetic animals, as well as in vivo cardiac tagged MRI of wall strain with in vivo chemical shift imaging and localized NMR spectroscopy of TAG content in hearts of transgenic mouse models mimicing the diabetic phenotype for TAG accumulation. Specific aims are: 1) Define changes in fatty acid uptake and TAG turnover due to different affinities of long chain fatty acids (palmitate vs. oleate) for incorporation into the TAG pool; 2) use 13CNMR of intact hearts to nondestructive^ detect perturbations of fatty acid transport/uptake into cardiomyocytesof transgenic mouse hearts and rat hearts receiving metabolic gene transfer; 3) measureregional 2D strain and intra/extracellular TAG content in the LVwall of mice with altered lipid metabolism.Anticipated results will provide a mechanistic link between cardiac lipid accumulation and contractile dysfunction in diseased hearts.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 本研究的长期目标是：1）阐明心功能不全与蛋白质介导、细胞摄取、积累和转换脂肪（以三酰甘油（TAG）的形式）和糖尿病心肌病中脂肪酸氧化改变相关的细胞内机制；2）促进心脏的非破坏性代谢谱利用碳-13（13C）核磁共振的新应用，监测在病变和应激心脏中发生的标签转换改变期间，脂质转运过程对心肌细胞的不同贡献。根据在目前资助期内获得的数据，新的实验将检验一个三重假设：1）长链脂肪酸摄取和决定标记转换的氧化之间的平衡受细胞膜上脂肪酸转运蛋白活性的严重影响，以及糖尿病心脏中这种平衡的破坏有助于心功能不全的发展；2）完整跳动心脏中TAG 13C富集率的动态核磁共振提供了细胞膜上脂肪酸转运体活性的精确动力学信息，确定了正常心脏和病变心脏中脂质沉积的程度；3）心肌内脂质含量通过导致收缩功能障碍的细胞内机制和/或对左心室壁动力学的机械影响，影响左心室壁的局部应变。这一假设将通过一种独特的多学科方法在大鼠和小鼠身上进行验证，该方法结合了完整心脏中代谢通量和脂质摄取动力学的13cnmr和糖尿病动物脂肪酸摄取和氧化的遗传操作，以及利用体内化学位移成像和局部核磁共振波谱对模拟糖尿病表型的转基因小鼠心脏中TAG含量进行体内心肌标记的壁应变磁共振成像。具体目标是：1）定义由于长链脂肪酸（棕榈酸盐和油酸盐）的不同亲和力而导致的脂肪酸摄取和标签转换的变化；2） 利用13CNMR无损检测转基因小鼠心脏和接受代谢基因转移的大鼠心脏对脂肪酸转运/摄取的干扰；3）检测脂质代谢改变小鼠左室壁的区域2D株和细胞内/细胞外标记物含量，预期结果将为进一步研究转基因小鼠心肌细胞的脂肪酸转运/摄取提供依据心脏脂质积聚与心脏收缩功能障碍的机制联系。

The long term objectives of this research are: 1) elucidate intracellular mechanisms linking cardiac dysfunction to protein-mediated, cellular uptake, accumulation and turnover of lipid, in the form of triacylglyceride (TAG), and the altered fatty acid oxidation in diabetic cardiomyopathy;2)advance nondestructive, metabolic profiling of the heart using novel applications of carbon-13 (13C) NMR, to monitor distinct contributions of lipid transport processesinto the cardiac muscle cell during the altered TAG turnover that occurs in diseased and stressed hearts. Based on data acquired during the currently funded period, new experiments will test a 3-fold hypothesis: 1)The balance between long chain fatty acid uptakeand oxidation that determines TAG turnover is heavily influenced by the activity of fatty acid transport proteins on the cell membrane and that disruption of this balance in the diabetic heart contributes to the development of cardiac dysfunction; 2) dynamic NMR of 13C enrichment rates of TAG in the intact, beating heart provide precise kinetic information on the activity of fatty acid transporters on the cell membrane that determine the extent of lipid deposition in both normal and diseased hearts; and 3) intramyocardial lipid content affects regional strain in the left venctricle (LV) wall by either intracellular mechanisms leading to contractile dysfunction and/or mechanical influences on LV wall dynamics. The hypotheses will betested on rats and mice using a unique multidisciplinary approach that combines 13C NMR of metabolic flux and lipid uptake dynamics in intact hearts with genetic manipulation of fatty acid uptake and oxidation for comparisonto diabetic animals, as well as in vivo cardiac tagged MRI of wall strain with in vivo chemical shift imaging and localized NMR spectroscopy of TAG content in hearts of transgenic mouse models mimicing the diabetic phenotype for TAG accumulation. Specific aims are: 1) Define changes in fatty acid uptake and TAG turnover due to different affinities of long chain fatty acids (palmitate vs. oleate) for incorporation into the TAG pool; 2) use 13CNMR of intact hearts to nondestructive^ detect perturbations of fatty acid transport/uptake into cardiomyocytesof transgenic mouse hearts and rat hearts receiving metabolic gene transfer; 3) measureregional 2D strain and intra/extracellular TAG content in the LVwall of mice with altered lipid metabolism.Anticipated results will provide a mechanistic link between cardiac lipid accumulation and contractile dysfunction in diseased hearts.

Source.Name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

Project.Title: TB goes viral: Interplay between mycobacteria RNA and host cytosolic surveillance pathways

Title_Other.Title: 结核病毒化：分枝杆菌RNA与宿主胞质监测途径的相互作用
TB goes viral: Interplay between mycobacteria RNA and host cytosolic surveillance pathways

Class.ClassName: 农用化学物质污染、农用化学物质污染防治
化学反应机理、化学反应动力学

Project.Abstract: PROJECT SUMMARY TB is now the number one infectious cause of death worldwide having recently surpassed HIV/AIDS. Despite its global importance, our understanding of the pathogen's fundamental strategies for evading human immune responses is limited, although it is now clear that the microbe utilizes an arsenal of molecular components to perturb phagolysosome maturation and autophagic killing. One recently recognized virulence strategy is that M.tb releases bacterial-derived nucleic acids (dsDNA and cyclic nucleotides such as cAMP and c-di-AMP) into the macrophage cytosol where they subvert innate immune signaling mediated by the host's cytosolic surveillance pathway (CSP). The central premise of this application is that in addition to dsDNA and cyclic nucleotides, M. tb RNA comprises yet another pathogen-derived molecule that gains access to the host cytosol and that M. tb RNA contributes to pathogenesis. Microbial RNA constitutes an important group of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) that potently stimulate innate immune activation. Although RNA of viral origin has been extensively studied as a trigger of the CSP, the concept that bacterial-derived RNA may be important in host pathogen interactions remains novel, and very little has been done to address the role of M.tb-derived RNA during infection. In exciting new preliminary data, we have observed that intracellular exposure to M.tb RNA skews host cell cytokine production. Additionally, we have discovered that loss of a key RNA sensor gene alters macrophage responses to M. tb infection. In this study we propose detailed exploratory studies to characterize the specific molecular determinants required for M.tb-derived RNA to trigger these responses. Additionally, we will use genome editing tools to generate targeted deletions of key pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) known to be RNA sensors in murine and human macrophages. These cell-lines will be evaluated for responsiveness to transfected M.tb RNA and for their ability to control intracellular M.tb proliferation. Further elucidation of the role of M.tb RNA in macrophage cell biology will better our understanding of M.tb pathogenesis and the microbe's ability to subvert innate immunity. More practically, these studies may also elucidate novel targets for pharmacologic and vaccine-based interventions to combat TB.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 项目摘要结核病是目前世界上第一大传染死亡原因，最近已超过艾滋病毒/艾滋病。尽管它具有全球重要性，但我们对病原体逃避人类免疫反应的基本策略的理解是有限的，尽管现在已经很清楚，这种微生物利用大量的分子成分来干扰吞噬溶酶体的成熟和自噬性杀灭。最近一种公认的毒力策略是结核分枝杆菌将细菌衍生核酸（dsDNA和环核苷酸，如c AMP和c-di-AMP）释放到巨噬细胞胞浆中，在那里它们破坏宿主胞浆监测途径（CSP）介导的固有免疫信号。该应用的中心前提是，除了dsDNA和环核苷酸外，结核分枝杆菌RNA还包含另一种病原体衍生分子，该分子可进入宿主细胞溶胶，结核分枝杆菌RNA参与致病。微生物RNA是一组重要的病原体相关分子模式（PAMPs），它能有效地刺激先天免疫激活。尽管病毒来源的RNA已被广泛研究作为CSP的触发因素，但细菌源RNA在宿主-病原相互作用中可能起重要作用的概念仍然是新的，而且很少有人研究结核分枝杆菌源RNA在感染过程中的作用。在令人兴奋的新的初步数据中，我们观察到细胞内暴露于结核分枝杆菌RNA会影响宿主细胞细胞因子的产生。此外，我们还发现，丢失一个关键的RNA传感器基因会改变巨噬细胞对结核分枝杆菌感染的反应。在这项研究中，我们提出了详细的探索性研究，以确定结核分枝杆菌衍生RNA触发这些反应所需的特定分子决定簇。此外，我们将使用基因组编辑工具在小鼠和人巨噬细胞中生成关键模式识别受体（prr）的靶向缺失，prr是已知的RNA传感器。将评估这些细胞系对转染的结核分枝杆菌RNA的反应性及其控制细胞内结核分枝杆菌增殖的能力。进一步阐明结核分枝杆菌RNA在巨噬细胞生物学中的作用，将有助于我们更好地了解结核分枝杆菌的发病机制和微生物破坏天然免疫的能力。更实际地说，这些研究还可能阐明以药理学和疫苗为基础的干预措施防治结核病的新目标。

PROJECT SUMMARY TB is now the number one infectious cause of death worldwide having recently surpassed HIV/AIDS. Despite its global importance, our understanding of the pathogen's fundamental strategies for evading human immune responses is limited, although it is now clear that the microbe utilizes an arsenal of molecular components to perturb phagolysosome maturation and autophagic killing. One recently recognized virulence strategy is that M.tb releases bacterial-derived nucleic acids (dsDNA and cyclic nucleotides such as cAMP and c-di-AMP) into the macrophage cytosol where they subvert innate immune signaling mediated by the host's cytosolic surveillance pathway (CSP). The central premise of this application is that in addition to dsDNA and cyclic nucleotides, M. tb RNA comprises yet another pathogen-derived molecule that gains access to the host cytosol and that M. tb RNA contributes to pathogenesis. Microbial RNA constitutes an important group of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) that potently stimulate innate immune activation. Although RNA of viral origin has been extensively studied as a trigger of the CSP, the concept that bacterial-derived RNA may be important in host pathogen interactions remains novel, and very little has been done to address the role of M.tb-derived RNA during infection. In exciting new preliminary data, we have observed that intracellular exposure to M.tb RNA skews host cell cytokine production. Additionally, we have discovered that loss of a key RNA sensor gene alters macrophage responses to M. tb infection. In this study we propose detailed exploratory studies to characterize the specific molecular determinants required for M.tb-derived RNA to trigger these responses. Additionally, we will use genome editing tools to generate targeted deletions of key pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) known to be RNA sensors in murine and human macrophages. These cell-lines will be evaluated for responsiveness to transfected M.tb RNA and for their ability to control intracellular M.tb proliferation. Further elucidation of the role of M.tb RNA in macrophage cell biology will better our understanding of M.tb pathogenesis and the microbe's ability to subvert innate immunity. More practically, these studies may also elucidate novel targets for pharmacologic and vaccine-based interventions to combat TB.

Source.Name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Project.Title: Outcomes of Sleep Disorders in Older Men-Birmingham

Title_Other.Title: Outcomes of Sleep Disorders in Older Men-Birmingham
伯明翰老年男性睡眠障碍的转归

Project.Abstract: DESCRIPTION (provided by applicant): It is estimated that over 50% of adults aged 65 and older report some sleep disruption, while about 20% suffer from chronic insomnia. Obstructive sleep apnea, a major cause of daytime drowsiness, occurs in an estimated 20-60% of older people, depending on the definition used and the specific population being studied. Despite the high prevalence of sleep disorders in the elderly, there have been relatively few studies focused on the consequences. Most studies have been limited by cross-sectional design, small sample size, or lack of comprehensive and objective assessment of sleep. The proposed study, Outcomes of Sleep Disorders in Older Men, will take advantage of the established cohort that has been recruited for the Osteoporotic Fractures in Men (MrOS) study (5U01AR045647-Dr. Eric Orwoll, PI). MrOS, a 7-year study that began in July 1999, is a multi-center prospective study of approximately 6000 men aged 65 and older. During the MrOS baseline visit, a broad variety of measurements were collected, including body composition and body fat distribution (by DEXA and quantitative computed tomography), bone density, anthropometry, performance-based tests of strength and balance, medical history, medication use, smoking and alcohol use, and other parameters. Blood, urine, and DNA specimens have been archived for use in future studies of importance to the health of older men. In a subcohort of 3000 MrOS participants, we propose to add comprehensive and accurate assessments of sleep using in-home polysomnography, wrist actigraphy, questionnaires and other measures; and prospective adjudication of CVD events, to the extensive measures that have already been performed or planned in the MrOS cohort study. These new measures will enable us to test several important hypotheses: 1) to characterize the associations between sleep disruption and subsequent CVD events during 3.5 years of follow-up, 2) to determine if sleep disturbances are associated with an increased risk of total and cause-specific mortality in older men, 3) to test whether sleep disturbances are associated with increased risk of falls and decreased physical function, 4) to test whether sleep disturbances are associated with impaired cognitive function in older men, and 5) to test whether sleep disorders are associated with bone density and fracture risk in older men. We will also supplement the bank of MrOS specimens to allow for testing of future hypotheses concerning the role of sleep in the development of age-related diseases and conditions.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 描述（由申请人提供）：据估计，超过50%的65岁及以上的成年人报告有睡眠障碍，而约20%的人患有慢性失眠。阻塞性睡眠呼吸暂停是白天困倦的一个主要原因，据估计20-60%的老年人会出现，这取决于所用的定义和正在研究的特定人群。尽管老年人睡眠障碍的患病率很高，但针对其后果的研究相对较少。大多数研究都受到横断面设计、样本量小或缺乏全面客观的睡眠评估的限制。这项被提议的研究，老年男性睡眠障碍的结果，将利用已被招募用于男性骨质疏松性骨折（MrOS）研究（5U01AR045647-Eric Orwoll博士，PI）的既定队列。MrOS是从1999年7月开始的一项为期7年的研究，是一项多中心前瞻性研究，研究对象约为6000名65岁及以上的男性。在MrOS基线检查期间，收集了各种各样的测量数据，包括身体成分和体脂分布（通过DEXA和定量计算机断层扫描）、骨密度、人体测量、基于性能的力量和平衡测试、病史、用药、吸烟和饮酒以及其他参数。血液、尿液和DNA样本已被存档，以供日后对老年男性健康具有重要意义的研究使用。在一个由3000名MrOS参与者组成的亚组中，我们建议在MrOS队列研究中已经实施或计划实施的广泛措施的基础上，增加使用家庭多导睡眠图、腕关节活动图、问卷调查和其他措施对睡眠进行全面和准确的评估；以及对CVD事件的前瞻性判断。这些新的措施将使我们能够检验几个重要的假设：1）在3.5年的随访中描述睡眠中断和随后的心血管疾病事件之间的关系，2）确定睡眠障碍是否与老年男性总死亡率和特定死亡率的增加相关，3） 为了测试睡眠障碍是否与跌倒风险增加和身体功能下降相关，4）测试睡眠障碍是否与老年男性认知功能受损相关，5）测试睡眠障碍是否与老年男性骨密度和骨折风险相关。我们还将补充MrOS样本库，以便测试未来关于睡眠在年龄相关疾病和条件发展中的作用的假设。

Obstructive sleep apnea, a major cause of daytime drowsiness, occurs in an estimated 20-60% of older people, depending on the definition used and the specific population being studied. Despite the high prevalence of sleep disorders in the elderly, there have been relatively few studies focused on the consequences. Most studies have been limited by cross-sectional design, small sample size, or lack of comprehensive and objective assessment of sleep. The proposed study, Outcomes of Sleep Disorders in Older Men, will take advantage of the established cohort that has been recruited for the Osteoporotic Fractures in Men (MrOS) study (5U01AR045647-Dr. Eric Orwoll, PI). MrOS, a 7-year study that began in July 1999, is a multi-center prospective study of approximately 6000 men aged 65 and older. During the MrOS baseline visit, a broad variety of measurements were collected, including body composition and body fat distribution (by DEXA and quantitative computed tomography), bone density, anthropometry, performance-based tests of strength and balance, medical history, medication use, smoking and alcohol use, and other parameters. Blood, urine, and DNA specimens have been archived for use in future studies of importance to the health of older men. In a subcohort of 3000 MrOS participants, we propose to add comprehensive and accurate assessments of sleep using in-home polysomnography, wrist actigraphy, questionnaires and other measures; and prospective adjudication of CVD events, to the extensive measures that have already been performed or planned in the MrOS cohort study. These new measures will enable us to test several important hypotheses: 1) to characterize the associations between sleep disruption and subsequent CVD events during 3.5 years of follow-up, 2) to determine if sleep disturbances are associated with an increased risk of total and cause-specific mortality in older men, 3) to test whether sleep disturbances are associated with increased risk of falls and decreased physical function, 4) to test whether sleep disturbances are associated with impaired cognitive function in older men, and 5) to test whether sleep disorders are associated with bone density and fracture risk in older men. Source.Name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

Project.Title: GoLife: Collaborative Research: Bringing the diverse microbial clade Stramenopila + Alveolata + Rhizaria (SAR) into a modern genomic context

Title_Other.Title: GoLife：合作研究：将不同的微生物分支Stramenopila+Alveolata+Rhizaria（SAR）引入现代基因组环境
GoLife: Collaborative Research: Bringing the diverse microbial clade Stramenopila + Alveolata + Rhizaria (SAR) into a modern genomic context

Project.Abstract: Most of the biological diversity in eukaryotes (organisms with distinct nuclei) is in the form of microscopic species and, when compared to other eukaryotes (plants, animals and fungi), is less well-studied in terms of morphological characterisitics, evolutionary relationships among species, and genetic variation. This relative lack of information on microbial eukaryotes not only has consequences for our understanding of all biodiversity on Earth, but also how we interpret cellular and evolutionary biology in the broadest sense. This research will advance our knowledge of a major evolutionary group (clade) of microbial eukaryotes that comprise the Stramenopila, Alveolata and Rhizaria, (SAR). SAR is a major clade of diverse microscopic eukaryotes that was recently identified by evolutionary analyses and additional data have robustly supported SAR as an independent evolutionary lineage. This discovery is forcing a re-evaluation of the evolution of several eukaryotic traits, most notably photosynthesis. Within SAR there are many diverse lineages but genetic data are rare and concentrated in only a few lineages: Apicomplexa (e.g. malarial parasites), omycetes (e.g. parasite water molds) and diatoms (e.g. ecologically important phytoplankton). This project proposes to increase the number of SAR species with genetic data as well as massively increase the amount of genetic data collected per species. Organisms used for genomic data will be imaged and will be integrated to the Encyclopedia of Life (EOL) to provide a comprehensive resource on microbial eukaryotic diversity. Despite their global ecological importance, fewer than 50% of all SAR clades are represented by even a single genome in public databases. The work proposed here would add at least 250 novel genomic-scale datasets (transcriptomes, draft genomes, single-cell amplified genomes), focused primarily on capturing diversity within SAR. These datasets will be made publicly available, substantially increasing our understanding of the evolution of these organisms. The application of both established phylogenomic and emerging similarity network methods will enable a multi-layered analysis that will provide new information for evolutionary analyses of these organisms. This will include: 1) diversity discovery using targeted environmental 18S surveys coupled with high-throughput FlowCam imaging; 2) high-throughput transcriptomic sequencing; and 3) single cell genomics of unculturable taxa. Phylogenetic analyses will capture the genetic mosaics that underlie the early evolution within SAR. Beyond the increase in genome scale resources from diverse members of the SAR clade, the proposed work will generate image data layers and integrate these with other images from the literature in EOL. Undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will be trained in cutting edge techniques and will provide a workshop for teacher training in microscopy. This project will increase diversity of participants by recruiting students from underrepresented groups and develop of a high school curriculum on the microbial tree of life.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 真核生物（具有不同细胞核的生物体）的大多数生物多样性是以微观物种的形式存在的，与其他真核生物（植物、动物和真菌）相比，在形态特征、物种间的进化关系和遗传变异方面的研究较少。相对缺乏关于微生物真核生物的信息，不仅会影响我们对地球上所有生物多样性的理解，还会影响我们如何从最广义上解释细胞生物学和进化生物学。这项研究将促进我们对微生物真核生物的一个主要进化群（clade）的认识，这个进化群包括斯特拉门诺皮拉、肺泡和Rhizaria（SAR）。合成孔径雷达（SAR）是多种微观真核生物的一个主要分支，最近通过进化分析和额外的数据证实，合成孔径雷达是一个独立的进化谱系。这一发现迫使人们重新评估一些真核生物特性的进化，尤其是光合作用。在合成孔径雷达中有许多不同的谱系，但遗传数据很少，只集中在少数谱系中：顶端复合体（例如疟疾寄生虫）、酵母菌（例如寄生虫水霉菌）和硅藻（例如具有重要生态意义的浮游植物）。该项目建议增加具有遗传数据的SAR物种的数量，并大量增加每个物种收集的遗传数据的数量。用于基因组数据的生物体将被成像并整合到生命百科全书（EOL）中，以提供有关微生物真核生物多样性的综合资源。尽管它们在全球具有重要的生态意义，但在公共数据库中，只有不到50%的合成孔径雷达（SAR）分支由单一基因组表示。这里提出的工作将增加至少250个新的基因组规模的数据集（转录体，草图基因组，单细胞扩增基因组），主要集中在捕获SAR内的多样性。这些数据集将公开提供，大大增加了我们对这些生物进化的理解。已建立的系统基因组学和新兴的相似网络方法的应用将使多层次分析成为可能，这将为这些生物体的进化分析提供新的信息。这将包括：1）利用目标环境18S调查和高通量FlowCam成像发现多样性；2）高通量转录组测序；3）不可培养分类群的单细胞基因组学。系统发育分析将捕获构成SAR早期进化基础的遗传镶嵌图。除了增加来自SAR分支不同成员的基因组尺度资源外，本文还将生成图像数据层，并将其与EOL中文献中的其他图像集成。本科生、研究生和博士后将接受尖端技术培训，并将为显微镜教师培训提供一个讲习班。该项目将通过从代表性不足的群体中招收学生，并开发关于微生物生命树的高中课程，增加参与者的多样性。

SAR is a major clade of diverse microscopic eukaryotes that was recently identified by evolutionary analyses and additional data have robustly supported SAR as an independent evolutionary lineage. This discovery is forcing a re-evaluation of the evolution of several eukaryotic traits, most notably photosynthesis. Within SAR there are many diverse lineages but genetic data are rare and concentrated in only a few lineages: Apicomplexa (e.g. malarial parasites), omycetes (e.g. parasite water molds) and diatoms (e.g. ecologically important phytoplankton). This project proposes to increase the number of SAR species with genetic data as well as massively increase the amount of genetic data collected per species. Organisms used for genomic data will be imaged and will be integrated to the Encyclopedia of Life (EOL) to provide a comprehensive resource on microbial eukaryotic diversity. Despite their global ecological importance, fewer than 50% of all SAR clades are represented by even a single genome in public databases. The work proposed here would add at least 250 novel genomic-scale datasets (transcriptomes, draft genomes, single-cell amplified genomes), focused primarily on capturing diversity within SAR. These datasets will be made publicly available, substantially increasing our understanding of the evolution of these organisms. The application of both established phylogenomic and emerging similarity network methods will enable a multi-layered analysis that will provide new information for evolutionary analyses of these organisms. This will include: 1) diversity discovery using targeted environmental 18S surveys coupled with high-throughput FlowCam imaging; 2) high-throughput transcriptomic sequencing; and 3) single cell genomics of unculturable taxa. Phylogenetic analyses will capture the genetic mosaics that underlie the early evolution within SAR. Beyond the increase in genome scale resources from diverse members of the SAR clade, the proposed work will generate image data layers and integrate these with other images from the literature in EOL. Undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will be trained in cutting edge techniques and will provide a workshop for teacher training in microscopy. This project will increase diversity of participants by recruiting students from underrepresented groups and develop of a high school curriculum on the microbial tree of life.

Project.Title: Design and Development of a Low Profile, Multi-band GNSS Antenna

Title_Other.Title: Design and Development of a Low Profile, Multi-band GNSS Antenna
一种低剖面多频段GNSS天线的设计与研制

Project.Abstract:
Integrated Antenna Solutions, Selex ES are proposing an antenna concept that uses novel microstrip technology to obtain multi frequency, GNSS operation from a single output, low profile patch antenna. The fundamental design is a quad-band circular patch antenna that has 3 parasitic concentric rings. This technology uses established printed circuit fabrication techniques and the proposed solution can therefore be easily manufactured, and at low cost, to suit a wide range of applications where size and weight is a key parameter, for example, the dismounted soldier or small vehicle. By applying a modular "unit cell" approach the antenna is scalable accoriding to the application and installed platform.
The key drivers for all these designs are optimum performance of the antenna on the platform itself, minimisation of the number of antenna elements required in the system, modularity, low through life costs and low Size, Weight and Power (SWaP). Rapid on-site prototyping provides fast insight into the physical solution once the initial concept analysis and simulation stages have been passed. Our design and measurement facilities include a secure, large, outdoor antenna test range with a turntable and workshop. Selex ES also possesses advanced platform analysis tools using large, secure computing resources and advanced computer analysis for 3D electromagnetic simulation.
Assured supply of antennas is achieved with a large, UK based, List-X antenna manufacturing capability; Selex ES have designed and manufactured over 40,000 antennas. This includes over 90% of all the UK (and Italian) military vehicle and manpack ECM antennas, conformal antennas for fast jets, body-worn antennas for the Defence , Science and Technology Laboratory (Dstl), the UK Ministry of Defence (MoD) and other government departments (OGDs), conformal antennas for international Unmanned Air Vehicles (UAVs), covert vehicle antennas and Control Radiation Pattern Antennas (CRPA) for a large defence prime.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 集成天线解决方案，Selex-ES提出了一种天线概念，它使用新的微带技术从一个单输出的低剖面贴片天线获得多频率、GNSS操作。基本设计是一个四频段圆形贴片天线，有3个寄生同心环。这项技术使用已建立的印刷电路制造技术，因此所提出的解决方案可以容易地制造，而且成本低，以适应尺寸和重量是关键参数的广泛应用，例如徒步士兵或小型车辆。通过采用模块化的“单元单元单元”方法，天线可根据应用和安装的平台进行扩展。 所有这些设计的关键驱动因素是平台上天线的最佳性能、系统所需天线元件数量的最小化、模块化、低贯穿寿命成本和低尺寸、重量和功率（SWaP）。一旦初始概念分析和模拟阶段通过，快速的现场原型提供了对物理解决方案的快速洞察。我们的设计和测量设施包括一个安全的、大的、室外天线测试范围，带有一个转台和车间。Selex-ES还拥有先进的平台分析工具，使用大型、安全的计算资源和先进的计算机分析进行三维电磁仿真。 有保证的天线供应是通过基于英国的List-X大型天线制造能力实现的；Selex ES已经设计和制造了40000多个天线。这包括超过90%的英国（和意大利）军用车辆和肩扛式电子对抗天线、用于快速喷气机的共形天线、用于国防、科学和技术实验室（Dstl）、英国国防部（MoD）和其他政府部门（OGDs）的体损天线、用于国际无人机（UAV）的共形天线，隐身车天线和控制辐射方向图天线（CRPA）用于大型防御系统。

Project.Title: Energy Efficiency Improvement via waste heat recovery and enhancment of production rate in aluminium industry

Title_Other.Title: Energy Efficiency Improvement via waste heat recovery and enhancment of production rate in aluminium industry
利用废热回收提高铝工业生产效率

Class.ClassName: 湿度测定仪器、凝结测定仪器、蒸发测定仪器

Project.Abstract: About 50% of inputenergy in aluminium production is lost as waste heat. This project is targeted to develop a prototype system for waste heat recovery and power generation in the aluminium industry via active cooling based on heat pipe technology. The sys tem will improve energy efficiency by 260 kW per production cell. The production rate will be increased by 20% and operational stability will be extended. The payback period will be between 2 and 3 years. Current heat pipe technology is used in high tech areas (space industry) and in the computer industry as a big volume market. Given the very efficient heat transfer rates compared to established state of the art technologies this technology might be used to recover waste heat of the production process fo r aluminium for significant increase of energy efficiency and the production rate. The project will transfer heat pipe technology to industrial applications, aluminium production as the first targeted industry. It will build up the core know how on indust rial heat pipe technology in Norway. Work to be done in this context lies in the basic heat pipe design (dimension & working fluid) for this novel application. In terms of the heat transfer on the evaporator and condenser end, the heat flux especially wit h focus on the basic heat transfer must be covered. It is the very different thermal expansion rates of the pipe and the surrounding ceramic material for highest possible heat transfer in all operating conditions. Therefore main mechanisms of heat transfe r between the elements must be identified and maximised. Any kind of degradation, aluminium plants operate for about 7 years, must be kept under control. Related to EHS the aspects of relief of over pressure inside the heat pipe, refill and repair will be solved. All other aspect such as selection of material, fluids and other basic aspects of design will be covered also. The work will be done theoretically and experimental and result in a demonstrator.

在铝生产中，约50%的工业废热损失。该项目旨在开发一个基于热管技术的铝工业主动冷却余热回收和发电原型系统。该系统将使每个生产单元的能源效率提高260千瓦。生产速度提高20%，操作稳定性提高。投资回收期为2至3年。 目前热管技术作为一个大的市场被应用于高新技术领域（航天工业）和计算机行业。与现有技术相比，该技术具有非常高的传热效率，可用于回收铝生产过程中的余热，显著提高能源效率和生产率。 该项目将热管技术转移到工业应用中，铝生产作为第一个目标产业。它将建立挪威工业热管技术的核心技术。在这方面要做的工作是为这一新应用的基本热管设计（尺寸和工作流体）。在蒸发器和冷凝器端部的传热方面，必须包括热流，特别是以基本传热为重点的热流。这是在所有操作条件下，管道和周围陶瓷材料的热膨胀率非常不同的最高可能传热。因此，必须确定并最大化元件之间的主要传热机制。任何一种退化，铝厂运转7年左右，都必须加以控制。与环境、健康和安全相关的热管内超压泄放、再填充和维修等方面的问题将得到解决。所有其他方面，如材料、流体的选择和设计的其他基本方面也将包括在内。 这项工作将在理论和实验上进行，并在一个演示。

Project.Title: ATD: Collaborative Research: Mathematical Challenges in Distributed Quickest Detection

Title_Other.Title: ATD: Collaborative Research: Mathematical Challenges in Distributed Quickest Detection
ATD：协作研究：分布式快速检测的数学挑战

Project.Abstract: The aim of the proposed research is to advance the state of the art of quickest detection by developing mathematical and statistical tools for systems consisting of large numbers of sensors with heterogeneous change times across sensors. Three related yet increasingly complicated and practical models will be considered. First, the assumption that the change times are the same at all sensors will be relaxed. The goal is to design quickest detection algorithms for the scenario with direct links between the sensors and the fusion center but with different change times. Next, the assumption that the access point can observe signals from all the sensors simultaneously will be relaxed. The goal is to develop quickest attack detection and localization algorithms for the scenario in which the fusion center can access only a subset of sensors at any given time. Finally, the assumption that there is a direct link between each sensor and the fusion center will be relaxed. The heterogeneity and sparsity of sensor observations will be exploited to develop quickest attack detection and localization algorithms for this scenario. The proposed research is expected to make substantial contributions to both applications and theory. On the application level, the proposed research has the potential to substantially improve the efficiency and robustness of chemical and biological threat detection algorithms. It is meant to develop low complexity algorithms that will be useful for implementation. On the theoretical level, the proposed project will advance the state of the art of sequential analysis and contribute new approaches to the general methodological base for optimal stopping and control problems for quickest detection. The proposed work has widespread potential applications not only in the detection of chemical and biological threats but also other areas as well. For example, in medical diagnosis, there are often more than one symptom related to a disease and these symptoms do not necessarily occur at the same time. The results of this research can be used to improve the performance of medical diagnostic techniques. The breadth of applications of the proposed research also makes this an ideal topic for attracting students from diverse disciplines and backgrounds from applied mathematics to engineering.

该研究的目的是通过开发数学和统计工具来提高由大量传感器组成的系统的最快检测技术，这些传感器具有跨传感器的非均匀变化时间。将考虑三个相关但日益复杂和实用的模型。首先，所有传感器的变化时间相同的假设将被放宽。目标是为传感器和融合中心之间有直接连接但变化时间不同的场景设计最快速的检测算法。接下来，假设接入点可以同时观察来自所有传感器的信号，这一假设将被放宽。目标是为融合中心在任何给定时间只能访问传感器子集的场景开发最快速的攻击检测和定位算法。最后，假设每个传感器和融合中心之间有直接的联系，这一假设将被放宽。传感器观测的异质性和稀疏性将被用来为这种情况开发最快的攻击检测和定位算法。本文的研究将对实际应用和理论研究做出重大贡献。在应用层面，本文的研究有可能大大提高化学和生物威胁检测算法的效率和鲁棒性。它的目的是开发低复杂度的算法，这将有助于实现。在理论层面上，该项目将推进序贯分析的最新进展，并为快速检测的最优停控问题的一般方法论基础提供新的方法。这项工作不仅在探测化学和生物威胁方面，而且在其他领域都有广泛的潜在应用。例如，在医学诊断中，通常有多个症状与疾病有关，这些症状不一定同时出现。本文的研究成果可用于提高医学诊断技术的性能。该研究的广泛应用也使其成为吸引从应用数学到工程等不同学科和背景的学生的理想课题。

Project.Title: Multi-Photon Gas Phase Spectroscopy

Title_Other.Title: Multi-Photon Gas Phase Spectroscopy
多光子气相光谱

Project.Title: Instrumentation For Undergraduate Instruction in Polymer AndFiber Science

Title_Other.Title: 高分子与纤维科学本科教学仪器
Instrumentation For Undergraduate Instruction in Polymer AndFiber Science

Class.ClassName: 高分子物理、高分子物理化学

Source.Name: Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering

Project.Title: I-Corps Sites: An Innovation Corps Site Program at The University of Alabama

Title_Other.Title: I-Corps Sites: An Innovation Corps Site Program at The University of Alabama
I-Corps站点：阿拉巴马大学的创新团队站点项目

Class.ClassName: 环境生态系统、生态环境

Project.Abstract: This project implements an Innovation Corps Site Program at The University of Alabama. NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. With this project, the Alabama Innovation and Mentoring of Entrepreneurs center (AIME) at The University of Alabama expands their existing proof-of-concept center into an I-Corps Site, to accelerate the commercialization of marketable ideas at The University of Alabama. The Site nurtures science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) faculty and students, with projects originating from student work, research, institutional or industrial projects, and creates a local innovation ecosystem that contributes to a larger, national network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. The University of Alabama Site provides infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. Working with their regional I-Corps Node at the Georgia Institute of Technology, The University of Alabama Site will improve and expand AIME's current innovation curriculum and training programs. Site funding offers entrepreneurial teams the opportunity to increase their chance of commercial success through funds for the acquisition of modest amounts of equipment or materials needed to fabricate prototypes, travel expenses to consult with potential clients or experts, or other resources needed to directly advance the goals of transitioning a team's project into the marketplace. In addition, the Site offers access to resources and training to the sponsored entrepreneurial teams in order to nurture UA faculty, staff and students to transition their innovative technologies into the marketplace. Broader Impacts: The direct impact is to educate the UA community in technology commercialization, transition teams to becoming NSF I-Corps trained teams and form start-up companies. The potential long term impact is to provide them with the education and skills that will position them to become part of the knowledgeable, creative workforce that will help the US maintain leadership in critical areas of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). The University of Alabama Site provides a formal structure to nurture entrepreneurial teams and guide the output of scientific discoveries closer to the development of technologies, products, and processes that benefit society. AIME has consistently recruited underrepresented STEM students and the Site will leverage the university's STEM Path to the MBA program and will encourage and advance minority participation in STEM-based entrepreneurial activities. In addition to impacting the university community, this Site program will enhance networking and partnerships through the involvement of AIME's mentors, who provide a network in their specific industries. Through providing a database of contacts, providing interaction with experts and providing top notch seminars, the University of Alabama Site has the opportunity to increase public participation in STEM activities by providing modest funds for prototypes and exploration into product-market fit, which increases the chance of commercial success. The University of Alabama Site has the opportunity to enhance the value of new ventures and make them better-positioned to hire employees and create transformative products and services for the benefit of society.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 这个项目在阿拉巴马大学实施了一个创新团队网站项目。NSF创新团队（I-Corps）网站是由NSF资助的实体，在大学设立，其目的是培养和支持多个本地团队，将其技术概念转化为市场。网站提供基础设施、建议、资源、网络机会、培训和适度的资金，使团队能够将工作转移到市场或成为I-Corps团队的申请者。I-Corps网站还加强了本地和区域创新，并为国家创新网络的导师、研究人员、企业家和投资者做出了贡献。通过这个项目，阿拉巴马大学阿拉巴马创新与创业指导中心（AIME）将其现有的概念验证中心扩展为I-Corps网站，以加速阿拉巴马大学市场化创意的商业化。该网站培养科学、技术、工程和数学（STEM）教师和学生，项目来源于学生工作、研究、机构或工业项目，并创建一个地方创新生态系统，为更大的全国导师、研究人员、企业家和投资者网络作出贡献。阿拉巴马大学网站提供基础设施、建议、资源、网络机会、培训和适度的资金，使团队能够将其工作转移到市场或成为I-Corps团队的申请者。阿拉巴马大学将与乔治亚理工学院的区域I-Corps节点合作，改进和扩大AIME目前的创新课程和培训计划。网站资金为创业团队提供了一个机会，通过购买制造原型所需的少量设备或材料、与潜在客户或专家进行咨询的差旅费或直接推进转型目标所需的其他资源来增加商业成功的机会一个团队进入市场的项目。此外，该网站还为受资助的创业团队提供资源和培训，以培养UA教员、员工和学生将其创新技术转化为市场。更广泛的影响：直接影响是在技术商业化方面教育UA社区，将团队转变为NSF I-Corps培训团队并组建初创公司。潜在的长期影响是为他们提供教育和技能，使他们成为知识渊博、富有创造力的劳动力队伍的一部分，这将有助于美国在科学、技术、工程和数学等关键领域保持领导地位（STEM）。阿拉巴马大学的网站提供了一个正式的结构来培养创业团队，并引导科学发现的产出更接近于有益于社会的技术、产品和过程的发展。AIME一直在招募代表性不足的STEM学生，该网站将利用大学的STEM路径进入MBA课程，并鼓励和推动少数人参与基于STEM的创业活动。除了影响大学社区之外，该网站计划还将通过AIME导师的参与加强网络和伙伴关系，AIME导师在其特定行业提供网络。通过提供联系人数据库、与专家互动和提供一流的研讨会，阿拉巴马大学网站有机会通过为原型提供适度的资金和探索适合产品市场的方式，增加公众对STEM活动的参与，从而增加商业成功的机会。阿拉巴马大学的网站有机会提高新企业的价值，使它们能够更好地雇佣员工，创造有利于社会的变革性产品和服务。

Site funding offers entrepreneurial teams the opportunity to increase their chance of commercial success through funds for the acquisition of modest amounts of equipment or materials needed to fabricate prototypes, travel expenses to consult with potential clients or experts, or other resources needed to directly advance the goals of transitioning a team's project into the marketplace. In addition, the Site offers access to resources and training to the sponsored entrepreneurial teams in order to nurture UA faculty, staff and students to transition their innovative technologies into the marketplace. Broader Impacts: The direct impact is to educate the UA community in technology commercialization, transition teams to becoming NSF I-Corps trained teams and form start-up companies. The potential long term impact is to provide them with the education and skills that will position them to become part of the knowledgeable, creative workforce that will help the US maintain leadership in critical areas of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). The University of Alabama Site provides a formal structure to nurture entrepreneurial teams and guide the output of scientific discoveries closer to the development of technologies, products, and processes that benefit society. AIME has consistently recruited underrepresented STEM students and the Site will leverage the university's STEM Path to the MBA program and will encourage and advance minority participation in STEM-based entrepreneurial activities. In addition to impacting the university community, this Site program will enhance networking and partnerships through the involvement of AIME's mentors, who provide a network in their specific industries. Through providing a database of contacts, providing interaction with experts and providing top notch seminars, the University of Alabama Site has the opportunity to increase public participation in STEM activities by providing modest funds for prototypes and exploration into product-market fit, which increases the chance of commercial success. The University of Alabama Site has the opportunity to enhance the value of new ventures and make them better-positioned to hire employees and create transformative products and services for the benefit of society.

Source.Name: Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering

Project.Title: VANN - Evolutionary ecology and hydrology - the effects of stream flow dynamics on the white-throated dipper

Title_Other.Title: VANN - Evolutionary ecology and hydrology - the effects of stream flow dynamics on the white-throated dipper
进化生态学和水文学：水流动力学对白喉斗七星的影响

Class.ClassName: 流水地貌学、湿润地貌学
环境生态系统、生态环境

Project.Abstract: In this project, we take an interdisciplinary approach and use a novel method of simulating daily hydrological runoff on a small spatial scale and apply it to an exclusive long-term study of breeding white-throated dippers Cinclus cinclus. This proposal p rovides a unique opportunity to understand how variation in the key local environment affects the ecology and evolution of a top predator of freshwater ecosystems. Floods, droughts and freezing of the river occur on a small spatial scale determined by the local hydro-meteorology and topography and can have severe consequences influencing the ecology and the evolutionary processes. Water flow dynamics also has potential to change due to climate change as well as due to riverine basin regulations caused by hydropower production. We therefore propose to analyse how environmental variation in terms of water flow dynamics (B1) affect breeding parameters and territory occupancy, leading to an understanding of how birds perceive habitat quality, (B2) determine t he amount of phenotypic plasticity and estimate selection and heritability, (B3) including knowledge of population age composition, influence the population dynamics, and (B4) influence the effects of liming and the subsequent competition of the recover ed salmonid population on territory occupancy and population dynamics of the white-throated dipper population.

在本研究中，我们采用跨学科的方法，利用一种在小空间尺度上模拟每日水文径流的新方法，并将其应用于培育白喉瓢虫的独家长期研究。这项提议提供了一个独特的机会，以了解关键的当地环境的变化如何影响生态和淡水生态系统顶级捕食者的进化。洪水、干旱和河流冰冻发生在由当地水文气象和地形决定的小空间尺度上，会对生态和演变过程产生严重影响。由于气候变化以及水力发电引起的河流流域规定，水流动力学也有可能发生变化。 因此，我们建议根据水流动力学（B1）分析环境变化如何影响繁殖参数和领地占有率，从而了解鸟类如何感知栖息地质量，（B2）确定表型可塑性的数量并估计选择和遗传力，（B3）包括种群知识年龄构成，对种群动态的影响，以及（B4）对恢复的鲑鱼种群的利明和随后的竞争对白喉北斗七星种群的领地占有率和种群动态的影响。

Project.Title: HIGH THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY CATALYSTS FOR ENDOTHERMIC FUEL REACTIONS

Title_Other.Title: HIGH THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY CATALYSTS FOR ENDOTHERMIC FUEL REACTIONS
吸热燃料反应的高导热催化剂

Project.Abstract: Aircraft designed for flight in the Mach 3-6 range must incorporate active cooling in the turbo-ramjet propulsion system. The required cooling can be provided by endothermic reactions of the fuel prior to its combustion. Endothermic fuel reactions require a catalyst. Previously developed catalysts for endothermic fuel reactions are supported on low thermal conductivity materials which makes it difficult to heat the catalysts. Consequently, heat transfer to the catalyst is a major problem in the design of endothermic fuel reactors. TDA Research proposes to investigate new catalysts for endothermic fuel reactions. These catalysts have very high thermal conductivity as well as the potential for lower cost and better high-temperature stability then previously developed catalysts.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: Aircraft designed for flight in the Mach 3-6 range must incorporate active cooling in the turbo-ramjet propulsion system. The required cooling can be provided by endothermic reactions of the fuel prior to its combustion. Endothermic fuel reactions require a catalyst. These catalysts have very high thermal conductivity as well as the potential for lower cost and better high-temperature stability then previously developed catalysts.

设计用于3-6马赫范围飞行的飞机必须在涡轮冲压发动机推进系统中加入主动冷却。燃料燃烧前的吸热反应可提供所需的冷却。吸热燃料反应需要催化剂。以前开发的用于吸热燃料反应的催化剂是由低导热材料支撑的，这使得催化剂很难加热。因此，催化剂的传热是吸热式燃料反应器设计中的一个主要问题。TDA研究提出了开发新型吸热燃料反应催化剂的设想。这些催化剂具有很高的热导率以及比先前开发的催化剂具有更低的成本和更好的高温稳定性的潜力。

Source.Name: United States Department of the Air Force

Project.Title: Integrin-Mediated Signaling in Prostate Cancer: Role of KAI1/CD82 in Regulating Integrin and Androgen Receptor Function During Metastasis

Title_Other.Title: 整合素介导的信号转导：KAI1/CD82在前列腺癌转移过程中对整合素和雄激素受体功能的调节作用
Integrin-Mediated Signaling in Prostate Cancer: Role of KAI1/CD82 in Regulating Integrin and Androgen Receptor Function During Metastasis

Class.ClassName: 植物病害、植物病害防治

Project.Abstract:
PUBLIC ABSTRACT
Tumors that develop in tissues of epithelial origin, carcinomas, represent the largest source of tumor burden in the United States. Prostate cancer is the most frequently diagnosed cancer and the second leading cause of cancer deaths in men in the United States. Prostate tumors that present at the time of diagnosis as androgen dependent and confined to the prostate are generally relatively easy to control through radical prostectomy or localized radiotherapy. However, there are no promising therapies for androgen-independent or metastatic tumors. This void in therapy is partially attributable to our lack of understanding of the metastatic process in prostate cancer.
The recent characterization of a gene involved in regulating prostate metastasis, KAI1 (also known as and subsequently referred to as CD82), provides a clue to a mechanism by which prostate cancer cells become metastatic. In addition to its role in suppressing prostate metastasis, CD82 also is known to associate with two members of a family of cell surface proteins known as integrins, which are involved in mediating cell adhesion to basement membranes and extracellular matrices. Interestingly, the loss of CD82 during metastasis correlates with an increase in the levels of the two integrins, alpha3 beta1 and alpha6 beta1, known to associate with CD82. Because integrins are important mediators of cell migration and adhesion, these observations suggest that loss of CD82 may have an effect on the function of these integrins in prostate cells, which could lead to an increase in cell motility and invasion.
In vivo, within the normal prostate, epithelial cells are polarized such that integrins are localized specifically to one side of the cell where they can interact with basement membranes. During tumor progression there is a loss of this polarized organization concomitant with changes in integrin localization, increases in tumor grade, and invasive potential. How loss of CD82 or changes in integrin function might contribute to this change in cell polarization is unknown.
In addition to their ability to regulate cell adhesion and migration integrins also are transmit signals and interface with signal transduction pathways in the cell. Integrins activate many of the same signal transduction pathways that oncogenes are known to activate. Integrins also are known to cooperate with or antagonize other cell receptor signaling pathways such as those activated by receptor tyrosine kinases or G-protein coupled receptors. Although the interactions between integrins and several transmembrane cellular receptors have been well established, the relationships between integrins and steroid receptors have not been investigated.
Our working hypothesis is that one of the mechanisms by which prostate cells become metastatic is by coordinate loss of CD82 and androgen dependence and an increase in the levels or activity of specific integrins. Together these events modify the normal regulation and function of integrins and enhance tumorigenic progression. The major goals of this project are to investigate these relationships by determining whether loss of CD82 increases the levels of integrin expression and/or alters the way in which integrins signal, leading to increased cell migration, invasion, and tissue disorganization. In addition, we will investigate whether androgen-dependent functions are altered because of changes in integrin function as a result of CD82 loss. These experimental approaches will provide us with insight into the mechanisms by which prostate tumor cells become metastatic. This will be important for designing therapeutic approaches for combating late stage prostate cancer.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 公共摘要 在上皮组织中发育的肿瘤，即癌，是美国最大的肿瘤负担来源。前列腺癌是美国最常见的癌症，也是男性癌症死亡的第二大原因。目前诊断为雄激素依赖性且局限于前列腺的前列腺肿瘤通常通过根治性前列腺切除术或局部放射治疗相对容易控制。然而，对于雄激素非依赖性或转移性肿瘤，目前还没有很好的治疗方法。这种治疗上的空白部分是由于我们对前列腺癌转移过程缺乏了解。 调控前列腺转移的基因KAI1（又称CD82）的最新特性为前列腺癌细胞转移的机制提供了线索CD82除了在抑制前列腺转移中的作用外，还与被称为整合素的细胞表面蛋白家族的两个成员相关，整合素参与介导细胞与基底膜和细胞外基质的粘附。有趣的是，转移过程中CD82的丢失与两种整合素α3β1和α6β1水平的升高相关，这两种整合素已知与CD82相关。由于整合素是细胞迁移和粘附的重要介质，这些观察表明CD82的丢失可能影响前列腺细胞中整合素的功能，从而导致细胞运动和侵袭的增加。 在体内，在正常前列腺内，上皮细胞被极化，因此整合素被定位在细胞的一侧，在那里它们可以与基底膜相互作用。在肿瘤发展过程中，伴随着整合素定位的改变、肿瘤分级的增加和侵袭潜能的增加，这种极化组织消失。CD82的丢失或整合素功能的改变如何导致细胞极化的改变尚不清楚。 整合素除了具有调节细胞粘附和迁移的能力外，还具有传递信号和与细胞内信号转导通路连接的能力。整合素激活许多与癌基因激活相同的信号转导途径。整合素也被认为与其他细胞受体信号通路（如由受体酪氨酸激酶或G蛋白偶联受体激活的通路）合作或拮抗。虽然整合素与多种跨膜细胞受体之间的相互作用已经被很好的证实，但是整合素与类固醇受体之间的关系还没有被研究。 我们的工作假设是前列腺细胞转移的机制之一是CD82和雄激素依赖性的协同丢失以及特异性整合素水平或活性的增加。这些事件一起改变了整合素的正常调节和功能，并促进了肿瘤的发生发展。该项目的主要目标是通过确定CD82的丢失是否会增加整合素的表达水平和/或改变整合素信号的方式，从而导致细胞迁移、侵袭和组织破坏，来研究这些关系。此外，我们将研究是否雄激素依赖的功能改变，因为整合素功能的变化，导致CD82的损失。这些实验方法将使我们深入了解前列腺肿瘤细胞转移的机制。这对于设计治疗晚期前列腺癌的方法具有重要意义。

PUBLIC ABSTRACT

Project.Title: Stratospheric Electrical Environments Applicable To Photovoltaic Arrays On HAA Platforms

Title_Other.Title: 适用于haa平台光伏阵列的平流层电学环境
Stratospheric Electrical Environments Applicable To Photovoltaic Arrays On HAA Platforms

Project.Abstract: The objective of this program is to characterize the upper atmosphere electrical environment so that the effects of this environment on high altitude airships (HAA) and other platforms intending to operate in this environment can be determined, and protection methods developed. This includes transient luminous events (TLEs), such as red sprites and blue jets and their associated electrical properties, in the region above active thunderstorms, as well as the fair-weather ambient. The induced and directly conducted currents that may be experienced by HAA PV arrays will also be defined. The approach is to fill gaps in present knowledge with a combination of high altitude electric field measurements, laboratory experiments to examine electrical streamer/leader and spark/arc characteristics at the reduced pressures equivalent to the 40,000 - 70,000 ft altitude range, and numerical modeling to compute the field enhancements and discharge currents at a high altitude airship operating in this range.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: The objective of this program is to characterize the upper atmosphere electrical environment so that the effects of this environment on high altitude airships (HAA) and other platforms intending to operate in this environment can be determined, and protection methods developed. This includes transient luminous events (TLEs), such as red sprites and blue jets and their associated electrical properties, in the region above active thunderstorms, as well as the fair-weather ambient. The induced and directly conducted currents that may be experienced by HAA PV arrays will also be defined. The approach is to fill gaps in present knowledge with a combination of high altitude electric field measurements, laboratory experiments to examine electrical streamer/leader and spark/arc characteristics at the reduced pressures equivalent to the 40,000 - 70,000 ft altitude range, and numerical modeling to compute the field enhancements and discharge currents at a high altitude airship operating in this range.

该程序的目标是描述高层大气的电气环境，以便确定该环境对高空飞艇（haa）和其他打算在该环境中运行的平台的影响，并制定保护方法。这包括在雷暴活动区和晴朗天气环境中的瞬态发光事件（TLE），如红色雪碧和蓝色喷流及其相关的电特性。还将定义haa光伏阵列可能经历的感应和直接传导电流。该方法是通过结合高海拔电场测量、实验室试验来检查电流注/引线和火花/电弧特性，在相当于40000-70000英尺高度范围的减压下，来填补现有知识的空白，以及数值模拟，以计算在该范围内运行的高空飞艇的场增强和放电电流。

Project.Title: Pyrophoric Nanoparticles for IR Decoys

Title_Other.Title: Pyrophoric Nanoparticles for IR Decoys
红外诱饵用自燃纳米粒子

Class.ClassName: 计算机安全、计算机保密

Project.Abstract: Pyrotechnic and pyrophoric IR decoy flares protect military aircraft from IR seeking surface-to-air missiles by closely mimicking the electromagnetic signature of the aircraft in order to divert the missile from its target. Pyrophoric based decoys have advantages over pyrotechnic technology in that they are more covert, are less likely to start fires, and produce a spectral signature that is more effective against dual spectral seeking MANPADs. During Phase II we demonstrated a nanoparticle based IR decoy that rapidly generated relevant apparent temperatures when exposed to air. During the Phase II.5 we will scale the production of devices and perform environmental, ground and flight tests to compare performance with current Raney metal foil technology.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 烟火和自燃红外诱饵弹通过密切模仿飞机的电磁特征，以使导弹偏离目标，从而保护军用飞机免受红外地空导弹的攻击。与烟火技术相比，基于自燃的诱饵具有更隐蔽、更不容易起火以及产生更有效对抗双光谱寻的便携式导弹的光谱特征等优点。在第二阶段，我们展示了一种基于纳米颗粒的红外诱饵，当暴露在空气中时，它能迅速产生相应的表观温度。在II.5阶段，我们将扩大设备的生产规模，并进行环境、地面和飞行测试，以将性能与当前的瑞尼金属箔技术进行比较。

Pyrotechnic and pyrophoric IR decoy flares protect military aircraft from IR seeking surface-to-air missiles by closely mimicking the electromagnetic signature of the aircraft in order to divert the missile from its target. Pyrophoric based decoys have advantages over pyrotechnic technology in that they are more covert, are less likely to start fires, and produce a spectral signature that is more effective against dual spectral seeking MANPADs. During Phase II we demonstrated a nanoparticle based IR decoy that rapidly generated relevant apparent temperatures when exposed to air. During the Phase II.5 we will scale the production of devices and perform environmental, ground and flight tests to compare performance with current Raney metal foil technology.

Source.Name: United States Department of the Navy

Project.Title: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Acquisition of Probabilistic Patterns in Spanish Phonology by Adult Foreign Language Learners

Title_Other.Title: 博士论文研究：成年外语学习者西班牙语语音中概率模式的习得
Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Acquisition of Probabilistic Patterns in Spanish Phonology by Adult Foreign Language Learners

Project.Abstract: Adult second language learners are confronted with a vast amount of information at many levels as they learn the grammar of the new language. Recent research has shown that native speakers are sensitive to fine-grained probabilistic patterns in their first language, in addition to the larger-scale patterns describable as grammatical rules. With support from the National Science Foundation, Mr. Matthew Carlson, under the direction of Dr. Chip Gerfen, will investigate whether adult learners of Spanish acquire similarly fine-grained knowledge of statistical idiosyncrasies of Spanish as is acquired by native speakers. Since the frequency of these irregularities are inherent in the language that learners have experienced, Mr. Carlson will also assess the cognitive capabilities that allow learners to record and track the probabilities of regular and irregular grammatical structures. To address these questions, a series of experiments will compare the performance of adult learners of Spanish at a variety of proficiency levels when given novel words with higher- or lower-probability phonological patterns. In one set of tasks, learners will judge whether an item is a real Spanish word or not, and in another set of tasks, they will repeat items that they hear. These tasks will reveal how the probability of a words form affects learners perception and production of the word. A comparison with monolingual Spanish speakers will show the extent to which learners are sensitive to nativelike Spanish patterns. Three different facets of memory and processing capacity will be assessed for their role in how learners construct lexical networks from their input. The performance of learners will also be compared across proficiency levels to see at what point nativelike knowledge of these probabilistic structures emerges. Furthermore, comparisons of learners with and without immersion experience will help to determine the extent to which the amount and intensity of input leads to more nativelike knowledge of statistical idiosyncrasies in the grammar. This research project has a number of broader implications. It will shed new light on adults ability to learn second languages at a time when language study that is becoming more and more important in an increasingly multilingual and global society, and more and more individuals are undertaking second language study beyond early childhood. The insights provided by this research will aid in understanding exactly how learners extract grammatical structure from their experience of the language. This is particularly important in the US, where the second language is not routinely encountered outside of the classroom, reducing learners opportunity to hear and use the language. This line of research will enable language teachers to tailor the language used in the classroom to draw learners attention to appropriate aspects of language use, highlighting not only regularity in grammar, but also the statistical predictability of idiosyncratic structures. This research will provide a basis for increasing diversity and collaboration among researchers in psycholinguistics by creating opportunities for undergraduate research assistants to receive training, and for collaboration between researchers in the US and Spain.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 成人第二语言学习者在学习新语言语法的过程中，在许多层面上都面临着大量的信息。最近的研究表明，母语者对第一语言中的细粒度概率模式很敏感，此外，更大范围的模式被描述为语法规则。在国家科学基金会的支持下，Matthew Carlson先生将在Chip Gerfen博士的指导下，调查成年西班牙语学习者是否获得了与母语者获得的西班牙语统计特性类似的精细知识。由于这些不规则现象的频率是学习者所经历的语言所固有的，卡尔森先生还将评估认知能力，使学习者能够记录和跟踪规则和不规则语法结构的概率。为了解决这些问题，一系列的实验将比较成年西班牙语学习者在不同水平上的表现，当给予具有高概率或低概率语音模式的新单词时。在一组任务中，学习者将判断一个项目是否是真正的西班牙语单词，在另一组任务中，他们将重复听到的项目。这些任务将揭示单词形式的可能性如何影响学习者对单词的感知和产生。通过与西班牙语单语者的比较，可以看出学习者对本土西班牙语模式的敏感程度。我们将从记忆和加工能力的三个不同方面来评估他们在学习者如何从输入中构建词汇网络中的作用。学习者的表现也将在不同的熟练程度上进行比较，看看这些概率结构的本土知识是在什么时候出现的。此外，对有或没有沉浸式学习经验的学习者进行比较，将有助于确定输入的数量和强度在多大程度上导致对语法中的统计特性有更多的本土知识。这个研究项目有许多更广泛的含义。在一个日益多语种和全球化的社会中，语言学习变得越来越重要，越来越多的人在幼儿期以后从事第二语言学习，这将为成年人学习第二语言的能力提供新的视角。这项研究提供的见解将有助于准确理解学习者如何从语言经验中提取语法结构。在美国，这一点尤为重要，因为在美国，第二语言通常不会出现在课堂之外，从而减少了学习者听和使用该语言的机会。这项研究将使语言教师能够根据课堂上使用的语言来吸引学习者注意语言使用的适当方面，不仅强调语法上的规律性，而且强调特殊结构的统计可预测性。这项研究将通过为本科生研究助理提供接受培训的机会，以及为美国和西班牙研究人员之间的合作，为增强心理语言学研究人员之间的多样性和协作奠定基础。

Adult second language learners are confronted with a vast amount of information at many levels as they learn the grammar of the new language. Recent research has shown that native speakers are sensitive to fine-grained probabilistic patterns in their first language, in addition to the larger-scale patterns describable as grammatical rules. With support from the National Science Foundation, Mr. Matthew Carlson, under the direction of Dr. Chip Gerfen, will investigate whether adult learners of Spanish acquire similarly fine-grained knowledge of statistical idiosyncrasies of Spanish as is acquired by native speakers. Since the frequency of these irregularities are inherent in the language that learners have experienced, Mr. Carlson will also assess the cognitive capabilities that allow learners to record and track the probabilities of regular and irregular grammatical structures. To address these questions, a series of experiments will compare the performance of adult learners of Spanish at a variety of proficiency levels when given novel words with higher- or lower-probability phonological patterns. In one set of tasks, learners will judge whether an item is a real Spanish word or not, and in another set of tasks, they will repeat items that they hear. These tasks will reveal how the probability of a words form affects learners perception and production of the word. A comparison with monolingual Spanish speakers will show the extent to which learners are sensitive to nativelike Spanish patterns. Three different facets of memory and processing capacity will be assessed for their role in how learners construct lexical networks from their input. The performance of learners will also be compared across proficiency levels to see at what point nativelike knowledge of these probabilistic structures emerges. Furthermore, comparisons of learners with and without immersion experience will help to determine the extent to which the amount and intensity of input leads to more nativelike knowledge of statistical idiosyncrasies in the grammar. This research project has a number of broader implications. It will shed new light on adults ability to learn second languages at a time when language study that is becoming more and more important in an increasingly multilingual and global society, and more and more individuals are undertaking second language study beyond early childhood. The insights provided by this research will aid in understanding exactly how learners extract grammatical structure from their experience of the language. This is particularly important in the US, where the second language is not routinely encountered outside of the classroom, reducing learners opportunity to hear and use the language. This line of research will enable language teachers to tailor the language used in the classroom to draw learners attention to appropriate aspects of language use, highlighting not only regularity in grammar, but also the statistical predictability of idiosyncratic structures. This research will provide a basis for increasing diversity and collaboration among researchers in psycholinguistics by creating opportunities for undergraduate research assistants to receive training, and for collaboration between researchers in the US and Spain.

Source.Name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral & Economic Sciences

Project.Title: VIVA - the Virtual Vehicle Assembler

Title_Other.Title: VIVA - the Virtual Vehicle Assembler
虚拟车辆装配器

Project.Abstract:
Purpose and goal: The overall aim is to develop a supportive tool that: -automatically can predict human behaviour considering dynamic effects and analyse human work in manual work stations from a musculoskeletal viewpoint. -automatically can optimise workstations where humans are supported with exoskeletons or collaborative robots. -considers human diversity in terms of appearance, shape, clothes, and safety equipment used during work. -easily can be understood, used and manipulated as well as adapted to recent developments within immersive VR and digital twin solutions.
Expected results and effects: At the end of the project, the demonstrator software will have: -functionality for advanced modelling of human body shapes, appearances and creation of personas. -functionality to simulate forces in muscle enabling musculoskeletal assessments. -functionality for assessment of human-robot collaboration from an ergonomics and productivity point of view. -functionality for automatic optimisation of workstations where workers are supported by either collaborative robots or exoskeletons or both. -full VR support and an efficient way of interaction.
Approach and implementation: The project is divided into a number of work packages that will lead the project towards the final objectives. From each work package, new knowledge and sub-solutions will be developed and implemented in a demonstrator. Throughout the project, the demonstrator will be tested and evaluated by industrial and academic partners. Cases from collaborating companies will be used to verify outcomes. A final demonstrator tool, combining the knowledge and solutions gained from the project, will be developed and allow for easier further adaptation and implementation in companies.

Abstract_Other.Abstract: 目的和目标： 总体目标是开发一个支持性工具： -自动预测考虑动态影响的人的行为，从肌肉骨骼的角度分析人工工作站中的人的工作。 -自动可以优化工作站，在那里人类被外骨骼或协作机器人支持。 -在外观、形状、衣服和工作期间使用的安全设备方面考虑人类的多样性。 -易于理解、使用和操作，并适应沉浸式虚拟现实和数字孪生解决方案的最新发展。 预期结果和效果： 在项目结束时，演示软件将具有： -用于人体形状、外观和人物角色创建的高级建模功能。 -用于模拟肌肉中的力的功能，支持肌肉骨骼评估。 -从人类工效学和生产力的角度评估人类机器人协作的功能。 -自动优化工作站的功能，其中工人由协作机器人或外骨骼或两者支持。 -全虚拟现实支持和有效的互动方式。 方法和实施： 该项目分为若干工作包，这些工作包将引导项目走向最终目标。从每个工作包中，新知识和子解决方案将在演示器中开发和实施。在整个项目中，演示者将由工业和学术合作伙伴进行测试和评估。合作公司的案例将用于验证结果。将开发一个最终演示工具，结合从项目中获得的知识和解决方案，使公司更容易进一步适应和实施。

Project.Title: Pan-specific vaccine to control Streptococcus agalactiae disease in tilapia aquaculture

Title_Other.Title: Pan-specific vaccine to control Streptococcus agalactiae disease in tilapia aquaculture
罗非鱼养殖中抗无乳链球菌病的泛特异性疫苗

Project.Abstract:
As the world population grows and becomes more affluent, an increasing number of people include
protein in their diet. Aquaculture is the fastest growing source of animal protein and a major source of
income in Asia, South-America and Africa. Tilapia is a popular fish, both with farmers and consumers,
but disease can cause massive losses on tilapia farms. Streptococcus agalactiae, which can affect tilapia
as well as people, is a major cause of such losses. Currently, antibiotics are commonly used to combat
this problem. This is not sustainable because of the risk of antimicrobial resistance. As an alternative, we
propose to develop a vaccine that would protect fish from all types of S. agalactiae that affect them. This
project brings together scientific expertise in the area of fish disease and vaccine development and
commercial expertise in vaccine production and distribution. Jointly, the partners aim to provide the
global aquaculture industry with effective and affordable tools for sustainable disease control.

project brings together scientific expertise in the area of fish disease and vaccine development and
commercial expertise in vaccine production and distribution. Jointly, the partners aim to provide the
global aquaculture industry with effective and affordable tools for sustainable disease control.

随着世界人口的增长和变得更加富裕，越来越多的人包括 他们饮食中的蛋白质。水产养殖是动物蛋白质增长最快的来源，也是 亚洲、南美和非洲的收入。罗非鱼很受农民和消费者的欢迎， 但疾病会给罗非鱼养殖场造成巨大损失。无乳链球菌，可影响罗非鱼 以及人，都是造成这种损失的主要原因。目前，抗生素常用于对抗 这个问题。这是不可持续的，因为有可能产生抗药性。作为替代方案，我们 建议开发一种疫苗，保护鱼类免受所有类型的无乳链球菌的影响。这个 该项目汇集了鱼类疾病和疫苗开发领域的科学专门知识 疫苗生产和销售方面的商业专业知识。合作伙伴共同致力于提供 全球水产养殖业提供有效和负担得起的可持续疾病控制工具。

Project.Title: DNA post-replication repair in mammalian cells

Title_Other.Title: DNA post-replication repair in mammalian cells
哺乳动物细胞dna复制后修复

Project.Title: SPECIFICITY OF PROTEIN TYROSINE PHOSPHATASES

Title_Other.Title: 蛋白质酪氨酸磷酸酶的特异性
SPECIFICITY OF PROTEIN TYROSINE PHOSPHATASES

Class.ClassName: 分子间的相互作用、超分子化学

Project.Abstract: A multidisciplinary research program is designed to understand the structural basis of substrate specificity of the protein-tyrosine phosphates (PTPases) and to develop specific, high-affinity low molecular weight nonpeptidic PTPase inhibitors. PTPases constitute a large family of enzymes that can be collectively categorized into two groups: receptor-like and intracellular PTPases. The receptor-like PTPases, exemplified by PTP-alpha, generally have an extracellular domain, a single transmembrane region, and one or two cytoplasmic PTPase domains. The intracellular PTPases, exemplified by PTP1B, contain a single catalytic domain and various amino or carboxyl terminal extensions including SH2 domains that may have targeting or regulatory specificity phosphatases. VHR is a representative of the dual specificity phosphatases that can utilize substrates containing phosphotyrosine as well as phosphoserine/phosphothreonine. Although ligand binding and localization/targeting domains are believed to be involved in the regulation of PTPase activity, the role of the PTPase catalytic site in determining substrate specificity has not been fully investigated. This proposal will be focused on PTP1B, PTP-alpha and VHR. The substrate sequence specificity of these enzymes will be evaluated via combinatorial phosphopeptide libraries in combination with detailed kinetic analyses of individual pure peptides with systematically altered chemical properties. Active site-directed inhibitors will be identifies by screening synthetic libraries of low molecular weight aromatic phosphonates. The in vivo efficacy of selected inhibitors will be assessed in a Chinese hamster cell line that overexpresses human insulin receptor. Since the elucidation of the fundamentals of molecular recognition events requires an understanding of the atomic details of how molecules interact, the three-dimensional structures of PTPases complexed with high affinity substrates/inhibitors will be determined. PTP1B, PTP-alpha and VHR are ideal in this regard, since their crystal structures have been solved. Thus the crystal structures of these PTPases complexed with tight-binding substrates/ inhibitors can be solved by molecular replacement techniques.
